229.background: NOAA recommends that to demonstrate ESU/DPS viability, annual documentation of a variety of biological parameters (including adult and juvenile abundance, age distribution, sex ratio, length, and run timing) is needed at the population, major population grouping, and ESU/DPS level for each listed species (Crawford and Rumsey 2011). Genetic stock identification (GSI) of steelhead and Chinook salmon adults and juveniles at Lower Granite Dam should be able to provide estimates of these parameters annually at the MPG and ESU/DPS level. GSI uses multi-locus genotype data from reference populations (presumably representing all contributing stocks) as a baseline and a complimentary set of genotype data from mixtures of fish of unknown origin to estimate stock proportions within the mixture (Shaklee et al. 1999; Anderson et al. 2008). In the Snake River basin, studies have indicated that both Chinook salmon and steelhead exhibit significant genetic structure at the watershed (or subbasin) level (Moran 2003; Narum et al. 2007; Nielsen et al. 2009). Previously, researchers have made use of this genetic structure to identify the stock origin of kelt steelhead at Lower Granite Dam (Narum et al. 2008b) and to estimate the stock composition of wild and hatchery Chinook salmon over Lower Granite Dam (Smith 2007). This project expands and evaluates GSI technologies to estimate genetic stock contributions of wild and juvenile Snake River steelhead and Chinook salmon as they migrate past Lower Granite Dam. This project also provides several measures of genetic diversity and life history characteristics for adult steelhead and Chinook salmon detected at PIT tag arrays in the Snake River basin. See Protocol "Snake River GSI baseline (2010-026-00)" for explanation of the genetic baseline used for GSI at Lower Granite Dam.
objectives: This protocol outlines how data is collected, managed, analyzed, and reported for GSI for steelhead and Chinook salmon returning to the Snake River basin.
229.assumptions: Adults and juveniles can be representatively sampled at Lower Granite Dam.  Wild populations can be sampled representatively and sufficiently to accurately estimate allele frequencies of "stocks". Temporal changes in allele frequency can be accurately measured. Genetic differentiation among stocks is sufficient for GSI analyses.

230.background: NOAA specifically recommends that to demonstrate ESU/DPS viability a long-term strategy for monitoring genetic diversity be implemented that involves the development of a SNP baseline for each population within each MPG and ESU/DPS (Recommendation 16; Crawford and Rumsey 2011). Snake River steelhead and Chinook salmon SNP baselines will be refined and maintained through annual population sampling and genotyping. Ultimately, annual sampling plans will be based on resolution of initial baselines and manager’s specific needs.

235.background:
Upper Columbia River steelhead stock assessment has been ongoing since 1986.  Initially, the program goal was to estimate the abundance, origin, and age composition of returning Upper Columbia River steelhead.  Recently, the program has addressed reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPA) identified in the NMFS biological opinion for the Federal Columbia River Power System, enabled monitoring of viable salmonid population (VSP) parameters, and provided data to multiple monitoring and evaluation programs.  Specifically, Upper Columbia River steelhead stock assessment activities have provided the opportunity to:

  • Conduct status and trend monitoring in the Upper Columbia River ESU (RPA 50.4)
  • Tag (PIT and/or Radio) a representative sample of Upper Columbia River steelhead to be used in PIT tag based escapement estimates (VSP)
  • Assess the efficacy of PIT tag detectors in natal streams throughout the Upper Columbia River ESU (RPA 55.9)
  • Monitor hatchery effectiveness and investigate hatchery critical uncertainties (RPA 63.1 and RPA 64.2)
  • Set regulations for selective fisheries aimed at reducing the abundance of hatchery fish and the spawning grounds
objectives: Determine the origin of all steelhead sampled at Priest Rapids Dam (PRD) OLAFT.
Determine the age of all steelhead sampled at Priest Rapids Dam.
PIT tag a representative sample of returning Upper Columbia River ESU steelhead.  Detection data will be used to generate and/or validate PIT tag based escampement estimates.
235.assumptions: Operation of the Off Ladder Adult Fish Trap (OLAFT) at Priest Rapids Dam for equal intervals throughout the entirety of the run provides the opportunity to tag a sample representative of the Upper Columbia River ESU steelhead run-at-large.

272.background: Predation by nonnative predators is a potential risk to subyearling fall Chinook salmon that rear in, and migrate through, lower Snake River reservoirs.  With the implementation of hatchery supplementation and increase in natural production, the abundance of subyearlings is far greater today than it was 15 years ago when the last subyearling predation studies were done in the Snake River.  It is currently unknown whether smallmouth bass abundance has increased in response to the increasing population of juvenile salmon and whether predation has increased as a consequence.  It is possible that predation may pose a significant risk to subyearlings and may reduce the productivity of the Snake River basin population. It is also unknown to what extent channel catfish prey on subyearlings in Lower Granite Reservoir.
objectives: Estimate the annual loss of subyearlings to smallmouth bass predation in the upper portion of Lower Granite Reservoir. Document the relative consumption of subyearlings by channel catfish.
272.assumptions:
1.  The diets of collected smallmouth bass and channel catfish will be representative of the population at large.

2.  Bias between different predator collection methods will be minimal or can be accounted for in analyses.

3.  Sufficient numbers of smallmouth bass can be marked and recaptured to accurately estimate their abundance.

4. Smallmouth bass abundance can be accurately expanded to the larger study area.

281.background: This protocol describes how data will be collected, managed, analyzed, and reported through 2016 to evaluate a new genetic technology, called Parentage Based Tagging (PBT), that should provide a better tool to meet Fish & Wildlife Program objectives associated with marking hatchery stocks, conducting hatchery evaluations and reform, and enforcing salmonid fishery management measures.  A large-scale evaluation of this technology was recommended by several committees and science review groups (PFMC 2008; PSC 2005; ISRP/ISAB 2009).  State, tribal and federal agencies in the Snake River basin are uniquely positioned to perform large-scale proof-of-concept PBT studies for both steelhead and Chinook because most hatchery steelhead and Chinook broodstock spawned in the Snake River basin (WA, OR, and ID) have been genetically sampled since spawn year 2008; significant resources have been dedicated to the development of powerful and cost-efficient genetic markers for both species (Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms-SNPs); and there are sampling programs in place at Bonneville Dam, at Lower Granite Dam, and in tribal and non-tribal fisheries in the mainstem Columbia River and in the Salmon and Clearwater rivers, to sample returning hatchery adults and verify the accuracy and utility of PBT technology. This project is currently creating the first generation of PBT parental genetic baselines for hatchery steelhead and Chinook in the Snake basin (Steele et al 2011). In doing so, it will effectively, permanently genetically mark ~12 million smolts, per species, per year.  This project will work closely with an existing BPA funded project (2008-907-00) to ensure that future genetic marker sets used in the Columbia River basin are standardized, providing unprecedented genetic tools for managing wild and hatchery stocks in the basin with GSI techniques segregating adult wild runs by stock of origin, and PBT technologies identifying the stock and age of sampled hatchery fish.
objectives: Describe how data are to be collected, managed, analyzed, and reported to develop and assess the utility of PBT technology for hatchery steelhead and Chinook salmon in the Snake river basin.
281.assumptions:
Genetic samples can be collected and properly preserved from every steelhead and Chinook salmon hatchery broodstock spawned in the Snake River basin.  In addition, accurate biological information (stock, spawn date, sex, cross information) can be recorded for every adult sampled.

A set of SNP markers can be developed/identified that can achieve high parental assignment accuracy even when tens of thousands of potential parents are involved and when parentage involves hatchery populations that are very similar genetically due to shared ancestry or in situations where the broodstock contains closely related individuals (ISRP/ISAB 2009).

287.background: A minimum viability threshold of a geometric mean of 3,000 natural-origin adults over 10 years was recommended for the Snake River basin fall Chinook salmon population listed under the ESA. Run reconstruction indicates that 3,000 or more natural-origin adults have arrived at Lower Granite Dam (the last dam passed prior to reaching upstream spawning areas in the lower Snake, Clearwater, and Grande Ronde rivers) during 5 of the last 10 years. A stock-recruitment analysis that tests the influence of anthropogenic, biological, and environmental change on the abundance of natural-origin adults observed after 1983 when reconstruction began would (1) help to understand why the abundance of natural-origin adults increased and (2) provide the ability to make predictions under “what if ?” scenarios for adaptive management. We describe such an analysis in this protocol. The explicit population level spatial structure criterion proposed for recovery requires the escapement of at least 2,500 natural-origin spawners to the lower Snake River. Though run reconstruction provides an estimate of the abundance of natural-origin adults at Lower Granite Dam to assess status relative to the minimum viability threshold, it does not provide the information on spatial distribution of natural-origin spawners needed to assess status relative to the explicit population level spatial structure criteria. A model that relates redd counts made to the explicit population level spatial structure criteria would be useful. This protocol describes one approach for developing such a model.
objectives: Increase the understanding of how the numerical trends in the estimated counts of natural-origin adults from 1983 onward were influenced by anthropogenic, biological, and environmental change.
Predict the status of escapement of natural-origin adults to the spawning areas relative to the explicit population level spatial structure criteria.
Predict how varying influential anthropogenic, biological, and environmental factors might affect the status of natural-origin adults relative to the minimum viability threshold.
287.assumptions: We assume our frame will be represented the natural-origin Snake River basin fall Chinook salmon population. We assume that trends in estimated abundance are not solely caused by error in run reconstruction. We assume that trends in geographic distribution of redd counts are not solely caused by error in redd counts.

295.background: The goal of this project (2002-053-00) is to determine the abundance and current productivity of the Asotin Creek steelhead population and to estimate life stage survival rates in the mainstem Asotin Creek. Under the ESA, the TRT, the Snake River Salmon Recovery Plan (SRSRB 2007) and NOAA Fisheries included George Creek and several other small adjacent Snake River tributaries (Tenmile Creek, Couse Creek, Almota and Alpowa Creek) as part of the Asotin Creek Steelhead population. As such, a full understanding of the abundance and productivity of steelhead in those tributaries is necessary to adequately understand the status of the Asotin Creek steelhead population. This project also implements the research, monitoring and evaluation (RM&E) criteria specified in the Asotin Subbasin Plan (ASP 2004), the MERR, and the Anadromous Salmonid Monitoring Strategy (ASMS 2010), by establishing a baseline of the salmonid population in Asotin Creek, upstream of the confluence with George Creek. The project provides estimates of abundance, productivity, survival rates, and additional information on temporal and spatial distribution of ESA-listed species, primarily for summer steelhead, and secondarily on spring Chinook salmon. In addition, this project will document the abundance of bull trout captured at the trapping locations. Future estimates of smolt-to-adult and adult-to-adult survival for the wild steelhead population in Asotin Creek will provide the data necessary to help determine if salmonid production in the subbasin is being limited by within- or out-of-basin factors. This protocol focuses on the adult monitoring and analysis components of the project. However, due to the inter-related metrics being calculated, overlap between analysis occurs within the metrics and methods mapping. Please refer to the Asotin Juvenile protocol for further information regarding those methods.
objectives: Estimate spawner abundance and escapement of wild and hatchery steelhead in the Asotin Creek salmon population.
Estimate adults per redd in the Asotin Creek mainstem.
Collect DNA samples future characterization the genetic structure of Asotin Creek focal species.
295.assumptions: We assume that our weirs are functioning properly, and we are sampling a representative portion of the population, and the remainder of the basic mark-recapture assumptions.

298.background: Juveniles from the historical populations of Snake River basin fall Chinook salmon were abundant, diverse, and spatially distributed. However, these measures of status declined from the late 19th century to 1992 due to anthropogenic activity. The increase in abundance and population distribution after ESA listing in 1992 restored some of the juvenile life history diversity based on results of mark recapture studies involving tagging natural fish in natal spawning areas and recapturing them at Lower Granite Dam—the first dam passed by juveniles en route to the sea. However, the tagging data do not fully represent the natural population due to technological limitations. To compliment mark-recapture analyses and move the state of knowledge forward, annual estimates of passage abundance for the population of natural-origin subyearlings at Lower Granite Dam are needed. This protocol describes such estimates and the accompanying analyses.
objectives: Estimate passage abundance of natural-origin fall Chinook salmon subyearlings.
Increase the understanding of how the numerical trends in passage abundance were associated with anthropogenic, biological, and environmental change.
298.assumptions: We assume that error in the model used to estimate collection probability at Lower Granite Dam is equal across seasons and fish sizes. We assume that estimates of the annual number of hatchery fish released are accurate.

citation.title: Understanding variation in passage abundance of natural Snake River basin fall Chinook salmon juveniles v1.0
citation.author: Kenneth Tiffan

298.title: Understanding variation in passage abundance of natural Snake River basin fall Chinook salmon juveniles

299.background: Predation is likely a significant source of mortality for subyearling fall Chinook salmon because of their relatively small size and because their main-stem rearing habitats often overlap or are in close proximity to habitats used by piscine predators. Under Project 199102900, we completed an assessment of smallmouth bass predation on subyearling fall Chinook salmon in the Hells Canyon Reach of the Snake River in 1996 and 1997 (Nelle 1999). This study was conducted during years of low abundance of wild subyearlings before the first returns of adults from hatchery supplementation releases. Consequently, we found low levels of predation in the Hells Canyon Reach of the Snake River. We estimated a total loss of 9,282 PIT-tagged hatchery fish and 5,102 wild fish to smallmouth bass predation in 1996 and 1997. Since the time of that study, the subyearling population has increased dramatically due to supplementation via the release of smolts and an increase in natural production from returning hatchery adults. This protocol addresses RPA 55 (Investigate key characteristics of the early life history of Snake River Fall Chinook Salmon in the mainstem Snake, Columbia, and Clearwater rivers) of the 2008 Biological Opinion.
objectives: Estimate loss of juvenile fall Chinook salmon to smallmouth bass predation in the Hells Canyon reach of the Snake River
299.assumptions:
1. The diets of collected smallmouth bass will be representative of the population at large.

2. Bias between different predator collection methods will be minimal or can be accounted for in analyses.

3. Sufficient numbers of smallmouth bass can be marked and recaptured to accurately estimate their abundance.

4. Abundance estimates can be accurately expanded to the larger study reach.

metrics.title: Abundance of smallmouth bass in Hells Canyon
Loss of juvenile fall Chinook to smallmouth bass predation

302.background: Hatchery releases of URB fall Chinook salmon (currently a key part of supplementation programs for ESA listed Snake River URB fall Chinook salmon) result in high minijack rates. This represents a loss of production of full size anadromous fish and is a threat to the maintenance of the genetic integrity of the naturally spawning population. High minijack rates approaching 50% of returning adults have been documented in the Umatilla River Basin, OR as well.  Co-managers from the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife and the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation are conducting a 2x2 factorial design experiment exploring the effects of two different commercial feeds (19 and 11% lipid) fed at two different rates (7 days/wk, 4 days/wk) on growth/smolt physiology and incidence of precocious parr and minijack maturation in yearling release URB fall Chinook salmon reared at Bonneville Hatchery for the Umatilla program over 4 consecutive brood years (BY 2010-2013) (Umatilla Hatchery Monitoring and Evaluation, BPA project # 1990-005-00).  The ultimate goal of this research study is to improve survival and reduce fitness loss in Columbia River URB Fall Chinook salmon.
objectives: Assess seasonal physiological status of fish in a feeding study to help determine how  changes in growth rate and adiposity may affect the propensity of male URB fall Chinook salmon to mature.
Determine the proportion of male Umatilla URB fall Chinook salmon undergoing early male maturation at age-1 and 2 in a 2x2 factorial size x dietary ration study.
302.assumptions: 1. The physiological assays are working properly and consistently with proper quality control monitoring in place. 2. Sampling of dip netted fish is random, robust and representative. 3. We sample a sufficient number of fish to have adequate statical power to characterize each life-history type based on physiological measures.

304.background: The long term aim of this research is to improve hatchery-rearing protocols to produce fish with life history characters similar to wild fish and minimize artificial selection due to altered phenotypes of juvenile fish at release. The knowledge gained from this work will be used to help develop rearing guidelines that allow hatchery programs to take advantage of the increased survival found in yearling release without the disadvantage of unnaturally high rates of early male maturation. In this study the effects of two environmental factors, photoperiod (at emergence) and food availability (growth during early rearing) wil be assessed with regard to seasonal timing of smolting, and age of male maturity in URB fall Chinook salmon. The experiment will be conducted using Umatilla River URB eyed eggs obtained from the Bonneville Hatchery in Winter 2012 and reared at the Northwest Fisheries Science Center Research Hatchery, NOAA Fisheries Seattle. At the time of ponding replicate treatments will be exposed to Early, Middle or Late Emergence photoperiod regimes and fed under either a High or Low ration according to the method of Beckman et al. (2007). This range of rearing regimes will allow us to examine the full range and proportion of life-history phenotypes expressed by URB Fall Chinook with regard to age of smoltification and early male maturation. Furthermore, monitoring of growth and development of treatment groups throughout the study will allow for a comprehensive understanding of the causative physiology driving the various life-histories.
objectives: Assess growth and smolt development of Umatilla River, URB Fall Chinook salmon reared in a laboratory scale 2x2 factorial experiment altering emergence time and early growth rate
Assess precocious male maturation rates at age-1 and 2 in Umatilla River, URB Fall Chinook salmon reared in a laboratory scale 2x2 factorial experiment altering emergence time and early growth rate.
304.assumptions: This methodology has been used successfully for similar studies of life-history diversity in bothWinter (Sacramento) and Spring (Yakima) Chinook stocks. It is very likely to be successful for our proposed work with Fall Chinook. However, as with comparisons between Winter and Spring Chinook salmon, the life-history response with regard to magnitude was very different for these two run types and is likely to be different still for Fall Chinook. So, making predictions with regard to response is challenging. However, this fact speaks to the need for conducting these types of studies in a repeated systematic way in order to understand where there are and are not parallel results and applications to different Chinook Run types.

305.background: Studies over the past decade have demonstrated that many Chinook salmon hatchery programs throughout the Columbia River basin produce high rates of early male maturation at age-2 (a.k.a. minijacks).  This protocol is used to determine if a male Chinook salmon has initiated the maturation process.  It is used to conduct pre-release monitoring of hatchery populations for rates of precocious male maturation (i.e. minijack production).  The method involves collecting plasma from fish and analyzing it by ELISA for the androgen 11-ketotestosterone.  11-KT is instrumental in initiating the process of spermatogenesis.  11-KT levels can then be examined via a frequency distribution of log-transformed levels.  11-KT levels measured above and below a predetermined threshold determine which fish have or have not initiated maturation for the following fall as a minijack.  This threshold has been confirmed through measurement of gonadosomatic index (testes size relative to body size) and most importantly histological analysis of cellular differentiation of testicular material.  Furthermore, once fish initiate the maturation process the process is essentially irreversible.  High rates of minijack maturation averaging 41% of all males have been observed in the Yakima hatchery spring Chinook salmon population over more than 10 years of monitoring.  In more recent years we have extended this monitoring effort to a series of other spring and summer Chinook salmon hatchery facilities throughout the Columbia and Snake River basins.
objectives: Minijack rate estimate using plasma 11-KT
Measure body weight of individual spring Chinook prior to release
Measure fork length of individual spring Chinook prior to release
Determine Fish sex
305.assumptions: The key assumption of this protocol is that the 11-KT ELISA is conducted according to standard published biochemical techniques.

352.background:
The Hood River Production Master Plan was adopted by the NWPCC in 1992 and its overarching goal was to “protect, enhance and restore wild and natural populations of anadromous and resident fish within the Hood River Subbasin”.  Program specific goals as defined by The Hood River Production Program Revised Master Plan (HDR/Fish Pro 2008) included:

  • Increasing production of wild summer and winter steelhead trout commensurate with the subbasin’s current carrying capacity
  • Re-introducing spring Chinook salmon into the Hood River Subbasin
  • Develop guidelines for implementing the hatchery supplementation program in a manner that will minimize its impact on indigenous resident and anadromous populations.

Monitoring salmonid smolts and resident species during out-migration provides a measurement of subbasin productivity during the freshwater life stage within the Hood River.  Trends in abundance serve as a primary indicator of species recovery potential and to provide insight into the effect the hatchery program is having on non-supplemented resident and anadromous species.
objectives:
Estimate steelhead and spring Chinook smolt production
Monitor juvenile rainbow-steelhead abundance status and trends 
Monitor status and trends of non-supplemented species including Coho, fall Chinook, cutthroat trout, bull trout, and other resident and andromous species.
352.assumptions: We assume that winter steelhead are native to the East and Middle Forks of the Hood River, and summer steelhead are native to the West Fork Hood River. We assume that marked individuals have the same opportunity to be caught in rotary screw traps as those who are caught for the first time.

363.background:
We created a new version of this protocol (#3370) because we transitioned this project from using microsatellite markers to SNP markers. 

This protocol monitors genetic changes associated with hatchery propagation in multiple Snake River sub-basins for Chinook salmon and steelhead. The information obtained from this protocol directly addresses a critical knowledge gap identified by comanagers: under what conditions does hatchery supplementation provide a sustained contribution to natural production? This protocol uses changes in gene frequencies through time in hatchery, natural, and wild Chinook salmon and steelhead populations to evaluate the genetic effects of hatchery supplementation on a broad geographic scale.  Co-managers are ODFW, CTUIR, NPT, WDFW, IDFG, and SBT.  

This type of monitoring work is now an essential part of hatchery reform and the goal of using widespread hatchery propagation in recovery of natural populations.  Tier 2 sites use changes in gene frequencies through time in hatchery, natural and wild Chinook salmon and steelhead populations to evaluate the genetic effects of hatchery supplementation on a broad geographic scale.  Tier 3 sites involve direct measures of the relative reproductive success of hatchery fish spawning in the wild by using parentage analysis to construct pedigrees.
objectives: Determine the degree to which supplemented populations affect nonsupplemented populations of Chinook and steelhead
Monitor population genetic relationships within and among populations of Chinook salmon and steelhead in the Snake River Basin
363.assumptions: We assume that by sampling a stretch of each site ranging from 1/4-1 mile in length, that we are not sampling a single family grouping. Additionally, we choose to sample juveniles at each study site rather than returning adults, as juveniles are not as susceptible to straying issues.

363.title: Monitor and evaluate the genetic characteristics of supplemented salmon and steelhead in the Snake River Basin--conventional population monitoring (1989-096-00)

364.background:
This protocol is designed to evaluate the effects of outplanting hatchery reared fish on natural and wild populations of spring/summer Chinook salmon and steelhead in the Snake River Basin. This protocol involves a direct examination of the relative reproductive success (RRS) of hatchery fish spawning in the wild. Hatchery- (marked) and natural-origin (unmarked) fish returning to a weir are genotyped using microsatellites and/or SNPs in order to establish parentage of juveniles sampled from rearing areas above the weir. We have three ongoing reproductive success projects, Little Sheep Creek (Imnaha Basin) for steelhead, and Catherine Creek and Lostine River for Chinook salmon.The information obtained from this protocol directly addresses a critical knowledge gap identified by comanagers: under what conditions does hatchery supplementation provide a sustained contribution to natural production? Co-managers are ODFW, CTUIR, NPT, WDFW, IDFG, and SBT.

This type of monitoring work is now an essential part of hatchery reform and the goal of using widespread hatchery propagation in recovery of natural populations. Tier 2 sites use changes in gene frequencies through time in hatchery, natural and wild Chinook salmon and steelhead populations to evaluate the genetic effects of hatchery supplementation on a broad geographic scale (See Protocol #363). Tier 3 sites involve direct measures of the relative reproductive success of hatchery fish spawning in the wild by using parentage analysis to construct pedigrees (this protocol). 

The samples needed for this protocol are collected by a number of different entities. For Little Sheep Creek steelhead, ODFW collects the returning anadromous adults and fish passing through the smolt trap (Protocol ID:702). Juveniles and resident rainbow trout are captured using backpack electrofishing (described in this protocol), by our personnel in cooperation with ODFW. For Catherine Creek Chinook, returning adults are captured by CTUIR (Protocol ID:1991) and for Lostine River Chinook, returning adults are captured by the Nez Perce tribe (Method ID:6640). For both Catherine Creek and Lostine River, outgoing migrants are captured in smolt traps and sampled by the ODFW Early Life History group (Protocol ID: 217).

Microsatellites were the genetic markers we used at the start of this project, but we have now transitioned to using SNP markers. See the attached form for a list of SNP markers we utilize for this protocol.
objectives: Monitor relative reproductive success of hatchery and wild Chinook and steelhead in the Snake River Basin
364.assumptions: We assume that every location and species may act differently within a supplementation framework, so our results here are not necessarily to be applied to other systems.

376.background: Recruitment of age-0 white sturgeon Acipenser transmontanus in the impounded reaches of the lower Columbia River (i.e., Bonneville, The Dalles, and John Day reservoirs) is assessed each year to identify and track status and trends in productivity (Cox 2015). This information is critical to the effective management of the resource, as dam construction and operation has negatively effected white sturgeon productivity in these reaches (Beamesderfer et al. 1995; Chapman and Jones 2010). This work, as part of a larger program designed to develop and implement a management plan for enhancing production of white sturgeon in the lower Columbia River Basin, has helped identify physical and environmental conditions favorable to spawning and subsequent age-0 recruitment within individual reservoirs.
objectives: Estimate the relative annual abundance of age-0 white sturgeon in each of the impounded reaches of the lower Columbia River
Relate age-0 recruitment to physical and enviromental variables
Develop management reccomendations to increase natural recruitment of age-0 white sturgeon in each of the impounded reaches of the lower Columbia River
376.assumptions:
1. Age-0 white sturgeon are effectively captured with the sampling gear utilized

2. Sampling takes place at specific sites utilized by age-0 white sturgeon

402.background: The Colville Tribes are facilitating the development of a locally-adapted, self-sustaining, Okanogan River summer/fall Chinook salmon population. The Selective Gear Deployment project (2008-105-00) in the Upper Columbia region uses selective fishing techniques and selective harvest gear to collect both the natural-origin and hatchery-origin summer/fall Chinook broodstock needed for the integrated and segregated programs at the Chief Joseph Hatchery (CJH), and; to reduce the proportion of hatchery-origin spawners (pHOS) reaching spawning areas of the Okanogan River basin. It is hoped that a future listing of summer/fall Chinook under the ESA will be prevented by these efforts. The project builds upon the lessons learned during implementation of the Evaluate Live Capture Gear project (2007-249-00).
objectives: Collect natural-origin and hatchery-origin summer/fall Chinook broodstock for the Chief Joseph Hatchery Program using purse seine, tangle nets and other selective fishing gears  and techniques
Reduce pHOS of summer/fall Chinook in the Upper Columbia and Okanogan river basins by harvesting HOR summer Chinook for subsistence and ceremonial uses and releasing NOR Chinook at point of capture
Sample harvested HOR summer/fall Chinook for CWTs
Interrogate salmonids encountered in program activities for PIT tags and other marks and tags.
Harvest Okanagan Sockeye to the yearly allocation level
Instruct individual tribal fishermen on the techniques of selective fishing
402.assumptions:
Okanogan River summer/fall Chinook are subject to a very high exploitation rate in Pacific Ocean and Columbia River fisheries. 

Numbers of returning fish fluctuate from year to year due to yearly changes in spawning conditions, hatchery production levels, SAR rate, ocean conditions, exploitation rate and river conditions. 

Hatchery supplementation and selective fisheries increase fish availablity for terminal fisheries and allow a higher proportion of NOR escapement into natural spawning areas.

metrics.title: Reduce pHOS of summer/fall Chinook in spawning areas
Selective harvest of HOR summer/fall Chinook

416.background: CHaMP is designed as a Columbia River basin-wide habitat status and trends monitoring program built around a single protocol with a programmatic approach to data collection and management (RM&E Workgroup 2010). CHaMP will result in the collection and analysis of systematic habitat status and trends information that will be used to assess basin-wide habitat conditions. When coupled with biological response indicators, this status and trends information will be used to evaluate habitat management strategies. This program will be integrated with ongoing Pacific Northwest Aquatic Monitoring Program (PNAMP) recovery planning efforts and will be part of the collaborative process across Columbia Basin fish management agencies and tribes and other state and federal agencies that are monitoring anadromous salmonids and/or their habitat. The implementation of CHaMP will characterize stream responses to watershed restoration and/or management actions in at least one population within each steelhead and spring Chinook Major Population Group (MPG) which have, or will have, “fish-in” and “fish-out” monitoring (identified in RPA 50.6), thereby meeting the requirements of RPA 56.3, RPA 57, and RPA 3. CHaMP was designed to deliver trends in habitat indicators and requires that monitoring occurs for three cycles of a sampling panel (see section 1.6), at least 9 years.
objectives: The stream habitat data will be applied in conjunction with salmonid growth, survival, abundance and productivity data to estimate fish-habitat relationships across the Upper Columbia River Basin area

To generate standardized status and trend and effectiveness monitoring data for salmonid habitat in important Major Population Groups and spaitally diverse watersheds of the Columbia River Basin area.

To assess the quantity and quality of stream habitat for salmonids in wadeable, perennial streams below natural impassible barriers within Technical Recovery Team population boundaries across the UCRB
416.assumptions: The protocol is structured around a general understanding of the link between habitat attributes and how they directly relate to the specific life history requirements of the salmonid fishes managed under the 2008 BiOp. These fish are likely not only responding to watershed and reach conditions but also to the conditions of individual channel units within reaches. Recognizing the importance of how interactions at the channel unit scale affect fish performance has led to an increased emphasis on the quantification of this important scale of fish habitat in the CHaMP protocol. We adopted the Hawkins et al. (1993) hierarchical classification scheme that allows for summarization of information across multiple scales. This preserves the ability to summarize information at the site scale as commonly practiced in major fish habitat monitoring programs throughout the Pacific Northwest as well as at the smaller channel-unit and topographical feature scales. The protocol employs spatially continuous sampling strategies using well-established surveying techniques to conduct precise topographic surveys from which digital elevation models (DEMs) can be produced. These topographic surveys are augmented by auxiliary data (e.g., channel classification, fish cover, substrate composition, distribution and embeddedness, large woody debris (LWD), solar input and water temperature, stream discharge, water chemistry, riparian structure, and site-level human influence) that help to characterize aspects of channel units that influence site-scale fish production potential. The CHaMP protocol draws together methods from many existing protocols as well as novel approaches to collecting and analyzing channel geomorphological data. The protocol is designed to collect data that fits within a geomorphological hierarchy spanning spatial scales ranging from within-unit topographical features to channel units to geomorphic to watershed and subbasin scales.

416.title: Scientific Protocol for Salmonid Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP)

428.background: This protocol is utilized toward the completion of objectives outlined in a project from the Fish & Wildlife Program Accords that addresses the use of genetic markers to evaluate population structure of white sturgeon in the lower Columbia River and upstream of Bonneville Dam. The specific objectives are to 1) evaluate population differentiation and migration (gene flow) among reservoirs, 2) determine relatedness, mean productivity, and relative spawner abundances within each reservoir, and 3) characterize broodstock including identifying origins (reservoir or population) and degree of relatedness among candidate broodstock fish for planned use in a restoration and enhancement facility. These three objectives address needs for distinguishing specific stocks, determining genetic diversity, stock specific abundance, distribution and movement, and supplementation efforts. A panel of microsatellite (uSAT) loci have been compiled and optimized with a locus scoring protocol adopted from researchers at the University of California at Davis (UCD; Andrea Drauch pers. comm.) for collection of standardized multilocus genotypic data. This provides the opportunity for future collaboration and complementary efforts among interested research groups. Beginning with the currently proposed long-term monitoring effort, establishing a data repository will allow implementation of future pedigree studies for monitoring survival of hatchery releases, and ultimately for estimating natural reproductive success of both wild and released hatchery reared sturgeon. The work related to these objectives will be completed by CRITFC and University of Idaho (UI) staff at the Hagerman Fish Culture Experiment Station. Tissue samples will be collected by staff from CRITFC, WDFW, and ODFW. Genotyping and genetic analysis will be completed by CRITFC and UI staff in Hagerman, ID.
428.assumptions: White sturgeon in the middle Columbia River impoundments are in decline compared to the lower Columbia River region. Migration and geneflow is limited. Those populations with relatively small and variable census sizes are likely to exhibit genetic drift. Effective numbers of breeders across impounments is variable and relatedness amoung young of the year and sub-adult fish may be high within some impoundments. Broodstock will be characterized and genetic variablility maintained relative to the natural-origin populations.

428.title: Genetic Assessment of Columbia River Sturgeon

436.background:
The cultural and spiritual relationship between the native peoples of the Pacific Northwest and salmon was, and is, central to their society. Historically, the upper Columbia River Basin was home to five anadromous fish species Chinook Salmon Oncorhynchus tshawytscha, Sockeye Salmon O. nerka, Coho Salmon O. kisutch, steelhead O. mykiss gairdnerii (anadromous Redband Rainbow Trout), and Pacific Lamprey Lampetra tridentata. However, fish passage in the Columbia River was blocked by the construction of Grand Coulee (1939; river km 960) and Chief Joseph dams (1956; river km 877). Currently, Chief Joseph Dam marks the most upstream extent of the habitat available to anadromous fish. The extirpation of these fish from the upper Columbia River Basin eliminated many subsistence fishing opportunities for Native American Tribes and First Nations in Canada. However, relict freshwater resident populations of historically anadromous fish still exist in these habitats including Redband Rainbow Trout and kokanee (lacustrine Sockeye Salmon). 

The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) Chief Joseph Kokanee Enhancement Project (CJKEP) and the Resident Fish Research Monitoring and Evaluation (RM&E) Project and Columbia River Fish Accord project that began in 1996 and 2008, respectively. The primary goal for both projects is to: conserve, enhance and restore native fish populations in the blocked area above Grand Coulee Dam in Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries, and where appropriate provide opportunities for subsistence harvest by the Colville Tribal members and recreational anglers. 

The CJKEP has focused on the protection and conservation of wild kokanee, while the RM&E Project has focused on the protection and conservation of Redband Trout populations on the CCT Reservation, with an emphasis on the Sanpoil River and Lake Roosevelt tributaries on the east side of the reservation.
objectives: Quantify escapement and population structure of wild redband trout in the Sanpoil River
Quantify escapement and population structure of wild kokanee salmon in the Sanpoil River

437.background: This Flow Restoration Accounting Framework emerges from an evolving foundation of reporting mechanisms developed since the inception of the Columbia Basin Water Transaction Program in 2002 to demonstrate project compliance and effectiveness of water transactions. With a focus specifically on water transactions, the Flow Restoration Accounting Framework is designed around a discrete logic path that tracks the four sequential components of a flow transaction. These steps comprise the four nested tiers of monitoring investments: Project Compliance: Ensure compliance with the terms of the transaction. Flow Accounting: Account for the flow added to the protected stream reach at the point of diversion (POD) before, during, and after the time period of the water transaction. Aquatic Habitat Response: Account for changes in flow-related aquatic habitat metrics along a specified section of the protected reach during the time period of the water transaction. Ecological Function: Evaluate changes in flow-related habitat characteristics that may track with changes broader-scale biological conditions and fish population dynamics.  This document has an adaptive management component and will be re-visited on a regular basis as the CBWTP Monitoring effort develops.
objectives: This programmatic monitoring protocol is designed to guide the CBWTP and our partners to validate, track and verify project compliance and effectiveness of our flow restoration program.
437.assumptions:
The Flow Restoration Accounting Framework is premised upon two key ecological assumptions that strengthen the development of water transactions as a tool for aquatic habitat restoration. i. Transacted water can be accounted for within a protected stream reach. ii. Flow is a limiting factor to ESA-listed Evolutionarily Significant Units (ESUs) and other at-risk species of concern.

Additionally, this programmatic monitoring protocol, integrates existing USGS stream-discharge monitoring methods and protocol, as well as establishing stage-discharge relationships for continuous flow monitoring, so assumes monitoring staff have some familiarity with these techniques and methods.

438.background: Nonnative predators, such as Walleye, Smallmouth Bass and Northern Pike are negatively affecting the conservation and restoration of native fish species around the country (Stroud et al. 2011, Sepulveda et al 2013, Bernall et al. 2005). Bioenergetics studies done in Lake Roosevelt, Washington, in 2011, found that Walleye and Smallmouth Bass populations combined consumed 94.7% of the hatchery kokanee fry released, 40.1% of the hatchery kokanee yearlings released, 24% of the out-migrating Rainbow Trout yearlings, and 27.4% of the rainbow trout 2 and 3 year old populations (Stroud et al. 2011). Mechanical removal methods such as gillnetting, boat electrofishing, fyke netting, beach seines, and angling can be used to reduce populations of invasive predators. By using an array of methods researchers can effectively sample during the entire year and decrease the catch rate of non target species by selecting the best method for the conditions and time of year.
objectives: Reduce non-native predator densities to increase the survival of native fish populations.
438.assumptions: We are assuming the reduction in predators will affect kokanee and rainbow trout survival.

442.background: A primary objective of the Chief Joseph Kokanee Enhancement Project (CJKEP) is to identify and address factors limiting naturally produced kokanee salmon. The Sanpoil River, tributary to the Columbia River in Lake Roosevelt, has been selected by the project for kokanee restoration and enhancement. Water quality and habitat surveys conducted in the Sanpoil River drainage in 2009-10 found areas that had conditions indicative of high quality kokanee spawning. Model results suggested the Sanpoil River could support a spawning escapement of 238,464 to 1,703,315 kokanee. The project began utilizing egg and and yearling plants in the Sanpoil River as a means to establish kokanee runs. The project plans to implement an egg to fry survival study to estimate survival during the period prior to out-migration. The objectives will be to determine egg to alevin survival during the intra gravel burial, monitor developmental stages, emergence times, alevin and juvenile sizes, and outmigration timing. The project will correlate developmental parameters with physical parameters (dissolved oxygen, temperature, and fine sediments)
objectives: Estimate egg to emergence survival and timing of out-migration
442.assumptions: The project assumes study areas will be safe to access during the key development and out-migration periods.

478.background:
Due to persistent recruitment failure, the subpopulation of white sturgeon inhabiting the upper Columbia River above Grand Coulee Dam is classified as Critically Endangered by the IUCN and endangered under the Canadian Species at Risk Act. Recruitment failure in the area between Grand Coulee and HLK dams (the Transboundary Reach) white sturgeon population was first documented during surveys of both the Keenleyside Reach (British Columbia) and the Roosevelt Reach (Washington State) in the 1990’s (Hildebrand et al. 1999; DeVore et al. 2000). Concerns over the threat of extinction led to the formation of the Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Initiative (UCWSRI) in 2000 and the production of an Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Plan (UCWSRP; UCWSRI 2002) compatible with the ESA and SARA legislation. The goal of the UCWSRI “is to ensure the persistence and viability of naturally reproducing populations of white sturgeon in the upper Columbia River and restore opportunities for beneficial use if feasible.” Lake Roosevelt Subyearling White Sturgeon Gill Net Surveys are primarily intended to 1) document annual natural recruitment and 2) evaluate the relative survival of experimental larval releases to subyearling and yearling juveniles as part of proposed research to test hypotheses relating to post-hatch dispersal (see BPA project 2008-116-00). Surveys will be standardized, coordinated and conducted simultaneously with efforts by the Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project (1995-027-00) and those conducted in the Keenleyside Reach.

All of the data analysis will be completed by the STOI's Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project (1995-027-00) per their project protocol, which has yet to be developed.
objectives: Monitor annual natural recruitment of white sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt.
478.assumptions: Our frame is representative of our target population.

491.background: Freshwater Mussels occupy very stable habitats in river systems, and their life histories do not easily accommodate relocation.  In instances of in-channel restoration or construction work, de-watering, or other  alterations to a river or stream, mussels are not able to move from the impacted site, and must be collected and relocated to a suitable, non-impacted areas to reduce direct mortality from the alteration.  Relocation or translocation efforts of adult mussels are stressful events for the animals and are often accompanied by high mortality rates.  Juvenile life stages below ~1cm are difficult to collect by standard survey methods, and are frequently overlooked in a collection effort.  Translocation events should only occur when it is determined that the stress of translocation is less than the stress of leaving mussels in place during channel alterations.  Steps should be taken to reduce stress to collected mussels during survey work, collection, transport, acclimation to new locations, and reestablishment in the new location.  Best Management Practices recently developed and published by the Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation aim to give restoration practitioners and others tools to recognize and protect freshwater mussels during stream alteration activities, reducing  negative impacts to mussel populations, and allowing better conservation of existing mussel populations.
objectives: Apply and evaluate efficacy of Best Management Practices outlined in "Conserving the Gems of Our Waters" - freshwater mussel BMPs published by the Xerces Society by Blevins et al. 2017.
491.assumptions: Translocation events will take place if mussels are in the immediate impact area of a ecologically justifyable and pre-planned stream alteration event.  The preproject timeline and project coordination will be such that survey, salvage, translocation, and following up monitoring of mussel populations will be able to follow methods and procedures specificed in the "Conserving the Gems of Our Waters" document.

492.background: Freshwater mussels are among the most imperiled freshwater fauna worldwide.  Native freshwater mussel species present in the Pacific Northwest have been reported to have range declines of 43-17% by watershed area (Blevins et al. 2017).  The CTUIR's Freshwater Mussel project has been conducting baseline surveys and research to understand mussel status and distribution across the ceded territory since 2003, with goal of understanding factors that underly the distribution and population health and status of mussel populations.  Conservation of existing mussel fauna and restoration of damaged populations relies on the baseline survey information and trends shown through ongoing monitoring of mussel populations.  General procedures outlined under this protocol generally follow methods from Box et al. 2006.
objectives: To determine distribution of freshwater mussel populations by sub-basin, and to evaluate population health and status through mussel specific surveys.
492.assumptions: 1. Monitoring efforts will give an accurate assessment of underlying mussel presence or abundances per site. 2. Monitoring will be timely and complete in order to detect underlying trends in abundance.

499.background: This report describes a protocol for monitoring fish densities and fish assemblage structure using snorkel surveys. The Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission (CRITFC), Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife (ODFW), and Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR) have recognized the need to use a common snorkel survey so that information collected by individual entities can help managers determine whether aggregate habitat restoration actions will yield a net improvement in basin-wide habitat quality for ESA listed fish species (NOAA 2007). To this end, we developed a snorkeling protocol drawing heavily from the protocols of Thurow (1994) and O’Neal (2007), intended for use among all agencies responsible for data collection in the upper Grande Ronde, Catherine Creek, Minam River, and potentially other nearby basins.
objectives: Document the relative abundance of juvenile salmonids at the habitat unit and reach scales.
Document fish assemblage structure at the habitat unit and reach scales.
499.assumptions: The key assumption of this protocol is that snorkeling provides a consistent measure of relative fish abundance and assemblage structure.

518.background:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss and ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes’ (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone 1991). The goal was to restore healthy and harvestable salmonid populations through rehabilitation of stream habitat and restoration of ecological function in the riparian corridors of streams. Numerous restoration actions were implemented and corresponding rainbow trout status and trend monitoring was conducted.

In 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committee’s Categorical Review process, there was an evaluation of project accomplishments and future direction. While it was obvious that the project made substantial attempts to improve habitat conditions and monitor trends in rainbow trout populations, it is was also apparent that the approach to both aspects was relatively haphazard. Monitoring study design lacked statistical rigor and prioritization of habitat restoration actions was unclear. In response to these shortcomings, we developed a new approach to habitat restoration and protection that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clearly defined prioritization strategy

We will use empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use from our monitoring efforts and an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help us evaluate where the highest priority areas are for habitat restoration and protection. EDT is an analytical model relating habitat features and biological performance to support conservation and recovery planning for salmonids (Lichatowich et al. 1995; Lestelle et al. 1996; Mobrand et al. 1997; Mobrand et al. 1998). It acts as an analytical framework that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis to determine which reaches and habitat attributes are likely to have the most benefit for improving fish performance.

Development of the EDT model requires the rating of Level II attributes for the current conditions. We place the highest confidence in Level II attribute ratings that are based on empirical data. Work conducted under this protocol will provide reach specific temperature data to be used to rate EDT Level II attributes associated with stream temperature.These data will also facilitate analysis of spatial patterns and variance in stream temperature among multiple watersheds in the Sanpoil and Upper Columbia River Subbasins
objectives: Collect continuous surface water temperature in all migratory redband rainbow trout spawning tributaries.
518.assumptions: The temperature data (~ 1m^2) collected at the logger location is representative of the water temperature within the entire reach it is located.

citation.title: LRHIP - Stream Temperature Monitoring v1.0

521.background: In 1949, the construction of Grand Coulee Dam on the Columbia River formed Franklin D. Roosevelt Lake (Lake Roosevelt). Grand Coulee Dam was built without fish passage and permanently blocked the anadromous migratory pathways of numerous fish species, extirpating salmon and lamprey and fragmenting resident fish populations. The current resident fishery is supported by the Lake Roosevelt Artificial Production Program (LRAPP), comprised of the Spokane Tribal Hatchery, WDFW Sherman Creek State Hatchery, and the volunteer operated Lake Roosevelt Rainbow Trout Net Pen Project. The LRAPP releases hatchery fish as partial mitigation for the loss of anadromous fish runs and supports a recreational and subsistence fishery for kokanee and rainbow trout. The Lake Roosevelt Fisheries Evaluation Program (LRFEP) uses the Lake Roosevelt angler creel survey to monitor  the efficacy of LRAPP release strategies. The Lake Roosevelt angler creel survey is cooperatively implemented by the Lake Roosevelt co-management entities, the Spokane Tribe of Indians, Colville Confederated Tribes, and the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife. All hatchery fish released into Lake Roosevelt are marked with a fin clip (typically an adipose fin clip) and/or an otolith mark prior to release. The ability to easily identify hatchery fish is critical for assessing performance of hatchery release strategies and also allows co-managers to develop fishing regulations that protect wild stocks of kokanee and rainbow trout. The Lake Roosevelt angler creel survey collects various data, including the numbers of each fish species caught, harvested, and released by anglers, reported angling effort, and fish morphometric data that is used to assess growth and condition at harvest. Estimates of total catch, harvest, total angler effort, and angler catch-per-unit-effort are used to assess the contribution of hatchery fishes to the fishery, and provides insight into the economic contribution of the Lake Roosevelt fishery to the region.
objectives: The primary objectives of the Lake Roosevelt angler creel survey are to estimate annual angler pressure, catch, harvest, and catch-rate, and the economic value of the fishery.
521.assumptions: 1. There are differences in the distribution of fishing efforts within a day. 2. There are no differences in the distribution of fishing efforts among or between days within the five weekdays or between days within the two weekend days. 3. There are differences in the distribution of fishing efforts from one time block to another. 4. All the fishing trips are completed between sunrise and sundown. 5. The number of boats launched outside access points is negligible. 6. Most of the fishing pressure comes from boat anglers, not shore anglers.

533.background: This protocol was designed as a methodology for monitoring surface hydrology, water quality, limnology, and zooplankton in Lake Roosevelt under the Lake Roosevelt Fisheries Evaluation Program (LRFEP). Reservoir characteristics examined under this protocol will include surface hydrology (inflow, outflow, spill, water retention time, lake elevation), physical properties and macronutrient water quality parameters (turbidity, total suspended solids, chloride, fluoride, total alkalinity, nitrate, nitrite, ammonia, total Kjeldahl nitrogen, total nitrogen phosphorus, orthophosphate, and sulfate), limnological properties (temperature, dissolved oxygen, conductivity, pH, oxidation-reduction potential, total dissolved solids, and total dissolved gas), chlorophyll a concentrations, and relative zooplankton densities and biomass. Data collected under this protocol will be used to identify spatial and temporal trends in water quality and lower trophic level organisms throughout the reservoir. Trends will be compared with fish data collected by the LRFEP to identify effects of hydro-operations on resident fish communities and the ecology of Lake Roosevelt.
objectives: Complete annual limnological assesment of Lake Roosevelt.
533.assumptions: Spatial and temporal design accurately characterize the reaches within the reservoir. Metrics respond predictably to hydro-operations.

536.background: The status of migratory salmonid populations are monitored by generating annual estimates of the number of adult spawners at either the tributary or watershed scale.  It is imperative to generate reliable estimates of spawners given that one of the primary objectives of recovery efforts is to augment sub-populations of migratory adults that would support a persistent meta-population structure at the watershed scale and ultimately provide a sustainable fishery.  Survival rates of salmonids during their residence time outside their spawning and early life-history rearing environment, a key vital rate in influencing population trajectories (Stapp and Hayward 2002), are also estimated to understand whether processes in adult rearing environments (e.g., larger streams or lakes) are limiting adult production.  Fixed weir migrant traps have been employed as a sampling technique across projects of the Coeur d'Alene Tribe's fisheries program to generate this data.  In the Hangman Creek watershed, a single fixed weir is located on each of Indian and Nehchen creeks to sample migratory redband trout populations that utilize larger stream habitats as adult rearing environments.  In the Coeur d'Alene basin, a single fixed weir is located on each of Lake and Benewah creeks to sample migratory westslope cutthroat trout populations that utilize Coeur d'Alene Lake as an adult rearing environment.  This protocol is intended to be used for each of these two projects.
objectives: Generate annual abundance estimates for migratory adult salmonids at the tributary or watershed scale.
Generate annual estimates of juvenile to adult return rates for migratory salmonids at the tributary or watershed scale.
Annually examine life-history attributes of migratory salmonids (e.g. migration timing, sex ratio, mean size of fish).
536.assumptions: Individual fish sampled at the migrant trap represent the population of interest at the tributary or watershed scale.

538.background: The anadromous life history form of redband trout was eliminated from the upper Columbia River with the construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939 and likely blocked migration routes and isolated populations and habitats of potamodromous redband trout. Identification of wild redband trout populations and their life history strategies have not been completed in portions of the Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River. Populations of wild redband trout are thought to spawning in gravel bars in the river channels and on shorelines of the reservoir. Investigations to determine the status of these stocks should be conducted to understand the importance of these main channel spawners into the overall redband trout population.
objectives: Quantify redband trout redds in the Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River
Quantify redband trout adult spawners in the Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River
Identify redband trout spawning locations in the Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River
Identify potential redband trout spawning locations in the Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River
538.assumptions: Adult redband trout are spawning in the lower Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River.

545.background: This protocol describes White sturgeon movement responses to mitigative flows and temperatures provided by Libby Dam.  We monitor sturgeon movements primarily with a passive telemetry array which extends from River kilometer (White sturgeon will be captured and tagged with Vemco sonic transmitters.  Movement throughout the Kootenai River/Kootenay Lake system will be determined with these stationary an array of Vemco VR2W receivers which extends from rkm 300 ("Sturgeon Hole") in Montana downstream to Kootenay Lake as far as rkm 18 near the Lardeau River delta. Real time active tracking and position monitoring will be determined during critical periods with Vemco VR-100 receivers.  This receiver array allows us to determine fish movement and behavioral responses to Libby dam operations as well as other mitigation measures (discharge and temperature).  In addition to general large scale movement monitoring with the Vemco VR2W array, this work element will also include incorporating Vemco's "Vemco Positioning System (VPS) which will allow us to evaluate finer scale sturgeon movements near Shorty's Island and possibly other areas where habitat enhancement projects are planned.
objectives: Determine specific environmental parameters that influence adult spawning movements into proper spawning habitat above Bonners Ferry, Idaho.
545.assumptions: One assumption of our sampling program is that our methods are unbiased, and the data we collect is representative of the true status of the population.

546.background: This protocol was established to evaluate trends in the timing and extend of spawning by Kootenai River white sturgeon. We hope to answer whether changes in physical habit proplosed by KTOI (Habitat Master Plan no. wt141243) will change spawning locations or timing and reproductive success.

547.background: Significant wild sturgeon recruitment has not occurred in the Kootenai River since at least 1972. Hatchery production from Kootenai Tribe of Idaho (KTOI) began in 1990. To evaluate the successes of the KTOI hatchery program and to evaluate the effects of mitigative flows provided by Libby Dam beginning in 1991, juvenile sturgeon sampling became a standard operating procedure beginning in 1978 (Partridge 1983). We evaluate survival, growth, disease presence, condition, and movements of hatchery reared juvenile sturgeon. Although significant wild recruitment is lacking, we catch about 10 wild recruits each year. Gill nets are the best method for evaluating significant recruitment.
objectives: Determine relative abundance, growth, and survival of juvenile Kootenai River White Sturgeon
547.assumptions: All hatchery released juvenile sturgeon are marked

548.background:
In Idaho, burbot Lota lota are endemic only to the Kootenai River (Simpson and Wallace 1982). Burbot in the Kootenai River once provided an important winter fishery. This fishery and that of Kootenay Lake, British Columbia, Canada may have been the most robust in North America (Paragamian and Hoyle 2005). However, after the construction and operation of Libby Dam by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) in 1972, the fishery in Idaho rapidly declined and was closed in 1992. Concomitant to the collapse in Idaho was the collapse of the burbot fishery in Kootenay Lake and Kootenay River, British Columbia (Paragamian et al. 2000).

Burbot stock limitations become an increasing factor to restoration with each passing season. Because the Kootenai River burbot stock is so limited, the introduction of a genetically similar donor stock was found to be a useful approach to enhance the population.

In the past few years, intensive culture techniques developed by the Kootenai Tribe of Idaho, BC Ministry of Environment, the UIARI, and Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG) have become an important restoration measure for burbot on the Kootenai River.

The management goal of this study is to restore the burbot population in the Idaho reach of the Kootenai River in order to provide an annual sustainable harvest of burbot.

In order to determine trends in the adult and juvenile burbot population, we use hoop nets throughout the Kootenai River, Kootenai Lake, and tributaries in Idaho and Canada. Numbers and distribution of adult and juveniles are documented in established trend locations. Biological information including length, weight, genetics , and presence of PIT tags or other identifying marks on adult and juvenile burbot are recorded. Abundance and survival are estimated using variations of the Jolly-Seber model applied to between-season recapture data (Ricker 1975). Burbot movements and responses to mitigative measures are evaluated with passive telemetry techniques. We implant VEMCO sonic transmitters in adult burbot to test if winter discharge management from Libby Dam is negatively affecting burbot spawning. Spawn timing, frequency, and response to environmental conditions are only measured by passive telemetry techniques. Since most burbot that have been released from the University of Idaho Aquatic Research Institute are marked with PIT tags, a full duplex (FDX) array is placed at the confluence of a release tributary to determine if hatchery burbot are returning to spawn once they reach sexual maturity. Parental based tagging (PBT) is also incorporated to determine parentage of all recaptured burbot.
objectives: Assess population demographics (survival, growth, and recruitment) of wild and hatchery produced natural burbot of the Kootenai River, ID.
548.assumptions: Burbot stocked since 2010 have survived and are now recruited to the population at large.

549.background:
Burbot stock limitations become an increasing factor to restoration with each passing season. Because the Kootenai River burbot stock is so limited (Paragamian and Laude 2008), the introduction of a genetically similar donor stock was found to be a useful approach to enhance the population.

In the past few years, intensive culture techniques developed by the Kootenai Tribe of Idaho, BC Ministry of Environment, the UIARI, and Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG) have become an important restoration measure for burbot on the Kootenai River. The management goal of this study is to restore the burbot population in the Idaho reach of the Kootenai River in order to provide an annual sustainable harvest of burbot.

This work element contains specific early life history evaluations. This protocol involves determining the survival and migration timing of PIT tagged burbot released into tributaries of the Kootenai River.  We use a PIT tag array in one specific tributary (Deep Creek) to investigate factors that affect survival and timing.  In the future, we may set up in-situ tests to determine if current conditions in the Kootenai River are suitable to rearing burbot naturally. Example of test hypothesis will include: Null Hypothesis (Ho) tested: tributary temperature and habitat conditions have no affect on residence time of larval or juvenile burbot.
objectives: Determine condition suitable for stocking burbot in tributaries of the Kootenai River.
Determine if burbot stocked into specific tributaries will return to their stocking location to spawn.
549.assumptions: Fish have an equal chance of being sampled once they are recruited to gear in the Kootenai River.

550.background: Dworshak Reservoir was impounded in 1972 with the construction of Dworshak Dam. Since this time, the reservoir has undergone a process of 'oligitropphication' due to a combination of natural processes and dam operations. The most notable of these is the loss of marine derived nutrients due to the extirpation of anadromous salmonids. In 2007, the US Army Corps of Engineers began supplementing the reservoir with liquid ammonium nitrate fertilizer to improve the N:P ratio and promote a more efficient foodweb. The Idaho Department of Fish and Game has been conducting limnological surveys to monitor the effects of this project on the limnological conditions in the reservoir. A detailed description of this monitoring program can be found in the project Standard Analysis Plan (SAP) and Quality Assurance Project Plan (QAPP).
objectives: Provide an assessment of the effects of nutrient restoration on the productivity, food web and limnological characteristics of Dworshak Reservoir.
Provide data for the adaptive management of nutrient applications in season.
Provide data to evaluate water quality standards set forth in the project NPDES permit issued by EPA and certified by IDEQ.
550.assumptions: Samples and measurements are representative of the reservoir conditions as a whole.

552.background: The Dworshak Reservoir Fisheries Mitigation Project was designed to mitigate for losses of resident fish and associated fisheries due to the construction and operation of Dworshak Dam. One of the goals of the project is to improve the resident fisheries within the reservoir and one of the objectives specifies catch rates and average size of fish in the creel for the kokanee fishery. The only way to determine whether these objectives are met is to perform a creel census. While Dworshak Reservoir is a large water body, it has limited access points and little opportunity for angling from shore. Therefore, it is well suited to an access-access type survey design.
objectives: Estimate the total fishing effort and the effort directed at each species during the time period of the creel survey.
Estimate the catch and harvest by species for the time period of the creel survey.
Estimate the mean size of harvested kokanee during the time period of the creel census.
552.assumptions: Anglers interviewed will be representative of the overall fishery. The number of shore anglers fishing at locations other than boat ramps is negligible. The number of boats launched at locations other than the established boat ramps is negligible.

554.background:
The Kootenai River basin has been impacted by many anthropogenic activities (e.g., agriculture, mining, land use practices, and the construction and operation of Libby Dam), all of which have affected the ecosystem and led to declines in resident fish populations.  Libby Dam has significantly altered the flow regimes and channel morphology of the Kootenai River since it was constructed in the early 1970s, and it has depleted nutrients and caused a decline in primary productivity in the Idaho portion of the river (Woods 1982; Snyder and Minshall 1996). By the 1990s, this reduction in productivity translated to a two- to four-fold decrease in the number of mountain whitefish, compared to numbers present in 1980-81 (Partridge 1983; Paragamian 1990); this was one noticeable effect, among many.

Lake Koocanusa, the reservoir created by Libby Dam, acts as a nutrient sink (Snyder and Minshall 1996), retaining approximately 63% of total phosphorus (P) and 25% of total nitrogen (N) entering the reservoir (Woods 1982). Due to low current velocities in the reservoir, these nutrients bind to sediments and precipitate out of solution (Snyder and Minshall 1996), making them unavailable to organisms in the river below the dam. Consequently, the Idaho portion of the Kootenai River has been considered “nutrient poor” (ultraoligotrophic) and P-limited (Snyder and Minshall 1996) since the completion of Libby Dam. The loss of nutrients in the Idaho portion of the Kootenai River has reduced primary production, and this has likely contributed to poor sport and non-sport fish production over the past two decades.

Increases in primary production have been successfully facilitated through the addition of inorganic P and N in other aquatic ecosystems (Ashley et al. 1999), which in turn has been successful in recovering wild fish populations. It was proposed that increases in primary production through nutrient restoration could be used to stimulate fish production in the Kootenai River from bottom up trophic cascades (Snyder and Minshall 1996).

The Kootenai River Ecosystem Project was designed to take an ecosystem-based approach to rehabilitating the fish populations in the Kootenai River. Whereas, past fisheries management programs on the Kootenai River have focused on recovering single species, this project was designed to support recovery of fish populations utilizing an ecosystem-based strategy (as opposed to simply treating the symptoms of degrading stocks). The addition of nutrients to this ultraoligotrophic system was hypothesized to stimulate production in the nutrient-depleted food web and reverse the downward trends in populations of trout, kokanee, mountain whitefish, burbot Lota lota, white sturgeon Acipenser transmontanus, as well as others species.  This report summarizes results specific to fish populations. Results relative to changes in primary productivity and macroinvertebrate communities will be reported by the Kootenai Tribe of Idaho.
objectives: Restore fish populations in the Idaho reach of the Kootenai River to densities present prior to Libby Dam.
554.assumptions: Sampling sites are representative of different reaches/habitat types of the Kootenai River.  Control sites aid in eliminating confounding factors, and provide the basis for evaluating the effect of nutrients.
