554.title: KRRFM – Ecosystem Restoration: Fish Biomonitoring

555.background:
The Kootenai River basin has been impacted by many anthropogenic activities (e.g., agriculture, mining, land use practices, and the construction and operation of Libby Dam), all of which have affected the ecosystem and led to declines in resident fish populations. Libby Dam has significantly altered the flow regimes and channel morphology of the Kootenai River since it was constructed in the early 1970s, and it has depleted nutrients and caused a decline in primary productivity in the Idaho portion of the river (Woods 1982; Snyder and Minshall 1996). By the 1990s, this reduction in productivity translated to a two- to four-fold decrease in the number of mountain whitefish, compared to numbers present in 1980-81 (Partridge 1983; Paragamian 1990); this was one noticeable effect, among many.

In order to document potential changes in abundance of mountain whitefish, rainbow trout, and largescale suckers a population estimate in a three km reach of the Kootenai River has been conducted since the early 1980s. The survey has been conducted intermittently since the 1980s; however, since the mid-2000s, attempts have been made to conduct the survey every two years.  The river reach in which the survey is conducted is located within a portion of the river that is directly affected by nutrient-additions.  Therefore, these data are used for historical documentation of population trends as well as evaluation of the ecosystem restoration project [detailed in Protocol ID: 554].
objectives: Estimate the abundance of mountain whitefish, rainbow trout, and largescale suckers in order to better inform management decisions.
Evaluate population trends through time to gauge the status of respective species populations relative to induced and naturally occurring changes in the Kootenai River.
555.assumptions: The sampling reach is representative and inclusive of all habitat types in the upper reaches of the Kootenai River.  Key assumptions for mark-recapture population estimates include:  (1) Between the mark and recapture periods, nothing has happened to upset the proportions of marked to unmarked animals (i.e., no new individuals enter or leave the study area.  (2) The chances for each individual in the population to be caught are equal and constant for both the initial marking period and the recapture period.  (3) A sufficient period of time has transpired between the initial marking period and the recapture period for all marked individuals to be randomly dispersed throughout the population.  (4) Marks do not affect survival, catchability, ability to migrate, reproduce etc. (5) Fish do not lose their marks, and all marks are detected when encountered.

555.title: KRRFM – Native Species Population Monitoring and Evaluation

556.background:
Knowledge about movements and life history of potamodromous salmonids is generally well-understood; however, declining or suppressed populations often require additional insight in order to effectively conserve, perpetuate, and manage such populations.  Potamodromous salmonids are (generally) known to utilize specific spawning, growth, and refuge habitats within large stream and river networks, and they often make extensive migrations to utilize these different habitats (Northcote 1997).  Although life history behaviors of resident, freshwater salmonids are oftentimes generalized across all stream and riverine systems, it is important to consider system-specific differences that may be driving population declines or suppression, especially in anthropogenically altered systems.

Rainbow Trout populations in the Kootenai River, Montana/Idaho have been impacted by the construction and operation of Libby Dam, Montana since 1972; population declines (primarily in Idaho), have been documented following the construction of Libby Dam.  In addition, populations have been impacted by a variety of other factors, including channelization, levees, and tributary alteration/functional disconnection.  It has long-been speculated that several tributaries in Montana provide the largest numbers of out-migrant recruits to the mainstem rainbow trout population in the Kootenai River.  These recruits are thought to seed the majority of the mainstem adult population, both in Idaho and Montana.  Although traditional methods exist to validate this assumption, newer, less labor-intensive and error-prone methods are now available to address such questions; in particular, otolith microchemistry has emerged as a powerful technique for such purposes.  Naturally occurring geochemical signatures in fish otoliths can provide valuable information on natal origins and life histories of individual fish, which can then be extrapolated to make population-level inferences (Campana and Thorrold 2001; Kennedy et al. 1997; Thorrold et al. 2001).  This technique has been widely-used for studies involving anadromous fish species; however, relatively few studies have used it for studying natal origins and movement patterns of freshwater fishes (Muhlfeld et al. 2005; Munro et al. 2005; Wells et al. 2003).  Through continual refinement of this technique, strontium (Sr) isotopes have been identified as having the most discriminatory power in freshwater systems (Barnett-Johnson et al. 2005; Kennedy et al. 2000, 2002).

An otolith strontium isotope pilot study was conducted on the Kootenai River during November 2012.  The pilot study addressed two questions as a proof-of-concept:  (1) could tributaries to the Kootenai River be differentiated from one another using strontium isotopes derived from otoliths of pre-outmigrant young-of-year (YOY) rainbow trout and (2) could adult rainbow trout collected from the mainstem be assigned back to natal tributary based on otolith strontium isotopes.  The results of this pilot study were completed in May 2014, and they verified that both questions could be affirmatively answered.  Based on these results, the Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG), the Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks (MFWP), the Idaho Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit (ICFWRU) and the New Mexico Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit (NMCFWRU) decided to implement a larger-scale study on the Kootenai River.
objectives: Derive strontium isotope signatures for all major tributaries to the Kootenai River from Libby Dam, Montana to Boundary Creek, Idaho.
Estimate the percent contribution of each tributary to the mainstem adult rainbow trout population (both in Idaho and Montana).
Evaluate the relative proportion of adflfuvial (i.e., from Kootenay Lake, B.C.) versus fluvial (i.e., from the mainstem Kootenai River, ID and MT) contributions to the rainbow trout population.
Determine  (if possible) the extent and directionality of dispersal from natal tributary into the mainstem Kootenai River
Determine age-at-outmigration for each surveyed tributary.
556.assumptions:
Tributaries will possess unique Sr 87/86 signatures based on local geographical characteristics.

Age-0 Rainbow Trout residing and collected in tributaries were spawned in the tributary in which they were collected.

The Sr 87/86 signature of the Kootenay Lake differs from the signature in the Kootenai River.

The sample of adults is representative of the population structure in terms of tributary of origin.

Age-at-outmigration will be detectable based on the ability to accurately age Rainbow Trout otoliths relative to changes in Sr 87/86 signatures.

572.background: This protocol was developed to track temporal and spatial trends in trout abundance in stream reaches of watersheds that support salmonid populations that are of importance to the Coeur d’Alene Tribe. Monitoring abundance trajectories will aid in the evaluation of whether reach-scale stream conditions are improving or declining for local trout populations. The detection of declining trends or persistently low numbers of fish at the reach scale may signal localized degradation or deficiencies in habitat conditions that need to be addressed and prioritized for prospective habitat improvements. The tracking of temporal changes in the reach-scale distribution of trout populations will also permit an examination of expansion rates to evaluate whether newly created suitable habitat (e.g., barrier removal) is undergoing colonization. Overall, monitoring reach-scale changes in the distribution of trout populations should reveal whether connectivity is improving to transform patchy distributions to more resilient, robust metapopulation structures.  This protocol is intended to be used for populations of either westslope cutthroat trout, redband trout, brook trout, or bull trout.
objectives: Obtain reach-scale indices of trout abundance that can be used in prospective trend analyses
572.assumptions: Habitat units (e.g., pool availability) and habitat attributes (e.g., percent canopy cover) in the selected sample sites are representative of the habitat in the reach from which they were randomly selected.

573.background:
The subpopulation of white sturgeon inhabiting the upper Columbia River above Grand Coulee Dam is classified as Critically Endangered (CE) by the IUCN and listed as endangered under the Canadian Species At Risk Act (SARA) due to persistent recruitment failure. Recruitment failure in the area between Grand Coulee and Hugh Keenleyside dams (the Transboundary Reach) white sturgeon population was first documented during surveys of both the Keenleyside Reach (British Columbia) and the Roosevelt Reach (Washington state) in the 1990’s (Hildebrand et al. 1999; DeVore et al. 2000). In response to concerns over the threat of extinction, the Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Initiative (UCWSRI) was formed in 2000. The Initiative produced an Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Plan (UCWSRP) that is compatible with the ESA and SARA legislation. The goal of the UCWSRI, as defined in the UCWSRP, “is to ensure the persistence and viability of naturally reproducing populations of white sturgeon in the upper Columbia River and restore opportunities for beneficial use if feasible.” Population status and trend monitoring are considered core components of the recovery effort and this protocol describes how setline stock assessment surveys in the Roosevelt Reach will provide information on population parameters. Survey methodology and implementation will be standardized, coordinated, and conducted simultaneously with surveys conducted in Lake Roosevelt by the Spokane Tribe (Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project - 1995-027-00) and BC Hydro in the Keenleyside Reach.

All data analysis will be completed by the STOI Lake Roosevelt Sturgeon Recovery Project (1995-027-00).
objectives: Estimate the abundance of hatchery and wild components of the white sturgeon population.
Describe spatial and depth distributions of white sturgeon.
Estimate growth and condition of hatchery and wild components of the white sturgeon population.
Estimate survival rates in the hatchery and wild components of the white sturgeon population.
573.assumptions: Our frame is representative of our target population.

577.background: Lake trout were stocked in numerous lakes throughout western North America during the late 1800s and early 1900s (Crossman 1995), including Lake Pend Oreille (LPO) in 1925. Lake trout present a threat to native salmonids, including kokanee and bull trout. Bull trout are particularly susceptible to negative interactions with lake trout, and bull trout populations cannot be sustained after lake trout introduction (Donald and Alger 1993; Fredenberg 2002) without human intervention. Lake trout predation resulted in drastic decreases in the kokanee population in Lake Pend Oreille since 2000 (Maiolie et al. 2002; Maiolie et al. 2006). Declines in kokanee abundance is especially concerning as they are the main prey source for ESA-listed bull trout. In 2000, IDFG removed all bag limits on lake trout and implemented an Angler Incentive Program (AIP), which pays anglers to harvest lake trout. To further reduce lake trout abundance, IDFG has contracted with Hickey Brothers Research, LLC (Bailey’s Harbor, Wisconsin) since 2006 to fish gill and trap nets in Lake Pend Oreille.
objectives: Reduce the lake trout population to pre-1999 abundance (about 1,800) for fish over 406 mm to minimize predation and competition risks to bull trout and westslope cutthroat trout.
577.assumptions: Commercial netting is a cost effective means to reduce Lake Trout densities over the long term.

580.background: Lake trout were stocked in numerous lakes throughout western North America during the late 1800s and early 1900s (Crossman 1995), including Lake Pend Oreille in 1925. Lake trout present a threat to native salmonids, including kokanee and bull trout. Bull trout are particularly susceptible to negative interactions with lake trout, and bull trout populations cannot be sustained after lake trout introduction (Donald and Alger 1993; Fredenberg 2002) without human intervention. Lake trout predation resulted in drastic decreases in the kokanee population in Lake Pend Oreille since 2000 (Maiolie et al. 2002; Maiolie et al. 2006). Declines in kokanee abundance is especially concerning as they are the main prey source for ESA-listed bull trout. In 2000, IDFG removed all bag limits on lake trout and implemented an Angler Incentive Program (AIP), which pays anglers to harvest lake trout. To further reduce lake trout abundance, IDFG has contracted with Hickey Brothers Research, LLC (Bailey’s Harbor, Wisconsin) since 2006 to fish gill and trap nets in Lake Pend Oreille. As the population decreases through overharvest, we evaluate the response by tracking growth rates, fecundity, catch rates, and size structure.

581.background: We use telemetry to determine lake trout distribution during spawning in Lake Pend Oreille (LPO). Acoustic transmitters are implanted in about 30 mature lake trout each year. Transmitters have depth and temperature sensors and an 18-month battery life. Mobile tracking is performed several times throughout the year outside of spawning, but occurs weekly during spawning. Locations where lake trout aggregate are identified and this information is used to guide gill netting efforts each week during spawning. Arrival and departure of fish at spawning sites is used to time netting operations at these sites. Previous telemetry work identified three spawning sites in the lake and it is likely that the same sites will continue to be used. However, it is possible that fish could change their behavior in response to netting and we need to assure that new spawning sites are not established. Further, each site spans several miles of shoreline and telemetry has proven useful for determining fine-scale distribution patterns (localized aggregations and depth) at each site that can be used to more effectively target fish with gill nets.
objectives: Identify areas of high concentration of lake trout at each spawning site, and use this information to guide the placement of gill nets.
581.assumptions: Acoustic tagged Lake Trout behave in a manner representative of the Lake Trout population.

583.background: The completion of Grand Coulee Dam in 1941 altered the natural ecology of the upper Columbia River by blocking waters historically used for reproduction and rearing by anadromous fish. Consequently, the Lake Roosevelt Artificial Production Program (LRAPP), formed in 1988, began stocking Rainbow Trout and kokanee as partial mitigation for the loss of anadromous fishes. The LRAPP includes the Spokane Tribal Hatchery, Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife’s Sherman Creek Hatchery, and the Lake Roosevelt Volunteer Net Pen Project, and has reestablished a recreational and subsistence mitigation fishery. The Lake Roosevelt Fisheries Evaluation Program (LRFEP) is a multi-agency collaborative comprised of the Spokane Tribe of Indians, Colville Confederated Tribes, and Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife. The primary focus of the LRFEP is to evaluate the performance of fishes stocked by the LRAPP. Additional goals of the LRFEP include assessing the impacts of stocked hatchery fish on resident fish populations, standardized reservoir-wide annual fisheries sampling in continuation of long-term monitoring efforts, and characterization of the impacts of hydro-operations on the fishery and lower trophic levels.
objectives: Collection of morphometric indices, calculation of catch-per-unit-effort and condition, and assessment of species diversity through boat electrofishing, fyke net, gill net, and beach seine surveys
Evaluate ecological impacts, size and age structure, predator/prey relationships, and diet of target fish species (e. g. native, introduced piscivorours, hatchery-stocked, etc.) in Lake Roosevelt.
Compare and contrast current and historical data to investigate changes in fish populations relative to hydro-project operations (e.g. maximum reservoir draw down, water retention time).
583.assumptions: 1) The number of fish captured is proportional to the population abundance. 2) Catchability is constant throughout the sampling period. 3) Every individual within a stock has the same probability of being captured. 4) Gear is properly calibrated and functionally properly. 5) Age composition of samples is representative of the age composition of the population.

584.background: Gill and trap nets are set in Lake Pend Oreille (LPO), Idaho in an effort to reduce lake trout abundance. In addition, ESA listed adfluvial bull trout are incidentally captured during these gill netting efforts, including some mortalities, and we are interested in the origin of these bull trout. A genetic data baseline was already available for assigning bull trout captured below Cabinet Gorge Dam to populations in upstream tributaries in the drainage or tributaries to Lake Pend Oreille (Bernall 2007). These data increase our understanding of bull trout behavior and life history characteristics in the drainage. In addition, we are able to use these data to determine whether netting in certain areas has a disproportionate effect on bull trout stocks of particular concern. Additionally, we evaluate how effectively the gill nets are capturing lake trout and avoiding bull trout. These analyses allow us to make changes to the nets (e.g., mesh size) to most effectively remove lake trout and reduce incidental catch of bull trout.
objectives: Assess whether contract netting efforts are having disproportionate effects on stocks of bull trout that are of particular concern.
Analyze the effectiveness of gill net characteristics (e.g., mesh size) in catching lake trout and avoiding bull trout.
584.assumptions: The overall Bull Trout population will benefit from Lake Trout removal, even though direct Buill Trout mortality as bycatch from the commercial netting occurs at variable rates.

586.background:
Lake Pend Oreille once provided the largest kokanee fishery in the state of Idaho. Between 1952 and 1966, harvests of kokanee averaged 1 million kokanee/yr with up to 523,000 angler-hours of fishing pressure (Jeppson 1953; Maiolie and Elam 1993). Additionally, kokanee are the forage base that allows Gerrard rainbow trout in Lake Pend Oreille reach trophy sizes, including the former world record. However, kokanee abundance declined, and in the early 2000s they were at risk of complete collapse (Hansen et al. 2010). High predation rates created by a rapidly expanding lake trout was the primary limiting factor for kokanee, but as a part of kokanee recovery, rainbow trout harvest was also liberalized during 2006-2012.

Kokanee have since rebounded in Lake Pend Oreille, and restrictive harvest regulations have been instituted for rainbow trout that are designed to improve population size structure and re-build the trophy fishery. With restrictive regulations again in place and a resurgent kokanee population, we sample rainbow trout to characterize age and growth rates for this population. Anglers are the most effective tool for capturing rainbows, so we coordinate sampling with fishing derbies. Samples are collected across all sizes of fish in the population. Results are compared to previous work in recent years to evaluate the response of rainbow trout to these changes.
objectives: Calculate rainbow trout growth rate
Calculate rainbow trout condition factor
586.assumptions: Rainbow trout sampled are representative of the entire population.

592.background: Shoreline spawning habitat is monitored to assess the influence of winter lake elevation on quality of spawning habitat. Additionally, new operations at Albeni Falls Dam (e.g., winter lake level fluctuations) have been proposed and have potential to impact spawning habitat. Therefore, we monitor habitat conditions at standardized shoreline sites to better understand the effects of winter dam operations on shoreline spawning habitat.
objectives: Evaluate how kokanee spawning substrate changes with respect to winter lake level management.

596.background:
Lake Pend Oreille once provided the largest kokanee fishery in the state of Idaho. Between 1952 and 1966, harvests of kokanee averaged 1 million kokanee/yr with up to 523,000 angler-hours of fishing pressure (Jeppson 1953; Maiolie and Elam 1993). Kokanee harvest dramatically declined after 1966, and by 1985 the annual harvest was only 71,200 kokanee with 179,000 angler hours (Bowles et al. 1987; Maiolie and Elam 1993). The extent and timing of winter lake drawdowns has been implicated as most detrimental effect on the population (Maiolie and Elam 1993), but by the early 2000s, high predation levels created by a rapidly expanding lake trout was the primary limiting factor for kokanee.

Several recovery strategies are currently in place, including a lake trout reduction program, and we survey the kokanee population annually to evaluate the effectiveness of recovery actions. Estimates of kokanee abundance are completed using hydroacoustic sampling during late August and follow a stratified sampling design of zigzag transects, with 21 total transects sampled.  A Simrad EK60 echosounder and 120 kHz split-beam transducer are used to conduct the mobile hydroacoustic survey; data are analyzed using echo integration techniques with Echoview software. Midwater trawl surveys are also conducted during the dark phase of the moon in August to collect physical kokanee samples. These samples are used to partition the hydroacoustic kokanee estimates into age classes and to obtain length and weight data. By combining data from the hydroacoustic and trawl surveys, we will calculate age class abundance, age-specific survival, biomass, production, and mortality by weight.
objectives: Estimate the proportion of hatchery and wild kokanee in each age class.
Estimate kokanee biomass, production, and mortality by weight.
Estimate kokanee age-specific abundance.
Estimate kokanee age-specific survival.

603.background: This will be done to evaluate incubation success to the pre-emergent stage and help assess the kokanee spawning habitat. Eggs will incubate over the winter and evaluation will occur during the following spring. Upon completion, data collected at the incubation site will be compared to incubation success rates from other locations in the lake that were determined during previous studies. This direct measure of kokanee egg to pre-emergent fry survival is one aspect of determining the quality of spawning habitat.
objectives: Use direct measures to better understand kokanee egg incubation and egg-to-fry survival.
603.assumptions: This research assumes that the conditions encountered by eggs burried in Whitlock-Vibert boxes by divers are equivalent to conditions encountered by eggs naturally deposited into the substrate by kokanee.

604.background: Mysids were introduced to Lake Pend Oreille in 1966 to improve kokanee growth rates, but mysids did not benefit kokanee. Competitive interactions with mysids were a concern following their establishment (Rieman and Falter 1981), but subsequent research suggested that competition with mysids did not limit the kokanee population (Maiolie and Elam 1993; Clarke and Bennett 2002a; Clarke and Bennett 2002b; Maiolie et al. 2002). However, competition may become limiting as kokanee abundance increases towards recovery goals (Maiolie et al. 2002). In contrast to other research, one study suggested that delayed onset of cladocerans following mysid introduction reduced survival of hatchery kokanee fry (Paragamian and Bowles 1995). A different mechanism by which mysids may (at some threshold level) limit kokanee abundance is altered nutrient dynamics (Chipps and Bennett 2000; Wilhelm and Caldwell 2011). Similarly, changes in lake productivity are not fully understood and may influence kokanee recovery. We have used a standardized approach to monitor mysid abundance since 1995 with historic trend data back to 1973. We plan to continue to evaluate mysid abundance given their potential to affect kokanee recovery.
objectives: Estimate mysid densities.

613.background: An overall goal of the Dworshak Reservoir nutrient restoration project is to improve the efficiency of the foodweb, thereby increasing the size and abundance of kokanee in the reservoir to benefit the sport fishery and other resident fishes. In order to assess the effects of nutrient restoration on the kokanee population, we examine a variety of metrics on an annual basis. We assess kokanee size, age structure and reproductive development using biological data obtained from mid-water trawl surveys conducted in July. Furthermore, we estimate age-specific abundance, survival rates, biomass, production and total mortality by weight. We will evaluate kokanee growth either through length back-calculations from scale analysis, additional trawl surveys conducted in the spring and fall, or a combination of the two. Each fall, we collect pre-spawn kokanee from index streams to evaluate size and fecundity. We conduct visual spawner counts for four index streams within three days of the historical peak of spawning activity.
objectives: Estimate kokanee biomass, production and mortality by weight.
Estimate kokanee age-specific survival.
Estimate kokanee age-specific abundance.
Estimate age specific mean length, weight and relative weight.

617.background: We use midwater trawling catch to estimate age-specific and mature proportions of kokanee in Lake Pend Oreille (LPO). These proportions are then applied to the hydroacoustic estimate of non-fry kokanee. However, large kokanee may be able to avoid our midwater trawl net, thus skewing our estimates. For this study, we will be comparing the size-specific catch rates of kokanee in our standard gear to that using suspended gill nets. The gill nets will provide an estimate of the "true" size distribution of kokanee available due to the relative ease of quantifying their size-selectivity (Hamley 1975). From these collections, we will attempt to build a model that predicts capture efficiency at a range of kokanee sizes and densities.
objectives: Create a correction factor for kokanee abundance for our standard midwater trawling gear.

618.background: Our goal is to more clearly understand factors that influence kokanee survival at early life-stages in Lake Pend Oreille (LPO). Specifically, we will focus on diet and growth of kokanee fry, both of hatchery and wild origin. We have not solidified the exact study design, but the methods will be similar to Clarke and Bennett (2002). We will compare the results of this work to the results of another study aimed at evaluating the spatial and temporal distribution and density of mysids and zooplankton.
objectives: Evaluate kokanee fry growth throughout the growing season.
618.assumptions: We can effectively preserve stomachs contents from age 0 kokanee.  Also, the food items identified in kokanee stomachs are representative of what kokanee actually eat and we are able to evaluate how kokanee diet changes temporally and seasonally.

623.background: The construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939 blocked migration routes for anadromous life histories of aquatic species- fragmenting populations and habitats in the upper Columbia River basin. Identification of habitat parameters that limit wild Redband Trout populations and their life history strategies have not been completed for many tributaries within the Spokane and upper Columbia subbasins. This protocol evaluates spawning and rearing habitats of Redband Trout in these watersheds. Habitat assessments will allow managers to better understand Redband Trout population characteristics and life histories, as well as identify habitat factors limiting populations.  Information generated from this assessment will then be used to identify and prioritize habitats in need of restoration to protect and restore Redband Trout populations. Methodologies used will be dependent on the limitations of data that can be collected within specific watersheds.
objectives: Identify habitat parameters that limit Redband Trout population characteristics.
Conduct habitat surveys in streams that contain Redband Trout populations.
623.assumptions: Redband trout are spawning in tributaries along the lower Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River. Redband trout are living a portion of their lives in the tributaries. Habitat parameters influence redband trout populations.

633.background: Fall walleye index netting (FWIN) is a multi-agency collaborative effort between the Spokane Tribe of Indians, Colville Confederated Tribes, and the Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife. The standardized FWIN protocol was originally developed for lakes and rivers in Quebec by Morgan (2002) and was modified for use in Washington lakes and was initatied in 2002. In 2013 site selection was changed to a Generalized Random Tessellation Stratified (GRTS) sampling. FWIN is conducted during the first week of November when water temperatures have cooled to 10 - 15 °C.  During this time walleye are evenly dispersed throughout the reservoir enabling researchers to collect a representative sample of the population. Experimental gill nets are set at randomly selected locations (GRTS) throughout the reservoir to collect walleye and burbot. Sampling gear consisted of 1.8 m (6 ft) by 61 m (200 ft) monofilament gillnets containing eight sections of increasing mesh sizes (25, 38, 51, 64, 76, 102, 127, and 152 mm).  FWIN is used by mangers to assess and monitor changes in relative abundance, population structure, health, condition, and sex and sexual maturity of the walleye and burbot populations in Lake Roosevelt.
objectives: Assess and monitor the long-term abundance, population structure, and health of the walleye and burbot populations in Lake Roosevelt.
633.assumptions: This sample is representation of the Walleye population in Lake Roosevelt. Walleye are evenly distributed during period of sampling.

654.background: Nespelem Creek on the Colville Reservation are regularly planted with fish from the Colville Tribal Hatchery. The Hatchery Program has instituted a program of surveying Nespelem Creek 30 and 60 days after stocking. This is done to prevent any introgression of any native stocks that may be present and to stock in the most efficient manner. This program has been effective in increasing the efficiency of the Hatchery Program.

Determine catch rates of anglers in stocked waters.
The goal of our stream stocking is to increase numbers of catchable size rainbow trout for angler harvest up to 30 days post-stocking.

685.background:
Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT; Lestelle et al. 1996) is a comprehensive model of habitat condition that uses theoretical habitat capacity and  productivity as currency to allow comparisons of historic, current and potential restored habitat condition. EDT modeling is a resource that LRHIP is using to aid development of a detailed and spatially explicit plan for future habitat project implementation. 
 

Initially, we will evaluate the EDT model output in terms of potential improvement in fish performance. Further analysis will be conducted across geographic areas (assessment units) within each watershed where an assessment unit is made up of several reaches within which the performance of each species is summarized. This assessment unit comparison will identify the relative importance of each area for either restoration or protection actions and help us to focus our restoration and protection actions in areas that are more likely to have higher benefits to our focal species.

Finally, we will evaluate conditions within individual stream reaches and identify the most important factors contributing to a loss in performance at specific life stages within to each reach. This “Stream Reach Analysis”, will identify the survival factors (classes of Level 2 environmental attributes; Lestelle 2005) that, if restored would produce the most significant improvements in overall fish population performance. This more detailed evaluation will allow us to link the EDT output to our monitoring variables and then crosswalk with the kinds of restoration actions that will address the degraded conditions.

Data sources used to assign EDT Level II attributes include:

  • physical habitat data collected by CCT following the Oregon Plan (Protocol ID: 1982);
  • fish distribution data collected by CCT and Tetra Tech  following Protocol ID: 1980;
  • discharge data was available from USGS stream gages and collected at point locations by CCT subcontractor Tetra Tech following CHaMP methods (Protocol ID: 2102);
  • macroinvertebrate drift data collected by CCT subcontractor Tetra Tech following CHaMP methods (Protocol ID: 2100)
  • water quality data collected by CCT subcontractor Tetra Tech following CHaMP methods (Protocol ID: 2101); and
  • continuous temperature data was collected by CCT (Protocol ID: 518).
objectives: Model current habitat condition, habitat capacity, and potential fish production in Sanpoil and Upper Columbia Subbasin streams in reference to historical and potential restored habitat conditions.
685.assumptions:
Attributes of template (historic) habitat conditions are accurate.

Attributes of current habitat conditions are accurate.

All measurable environmental conditions that effect habitat productivity and potentia are included in the EDT model.

687.background:
Continuation of ISCO sediment sampling which started approximately 7 years ago. Columbia Conservation District contracts with USDA Forest Service. Measure impacts to spawning gravels. Monitor sediment delivery to the Tucannon River. Monitor trend based on project impacts.

This is a continuation of work from previous BPA contracts with CTUIR Habitat Enhancement Project (1987-100-01). This work was moved from the habitat project to the this project (1990-005-01) project for FY 2016 at the request of BPA staff: Peter Lofy, Russell Scranton, and Deborah Docherty. This work element is a 1/3 cost-share with EPA and the Umatilla Basin Watershed Council. We subcontract to USDA Forest Service Water Quality Laboratory to analyze samples from an automated water quality monitoring sampler (ISCO) near the mouth of Meacham Creek. Water samples are analyzed for turbidity, total suspended solids (TSS), total dissolved solids, and specific conductivity. Data is entered into the CTUIR water quality data base (via separate funding). About 1600 samples are processed yearly. Analyzed data measures changes in suspended solids and turbidity from watershed activities over time. Deliverable Specification: Cost-share with the Umatilla Basin Watershed Council and the EPA for the laboratory analysis of water samples for turbidity, total suspended solids, total dissolved solids, and specific conductivity. Sampling procedures and water quality analysis will conform to the stipulations included in the latest edition of EPA¶s Water Quality Criteria (1986) and A Guide to the Sampling and Analysis of Water and Wastewater (1987). All approved data is then uploaded to the CTUIR water quality data base semi-annually.
objectives: Determine project effectiveness in addressing and reducing sediment loading in spawning gravels.
687.assumptions: Changes in farming practices should reduce the sediment input in the Tucannon River within Columbia County. The monitoring is attempting to track any noticable trends in sediment entering the streams.

693.background:
Lake Roosevelt is one of 11 lakes and reservoirs within the Columbia River drainage in Washington State that supports a Burbot population. Standardized stock assessment data is needed to facilitate management of the Lake Roosevelt Burbot population. In the absence of standardized stock assessment data, Burbot populations in Washington State, including Lake Roosevelt, have been managed conservatively. A suspected increase in abundance and high survival suggests that the population could potentially support greater harvest, although this needs confirmation.

For the 2011 Resident Fish Categorical Review, the Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) submitted a proposal to develop a standardized stock assessment program for Burbot in Lake Roosevelt. The objective was to facilitate management of the Burbot population to provide for sustainable harvest through the development of a status and trends monitoring program. Because burbot are commonly observed in the bycatch of annual Lake Roosevelt Fall Walleye Index Netting (FWIN) surveys, the Independent Scientific Review Panel (ISRP) and Northwest Power and Conservation Council (NPCC) recommended that the CCT first evaluate the potential for using FWIN as the basis for Burbot stock assessment in Lake Roosevelt. Accordingly, in 2013 the CCT hired a subcontractor to analyze ten years of FWIN data (2003-2012) and assess its adequacy for Burbot stock assessment. The overarching conclusion of the analysis was that the FWIN program is adequate for monitoring year-to-year differences in Lake Roosevelt Burbot population indices.

Despite the demonstrated utility of FWIN as a tool for Lake Roosevelt Burbot stock assessment, there is a need to evaluate the size selectivity of the gill net gear. Gill net size selectivity can be estimated indirectly by fishing multiple mesh gill nets with equal effort and comparing catch frequencies within each of the mesh sizes. We propose to use a maximum-likelihood approach to estimate parameters of log-linear selectivity models (Normal location, Normal scale, Gamma, Lognormal, and Bi-normal), also known as the SELECT method (Share Each Length’s Catch Total), and correct the length data prior to the calculation of length-based stock assessment indices.

Age bias resulting from gill net selectivity can be corrected by applying the proportion of fish of each age within each length bin to the bias-corrected length data. To increase sample sizes of small (young) and large (old) Burbot, supplemental sampling with alternative gears can be conducted. We will conduct supplemental sampling concurrent with FWIN using towed bottom trawls (to capture small fish), modified cod traps (large fish), and trammel nets (large fish) – all of which have been used to sample Burbot populations.

Protocol 2170 "Lake Roosevelt Burbot - FWIN Data Analysis" addresses the work element 162: https://www.cbfish.org/WorkStatementElement.mvc/Summary/97551  that "continue to monitor status and trends in relative abundance, mortality, size and age structure, condition growth, and recruitment."
objectives: Collect Burbot using trammel nets and modified cod traps to evaluate length and age bias in Fall Walleye Index Netting Burbot catch.
693.assumptions: Our sample will be representative of the entire population.

695.background: High summer water temperature limits steelhead production in many reaches of the Columbia River tributaries.  We monitor water temperature using dataloggers to identify the lower bounds of steelhead rearing habitat.  Stream flow is also a primary limiting factor for steelhead production.   Stream discharge measurements are collected for managing instream flows, stream gaging, and planning and implementing restoration projects. Temperature information is often requested by restoration contractors for design of stream restoration projects, for drafting reach assessments, and it is requested by other agencies and programs.
objectives: Our objective is to produce a water temperature and stream discharge record to evaluate salmonid spawning and rearing habitat.
Our objective is to collect stream discharge and water temperature information to manage stream flows for salmonids and design effective stream restoration projects.
695.assumptions: Water temperature and stream discharge are important limiting factors for steelhead population growth.

701.background:
Duck Valley Fisheries O&M operates a tribal and non-tribal fishery on three reservoirs located within the boundary of Duck Valley Indian Reservation. Tribal members use the reservoirs for substance fishing to offset the loss of anadromous fish. Non-tribal members pay a fee to fish. The revenue from non-tribal member fees are put into the tribal general fund and used to help the Shoshone-Paiute Fish, Wildlife and parks Department as well as other Tribal agencies.

The fisheries in the three Duck Valley Reservation reservoirs are put-and-take-fisheries. As a put and take fisheries it is important to understand the exploitation rate in order to make sound management decisions. The creel surveys will be used to estimate the satisfaction and exploitation rates by tribal and non-tribal anglers.

The non tribal angler fees add income to the economy of Duck Valley Indian Reservation. The campgrounds are used by tribal members for a variety of personal and community functions. These two reasons make it important to understand how satisfied the anglers are with the facilities around the reservoirs. The creel surveys will give DV Fisheries Managers information on improvements that may need to be completed at the campgrounds at the reservoirs.
objectives:
Estimate satisfaction of the tribal and non-tribal anglers
Estimate the exploitation rate of the reservoirs.
Bring attention to any problems with our facilities
701.assumptions: The first Key assumption is that people being surveyed are giving honest answers to the number of fish caught, kept, or released. The second assumption is closely related to the first. That people are being honest and fair about their experience and the facilities. The third assumption is the anglers being surveyed are a random sample.

705.background: The required transition to local steelhead broodstock at Winthrop National Fish Hatchery requires hatchery reform actions that i) can accommodate a later return and spawn timing, ii) induce proper smoltification, iii) promote high survival, and iv) maintain natural levels of fitness in the hatchery stock. The later spawn timing and cold hatchery culture temperatures at Winthrop National Fish Hatchery preclude raising a yearling smolt from locally collected broodstock. Steelhead in Pacific Northwest hatcheries are typically reared for release as 1-year-old smolts, rather than the 2¬and 3-year-old smolt life history patterns found in nature. High growth rates associated with accelerated hatchery rearing to a 1-year-old smolt life history may contribute to maladaptive behavioral traits and reduced post-release survival, and may constitute a primary mechanism leading to reduced fitness in hatchery fish. Rearing steelhead to smoltification at age 2 may increase survival and alleviate fitness loss. To do so, we will evaluate genetic, physiological, and life history impacts of rearing 1- vs 2-year-old steelhead smolts.
objectives: Measure growth and compare size frequency distributions of 1- and 2-year old steelhead smolts released from Winthrop National Fish Hatchery.
Assess indicators of smoltification and precocious male maturation in 1- and 2-year old steelhead smolts released from Winthrop National Fish Hatchery.
Determine whether outmigration and residualism are gender-biased in 1- and 2-year old steelhead smolts released from Winthrop National Fish Hatchery.
Estimate survival and migratory behavior of 1- and 2-year old steelhead smolts released from Winthrop National Fish Hatchery.
705.assumptions:
The Wells hatchery and Methow River broodstocks used to produce yearling and two-year old smolts are part of the same population. Any differences in the growth, survival, and behavior of the 1- and 2-year old steelhead smolts is due to rearing conditions in the hatchery.

Detection rates at PIT tag interrogators in the Columbia River Basin are equal for 1- and 2-year old steelhead smolts.

Recapture efficiencies are equal for 1- and 2-year old steelhead smolts.

metrics.title: Measure growth rates of 1- and 2-year steelhead smolts at WNFH
Determine relative proportions of 1- and 2-year steelhead smolts
Survival of 1- and 2-year steelhead through mainstem Columbia

707.background: The required transition to local steelhead broodstock at Winthrop National Fish Hatchery requires hatchery reform actions that i) can accommodate a later return and spawn timing, ii) induce proper smoltification, iii) promote high survival, and iv) maintain natural levels of fitness in the hatchery stock. The later spawn timing and cold hatchery culture temperatures preclude raising a yearling smolt from locally collected broodstock. Steelhead in Pacific Northwest hatcheries are typically reared for release as 1-year-old smolts, rather than the 2¬and 3-year-old smolt life history patterns found in nature. High growth rates associated with accelerated hatchery rearing to a 1-year-old smolt life history may contribute to maladaptive behavioral traits and reduced post-release survival, and may constitute a primary mechanism leading to reduced fitness in hatchery fish. Rearing steelhead to smoltification at age 2 may increase survival and alleviate fitness loss. To do so, we will evaluate genetic, physiological, behavioral and life history impacts of rearing 1- vs 2-year-old steelhead smolts.  In our laboratory scale research we are comparing 1- and 2-year steelhead smolts sourced from a common broodstock consisting of steelhead returning to the Methow River.  The broodstock is a combination of returning hatchery fish and wild fish.
objectives: Monitor seawater growth and maturation of 1- and 2-year old hatchery steelhead.
Assess smoltification of 1-and 2-year old hatchery steelhead with seawater challenge and swimming assay.
Measure behavior of steelhead parr under 1- and 2-year old rearing strategies.
Measure in-culture growth, survival, smoltification, and maturation of hatchery steelhead under 1- and 2-year rearing strategies.
707.assumptions: The broodstock used to produce yearling and two-year old smolts are from a common genetic population. Any differences in the growth, survival, and behavior of the 1- and 2-year old steelhead smolts is due to rearing conditions in the laboratory/hatchery.  One- and two-year smolts experience a common rearing environment with the exception of ration and duration of rearing.  Responses measured in the laboratory populations of steelhead are equivalent and scalable to the hatchery populations of steelhead.

757.background:
Steelhead were listed as threatened in the MId-Columbia Distinct Population Segment (DPS) in 1999 (reaffirmed in 2006 and 2016), and includes populations in the John Day, Deschutes, Umatilla and Walla Walla River basins. The Snake River Steelhead DPS was listed as threatened in 1997 (reaffirmed in 2017), and includes populations in the Grande Ronde River, Joseph Creek, Wallowa River and Imnaha River basisns (U.S. Office of the Federal Register 2006).  De-listing of these threatened steelhead populations depends on increasing and maintaining spawner abundance at or above determined abundance and productivity threshholds (McElhany et al. 2000; Gallagher et al. 2010). Thus obtaining accurate and precise estimates of spawner abundance has become increasingly important.

To meet scientific review recommendations, we extended the structure and methods successfully employed by the Oregon Plan for Salmon and Watersheds Monitoring Program to NE Oregon steelhead populations (Stevens 2002). This approach incorporates the sampling strategy of a general random-tessellation stratified (GRTS) algorithm (Stevens and Olsen 2004) and spatially explicit, probabilistic sampling design developed by Stevens et al. for the EMAP program. The GRTS approach applies a rigorous statitical site selection sampling design and analysis structure which can answer key monitoring questions, integrate on-going sampling efforts, and improve agency coordination (Stevens 2002). This approach is a sample survey, and relies on selecting part of the resource of interest, characterizing that part, and then making inferences to the entirety.

A spatially balanced sample of sites are selected from a known 'universe' of spawning distribution using the R statistical package spsurvey. Generally sites are assigned to panels, in which a subset of sites are surveyed in a rotating block, either annually, or every two or three years, depending on project needs. Sites are surveyed every 10 days for the duration of the spawning season, and data is collected about number of redds and any live or dead fish encountered.  After surveys are complete, spawnder abundance is calculted by estimating spawner density per site by multiplying a fish/redd ratio from Deer Creek (a tributary to the Wallowa River) by redd density. From the fish density per site data, spawner abundance and 95% confidence intervals (from a nearest neighbor liklihood estimator) are calculated using the R statistical package spsurvey.

ODFW conducted annual GRTS-based spawning surveys of summer steelhead in the John Day River basin from 2004-2012 (Wiley et al. 2005). GRTS based spawning ground surveys were conducted from 2008-2018 in the Upper Grande Ronde River, from 2012-2017 in Joseph Creek and from 2012-2018 in the upper Umatilla River watershed. GRTS spawning ground surveys continue in the South Fork and MIddle Fork John Day Rivers.
objectives: Estimate the population-scale escapement of summer steelhead
Estimate the distribution of summer steelhead redds and spawners across watersheds.
Enumerate redds at each selected site
757.assumptions:
The sample universe conservatively represents the spatial extent utilized by spawning adult steelhead.

Redds are counted with minimal error (no double, over-, or under counting errors)

Redd numbers reflect population status.

Sampled sites represent like unsampled sites.

766.background: The Hood River Production Program was founded in 1991 to reintroduce spring Chinook and supplement winter and summer steelhead to recover depleted stocks. One of the first projects ODFW and CTWS embarked upon in the early 1990’s were fish surveys of the Hood River and its major tributaries to determine a fish community assemblage and gather baseline data on rearing densities of salmonids in the Hood River basin. Methods employed were generally electrofishing depletion techniques. Since these initial surveys the HRPP has been supplementing populations of winter steelhead, summer steelhead, and spring Chinook for nearly 20 years and over several complete generations of adult returns. Various monitoring efforts (spawning surveys, smolt trapping, fish salvage, snorkeling, radio telemetry) conducted by CTWS and ODFW during the proceeding years have observed salmon and steelhead presence in many areas considered unoccupied prior to the inception of the HRPP. However no deliberate and systematic effort has been made to map the distribution of these reintroduced, supplemented, and hopefully expanding populations since the initial surveys at the beginning of the Hood River M&E program. We believe it is time to reinvestigate and potentially redraw the map of salmon and steelhead distribution in the Hood River basin.
objectives: Determine distribution of juvenile anadromous salmonids through the Hood River basin.
Determine fish community composition in Hood River basin streams

778.background: The Wind River has a TMDL for temperature, a limiting factor for steelhead spawning, rearing, and migration. To help assess changes in this parameter, continuous temperature monitoring is essential. UCD will work with partnering agencies to continue to monitor temperature throughout the watershed, utilizing UCD's standard operating procedures and water quality database. UCD supports operation and maintenance of 7 thermographs in the Wind River watershed. USGS has managed an additional 11 sites as well, and both agencies coordinate placement of thermographs to best capture watershed conditions while avoiding duplication. Data from this effort will inform and guide habitat restoration work.

By placing thermographs throughout a river system, it allows

787.background: Recent publication suggest that domestication may cause a tradeoff such that families that perform well in the hatchery (produced many surviving adult offspring), produce offspring that have lowered reproductive success in the wild (Christie et al., 2012; Ford et al., 2012). Circumstantial evidence in Christie et al. (2012) suggest that crowding enhances the rate of domestication, and therefore that fish may be adapting to high crowding levels. If true, one prediction is that the rank performance of families (growth rate) depends on the density at which they were raised (i.e families that do best at low density do worst at high, and vice versa).
objectives: Test for presence of significant family by environment (crowding level) interaction in fish raised in a hatchery
787.assumptions: Juvenile growth rate is assumed to be a component of total fitness because size at release is correlated with subsequent survival.

metrics.title: family by environment interaction in growth

791.background: The goal of this project is to determine the abundance and current productivity of the Asotin Creek steelhead population and to estimate life stage survival rates in the mainstem Asotin Creek. Under the ESA, the TRT, the Snake River Salmon Recovery Plan (SRSRB 2007) and NOAA Fisheries included George Creek and several other small adjacent Snake River tributaries (Tenmile Creek, Couse Creek, Almota and Alpowa Creek) as part of the Asotin Creek Steelhead population. As such, a full understanding of the abundance and productivity of steelhead in those tributaries is necessary to adequately understand the status of the Asotin Creek steelhead population. This project also implements the research, monitoring and evaluation (RM&E) criteria specified in the Asotin Subbasin Plan (ASP 2004), the MERR, and the Anadromous Salmonid Monitoring Strategy (ASMS 2010), by establishing a baseline of the salmonid population in Asotin Creek, upstream of the confluence with George Creek. The project provides estimates of abundance, productivity, survival rates, and additional information on temporal and spatial distribution of ESA-listed species, primarily for summer steelhead, and secondarily on spring Chinook salmon. In addition, this project will document the abundance of bull trout captured at the trapping locations. Future estimates of smolt-to-adult and adult-to-adult survival for the wild steelhead population in Asotin Creek will provide the data necessary to help determine if salmonid production in the subbasin is being limited by within- or out-of-basin factors. This protocol focuses on juvenile steelhead trapping, data collection and analysis. This protocol is closely tied with the Asotin Creek Adult Trapping and Analysis protocol(#295). For further information and detail please refer to that protocol. (Estimated cost refers to the cost of a rotary smolt trap)
objectives: Document juvenile steelhead and Chinook salmon life history patterns, survival rates, and estimate emigrant production in the Asotin Creek mainstem.
Provide an Annual Report and disseminate data from the Asotin Creek Salmon Population Assessment project

797.background: Prey quantity and quality in part determine the growth opportunity of rearing juvenile fall Chinook salmon in lower Snake River reservoir habitats. Growth opportunity in part dictates the life history pathway (i.e, ocean-type or reservoir-type) that fish will select. The food web in the lower Snake River has changed in the last 20 years. Species like Neomysis mercedis and the Siberian prawn (Exopalaemon modestus) were not present 20 years ago when Curet (1993) found that subyearling fall Chinook salmon in Lower Granite Reservoir consumed mainly aquatic insects. Today, Corophium spp., and Neomysis makes up the majority of subyearling diets at certain times in Lower Granite Reservoir (Tiffan et al. 2014). The quantity and quality (i.e., energy content) of these prey are not known. It is possible that food resources have influenced the shift in subyearling outmigration timing that has been observed in recent years.  Furthermore, work conducted under this protocol will increase our understanding of the food web that supports juvenile salmon and native fishes in the lower Snake River.
objectives: Determine the different types of prey available to juvenile fall Chinook salmon during reservoir rearing and their spatial and seasonal densities.
797.assumptions:
Collected taxa are either directly or indirectly important to the production of juvenile salmon.

Sample sites are representative of the entire reservoir.

Sampling frequency is sufficient to detect seasonal trends.

819.background: Adult summer steelhead life history information can be scarce for wild Snake River A-run fish. The existence of a weir on Lookingglass Creek allows for collection of adult summer steelhead escapement and life history information.  Data collected from the Lookingglass weir is compared with data from Catherine Creek weir and the Upper Grande Ronde weir (operated by CTUIR Artificial Production). Data collected by CTUIR are shared with cooperator and funding agencies so that it can be used in recovery planning in the Grande Ronde Basin.
objectives: Describe wild adult summer steelhead life history and abundance for Lookingglass Creek.
819.assumptions: The adult trap is effective in capturing a large (>90%) portion of the run going above Lookingglass weir and the sample provides unbiased estimates of escapement and life history metrics.

820.background: Volitional release is advocated as part of a natural rearing strategy for spring Chinook salmon and other anadromous species. We describe and compare the short-term benefits (survival to Lower Granite Dam), if any, and differences in arrival timing at Lower Granite Dam between volitional release and forceout. We also describe differences in travel time to Lower Granite Dam.
objectives: Describe and compare differences in survival, arrival timing, and travel time for hatchery-origin spring Chinook salmon reared at Catherine Creek and Upper Grande Ronde River acclimation facilities.
820.assumptions: PIT tag readers detect representative numbers of each release group.

1853.background: Stream flow (discharge) monitoring provides critical information for restoration efforts. Knowing how much water is in a stream is extremely important for fish restoration. Many communities rely upon stream water for irrigating their crops and livestock. By having a robust stream flow monitoring program information is collected to inform water management, restoration and other decisions.
objectives: Provide stream flow information to partners for use in decision making.
Quantify stream flow, especially with the use of data loggers for analysis of stream trends and status.
1853.assumptions: 1 - Cross-sectional measurements are an accurate estimate of actual stream discharge. 2 - Equipment is calibrated to manufacturer's specifications.

1854.background: Stream water temperatures have a direct impact on fish populations. High water temperatures can cause fish to be stressed or even kill fish if they get high enough. Monitoring stream water temperatures provides data to inform restoration priorities and projects, determine if fish are being stressed and help determine if there are thermal barriers to fish migration.
objectives: Monitor surface water temperatures during the summer, fall and early winter.
1854.assumptions: 1 - Temperature recorded by the data logger is representative of the water in that reach of the stream. 2 - Temperature data loggers have been compared to a NIST thermometer. 3 - Temperature measurements are taken every 30 minutes therefore short temperature spikes may not be captured.

1868.background:
This protocol is in proposed status and is still actively being modified to address comments.

This document details the monitoring design, procedures, and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of Acquisition Projects at the project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s (BPA) programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: A programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program. This is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB) protocol, Monitoring Effectiveness of Habitat Protection Projects; (ID: 31) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/31), and the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID: 18) (https://www.monitoringresources.org/ Resources/Program/Detail/18); however, variations in the monitoring design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.

There are two scales for assessing the effectiveness of habitat acquisitions - the parcel scale and the watershed scale. Monitoring at the parcel scale determines whether the desirable attributes of the property, in terms of habitat and fish populations, have continued at original levels or improved over time. This is purely a local evaluation and is blind to the overall watershed needs and existing conditions.  It only answers the questions: 

  • What is the status of the habitat and fish on acquired lands?
  • Is it improving, remaining the same, or declining?

The assumption behind this form of effectiveness monitoring is that acquired habitat that remains unchanged or is improving reflects an effective acquisition. If the habitat is declining, the causes may or may not be directly attributable to changes occurring on the sampled land parcel. For example, there could be activities occurring upstream that affect instream morphology or stream bank structure within the acquisition boundaries. The watershed scale is more complex but also more directly answers the questions of interest.  However, this document does not address those larger questions, such as:

  • How do acquisitions fit into the overall critical habitat protection needs identified for each watershed?
  • Have acquisitions been effective in addressing watershed habitat protection goals?

The assumption behind these questions is that we know what needs to occur in a watershed in terms of restoring habitat, providing refuges, and halting habitat destruction.Furthermore, these questions also assume that the needs have been prioritized and have broad support.

This Protocol for Monitoring Effectiveness of Habitat Protection Projects addresses only the characteristics of the parcels as separate and independent entities (parcel scale). It does not attempt to answer land protection effectiveness monitoring questions at watershed or regional scale. Questions to be answered:

  • Have the protected properties maintained or improved the riparian habitat benefits for which they were purchased?
  • Have the protected properties maintained or improved the upland habitat benefits for which they were purchased?
  • Has the biological condition of the macroinvertebrate and fish species assemblages improved, declined or stayed the same within the protected properties?
objectives: Determine the biological condition of macroinvertebrate and fish species assemblages using a multi-metric index for each randomly selected parcel (Years 1 3, 6, 9, and 12)
Determine status and trends of instream, riparian, and upland habitat within each randomly selected parcel (Years 1 3, 6, 9, and 12)
1868.assumptions: Access to survey reach will be provided for a period of at least twelve years following project implementation.

1868.title: BPA MBACI Monitoring Effectiveness of Habitat Protection Projects

1869.background: The protocol details the monitoring design, procedures and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of: Complete Fish Passage Barriers projects at the project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administrations Programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM) for Extensive Post Treatment (EPT), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: a programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program". This is based on the WA Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB) protocol SRFB - Monitoring Effectiveness of Fish Passage Projects (ID: 34) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/34) however variations in the design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.
objectives: Determine: Are the post-barrier juvenile salmon and steelhead numbers similar above and below the barrier?
Determine: Is there a relationship between the number of salmon and steelhead above the barrier relative to below and the time since barrier removal?
Determine: Is there a relationship between habitat quality (pool frequency, variation in depth, stream channel slope, instream cover, streambed substrate size) and the number of salmon and steelhead?
1869.assumptions: Access will be provided to impact and suitable control reaches.

1869.title: BPA - EPT Monitoring Effectiveness of Complete Fish Passage Barriers Projects

1870.background:
This document details the monitoring design, procedures, and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of Partial Barrier Projects at the project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s (BPA) programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: A programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program." This is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB) protocol,–“Monitoring Effectiveness of Fish Passage Projects” (ID: 34) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/DownloadDescription/34), and the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID: 18) (https://www.monitoringresources.org/ Resources/Program/Detail/18); however, variations in the monitoring design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.

Fish passage barriers, such as culverts and dams, can restrict movement of adult and juvenile fish, as well as degrade fish habitat by affecting transport of sediment, wood and other organic materials, and can restrict nutrient transport from returning spawning fish (Roni et al. 2002). It has been shown that if suitable habitat is present upstream of the barrier and/or fish have historically used upstream habitat, the likelihood of fish moving upstream and utilizing that habitat after successful barrier removal is high (SRFB 2009).  Because of this, when implemented properly, fish passage improvements are a very popular kind of habitat restoration project and have great potential to create dramatic improvements in fish production in a very short time (1-5 years) (SRFB 2009). However, detecting statistically significant increases in fish density may be difficult unless fish numbers downstream of the barrier before restoration work are sufficient for statistical tests (SRFB 2009).

This protocol details the monitoring procedures and methods necessary to document and report the reach-scale effectiveness of these projects.  Projects designed to restore fish passage that can be monitored using this protocol include actions such as bridge projects, culvert improvements, dam removals, debris removals, diversion dam passage, fishway construction, and weirs.

Questions to be answered:

  • Does the project reflect the design and requirements in the permit and/or funding application?
  • Has the engineered fish passage project continued to meet fish passage and design criteria post-project for at least five years?
  • Has the fish passage project demonstrated upstream presence of target species (by life stage) post-project within five years?
objectives: Determine whether the design and information in the permit and/or funding application for fish passage are being met post-implementation (Years 1, 2, and 5)
Determine whether adult and juvenile salmonid density both in aimpact reach upstream of the fish barrier is increasing relative to the desenties in the downstream control reach.  year -1 to 2 and 5
Determine whether fish passage design criteria are being met at each project monitored (Years 1, 2, and 5)
1870.assumptions: Access to impact and suitable control reaches will be provided prior to project implementation and for a period of five years following project completion.

1870.title: BPA – MBACI Protocol for Monitoring the Effectiveness of Partial Barrier Projects

1875.background:
Many streams in the Pacific Northwest have depleted wood volume due to past human activities such as logging in riparian areas, salvage logging of wood in streams, splash-dams, and misguided attempts to remove perceived obstructions to salmon migration.  In addition, streams have been modified and simplified due to agriculture and urban development.  This process has reduced channel complexity, isolated main stem habitats from side-channels and floodplains, reduced cover for aquatic species, and altered channel morphology.  Instream structures can be used to create pools, increase habitat complexity, reduce sediment transport, trap gravel needed for spawning, stabilize stream channels, provide food for aquatic invertebrates, and provide stream nutrients, increasing overall stream productivity (Roni and Quinn 2001). As a result, installation of instream structures, particularly placement of large woody debris (LWD), has become one of the longest used and most common techniques for improving fish habitat and mitigating human-caused degradation (Roni and Quinn 2001; Roni et. al. 2005).  Use of instream structures began as early as the 1930’s in the Midwest and has been adapted to the higher gradient systems in the Pacific Northwest (Roni et al. 2005).

The effectiveness of instream structures in enhancing habitat has been debated due to the lack of evaluation, as well as confounding results due to improper structure placement and lack of documentation of effects on factors directly limiting habitat quality (Roni et al. 2005). Calls to better evaluate habitat improvement projects began in the early 1980s (Reeves and Roelofs 1982), and continued throughout the 1990s (Reeves et al. 1991; Chapman 1996; Kauffman et al. 1997). Others have suggested the approach to restoration should shift to protecting high-quality habitats and restoring connectivity and watershed processes before implementing instream habitat improvement projects (Roni et al. 2008; Frissell and Nawa 1992), or focusing on restoring riparian forests with trees large enough to replenish LWD naturally in the system over time (Collins and Montgomery 2002). The need for additional effectiveness monitoring and evaluation is widely apparent in the Pacific Northwest.

This document details the monitoring design, procedures and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects at the Project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s Programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: a programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program". This protocol is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board  (SRFB) protocol, “SRFB - Monitoring Effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects” (ID: 35) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/35); however, variations in the design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.  This approach also draws heavily from the Scientific Protocol for Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID:806). This document details the monitoring design and procedures necessary to document and report reach scale effectiveness of projects treating:

·         Channel Reconfiguration

·         Installed Deflectors

·         Log and Rock Control weirs

·         Roughened Channels

·         Woody Debris
objectives: Bank Stability (a) -Determine if bank stability changed (amount and rate) as a result of the project (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Bank Stability (b) -Determine how bank erosion rate changed as a result of bank stabilization project (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Bank Stability (c) -Determine if percent pool tail fines changed as a result of the project (Only if change in fines is a goal) (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Vegetation Enhancement – see Riparian Planting protocol for evaluation procedures
Determine if local juvenile fish density increased as a result of the project (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10) (seasonal focus for specific project habitat outcome)
Determine if fish use differs by structure type (e.g. wood revetment, rock revetment, vegetated revetment), life stage, or species composition (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the distribution of habitat types within the reach (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if pool frequency, area and depth and pool/riffle ratio changed due to the project
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the volume of functional wood increased by Year 10 (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the amount of instream cover increased as a result of the project by Year 10 (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the complexity of the channel increased as a result of the project (only if increasing complexity is a stated goal of the project)(Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Increase Spawning Habitat - Determine if spawning habitat been enhanced. (Only if enhancing spawning habitat is a goal) (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
1875.assumptions: Access to impact and suitable control sites is provided

images.caption: Figure 01. Examples of benchmark spacing. Optimally placed benchmarks are as far apart as possible while still maintaining an equilateral triangle, are inter-visible, and extend the length of the site. Poorly placed benchmarks are close in proximity and in a non-equilateral triangle (CHaMP 2013).
Figure 02. Example of a good site overview photo.  Photo captures the stream as well as the surrounding riparian area and floodplain.

Figure 03. Example of a good repeat photo.  Photo captures both sides of the stream as well as the woody debris in the foreground.  The trees are also lined up in the exact location as the previous year’s photo.
Figure 04. The hierarchical channel unit classification adapted from CHaMP which is a modification of the system developed by Hawkins et al. (1993) as reported in Bisson et al. (2006).
Figure 05. Representation of Pool A) cross-sectional (lateral) and B) longitudinal concavity from CHaMP.
Figure 06. An example of channel unit delineations.
Figure 07. Dichotomous key of criteria adapted from CHaMP used to classify Tier I (slow-water and fast water) channel units.
Figure 08. Dichotomous key adapted from CHaMP of criteria used to classify Tier II fast water channel units.
Figure 09. Dichotomous key adapted from CHaMP of criteria used to classify Tier II slow water channel units.

Figure 10. How to number channel segments within a site. The main channel is assigned segment 1 throughout the site. Both large and small side channels are assigned sequential segment numbers working upstream. In the figure, channel segment numbers are preceded with a “S” (S1-S3) and channel unit numbers with a “U” (U1-13).
Figure 11. Representation of topographic points and descriptions used to capture the topography of the stream during surveys.
Figure 12. Channel cross-sectional view showing proper delineation of the bottom of site cross-section at transect 1.

Figure 13. Channel cross-section indicating how water surface points (ws) are used to represent A) the water surface elevation at overhanging banks and B) mid-channel water surface gradient changes (i.e., pitched riffles).
Figure 14. Channel view showing proper use of toe of bank (to) and top of bank (tb) lines.
Figure 15. Channel view of lines and points representing the bankfull elevation.
Figure 16. Longitudinal view of the stream channel showing the location of survey points that effectively capture inflection points in the thalweg profile.
Figure 17. Channel view of lines and points representing the thalweg.
Figure 18. Channel view showing channel unit perimeter points and edge of water points.
Figure 19. Example of how to distribute pebble count cross-sections at a site.
Figure 20. Example of a cross-section layout.  In this example, distance between samples is 1 m, because the bankfull width is 12 m.  Particle sample location is shown with a circle and crosshairs.
Figure 21. Gravelometer used to classify the b-axis of particles.

Figure 22. Illustrations depicting the two methods used to estimate embeddedness: percent buried (Panel A) and percent fines (Panel B).  Panel A) The cobble is buried 20% beneath the streambed surface.  Panel B) The sediment in the depression immediately surrounding the cobble or beneath the cobble (indicated by the circle) is composed of approximately 10% of fine sediment <2 mm.
Figure 23. Cross-section of a streambed showing location of discharge measurements. Source CHaMP 2013.
Figure 24. Snorkeler looking for fish along a stream bank during a snorkel survey.
Figure 25. Sample Snorkel Survey Form
Figure 26. Juvenile Chinook on a measuring board.
Figure 27. Sample Fish Survey Form
Figure 28. Depiction of diameter and length measurement locations for LWD with attached roots.

Figure 29. Cross-section view depicting LWD wet/dry scenarios. Grey pieces are considered “wet” and light grey pieces “dry”.  Panel A) LWD piece on left is “dry” because the portion of the main stem touching the water is < 10 cm.  LWD piece on right is “wet” because a root = 10 cm diameter touches the water.  Panel B) Note that “dry” pieces above the bankfull elevation but within the bankfull prism are supported by other LWD pieces and are counted (see Step 2).
Figure 30. LWD Data Form
Figure 31. Example AIS inventory form.
Figure 32. Orientation and location of grid placement (from Heitke et al (2010)).
Figure 33. Non-measureable substrate at the 50% placement for pool tail fines measurements (from Heitke et al (2010)).
