2051.background:
The Kelt Steelhead Reconditioning and Reproductive Success Evaluation Project is a research, monitoring, and evaluation (RM&E) category project funded through the Columbia Basin Fish Accords.  The project studies and evaluates two broad topics with respect to post-spawn steelhead, first it assesses reconditioning processes and strategies, and second, it measures reproductive success of artificially reconditioned kelt steelhead.  The project associates with RPAs 33 and 64 in the Federal Columbia River Power System Biological Opinion.  RPA 33 requires the Action Agencies to develop, in cooperation with regional salmon managers, and to then implement a Snake River steelhead kelt management plan designed to provide at least a 6% improvement in B-run population productivity.  Toward that goal, a variety of approaches are being tested and implemented including passage improvements and reconditioning kelt stage steelhead.  This project focuses on the reconditioning component.  RPA 64 involves resolving artificial propagation critical uncertainties primarily through relative reproductive success studies.  This project is working toward evaluating reproductive success of artificially reconditioned kelt steelhead. 

Kelt steelhead reconditioning process evaluations involve fish culturing practices, studying alternative management strategies, and implementing research scale reconditioning programs. 

This evaluation program is designed to investigate the reproductive success of artificially reconditioned kelt steelhead.  Since direct examination of reproductive success in the field has proven very difficult, we are concentrating on measuring physiological and endocrinological parameters as an index to rematuration and reproductive success.  Additionally, we are evaluating gamete and progeny viability and conducting reproductive success studies in the Yakima River using pedigree analysis.
objectives: Evaluate rematuration rates of long-term reconditioned kelt steelhead.
Conduct relative reproductive success study of artificially reconditioned kelt steelhead in the Yakima River.
Estimate the genetic stock structure of Snake River Basin kelt steelhead at Lower Granite Dam.
Study of alternative management strategies include measuring in-river survival of kelt steelhead to compare against reconditioning strategies.
Refine fish culturing practices for reconditioning kelt steelhead including diet experiments to investigate the benefits of specialized diets in terms of survival and rematuration metrics.
2051.assumptions: Kelt steelhead are available and collectable at study sites.

metrics.title: Relative reproductive success of artifically reconditioned kelt steelhead

2055.background:
124 acres of rolling benches were under cultivation for wheat and hay production by the previous owner. These fields were replanted with native grasses and forbs to promote wildlife value. Monitoring plots were established on both a control field (natural bunchgrass community) and a treatment field. Plots were monitored for three years to establish baseline data, and then subsequently every five years. 

While monitoring was initially used to evaluate the baseline condition of the project area, long-term monitoring will continue to help document trends in plant community health, weedy encroachment, limiting factors for wildlife, and identify/monitor areas of habitat degradation.
objectives: Reclamation of the natural floral components native to the area.
2055.assumptions:
1.Personnel are trained in the identification of the local flora as well as familiar with the sampling design.

2.Plots will be monitored at height of growing season (middle of summer) to limit year to year variability.

2056.background:
Under the Northwest Power Planning Act, the Bonneville Power Administration was mandated to mitigate for wildlife habitat losses. In order to do that BPA must be able to measure the amount and quality of habitat lost and gained through their activities, including the Precious Lands project. The accounting system adopted by BPA is a habitat modeling strategy known as a Habitat Evaluation Procedure (HEP) developed by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. This procedure uses models to measure the quality of a specific habitat for target wildlife species. The models are based on key habitat parameters (ex. shrub height, snag density, or distance to water) and provide a measure of the habitat quality for that particular species. One product of HEP is a quantitative evaluation of habitat quality that is provided in terms of a Habitat Unit (HU). One acre of optimum habitat equals one HU. This HU accounting system is used to determine the amount of credit BPA receives for the land being protected.

While HSI models were initially used to evaluate the baseline condition of the Precious Lands Area, long-term monitoring will be conducted based on HEP data collection procedures, but not limited to particular wildlife variables. For example, percent microbiotic crust cover and percent bare ground are recorded for microplots in grasslands while the number of woody debris >4" diameter is recorded for transects in riparian and conifer cover types. Surveys will be used to assess long-term trends in plant community health, weedy encroachment, limiting factors for wildlife and identify/monitor areas of habitat degradation.
objectives: Develop trend data for plant community health and weed encroachment from long term monitoring of HEP transects.
Determine limiting factors for wildlife.
Identify and monitor areas of habitat degradation.
2056.assumptions:
1. Personnel will be properly trained in HEP monitoring as well as identification of local flora.

2. Transects, when revisited, will be run at the same time of year and phenological stage of the indicator plants as the baseline transects.

metrics.title: Number of Saplings, Pole, and Mature for Conifer and/or Deciduous trees

2057.background: Maintenance of the life history characteristics of the natural juveniles that are part of the Snake River fall Chinook salmon population/ESU is important for assessing the diversity aspect of the draft recovery plan and assessing actions to recover the population/ESU.  Specifically, adding additional years to the existing 1992-2014 data set collected on timing of juvenile presence, size, growth, and dispersal timing into the reservoir provides information for assessing evidence for density-dependent phenotypic change in Chinook Salmon subyearlings native to an 8th order river.
objectives: (5) Document trends in rate of downstream movement of natural juveniles measured between time of riverine rearing and passage at Lower Granite Dam.
(4) Document trends in passage timing of natural juveniles at Lower Granite Dam.
(3) Document trends in relative abundance of natural fall Chinook salmon juveniles along the shorelines of the free-flowing Snake River upstream of Lower Granite Reservoir.
(2) Document trends in growth of parr in length and weight during rearing along the shorelines of the free-flowing Snake River upstream of Lower Granite Reservoir.
(1) Document trends in time of presence of natural fry and parr along the shorelines of the free-flowing Snake River upstream of Lower Granite Reservoir.
2057.assumptions:
(1) Our frame is representative of the target population.

(2) Changes in timing of fish presence are affected more by changes in fish behavior than by flow-related changes in sampling efficiency.

(3) Growth of juveniles is not strongly affected by PIT tagging.

(4) Catch per unit effort reflects changes in abundance to a greater extent than flow-related changes in sampling efficiency.

(5) Collection probability at Lower Granite Dam is affected more by outflow and spill than by fish size.

(2)Count redds in deep water

2059.background:
Photographs of habitat status can help monitor long-term trends in plant cover, weed invasion, and disturbances. Plant height, size, flowering effort, and levels of herbivory are some of the conditions that will be used to document general health trends of vegetative communities. Photo points can be useful in documenting effects and subsequent succession after flood, fire, grazing, or mass wasting events, and can quantitatively monitor habitat and long-term plant growth (Skovlin and Thomas 1995). They will be used to establish baseline conditions and stature of plant communities.

In addition to general habitat trends, succession on newly reclaimed sites will be documented photographically annually for the first 3 years, and every 5 years thereafter.
objectives: Document any changes in vegetation cover, density, and composition over time
2059.assumptions:
Photos are taken at approximately the same time each revisit

The same azimuth is used to duplicate original photo orientation

2065.background:
Spalding’s catchfly (Silene spaldingii) is a rare plant endemic to the bunchgrass, sagebrush-steppe, and open pine communities of the inland Pacific Northwest. Large portions of these habitats have been eliminated by cultivation or degraded by livestock grazing. Spalding’s catchfly was listed as Threatened by the U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service in 2001.

During a noxious weed survey conducted in 2003, a Wallowa Resources employee located what he thought was a small population of Silene spaldingii above Joseph Creek on the Precious Lands Wildlife Area in Northeast Oregon. Tribal botanists returned to the site on July 14, 2004 and confirmed that he had indeed located the first population of Spaulding’s catchfly on the Tribal lands in Oregon.
objectives: To collect seeds for cryopreservation.
Continuous monitoring to learn more about reproduction, dormancy and pollination of this plant.
2065.assumptions:
1.Personnel can properly identify Spalding's Catchfly.

2.Sampling twice during the growing season will capture all plants present within the plots, with enough information collected to inform introduction, dormancy and pollination of this plant.

2074.background:
Floodplain restoration has been shown to be an effective technique for increasing rearing habitat for Chinook salmon and other species (Sommer et al. 2005). Fish that rear in floodplains have shown significant increases in growth compared to those rearing in mainstem habitats, likely due to favorable velocities, temperatures, and available food resources (Sommer et al. 2001, Sommer et al. 2005, Urabe et al. 2010).  Riverine species benefit from having access to floodplains for rearing and spawning and as refuge from high velocities (Jeffres et al. 2008).  New floodplain channels were associated with higher numbers of juvenile coho, cutthroat, and steelhead (Solazzi et al. 2000 as cited in Pess et al. 2005), and groundwater fed channels have supported increased numbers of chum, coho, pink, and sockeye salmon (Hall et al. 2000 as cited in Pess et al. 2005).

Common techniques for floodplain restoration and enhancement include levee removal or setback, reconnection of side-channels and floodplain channels, and creation of new floodplain channels.  These types of projects are targeted at increasing off-channel habitat and floodplain connection with mainstem channels, and range in size and scale from smaller side channel projects to floodplain reconnection and levee removal projects that are several miles long.  Techniques to reconnect floodplains are still in development (Cowx and Welcomme 1998 as cited in Pess et al. 2005, Pess et al. 2005) and additional study on the effectiveness of this project type is warranted.

This document details the monitoring design, procedures, and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of Floodplain Enhancement Projects at the project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s (BPA) programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: A programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program." This is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB) protocol,–“Monitoring Effectiveness of Floodplain Enhancement Projects” (ID: 38) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/38); and also draws heavily from the Scientific Protocol for Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID:806) (https://www.monitoringresources.org/Resources/Program/Detail/18); however, variations in the monitoring design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.

Questions to be answered:

  • Has the total habitat area, quantity of slow water habitat, and complexity of habitat increased as a result of the project?
  • Has flood capacity increased?
  • What is the level of water connection by season as intended by the project design? (e.g. designed to be connected at high water only, or also during low flows)
  • What habitats are connected during each season?
  • Have channel dynamics increased?
  • Have juvenile salmon and steelhead numbers increased following restoration?  What is the presence and relative abundance of fish species and life stages by habitat type and season? How does fish use relate to limiting factors for given populations?
  • Has abundance, diversity and ecological integrity of benthic invertebrates changed?  Does benthic invertebrate species composition indicate other ecological problems not addressed by the project?
objectives: Determine the pre-project topography of the floodplain and channel bed (Year-1 and 0)
Map habitat area by habitat type (turbulent, non-turbulent, edge) (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the proportion of slow water habitat at various flows through mapping or modeling (<0.15m/s (Beechie 2005) (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the value of the River Complexity Index (Brown 2002), braid-channel ratio, and sinuosity (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the ratio of floodplain area to channel area (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the variation (standard deviation) in residual depth and channel size (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine inundated floodplain area (length2)/channel length (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the proportion of each habitat type relative to total area (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the channel migration rate (between survey years, or with aerial photos)(Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine secondary production (benthic macroinvertebrates) by habitat type (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the relative fish abundance by habitat, season, species and life stage (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the presence of fish species by season (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Develop predictive model for inundation of off-channel habitat (Years 1, 3, 5, and 10)
2074.assumptions: Access to impact and suitable control reaches will be provided prior to project implementation and for a period of ten years following project completion.

images.caption: Figure 10.  How to number channel segments within a site. The main channel is assigned segment 1 throughout the site. Both large and small side channels are assigned sequential segment numbers working upstream. In the figure, channel segment numbers are preceded with a “S” (S1-S3) and channel unit numbers with a “U” (U1-13).

Figure 01. Examples of benchmark spacing.Optimally placed benchmarks are as far apart as possible, whilke still maintaining an equilateral triangle, are inter-visible, and extent the length of the site. Poorly place benchmarks are close in proximity and in a non-equilateral triangle (CHaMP 2013).
Figure 02.  Example of a good site overview photo.  Photo captures the stream as well as the surrounding riparian area and floodplain.

Figure 03. Example of a good repeat photo.  Photo captures both sides of the stream as well as the woody debris in the foreground.  The trees are also lined up in the exact location as the previous year’s photo.

2074.title: BPA MBACI Protocol for Monitoring the Effectiveness of Off-Channel Habitat / Floodplain Enhancement Projects (Mill Creek)

2100.background:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss and ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes’ (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone 1991). The goal was to restore healthy and harvestable salmonid populations through rehabilitation of stream habitat and restoration of ecological function in the riparian corridors of streams. Numerous restoration actions were implemented and corresponding rainbow trout status and trend monitoring was conducted.

In 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committee’s Categorical Review process, there was an evaluation of project accomplishments and future direction. While it was obvious that the project made substantial attempts to improve habitat conditions and monitor trends in rainbow trout populations, it is was also apparent that the approach to both aspects was relatively haphazard. Monitoring study design lacked statistical rigor and prioritization of habitat restoration actions was unclear. In response to these shortcomings, we developed a new approach to habitat restoration and protection that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clearly defined prioritization strategy.

We will use empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use from our monitoring efforts and an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help us evaluate where the highest priority areas are for habitat restoration and protection. EDT is an analytical model relating habitat features and biological performance to support conservation and recovery planning for salmonids (Lichatowich et al. 1995; Lestelle et al. 1996; Mobrand et al. 1997; Mobrand et al. 1998). It acts as an analytical framework that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis to determine which reaches and habitat attributes are likely to have the most benefit for improving fish performance.

Development of the EDT model requires the rating of Level II attributes for the current conditions. We place the highest confidence in Level II attribute ratings that are based on empirical data. Many of the Level II attributes are related to physical habitat and flow; however, there are also fish, macroinvertebrate, and water chemistry attributes. Benthic macroinvertebrate community data is limited for most reservation streams without anadromous fish, particularly in smaller streams.

While status and trends monitoring is not currently an LRHIP objective, we wanted to collect baseline information on the benthic macroinvertebrate communities in a manner that would allow for future monitoring. With the future monitoring option in mind, we developed our protocol so that it was consistent with other monitoring programs in the Basin, such as the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (Bouwes et al. 2011) and the Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP) (Terraqua Inc. 2009).
objectives: Describe benthic macroinvertebrate communities for use in EDT model development that will aid in habitat restoration and protection prioritization.
Provide a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of benthic macroinvertebrate communities.
Provide baseline benthic macroinvertebrate data sets for use in EDT model development.
2100.assumptions: Sample sizes are large enough to provide high confidence in EDT Level II attribute ratings.

2101.title: LRHIP - Sanpoil and Upper Columbia Subbasin Stream Water Chemistry Monitoring

2102.background:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss and ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes’ (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone 1991). The goal was to restore healthy and harvestable salmonid populations through rehabilitation of stream habitat and restoration of ecological function in the riparian corridors of streams. Numerous restoration actions were implemented and corresponding rainbow trout status and trend monitoring was conducted.

In 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committee’s Categorical Review process, there was an evaluation of project accomplishments and future direction. While it was obvious that the project made substantial attempts to improve habitat conditions and monitor trends in rainbow trout populations, it is was also apparent that the approach to both aspects was relatively haphazard. Monitoring study design lacked statistical rigor and prioritization of habitat restoration actions was unclear. In response to these shortcomings, we developed a new approach to habitat restoration and protection that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clearly defined prioritization strategy.

We will use empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use from our monitoring efforts and an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help us evaluate where the highest priority areas are for habitat restoration and protection. EDT is an analytical model relating habitat features and biological performance to support conservation and recovery planning for salmonids (Lichatowich et al. 1995; Lestelle et al. 1996; Mobrand et al. 1997; Mobrand et al. 1998). It acts as an analytical framework that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis to determine which reaches and habitat attributes are likely to have the most benefit for improving fish performance.

Development of the EDT model requires the rating of Level II attributes for the current conditions. We place the highest confidence in Level II attribute ratings that are based on empirical data. Many of the Level II attributes are related to physical habitat and flow; however, the discharge data is limited for most reservation streams without anadromous fish, particularly in smaller streams.

While status and trends monitoring is not currently an LRHIP objective, we wanted to collect baseline information on the stream discharge in a manner that would allow for future monitoring. With the future monitoring option in mind, we developed our protocol so that it was consistent with other monitoring programs in the Basin, such as the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (Bouwes et al. 2011) and the Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP) (Terraqua Inc. 2009).
objectives: Provide baseline discharge data sets for use in EDT model development.
Describe stream discharge for use in habitat restoration and protection prioritization.
2102.assumptions: Sample sizes are large enough to provide high confidence in EDT Level II attribute ratings.

2103.background: Egg-to-fry survival is one of the major factors thought to limit freshwater production and recovery of Chinook salmon Oncorhynchus tshawytscha and other salmon populations (Reiser and White 1988; Peterson and Quinn 1996; DeVries 1997). Despite being critical data that is needed to assist with efforts to recover threatened and endangered salmonid populations, adequate estimates of egg-to-fry survival for Chinook salmon do not currently exist (Healey 1991; Bradford 1995). This lack of information is likely due to the difficulty in measuring Chinook salmon and other salmonid egg-to-fry survival in the field because they deposit their eggs in the gravel during periods that make extensive field research difficult (Quinn 2005). This is particularly true for Chinook salmon, which spawn in large rivers with deeper and swifter water than most other salmon, and for which developing embryos remain in the gravel throughout the winter and early spring when it is difficult to sample (Quinn 2005). Therefore, many of the existing studies of Chinook salmon egg-to-fry survival have occurred in a laboratory setting (Jensen et al. 2009) and may not adequately represent egg-to-fry survival in the natural environment. This work provides estimates of survival and development, and an assessment of factor potentially affecting either metric, over large temporal and spatial scales, in the natural environment. See Johnson et al (2012) for a complete explanation of the methodology associated with this protocol
objectives: Investigate the extent to which environmental factors such as scour, redd superimposition, fines sediment infiltration, and temperature may influence survival and development spatially and temporally.
Estimate relative developmental stage at recovery among and within primary spawning locations of the target watershed, within and among years, while controlling for parental effects.
Estimate relative spring Chinook egg-to-fry survival among and within primary spawning locations of the target watershed, within and among years, while controlling for parental effects.
2103.assumptions:
1) Selected study locations are spatially and temporally representative of the population

2) Environmental conditions within buried Whitlock-Vibert egg boxes are representative of conditions in the surrounding environment (see Wesche et al. 1989; Garrett and Bennett 1996).

3) Environmental conditions experienced among study years sufficiently represent inter-annual variation within the target watershed.

4) A simple thermal sums model is sufficient to calculate duration of deployment such that developmental stage at recovery is similar among study areas; which may differ substantially in the rate and magnitude of temperature unit delivery to the egg pocket.

2104.background: The Wind River Watershed Project is a multi-agency watershed-scale effort to restore wild Wind River steelhead through habitat restoration and a robust RM and E program.  Streamflow measurements on the Wind River are used to help manage juvenile traps, and to provide data for design and monitoring of habitat restoration work in the drainage.
objectives: Provide hourly streamflow data available in realtime.
2104.assumptions: Stream stage measurements can be used to approximate stream discharge using an established rating curve developed at the monitoring location.

2121.background:
The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss and ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes’ (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone 1991). The goal was to restore healthy and harvestable salmonid populations through rehabilitation of stream habitat and restoration of ecological function in the riparian corridors of streams. Numerous restoration actions were implemented and corresponding rainbow trout status and trend monitoring was conducted.

In 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committee’s Categorical Review process, there was an evaluation of project accomplishments and future direction. While it was obvious that the project made substantial attempts to improve habitat conditions and monitor trends in rainbow trout populations, it is was also apparent that the approach to both aspects was relatively haphazard. Monitoring study design lacked statistical rigor and prioritization of habitat restoration actions was unclear. In response to these shortcomings, we developed a new approach to habitat restoration and protection that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clearly defined prioritization strategy.

We will use empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use from our monitoring efforts and an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help us evaluate where the highest priority areas are for habitat restoration and protection. EDT is an analytical model relating habitat features and biological performance to support conservation and recovery planning for salmonids (Lichatowich et al. 1995; Lestelle et al. 1996; Mobrand et al. 1997; Mobrand et al. 1998). It acts as an analytical framework that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis to determine which reaches and habitat attributes are likely to have the most benefit for improving fish performance.

Development of the EDT model requires the rating of Level II attributes for the current conditions. We place the highest confidence in Level II attribute ratings that are based on empirical data. Many of the Level II attributes are related to physical habitat and flow; however, there are also water chemistry attributes. Water chemistry and discharge data is limited for most reservation streams without anadromous fish, particularly in smaller streams.

While status and trends monitoring is not currently an LRHIP objective, we wanted to collect baseline information on the water chemistry and discharge in a manner that would allow for future monitoring. With the future monitoring option in mind, we developed our protocol so that it was consistent with other monitoring programs in the Basin, such as the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (Bouwes et al. 2011) and the Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP) (Terraqua Inc. 2009).
objectives: Describe stream water chemistry and discharge for use in habitat restoration and protection prioritization.
Provide a standardized protocol for future status and trend monitoring of stream water chemistry and discharge.
Provide baseline water chemistry and discharge data sets for use in EDT model development.
2121.assumptions: Sample sizes are large enough to provide high confidence in EDT Level II attribute ratings.

2122.background:
The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) Resident Fish RM&E project is a Columbia River Fish Accord project that began in 2008. The primary goal for the Resident Fish RM&E Project is to conserve, enhance and restore native fish populations in the blocked area above Grand Coulee Dam in Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries, and where appropriate provide opportunities for subsistence harvest by the Colville Tribal members and recreational anglers. The current work of the RM&E project will focus on the protection and conservation of Redband Trout populations on the Colville Confederated Tribes Reservation, with a focus on the Sanpoil River.

Rainbow trout are a focal species in the Sanpoil Subbasin under the Intermountain Province Subbasin Plan (IMP) due to their recreational value as a sport fish and their cultural significance to the CCT (Gillin and Pizzimenti 2004). The Columbia River Redband Trout are a subspecies of Rainbow TInrout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992; McLellan and Lee 2010). Effective fisheries management of redband trout requires an understanding of population structure, complex historical management activities, geography, and life history strategies ( McCusker et al. 2000; Spidle et al. 2003; Spruell et al. 2003; Small et al. 2006;2007).
 
In 2010, the CCT implemented a Redband Trout stock assessment project in the Sanpoil River (McLellan and Lee 2010).  The project plans to implement four primary tasks which include monitoring abundance, monitoring recruitment, monitoring harvest, and monitoring escapement to assist with management decisions. The development of a multi-year data set will enable managers to monitor trends over time and address potential limiting factors.  Water temperature monitoring is required to understand limiting factors and movement patterns.
objectives: Collect continuous surface water temperature at fish trap locations in the Sanpoil River.
2122.assumptions: The temperature data (~ 1m^2) collected at the logger location is representative of the water temperature within the entire reach it is located.

2127.background:
Collection of juvenile outmigrant summer Chinook (Oncorhynchus tschawytscha) by use of a rotary screw trap (RST) allows for the estimation of abundance, migration timing, size scoping at the trap location, and provides data that can be used to calculate freshwater production and monitor status and trends of a fishery at that specific life stage.  It also allows for PIT tagging of captured individuals which are of taggable size (≥ 65 mm). Rotary screw trapping has occurred in the mainstem of the Okanogan River since 2006, producing a large amount of data useful for monitoring and evaluation.  Since 2011, the Chief Joseph Hatchery Science Program (CJHP) has overseen operations as part of its monitoring and evaluation responsibilities towards summer/fall Chinook in the Okanogan River Basin.

This protocol is adapted from the general screw trapping principles outlined in Volkhardt et al. (2007) and the modifications implemented by Rayton (2006) to account for the conditions of the Okanogan River.  It has been further refined to specifically target summer/fall Chinook outmigrants.
objectives: To estimate natural summer/fall Chinook production in the Okanogan River Basin
To monitor presence/absence of other fish species in the Okanogan River Basin
To deploy PIT tags in Chinook longer than 65 mm.
To monitor fish size at the trap location
To monitor migration timing as juvenile Chinook leave the Okanogan River Basin
2127.assumptions:
Regarding efficiency trials, our assumptions are as follows:

  1. Mortality between marked and unmarked individuals is equal.
  2. Marked individuals retain their marks and all marks are recognized.
  3. Marked individuals are captured at the same rate as unmarked (no trap avoidance or trap happiness).
  4. Marked individuals mix randomly with unmarked.
  5. Marked individuals are representative in size, life-stage, age, etc. of the study population.
  6. Trap efficiency is consistent.

Regarding hourly trapping estimates, our assumptions are as follows:

  1. The daily proportion of fish captured in the trap during hours the trap was inoperable is equal to the average daily proportion of fish that enter the trap during that hour for all days the trap was operable.
  2. Fish entry into the trap occurs constantly and uniformly between trap checks (e.g. If a trap check is conducted after two hours of unchecked trapping, and it reveals 20 fish, it is assumed 10 fish entered the trap during each hour).

The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss and ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes’ (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone 1991). Work conducted under this protocol will provide reach specific water chemistry and stream discharge data to be used to rate EDT Level II attributes associated with each data type. These data will also facilitate analysis of spatial patterns and variance in stream water chemistry, and discharge among multiple watersheds in the Sanpoil and Upper Columbia River Subbasins

2136.background:
NOTE: The details in this protocol have been revised and are now contained in protocol ID: 518; https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/518

The Lake Roosevelt Habitat Improvement Project (LRHIP) was initiated in 1990 to increase the survival of migratory (adfluvial) rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss and ultimately improve Tribal subsistence and recreational harvest opportunity in streams on the Colville Confederated Tribes’ (CCT) reservation (LeCaire and Peone 1991). The goal was to restore healthy and harvestable salmonid populations through rehabilitation of stream habitat and restoration of ecological function in the riparian corridors of streams. Numerous restoration actions were implemented and corresponding rainbow trout status and trend monitoring was conducted.

In 2011, as part of the Northwest Power and Conservation Committee’s Categorical Review process, there was an evaluation of project accomplishments and future direction. While it was obvious that the project made substantial attempts to improve habitat conditions and monitor trends in rainbow trout populations, it is was also apparent that the approach to both aspects was relatively haphazard. Monitoring study design lacked statistical rigor and prioritization of habitat restoration actions was unclear. In response to these shortcomings, we developed a new approach to habitat restoration and protection that focuses on restoring natural stream function and has a clearly defined prioritization strategy

We will use empirical observations of habitat conditions and current fish use from our monitoring efforts and an Ecosystem Diagnosis and Treatment (EDT) model to help us evaluate where the highest priority areas are for habitat restoration and protection. EDT is an analytical model relating habitat features and biological performance to support conservation and recovery planning for salmonids (Lichatowich et al. 1995; Lestelle et al. 1996; Mobrand et al. 1997; Mobrand et al. 1998). It acts as an analytical framework that brings together information from empirical observation, local experts, and other models and analysis to determine which reaches and habitat attributes are likely to have the most benefit for improving fish performance.

Development of the EDT model requires the rating of Level II attributes for the current conditions. We place the highest confidence in Level II attribute ratings that are based on empirical data. Work conducted under this protocol will provide reach specific temperature data and Sanpoil River discharge data to be used to rate EDT Level II attributes associated with both data types.These data will also facilitate analysis of spatial patterns and variance in stream temperature among multiple watersheds in the Sanpoil and Upper Columbia River Subbasins
objectives: Collect continuous surface water temperature in all migratory redband rainbow trout spawning tributaries.
Continuous monitoring of Sanpoil River discharge measured near its mouth.
2136.assumptions: The temperature data (~ 1m^2) collected at the logger location is representative of the water temperature within the entire reach it is located.

2140.background:
The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) Resident Fish RM&E project is a Columbia River Fish Accord project that began in 2008. The primary goal for the Resident Fish RM&E Project is to conserve, enhance and restore native fish populations in the blocked area above Grand Coulee Dam in Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries, and where appropriate provide opportunities for subsistence harvest by the Colville Tribal members and recreational anglers. The current work of the RM&E project focuses on the protection and conservation of Redband Trout populations on the Colville Confederated Tribes Reservation.

Rainbow Trout are a focal species in the Sanpoil Subbasin under the Intermountain Province Subbasin Plan (IMP) due to their recreational value as a sport fish and their cultural significance to the CCT (Gillin and Pizzimenti 2004). The Columbia River Redband Trout are a subspecies of rainbow trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992; McLellan and Lee 2010). Effective fisheries management of Redband Trout requires an understanding of population structure, complex historical management activities, geography, and life history strategies (McCusker et al. 2000; Spidle et al. 2003; Spruell et al. 2003; Small and Dean 2006; Small et al. 2007).

In order to properly manage the Redband Trout populations managers require a basic understanding of population dynamics and an understanding of survival in trends during key life-histories.  In 2010 the Colville Tribe began working with regional co-managers to develop a comprehensive plan to monitor the Redband Trout populations in the blocked area. The Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (McLellan and Lee 2010) developed a Redband Trout Stock Assessment Plan that could be used by the co-managers to collect key life history information. 

This is the outline the CCT has used to develop the Resident Fish RM&E program to conduct stock assessment study on Redband Trout in the Sanpoil River. The project plans to implement four primary tasks which include monitoring abundance, monitoring recruitment, monitoring harvest, and monitoring escapement to assist with management decisions. The development of a multi-year data set will enable managers to monitor trends over time and address potential limiting factors.

This protocol describes recruitment of Redband Trout from the Sanpoil River to Lake Roosevelt.
objectives: The objective of this protocol is to estimate juvenile Redband Trout recruitment from the Sanpoil River into Lake Roosevelt.
2140.assumptions: The key assumption for this project is that the screw trap is an adequate method to collect migrating juvenile Redband Trout.

2140.title: Redband Trout Recruitment in the Sanpoil River

2141.background:
The Columbia River Redband Trout Oncorhynchus mykiss gairdneri are a subspecies of Rainbow Trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains. Their known distribution extends upstream as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992). There is considerable variability in the life history of Columbia River Redband Trout (Redband Trout) including both anadromous (O. mykiss that migrate to the ocean) and potamodromous (O. mykiss that migrate solely within fresh water) forms (Behnke 1992). Recently, potamodromous Redband Trout were estimated to occur in 42% of their historic range with invasive species habitat degradation and fragmentation, and climate change being the primary threats to their long term survival (Muhlfeld 2015). Redband Trout are classified as a sensitive species or species of special concern by several states and federal agencies and the American Fisheries Society Endangered Species Committee (Williams et al. 1989; Muhlfeld et al. 2001).

The construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939 eliminated the opportunity for Redband Trout in the Upper Columbia River to express anadromy (Scholz et al. 1985) and likely blocked migration routes and isolated populations and habitats of potamodromous Redband Trout. Lake Roosevelt formed in the impounded portion of the Columbia River behind Grand Coulee Dam and supports important tribal and recreational fisheries. Non-native hatchery Rainbow Trout (McCloud River, California  O. stonei) have been stocked in the upper Columbia River and its tributaries to provide angling opportunities and as mitigation for hydropower related impacts (Stober et al. 1977; Peone et al. 1989). Naturally reproducing Rainbow Trout still occur in the upper Columbia River drainage upstream of Grand Coulee Dam. 

Potamodromy can be divided into four types: fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, lacustrine-adfluvial, and allacustrine (Varley and Gresswell 1988; Northcote 1997). Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries support fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, and lacustrine-adfluvial life history types. All three life history types have also been documented within the Sanpoil River drainage, including a small fall run of lacustrine adfluvial fish (Brown et al. 2013). The Sanpoil is the only documented tributary in Lake Roosevelt supporting fall migrating adult Redband Trout.

Microsatellite DNA analysis conducted on wild-born Rainbow Trout in the upper Columbia River drainage indicated that some stocks were pure Redband Trout (Powell and Faler 2002; Taylor 2002; Small and Dean 2006, 2007; Small et al. 2007). Redband Trout persisted in many tributaries with no history of coastal-lineage hatchery Rainbow Trout introductions and where barriers prevented hatchery fish from moving into tributaries (Small et al. 2007).

The Redband Trout Stock Assessment Project (RTSAP) was initiated in Lake Roosevelt by the three co-managers in 2010, Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW), Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT), and the Spokane Tribe of Indians (STI). One of the objectives of RTSAP study is to develop a basin wide genetic stock inventory of the remnant Redband Trout populations in the Lake Roosevelt watershed. This information will be used by regional fisheries managers to assist with habitat restoration plans, conservation needs, and harvest regulation changes.
objectives: Determine the genetic status (pure, introgressed, or naturalized non-native) of wild trout populations within the Lake Roosevelt watershed.
2141.assumptions:
The tissue samples collected for each population are representative of the entire genetic diversity found within the population and not just a small sample representing siblings.

The 192 SNPs are appropriate for determining Redband Trout population level distinctions.

2151.background:
The Grande Ronde River Upper Mainstem summer steelhead population (GRUM) area is 4,239 km2 in size and consists of six MaSAs and seven MiSAs (ICTRT 2010).  Steelhead are widely distributed throughout the population area and occupy all six of the MaSAs and five of the seven MiSAs.  Steelhead spawners are predominantly natural origin, although from 1999-2002, a portion of spawners were comprised of Wallowa Hatchery stock, which were directly released into Catherine Creek and the upper Grande Ronde River (ICTRT 2010).  Although Wallowa stock hatchery fish are still released into portions of the Grande Ronde River subbasin, there have been a significant number of hatchery management changes which have reduced the number of hatchery fish spawning in nature (ICTRT 2010).   The ODFW currently manages the GRUM for natural origin steelhead where hatchery influence is considered negligible.

Index spawning ground surveys began in 1967, and redd counts from annual index area spawning ground surveys and intrinsic potential of spawning habitat were used to estimate abundance of adult summer steelhead (ICTRT 2010).  In 2008, index site surveys were maintained for historical continuity, but the protocol was adjusted, and abundance is now based on a Generalized Random Tessellation Stratified (GRTS) design to achieve a statistically useful dataset (Ruzycki et al. 2008).  Data used for calculating age proportion and proportion hatchery origin spawners (pHOS) are collected by the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR) at three weirs in the GRUM population area.  

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has an obligation under the Sustainable Fisheries Act to restore depleted populations to optimal levels of abundance and productivity (McElhany et al. 2000).  The Viable Salmonid Parameter (VSP) concept can be used to inform management decisions and is used by NOAA to assess the current status of the populations, in terms of extinction risk (ICTRT 2010).  The VSP parameters include abundance, productivity, spatial structure, and diversity.  Natural origin spawner abundance (NOSA) is a measure of abundance and is assessed annually.
objectives: To provide natural origin spawner abundance estimates to NOAA, allowing them to assess the current status of the population.
To provide accurate and up to date metric and indicator data for salmon and steelhead in the Columbia Basin to users via a data exchange network and web applications.
2151.assumptions:
The Grande Ronde Upper Mainstem (GRUM) population is genetically distinct from surrounding populations.

Steelhead spawners in the GRUM are predominantly natural origin since 2002.

Data collection is as accurate as possible and has been quality checked.

Total spawner abundance (TSA) and proportion of hatchery origin spawners (pHOS) are accurate.

pHOS was assumed to be zero prior to 1989.

2165.background: This protocol provides research techniques associated with  understanding O. mykiss life history diversity in the upper Yakima Basin, while concurrently providing resident and anadromous population status and trend data.  The upper Yakima supports a large robust resident rainbow trout population that overlaps spatially and temporally with a relatively small sympatric anadromous population (Pearsons et al. 2007).  The interaction between life history forms is a primary uncertainty documented in all major steelhead recovery documents.  This protocol outlines one strategy that generates data to improve our understanding of how resident O. mykiss in the upper Yakima may influence recovery of the anadromous form.  Abundance estimates in tributary and main stem areas are generated annually using mark recapture electrofishing techniques.  Rearing juvenile fish captured under this protocol are PIT tagged, genetically sampled for inclusion in a parentage analysis, and scale sampled for cohort tracking/analysis.  The proportion of juvenile migrants detected in subsequent years is used to partition abundance estimates into the abundance estimates for each form.  PIT tag detection histories are used to identify areas that produce anadromous juveniles such that the relative production by stream can be evaluated and compared. This protocol collaborates with data collection activities conducted by the Yakima Klickitat Fisheries Project (protocols 94 and 328).
objectives: Determine viable salmonid population (VSP) metrics for sympatric resident and anadromous O. mykiss life history types in pre selected locations.
2165.assumptions: There are minimal assumptions associated with this work in the context of uncertainties research, because it supplies data necessary to understand the interplay between life history forms (we make no assumptions).  However, in generating abundance estimates of both resident trout and juvenile anadromous steelhead, we assume instream survival of both forms is the same prior to the smolt stage for the migrants.

2169.background:
The purpose of this protocol is to provide a comprehensive description of state-of-the-art standardized stream-gaging procedures, within the scope described below. It is intended for use as a training guide and reference text, primarily for hydraulic engineers and technicians in the U.S. Geological Survey, but the manual is also appropriate for use by other stream-gaging practitioners.

The technical work involved in obtaining systematic records of streamflow is discussed in accordance with the following six major topics:

Measurement of stage and discharge:

  1. Selection of gaging-station sites
  2. Measurement of stage
  3. Measurement of discharge

Computation of discharge:

  1. Computation of the stage-discharge relation
  2. Computation of daily-discharge records
  3. Presentation and publication of stream-gaging data
Streamflow serves man in many ways. It supplies water for domestic, commercial, and industrial use; irrigation water for crops; dilution and transport for removal of wastes; energy for hydroelectric power generation; transport channels for commerce; and a medium for recreation. Records of streamflow are the basic data used in developing reliable surface-water supplies because the records provide information on the availability of streamflow and its variability in time
and space. The records are therefore used in the planning and design of surface-water related projects, and they are also used in the management or operation of such projects after the projects have been built or activated.
 
The streamflow records referred to above are primarily continuous records of discharge at stream-gaging stations, a gaging station being a stream-site installation so instrumented and operated that a continuous record of stage and discharge can be obtained. Networks of stream-gaging stations are designed to meet the various demands for streamflow information, including inventory of the total water resource. The networks of continuous-record stations, however, are often augmented by auxiliary networks of partial-record stations to fill a particular need for streamflow information at relatively low cost. For example, an auxiliary network of sites, instrumented and operated to provide only instantaneous peak-discharge data, is often established to obtain basic information for use in regional flood frequency studies. An auxiliary network of uninstrumented sites for measuring low flow only is often established to provide basic data for use in regional studies of drought and of fish and wildlife maintenance or enhancement.
 
Discharge measurements are then made at periodic intervals, usually monthly, to verify the stage-discharge relation or to define any change in the relation caused by changes in channel geometry and (or) channel roughness.
 
Project objectives include:

1.Provide flow data for irrigation water management and coordinated fish flushes between co-managers by which irrigation ditches are turned off to accomplish fish passage in seasonally low streams.  Short term (annual). 

2.Provide flow data to assist fishery managers in the effective operation of trap & haul, screw trap, weir, and hatchery facilities.  Short term (annual).

3.Provide flow data to assist in conservation project development.  Medium term (5-10 years).

4.Provide flow data to correlate with existing and on-going data collection efforts.  Long term (>10 years).

5.Provide flow data for basin wide management plans cumulative effects response to conservation.  Long term (>10 years).
objectives: Flow gauging provides the opportunity to access watershed conditions and monitoring objectives include a combination of short (annual), medium (5-10 years), and long-term (>10 years) objectives.
2169.assumptions:

objectives: The objectives of eDNA monitoring are to identify the presence of DNA fragments in environmental samples that are diagnostic of the recent proximity of individuals of a species or set of species.
2172.assumptions:
1) eDNA in the water column is shed from a living organism or a recent corpse of the target species or taxonomic group;

2) eDNA does not move counter to the flow of water and does not enter the water column from a reservoir in sediments;

3) eDNA is not appreciably moved by predators/parasites or derive from anthropogenic sources.
2172.title: Environmental DNA Sampling eDNA

2176.background:
The Fifteenmile Creek watershed in North Central Oregon hosts a native population of steelhead (Oncorhynchus mykiss) that is without influence of previous hatchery augmentation (Newton and Nelson 2000). The Fifteenmile Creek steelhead are a subpopulation within the Distinct Population Segment (DPS) of the Middle Columbia River steelhead, which consists of all historical populations of steelhead in tributaries to the Columbia River upstream of the Hood River and Wind River systems, up to and including the Yakima River. This steelhead DPS was listed as ‘threatened’ by the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) first on March 25, 1999 and relisted as a DPS on January 5, 2006.


Subsequently, a conservation and recovery management plan was developed for the Middle Columbia River steelhead DPS within Oregon state borders. The goal of the plan is to recover Middle Columbia River steelhead to a level that would allow the removal of threatened status, in addition to providing a long-term goal to recover the population sufficiently to provide “sustainable fisheries and other ecological, cultural, social and economic benefits for future generations” (Carmichael and Taylor 2010). The DPS-level recovery plan sets specific recovery goals for the areas within the DPS, which designates Fifteenmile Creek explicitly.


The Fifteenmile Creek steelhead population is considered the most inland winter race of steelhead in the Columbia River Basin, as designated by NOAA fisheries. However review of this designation maybe necessary at the next BiOp status-review in 2015 because the run-timing of adult steelhead passing Bonneville Dam has been inconsistent with known winter-run steelhead in the area. The population was identified as “must have viable” by the Interior Columbia Technical Recovery Team (ICTRT) reaching viable status is essential for achieving DPS delisting. The ICTRT, Recovery Plan, and the Federal Columbia River Power System (FCRPS) Biological Opinion (BiOp) have all identified this population as high priority for improving precision and accuracy of abundance, productivity, diversity, and spatial structure information. This status and trend monitoring by ODFW is designed to establish a comprehensive monitoring and evaluation program for abundance, productivity, and life history of steelhead in the Fifteenmile Creek population. This work is critical to gaining a better understanding of the status of the population and DPS, monitoring and adapting recovery actions, and improving the knowledge of steelhead critical habitat.

This protocol is interim due to contract issues.
objectives: Determine population dynamics for Fifteenmile Creek steelhead
Determine life history characteristics (through metrics associated with life history attributes)
Improve accuracy and precision of estimates of abundance of stray hatchery fish
Improve accuracy and precision of estimates of spawner abundance
2176.assumptions:
Weir is a persistent barrier throughout the season.

Assume that you are capturing all Steelhead, and if not that you accurately estimate those that evaded capture.

Assume that video reviewers accurately identify individuals as adult or kelt.

Assume the weir moves fish into the live-box or the video by-pass chute.

2185.background:
Stream channel incision is one cause of riparian zone degradation in the arid western United States. Channel incision may be initiated by factors such as major floods, changes in sediment regimes, urban development, and channelization (Rosgen, 1997). As the stream bed becomes progressively deeper, the channel can contain large peak flows and the stream can no longer dissipate energy, water, and materials across its former floodplains (Simon and Rinaldi, 2006). This reduces the area for surface water and groundwater exchange, and aquifer infiltration and water table elevation decline (Brunke and Gonser, 1997). Therefore, streambed degradation is associated with reduced groundwater recharge, reduced reliability and consistency of baseflow, and damaged hyporheic zone connections (Brunke and Gonser, 1997; Cluer and Thorne, 2014). Riparian vegetation that relies on high water tables may also be undercut or stressed (Scott et al., 1999; Shafroth et al., 2000). Ultimately, this impairs stream channel habitat by isolating it from the floodplain, limiting nutrient cycling, and increasing water temperatures (due to lack of shade and poor hyporheic exchange), with negative effects on both in-stream and riparian biota (reviewed in Brunke and Gonser, 1997; Cluer and Thorne, 2014).

Channel incision may be mitigated if beaver return and build dams on streams (Pollock et al., 2007). Pollock et al. (2014) describe how beaver dams can greatly accelerate the channel recovery process by promoting trench widening and aggradation. Beaver dams are an integral part of the restoration strategy currently underway in Bridge Creek, a tributary to the John Day River in eastern Oregon, USA, where channel incision limits habitat quantity and quality for a population of threatened, wild Mid Columbia River steelhead (Oncorhynchus mykiss) (Pollock et al., 2012 Pollock et al. 2015). In 2009, beaver dam analog (BDA) structures were installed to increase the number and lifespan of beaver dams on Bridge Creek.  One hypothesis of the Bridge Creek restoration approach is that water table elevation will increase as surface water elevations rise due to beaver dam impoundments and ongoing sedimentation and bed aggradation (Figure 1); these changes are also expected to enhance groundwater recharge by increasing the duration and extent of floodplain inundation (Pollock et al., 2012).

Wells drilled into floodplain surfaces allow access to groundwater, and data loggers can be deployed to monitor hourly changes in temperature and pressure.  Pressure changes can be transformed into water table elevation data using computer software. This protocol and methods were used to monitoring changes in groundwater elevation and temperature in two well fields in the Bridge Creek Intensively Monitoring Watershed. One well field is adjacent to a restored reach treated with BDA structures (treatment), while the second well field is adjacent to an unrestored, reference reach (control). The purpose of groundwater monitoring was to determine whether trends in water table elevation and groundwater temperature support the hypothesis that restoration actions enhance groundwater recharge and improve hydrologic connections between the stream and its floodplain, mitigating the effects of channel incision.
objectives: Monitor hourly changes in water table elevation and groundwater temperature in well fields adjacent to a restored stream reach (treatment) and a nearby unrestored, reference stream reach (control)
Determine whether trends in water table elevation and groundwater temperature support the hypothesis that restoration actions have improved hydrologic connectivity and mitigated effects of incision
2185.assumptions:
• The reference site provides an appropriate control scenario
  • The depth and spatial locations of the groundwater wells are appropriate for detecting changes in water table elevation and groundwater temperature resulting from restoration activities
  • Long term differences in water table elevation trajectories and groundwater temperature patterns recorded from the two instrumented well fields are attributable to their treated vs. reference status
  • Data loggers are calibrated and functioning properly
  • Field measurement data for each well (well elevations, cap perch measurements, and cable length measurements) are accurate

citation.title: Monitoring groundwater fluctuations using data loggers deployed in shallow groundwater wells v1.0

2191.background:
Many streams in the Pacific Northwest have depleted wood volume due to past human activities such as logging in riparian areas, salvage logging of wood in streams, splash-dams, and misguided attempts to remove perceived obstructions to salmon migration.  In addition, streams have been modified and simplified due to agriculture and urban development.  This process has reduced channel complexity, isolated main stem habitats from side-channels and floodplains, reduced cover for aquatic species, and altered channel morphology.  Instream structures can be used to create pools, increase habitat complexity, reduce sediment transport, trap gravel needed for spawning, stabilize stream channels, provide food for aquatic invertebrates, and provide stream nutrients, increasing overall stream productivity (Roni and Quinn 2001). As a result, installation of instream structures, particularly placement of large woody debris (LWD), has become one of the longest used and most common techniques for improving fish habitat and mitigating human-caused degradation (Roni and Quinn 2001; Roni et. al. 2005).  Use of instream structures began as early as the 1930’s in the Midwest and has been adapted to the higher gradient systems in the Pacific Northwest (Roni et al. 2005).

The effectiveness of instream structures in enhancing habitat has been debated due to the lack of evaluation, as well as confounding results due to improper structure placement and lack of documentation of effects on factors directly limiting habitat quality (Roni et al. 2005). Calls to better evaluate habitat improvement projects began in the early 1980s (Reeves and Roelofs 1982), and continued throughout the 1990s (Reeves et al. 1991; Chapman 1996; Kauffman et al. 1997). Others have suggested the approach to restoration should shift to protecting high-quality habitats and restoring connectivity and watershed processes before implementing instream habitat improvement projects (Roni et al. 2008; Frissell and Nawa 1992), or focusing on restoring riparian forests with trees large enough to replenish LWD naturally in the system over time (Collins and Montgomery 2002). The need for additional effectiveness monitoring and evaluation is widely apparent in the Pacific Northwest.

This document details the monitoring design, procedures and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects at the Project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s Programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: a programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program". This protocol is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board  (SRFB) protocol, “SRFB - Monitoring Effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects” (ID: 35) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/35); however, variations in the design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.  This approach also draws heavily from the Scientific Protocol for Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID:806). This document details the monitoring design and procedures necessary to document and report reach scale effectiveness of projects treating:

·         Channel Reconfiguration

·         Installed Deflectors

·         Log and Rock Control weirs

·         Roughened Channels

·         Woody Debris
objectives: Bank Stability (a) -Determine if bank stability changed (amount and rate) as a result of the project (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Bank Stability (b) -Determine how bank erosion rate changed as a result of bank stabilization project (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Bank Stability (c) -Determine if percent pool tail fines changed as a result of the project (Only if change in fines is a goal) (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Vegetation Enhancement – see Riparian Planting protocol for evaluation procedures
Determine if local juvenile fish density increased as a result of the project (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10) (seasonal focus for specific project habitat outcome)
Determine if fish use differs by structure type (e.g. wood revetment, rock revetment, vegetated revetment), life stage, or species composition (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the distribution of habitat types within the reach (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if pool frequency, area and depth and pool/riffle ratio changed due to the project
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the volume of functional wood increased by Year 10 (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the amount of instream cover increased as a result of the project by Year 10 (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the complexity of the channel increased as a result of the project (only if increasing complexity is a stated goal of the project)(Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Increase Spawning Habitat - Determine if spawning habitat been enhanced. (Only if enhancing spawning habitat is a goal) (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)

images.caption: Figure 01. Examples of benchmark spacing. Optimally placed benchmarks are as far apart as possible while still maintaining an equilateral triangle, are inter-visible, and extend the length of the site. Poorly placed benchmarks are close in proximity and in a non-equilateral triangle (CHaMP 2013).
Figure 02. Example of a good site overview photo.  Photo captures the stream as well as the surrounding riparian area and floodplain.

Figure 03. Example of a good repeat photo.  Photo captures both sides of the stream as well as the woody debris in the foreground.  The trees are also lined up in the exact location as the previous year’s photo.
Figure 04. The hierarchical channel unit classification adapted from CHaMP which is a modification of the system developed by Hawkins et al. (1993) as reported in Bisson et al. (2006).
Figure 05. Representation of Pool A) cross-sectional (lateral) and B) longitudinal concavity from CHaMP.
Figure 06. An example of channel unit delineations.
Figure 07. Dichotomous key of criteria adapted from CHaMP used to classify Tier I (slow-water and fast water) channel units.
Figure 08. Dichotomous key adapted from CHaMP of criteria used to classify Tier II fast water channel units.
Figure 09. Dichotomous key adapted from CHaMP of criteria used to classify Tier II slow water channel units.

Figure 10. How to number channel segments within a site. The main channel is assigned segment 1 throughout the site. Both large and small side channels are assigned sequential segment numbers working upstream. In the figure, channel segment numbers are preceded with a “S” (S1-S3) and channel unit numbers with a “U” (U1-13).
Figure 11. Representation of topographic points and descriptions used to capture the topography of the stream during surveys.
Figure 12. Channel cross-sectional view showing proper delineation of the bottom of site cross-section at transect 1.

Figure 13. Channel cross-section indicating how water surface points (ws) are used to represent A) the water surface elevation at overhanging banks and B) mid-channel water surface gradient changes (i.e., pitched riffles).
Figure 14. Channel view showing proper use of toe of bank (to) and top of bank (tb) lines.
Figure 15. Channel view of lines and points representing the bankfull elevation.
Figure 16. Longitudinal view of the stream channel showing the location of survey points that effectively capture inflection points in the thalweg profile.
Figure 17. Channel view of lines and points representing the thalweg.
Figure 18. Channel view showing channel unit perimeter points and edge of water points.
Figure 19. Example of how to distribute pebble count cross-sections at a site.
Figure 20. Example of a cross-section layout.  In this example, distance between samples is 1 m, because the bankfull width is 12 m.  Particle sample location is shown with a circle and crosshairs.
Figure 21. Gravelometer used to classify the b-axis of particles.

Figure 22. Illustrations depicting the two methods used to estimate embeddedness: percent buried (Panel A) and percent fines (Panel B).  Panel A) The cobble is buried 20% beneath the streambed surface.  Panel B) The sediment in the depression immediately surrounding the cobble or beneath the cobble (indicated by the circle) is composed of approximately 10% of fine sediment <2 mm.
Figure 23. Cross-section of a streambed showing location of discharge measurements. Source CHaMP 2013.
Figure 24. Snorkeler looking for fish along a stream bank during a snorkel survey.
Figure 25. Sample Snorkel Survey Form

Figure 27. Sample Fish Survey Form
Figure 28. Depiction of diameter and length measurement locations for LWD with attached roots.

Figure 29. Cross-section view depicting LWD wet/dry scenarios. Grey pieces are considered “wet” and light grey pieces “dry”.  Panel A) LWD piece on left is “dry” because the portion of the main stem touching the water is < 10 cm.  LWD piece on right is “wet” because a root = 10 cm diameter touches the water.  Panel B) Note that “dry” pieces above the bankfull elevation but within the bankfull prism are supported by other LWD pieces and are counted (see Step 2).

2191.title: BPA MBACI Monitoring Effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects (Bank Stabilization)

2192.background:
Floodplain restoration has been shown to be an effective technique for increasing rearing habitat for Chinook salmon and other species (Sommer et al. 2005). Fish that rear in floodplains have shown significant increases in growth compared to those rearing in mainstem habitats, likely due to favorable velocities, temperatures, and available food resources (Sommer et al. 2001, Sommer et al. 2005, Urabe et al. 2010).  Riverine species benefit from having access to floodplains for rearing and spawning and as refuge from high velocities (Jeffres et al. 2008).  New floodplain channels were associated with higher numbers of juvenile coho, cutthroat, and steelhead (Solazzi et al. 2000 as cited in Pess et al. 2005), and groundwater fed channels have supported increased numbers of chum, coho, pink, and sockeye salmon (Hall et al. 2000 as cited in Pess et al. 2005).

Common techniques for floodplain restoration and enhancement include levee removal or setback, reconnection of side-channels and floodplain channels, and creation of new floodplain channels.  These types of projects are targeted at increasing off-channel habitat and floodplain connection with mainstem channels, and range in size and scale from smaller side channel projects to floodplain reconnection and levee removal projects that are several miles long.  Techniques to reconnect floodplains are still in development (Cowx and Welcomme 1998 as cited in Pess et al. 2005, Pess et al. 2005) and additional study on the effectiveness of this project type is warranted.

This document details the monitoring design, procedures, and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of Floodplain Enhancement Projects at the project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s (BPA) programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: A programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program." This is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB) protocol,–“Monitoring Effectiveness of Floodplain Enhancement Projects” (ID: 38) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/38); and also draws heavily from the Scientific Protocol for Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID:806) (https://www.monitoringresources.org/Resources/Program/Detail/18); however, variations in the monitoring design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.

Questions to be answered:

  • Has the total habitat area, quantity of slow water habitat, and complexity of habitat increased as a result of the project?
  • Has flood capacity increased?
  • What is the level of water connection by season as intended by the project design? (e.g. designed to be connected at high water only, or also during low flows)
  • What habitats are connected during each season?
  • Have channel dynamics increased?
  • Have juvenile salmon and steelhead numbers increased following restoration?  What is the presence and relative abundance of fish species and life stages by habitat type and season? How does fish use relate to limiting factors for given populations?
  • Has abundance, diversity and ecological integrity of benthic invertebrates changed?  Does benthic invertebrate species composition indicate other ecological problems not addressed by the project?
objectives: Determine the pre-project topography of the floodplain and channel bed (Year-1 and 0)
Map habitat area by habitat type (turbulent, non-turbulent, edge) (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the proportion of slow water habitat at various flows through mapping or modeling (<0.15m/s (Beechie 2005) (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the value of the River Complexity Index (Brown 2002), braid-channel ratio, and sinuosity (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the ratio of floodplain area to channel area (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the variation (standard deviation) in residual depth and channel size (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine inundated floodplain area (length2)/channel length (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the proportion of each habitat type relative to total area (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the channel migration rate (between survey years, or with aerial photos)(Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine secondary production (benthic macroinvertebrates) by habitat type (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the relative fish abundance by habitat, season, species and life stage (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the presence of fish species by season (Years -1, 0, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Develop predictive model for inundation of off-channel habitat (Years 1, 3, 5, and 10)
2192.assumptions: Access to impact and suitable control reaches will be provided prior to project implementation and for a period of ten years following project completion.
