2192.title: BPA MBACI Protocol for Monitoring the Effectiveness of Off-Channel Habitat / Floodplain Enhancement Projects

2193.background:
As a fishery co-manager the Yakama Nation is obligated to examine and apply management tools that improve the status of its resources for the benefit of present and future tribal members. The Yakama Nation remains extremely concerned that low levels of natural production by ESA-listed fish species throughout the Columbia Basin constrain Treaty-reserved tribal fisheries at usual and accustomed fishing areas. Naturally reproducing salmonid populations within the Upper Columbia River ESU/DPS remain among the least productive and at greatest risk of extinction (NOAA 2009, 2014) despite considerable past and ongoing recovery efforts (NPCC 2009).

Chronically low numbers of returning adult salmon and steelhead can be traced to well documented factors in the Columbia Basin. One factor, documented by the Independent Scientific Advisory Board (ISAB), is density dependence (ISAB 2015).  Salmonid densities are limited by dramatically reduced marine derived nutrients (MDN), caused by the decline in returning adult salmonids over the past century.  Gresh et al. (2000) reported current MDN loading rates of 6 to 7% of historic levels across the Columbia basin.  The implications of these studies suggest that a food web perspective is needed to provide a broader and more ecologically informed context for restoration efforts (ISAB 2011; Naiman, Alldredge et al. 2012; Bellmore, Fremier et al. 2014).

Marine subsidies have been documented to stimulate aquatic productivity, particularly in low-nutrient, headwater streams (Schindler, Scheuerell et al. 2003; Moore and Schindler 2004). Numerous studies in the Upper Columbia River Basin have confirmed the benefits of nutrient addition for biological production (Gresh et al. 2000, Stockner 2003; Kohler and Taki 2010; Kohler et al. 2012; Marcarelli et al. 2014).  Fewer studies have directly measured responses of nutrient supplementation on natural production of ESA-listed anadromous salmonids, and on the required supporting food webs and energy flows.

Considering the recent ISAB report on density dependence, the Yakama Nation believes that the direct, controlled addition of MDN into streams (nutrient supplementation) in juvenile rearing habitats must be examined as a viable action to restore natural production of anadromous salmonids. This project proposes a multiyear experimental MDN addition to a Methow basin stream, Hancock Springs, to clarify the empirical effects, benefits, and potential risks of MDN addition to juvenile salmonid food webs. The proposed study design, along with a robust 3-year pre-treatment will allow us to isolate fine-scale effects and trophic cascading energy patterns from annual nutrient treatments. We will also assess the risk that MDN addition could produce deleterious effects by disrupting or altering food web dynamics to for invasive, non-native species such as brook trout.

Research Questions and Hypotheses :

  1. How does MDN replacement (carcass analogue addition) affect the productivity and dynamics of salmonid food webs, natural production, and the growth, condition, and survival of juvenile salmonids in the freshwater rearing environment?
  2. Can MDN replacement disrupt the trophic ecology of salmonid food webs to preferentially benefit non-target competitor or predator fish species?
objectives: Determine if MDN replacement will disrupt the trophic ecology of salmonid food webs to preferentially benefit non-target competitor or predator fish species.
Evaluate how MDN replacement affects productivity and dynamics of salmonid food webs, natural production, and the growth and condition of juvenile salmonids in the freshwater rearing environment.
2193.assumptions:
• General: (1) Equipment is functioning properly and in the same fashion during each sampling event.  (2) Sampling events occurring from March-December accurately capture annual changes.  (3) Sites selected for sampling are representative of the sample reach.
  • Electrofishing: (1) Catchability of focal species is the same across all individuals at large and during all sample events, or within designated size classes. (2) Sufficient numbers of fish (of each species) can be PIT tagged and recaptured to estimate production.  (3) Growth of PIT tagged fish is the same as non-tagged fish.
  • Fish Diets: (1) The diets of collected species are representative of the population at large.  (2) Isotopes from fin clips are representative of fish trophic position.

2197.background:
Steelhead endemic to the lower Deschutes River are considered a component of the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment (DPS) and are listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act (ESA).  Lower Deschutes steelhead are composed of two distinct populations, Deschutes Westside and Deschutes Eastside (Carmichael et al. 2005). Steelhead inhabiting Bakeoven and Buck Hollow creeks are a component of the Deschutes Eastside population.   Concomitant with reductions in steelhead escapement in the Deschutes River populations, a significant increase in the number of stray hatchery origin steelhead was detected at several trapping and counting sites in the Deschutes River.  The number of stray hatchery steelhead captured at the Sherars Falls trap (river mile 44) peaked during the 1997–98 run when escapement of stray hatchery steelhead were nearly ten times that of wild steelhead.

Carmichael et al. (2005) concluded that the proportion of naturally spawning steelhead that were hatchery origin in both the Eastside and Westside Deschutes River tributaries resulted in a high risk rating for viability due to the likelihood of high introgression rates between Snake River steelhead and native Mid-Columbia steelhead.  Some level of straying and gene flow occurs naturally in wild populations.   However, natural levels of gene flow and straying was presumed to be at a much lower rate than what was observed in recent years during spawning surveys conducted by ODFW personnel.  In the late 1990’s greater that 50% of the steelhead observed spawning in Bakeoven and Buck Hollow creeks were determined to be of hatchery origin (ODFW, 2000).  However, the number of stray hatchery steelhead that remain in the lower Deschutes and tributaries to spawn is unknown.  Stray hatchery steelhead remaining to spawn with wild fish have the potential to impact the viability of the wild populations by reducing the fitness and productivity of native fish.

This is the fifth year of a multiple year study to investigate the relative reproductive success of introgressed stray hatchery and wild steelhead to investigate whether  hatchery stray steelhead influence natural productivity of wild steelhead returning to Bakeoven and Buck Hollow creeks.  The two study streams are in close proximity and are very similar in basin size, geology, land-use, habitat, and fishery resources.  These streams were chosen because they are significant spawning tributaries for the Deschutes Eastside population and because of the importance of Deschutes steelhead to the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment (DPS) and the potential impact of stray hatchery spawners on Deschutes Basin steelhead.

Prior to our study, ODFW conducted spawning surveys to monitor relative abundance.  Single pass steelhead redd counts in the same river reach were conducted during late-March or early April each year in both streams from 1990-2009.  In Bakeoven Creek, redd counts ranged from a low of 8 redds in 1991 to a high of 480 redds in 2001, and in Buck Hollow Creek, redd counts ranged from 8 redds in 1994 to 445 redds in 2001.  We continue to conduct summer steelhead spawning surveys  to provide retrospective analysis of steelhead production, and an independent means of assessing escapement.
objectives: Improve accuracy and precision of estimates of spawner abundance
Determine population dynamics for Deschutes steelhead
2197.assumptions: Steelhead redd counts were difficult to complete during periods of high discharge and efforts were sometimes limited by the availability of staff at optimum survey times, which could affect the accuracy of surveys.  In addition, landowner denial of access caused the delay or prevented the completion of some surveys. Surveyors can distinguish between Steelhead, Coho or Chinook redds.

2197.title: Deschutes Bakeoven and Buck Hollow Spawning Surveys (2007-299-00)

2198.background:
Steelhead endemic to the lower Deschutes River are considered a component of the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment (DPS) and are listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act (ESA).  Lower Deschutes steelhead are composed of two distinct populations, Deschutes Westside and Deschutes Eastside (Carmichael et al. 2005). Steelhead inhabiting Bakeoven and Buck Hollow creeks are a component of the Deschutes Eastside population.   Concomitant with reductions in steelhead escapement in the Deschutes River populations, a significant increase in the number of stray hatchery origin steelhead was detected at several trapping and counting sites in the Deschutes River.  The number of stray hatchery steelhead captured at the Sherars Falls trap (river mile 44) peaked during the 1997–98 run when escapement of stray hatchery steelhead were nearly ten times that of wild steelhead.

Carmichael et al. (2005) concluded that the proportion of naturally spawning steelhead that were hatchery origin in both the Eastside and Westside Deschutes River tributaries resulted in a high risk rating for viability due to the likelihood of high introgression rates between Snake River steelhead and native Mid-Columbia steelhead.  Some level of straying and gene flow occurs naturally in wild populations.   However, natural levels of gene flow and straying was presumed to be at a much lower rate than what was observed in recent years during spawning surveys conducted by ODFW personnel.  In the late 1990’s greater that 50% of the steelhead observed spawning in Bakeoven and Buck Hollow creeks were determined to be of hatchery origin (ODFW, 2000).  However, the number of stray hatchery steelhead that remain in the lower Deschutes and tributaries to spawn is unknown.  Stray hatchery steelhead remaining to spawn with wild fish have the potential to impact the viability of the wild populations by reducing the fitness and productivity of native fish.

This is the fifth year of a multiple year study to investigate the relative reproductive success of introgressed stray hatchery and wild steelhead to investigate whether  hatchery stray steelhead influence natural productivity of wild steelhead returning to Bakeoven and Buck Hollow creeks.  The two study streams are in close proximity and are very similar in basin size, geology, land-use, habitat, and fishery resources.  These streams were chosen because they are significant spawning tributaries for the Deschutes Eastside population and because of the importance of Deschutes steelhead to the Mid-Columbia Distinct Population Segment (DPS) and the potential impact of stray hatchery spawners on Deschutes Basin steelhead.

This protocol is in interim status related to contract issues.
objectives: Determine population dynamics for Bakeoven/ Buck Hollow steelhead
Determine life history characteristics (through metrics associated with life history attributes)
Improve accuracy and precision of estimates of abundance of stray hatchery fish
Improve accuracy and precision of estimates of spawner abundance
Compare measures of fitness and productivity between the wild and introgressed populations
Determine the number and origin of stray hatchery steelhead escaping into the Bakeoven and Buck Hollow Creeks
Determine the relative reproductive success of wild vs. stray hatchery steelhead
2198.assumptions:
Weir is a persistent barrier throughout the season.

Assume that you are capturing all Steelhead, and if not that you accurately estimate those that evaded capture.

Assume that video reviewers accurately identify individuals as adult or kelt.

Assume the weir moves fish into the live-box or the video by-pass chute.

2211.background:
This protocol was developed to document status (current conditions) and trend (changes over time) monitoring for juvenile spring Chinook and steelhead in the Entiat River subbasin under the Integrated Status and Effectiveness Monitoring Program (ISEMP; BPA Project 2003-017).  The work described in this protocol is guided by the Upper Columbia Monitoring Strategy (UCMS, Hillman 2006), which outlines a monitoring strategy specific to the Upper Columbia Basin that was based on monitoring approaches adopted by the Independent Scientific Advisory Board of the Northwest Planning council (ISAB), Action Agencies/NOAA Fisheries, and the Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB). The sampling design for fish status and trend monitoring in the Entiat River subbasin is based on a Generalized Random-Tessellation Sampling design with an annual panel of up to 18 sites structured to distribute sampling effort in space (Stevens and Olsen 2004). These sites are co-located with the habitat monitoring annual panel sites proposed under the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP; BPA Project 2011-006). All fish monitoring data will be subjected to standard QA/QC processes and uploaded to PTAGIS.

This monitoring will result in the collection and analysis of systematic anadromous salmonid status and trends information that will be used to assess basin-wide population trends.  When coupled with habitat data, this status and trends information will be used to evaluate habitat management strategies.

This protocol describes techniques used to capture, handle and PIT tag fish and includes Electro Fishing, Snorkeling, Angling and Dip-net/Seining as the major capture methods. The use of Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags to support status and trend and effectiveness monitoring for listed juvenile spring Chinook and steelhead in the Upper Columbia has increased significantly over the past 5 years as the technology associated with passive detection of tags in the tributary environment and the coverage afforded by instream PIT tag detection arrays has improved. Data from PIT-tagged juveniles can be used to monitor the response of fish to habitat restoration actions and the status and trend of populations through survival, growth and abundance.  PIT tag data also allows us to characterize the movement patterns of tagged fish, supporting estimations of residency time, migration timing, and habitat use if the detection infrastructure is sufficient.
objectives: Evaluate status and trends of juvenile spring Chinook and steelhead in the Entiat River subbasin in wadeable, perennial streams below natural impassible barriers within TRT population boundaries.
2211.assumptions:
1. The sampling frame is representative of the target populations of spring Chinook and steelhead in the Entiat River subbasin.

2. That the frame is outside the scope of influence of any habitat or hatchery or harvest actions and therefore is representative of natural variability of the populations.

Growth rate of juvenile stream-type Chinook and steelhead

2220.background: The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) staff analyzes Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tag data to determine juvenile outmigration behavior in the Columbia River, smolt to smolt survival (to Rocky Reach Juvenile Bypass (RRJ) and McNary), smolt to adult survival (SAR),  adult run timing to Bonneville and through the Federal Columbia River Power System (FCRPS), and stray rates and locations.  These metrics are important In Season Implementation Tool (ISIT) inputs for status and trends, in season fish management, and evaluating performance of the Chief Joseph Hatchery (CJH).  PIT tagged Natural-Orign Recruits (NOR) returns will be important in-season predictors of the NOR estimate to the Okanogan, particularly in combination with valid smolt outmigration estimates.  Developing an alternative to the current regression analysis in ISIT will be important once adults from the CJH program are returning.
objectives: Estimate survival (smolt to smolt, smolt to adult) and travel time for the natural-origin and hatchery-origin Okanogan Chinook salmon using PIT tags.
Monitor adult run timing at Bonneville

2221.background:
The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) Resident Fish Division operates the Colville Resident Fish Hatchery Program to address a host of resident fish management goals on the CCT Reservation in northeast Washington State. Due to the development and operation of the Federal hydroelectric system in the Columbia River, CCT tribal member access to anadromous fish resources was largely eliminated with the completion of Chief Joseph Dam, which did not provide upstream passage facilities for fishes. Mitigation for lost access to fish resources upstream of Chief Joseph Dam includes use of hatchery-origin Rainbow Trout Oncorhynchus mykiss, Brook Trout Salvelinus fontinalis, and Lahontan Cutthroat Trout O. clarkii henshawi in waterbodies on and bordering the CCT Reservation.

The hatchery monitoring and evaluation program is tasked with assessing the fisheries in stocked lakes, with the main goal of providing guidance and feedback for stocking and management actions to enhance or maintain subsistence and sport-fishing opportunities.In order to determine angler success and satisfaction on stocked lakes, roving and voluntary creel surveys will be conducted.
objectives: Estimate total fishing effort (angler-hours) for shore and boat anglers for all strata (i.e., lake, weekday/weekend, and month).
Monitor angler satisfaction.
Estimate harvested fish size statistics (length) for each fish species and stocking class by month.
Estimate monthly and annual stocking class return-to-creel (portion of each stocking class harvested).
Estimate total catch by species and stocking class, when possible, for all strata (i.e., lake, weekday/weekend, morning/evening, and month).
Estimate average harvest and total caught per angler-hour by species and stocking class (when possible) for all strata (i.e., lake, weekday/weekend, and month).
2221.assumptions: Responses of surveyed anglers are representative of overall angler experience.

2222.background:
The Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT) Resident Fish Division operates the Colville Resident Fish Hatchery Program to address a host of resident fish management goals on the CCT Reservation in northeast Washington State. Due to the development and operation of the Federal hydroelectric system in the Columbia River, CCT tribal member access to anadromous fish resources was largely eliminated with the completion of Chief Joseph Dam, which did not provide upstream passage facilities for fishes. Mitigation for lost access to fish resources upstream of Chief Joseph Dam includes use of hatchery-origin Rainbow Trout Oncorhynchus mykiss, Brook Trout Salvelinus fontinalis, and Lahontan Cutthroat Trout O. clarkii henshawi in waterbodies on and bordering the CCT Reservation.

Annually, a minimum of 22,697 kg of fish are stocked on CCT reservation waters. The goal of the monitoring and evaluation program is to provide information and recommendations that help guide fish stocking and management decisions for individual water bodies based on fisheries performance objectives.

2223.background: Critical to the The Chief Joseph Hatchery RM&E program are appropriate tagging/marking of natural origin summer/fall and spring Chinook emigrants to monitor populations status and tred, assess/update key program assumptions and decision rules.  These monitoring and assessments will allow the CJH program to annually review previous year's program performance and stock status, thereby allowing the hatchery program to develop the upcoming hatchery implementation plan to manage the program goal. The RM&E program calls for up to 25,000 PIT tagged natural-origin summer/fall Chinook parr/smolts in order to monitor and evaluate the program annually.  PIT tagging of natural-origin summer/fall juvenile Chinook occurs at the Okanogan River rotary screw trap site in and on the Columbia River near the confluence with the Okanogan.

2224.background:
A hypolimnetic oxygenation (HO) system has been operational throughout the open-water season in North Twin Lake (NT) since May 12, 2009 with the main goal of increasing suitable trout habitat availability. Suitable trout habitat for long-term survival has been defined as ≤ 21 C and ≥ 4.25 mg/L dissolved oxygen (DO) (Davis 1975, Overholtz et al. 1977, Wydoski and Whitney 2003). The target level of DO throughout the hypolimnion with oxygenation is 4.25 mg/L. This project provides the unique opportunity of studying NT before/after HO as well as a side-by-side comparison with un-oxygenated ST. We hypothesized that HO would expand suitable trout habitat in NT while trout habitat would remain restricted in un-oxygenated ST by a hypoxic hypolimnion.

During 2011–2013, to create more trout habitat, NT was oxygenated from June 1 – October 18, May 24 – October 23, and May 24 – mid-October in 2011, 2012, and 2013, respectively. A total of 10,045,096, 8,231,850, and 10,133,800 cu. ft of liquid oxygen were delivered for injection into NT in 2011, 2012, and 2013, respectively. Winter DO depletion rates were also monitored to determine sediment oxygen demand and to identify trends in HO reducing those demands. In theory, as NT is oxygenated, sediment oxygen demand will decrease over time as the legacy nutrients are oxidized.
objectives: Monitor dissolved oxygen levels in North Twin Lake.
Assess effectiveness of oxygen addition to North Twin Lake.

2225.background: Many Eastern Washington lakes are highly stratified in the summer months, with water temperatures in the epilimnion exceeding the tolerance levels for salmonids and the hypolimnion becoming anoxic causing a "habitat squeeze" (Christensen and Moore 2008). North and South Twin Lakes on the Colville Reservation suffer this problem which severely limits the trout fishery in these lakes. In 2008 a hypolimnetic oxygenation system was installed in North Twin Lake and has been in operation since 2009. The purpose of this system was to oxygenate the hypolimnion and make it available to trout. The purpose of this protocol is to evaluate the effectiveness of hypolimnetic oxygenation as a tool to improve the fishery in stratified lakes. In order to answer these questions North Twin is being oxygenated and South Twin is being used as a control.
objectives: Determine if oxygenation in North Twin Lake has resulted in physical or biological changes relative to unoxygenated South Twin Lake.
Determine daphnia and copepod abundance and distribution in Twin Lakes.
Assess water quality in Twin Lakes.
2225.assumptions: North and South Twin Lakes are sufficiently similar so that South Twin can act as a reference site.

2226.background:
Carcass surveys for summer/fall Chinook (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) are conducted annually throughout many of the river systems in Washington state. Carcass surveys generally occur contemporaneously with redd survey efforts. A single float survey serves the dual purpose of allowing for enumeration of redds while collecting carcasses for data collection. For additional information regarding summer/fall Chinook redd surveys, please consult Protocol ID#: 3276. Carcass survey data are combined with additional information (e.g. redd counts) to monitor the status and trends of Chinook species. 
 
Float surveys for carcass recoveries are conducted each week during the spawning period, which is typically from late September to mid November. Carcass recovery objectives are 20% of the estimated spawner abundance. Carcasses are sampled for origin, marks (e.g. adipose-fin clip), tags (e.g. CWT, PIT), length (e.g. POH, FKL), sex, genetics, scales (NOR only), and recovery location and date.
objectives:
Monitor status and trends of summer/fall Chinook:

Spawning escapement
Pre-spawn mortality and egg-retention
Demographic characteristics
Proportion of hatchery-origin spawners (pHOS)
Stray rates (into basin, out of basin)
Phenotypic traits
Genotypic traits
2226.assumptions:
All carcasses had the same probability of being recovered on the spawning grounds (despite differences in sex, origin, size or spawning location).

The reach in which a carcass is recovered is the same as the reach in which the fish spawned.

Sampled carcasses are representative of the overall spawning composition within each reach.

2227.background:
Chief Joseph Hatchery Science Program (CJHP) collaborates with USGS to conduct Environmental DNA (eDNA) sampling and analysis in an effort to monitor status and trends in spring-Chinook spatial distribution throughout the Okanogan basin in response to the reintroduction of the experimental population. Monitoring began prior to the reintroduction in an attempt to assess the pre-management action spatial distribution of spring-Chinook, allowing CJHP to assess the status and progress of the reintroduction efforts. Analysis of eDNA data revealed that while spring-Chinook were listed as extirpated within the Okanogan ESU, the basin likely does have a limited distribution of spring-Chinook. Additionally, PIT tag detections confirm the presence of occasional strays from out of basin.

As a proof of concept, sampling was initiated in 2012 with 5 mainstem Okanogan River sites and 11 Okanogan tributary sites as well as 32 sites throughout the Methow basin (See Laramie et al 2015a and CJHP 2013 Annual Report). Sampling was conducted in June and August 2012 at all sites. In 2013, sampling was conducted only in the Okanogan basin, at 8 additional tributary sites not visited during the proof of concept study. These sites were sampled in June and were located in tributary streams with potential for spring-Chinook recolonization. In 2014, all previously sampled sites in the Okanogan basin were re-visited and sampled (US sites on 12-13 July, 2014, and Canada sites on 2 October 2014). See CJHP 2014 Annual Report (appendix C) for results from 2012 thru 2014 eDNA analyses. Several tributaries have produced consistent annual detection of Chinook eDNA, including Shingle Creek, Vaseux Creek, Salmon Creek and Omak Creek. Monitoring eDNA will serve as a resource prioritization tool, indicating which streams may warrant additional, more intensive survey efforts (e.g. electrofishing mark/recapture, snorkle surveys) to obtain density/abundance information, and which stream are not likely utilized by spring-Chinook. Results may also inform habitat rehabilitation/restoration efforts (e.g. removal of barriers to anadromy, habitat improvements).
objectives: Determine which Okanogan Basin tributaries are utilized by spring-Chinook, as indicated by the presence of Chinook eDNA.
Monitor the status and trends of spring-Chinook distribution throughout the Okanogan Basin (USA & Canada) using environmental DNA (eDNA) analysis.
2227.assumptions: The presence of Chinook DNA at a stream site is the result of the recent presence of Chinook at the site (i.e. not from alternative, less likely sources such as site contamination from birds, etc.)

2229.background:
Colville Confederated Tribes - Chief Joseph Hatchery Science Program (CJHP) was contacted by the Columbia River Intertribal Fish Commission (CRITFC) with the request to collect genetic samples (DNA) from all Chinook spawned at the Chief Joseph Hatchery. CJHP complied with the request and annually collects genetic samples from all Chinook spawned at Chief Joseph hatchery, along with basic biological data. All sampling supplies and data sheets are provided by CRITFC prior to the spawning season. Following the spawning season, all samples and data and shipped to CRITFC Hagerman Genetics Laboratory (3059F National Fish Hatchery Road, Hagerman, Idaho 83332). 

Parentage-based tagging (PBT) involves the annual genotyping of all broodstock at each hatchery, creating a parental genotype database. Progeny from any of these parents (either collected as juveniles or returning adults), if genotyped, could be assigned back to their parents, thus identifying the hatchery they originated from and exact brood year they were produced in (Anderson and Garza 2005; Steele et al 2011). Essentially this technology is very similar to human parentage analyses (i.e. “who’s the father?”). The exceptional advantage PBT has over mechanical tagging technology is increased sample size. By genotyping all parental broodstock, every juvenile is “tagged”. The key to this technology ultimately working is the ability to sample all (100%) of the hatchery broodstock. 100% broodstock sampling- The primary annual objectives for any hatchery using PBT tagging are to: • Obtain tissue samples (fin clips) from every adult hatchery broodstock that contributes to spawning. • Ensure that all samples come from fresh, “live” tissue and that each sample is properly preserved until DNA extraction and free of contamination. • Ensure that every sample is properly labeled and inventoried. • Ensure that data/information from every fish sampled is recorded and tied to a field/hatchery sample number (sample/spawn date, take #, hatchery, sex, length, cross information, etc.) and that field/hatchery sample number is tied to a unique genetic number. The step by step instructions below summarize tissue sampling and storage in either coin envelopes (dry method) or in tubes filled with ethanol.
objectives: Describe how PBT genetic samples are to be collected from hatchery Chinook salmon at Chief Joseph Hatchery.
2229.assumptions:
*NOTE: Chief Joseph Hatchery staff are responsible for collecting the genetic samples and biological information ONLY. Samples and data are shipped to the Columbia River Intertribal Fish Commission (CRITFC) Hagerman Genetics Laboratory (3059F National Fish Hatchery Road, Hagerman, Idaho 83332) for any futher processing and/or data analysis.

Genetic samples can be collected and properly preserved from every Chinook salmon hatchery broodstock spawned at Chief Joseph Hatchery. In addition, accurate biological information (stock, spawn date, sex, cross information) can be recorded for every adult sampled. A set of SNP markers can be developed/identified that can achieve high parental assignment accuracy even when tens of thousands of potential parents are involved and when parentage involves hatchery populations that are very similar genetically due to shared ancestry or in situations where the broodstock contains closely related individuals (ISRP/ISAB 2009).

2229.title: Parentage based tagging sample collection from Chinook salmon at Chief Joseph Hatchery

2231.background:
Floodplain restoration has been shown to be an effective technique for increasing rearing habitat for Chinook salmon and other species (Sommer et al. 2005). Fish that rear in floodplains have shown significant increases in growth compared to those rearing in mainstem habitats, likely due to favorable velocities, temperatures, and available food resources (Sommer et al. 2001, Sommer et al. 2005, Urabe et al. 2010).  Riverine species benefit from having access to floodplains for rearing and spawning and as refuge from high velocities (Jeffres et al. 2008).  New floodplain channels were associated with higher numbers of juvenile coho, cutthroat, and steelhead (Solazzi et al. 2000 as cited in Pess et al. 2005), and groundwater fed channels have supported increased numbers of chum, coho, pink, and sockeye salmon (Hall et al. 2000 as cited in Pess et al. 2005).

Common techniques for floodplain restoration and enhancement include levee removal or setback, reconnection of side-channels and floodplain channels, and creation of new floodplain channels.  These types of projects are targeted at increasing off-channel habitat and floodplain connection with mainstem channels, and range in size and scale from smaller side channel projects to floodplain reconnection and levee removal projects that are several miles long.  Techniques to reconnect floodplains are still in development (Cowx and Welcomme 1998 as cited in Pess et al. 2005, Pess et al. 2005) and additional study on the effectiveness of this project type is warranted.

This document details the monitoring design, procedures, and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of Floodplain Enhancement Projects at the project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s (BPA) programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: A programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program." This is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board (SRFB) protocol,–“Monitoring Effectiveness of Floodplain Enhancement Projects” (ID: 38) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/38); and also draws heavily from the Scientific Protocol for Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID:806) (https://www.monitoringresources.org/Resources/Program/Detail/18); however, variations in the monitoring design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.

Questions to be answered:

  • Has the total habitat area, quantity of slow water habitat, and complexity of habitat increased as a result of the project?
  • Has flood capacity increased?
  • What is the level of water connection by season as intended by the project design? (e.g. designed to be connected at high water only, or also during low flows)
  • What habitats are connected during each season?
  • Have channel dynamics increased?
  • Have juvenile salmon and steelhead numbers increased following restoration?  What is the presence and relative abundance of fish species and life stages by habitat type and season? How does fish use relate to limiting factors for given populations?
  • Has abundance, diversity and ecological integrity of benthic invertebrates changed?  Does benthic invertebrate species composition indicate other ecological problems not addressed by the project?
objectives: Determine the pre-project topography of the floodplain and channel bed (Year -2 and -1)
Map habitat area by habitat type (turbulent, non-turbulent, edge) (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the proportion of slow water habitat at various flows through mapping or modeling (<0.15m/s (Beechie 2005) (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the value of the River Complexity Index (Brown 2002), braid-channel ratio, and sinuosity (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the ratio of floodplain area to channel area (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the variation (standard deviation) in residual depth and channel size (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine inundated floodplain area (length2)/channel length (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the proportion of each habitat type relative to total area (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the channel migration rate (between survey years, or with aerial photos) (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine secondary production (benthic macroinvertebrates) by habitat type (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the relative fish abundance by habitat, season, species and life stage (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the presence of fish species by season (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Develop predictive model for inundation of off-channel habitat (Years 1, 3, 5, and 10)
2231.assumptions: Access to impact and suitable control reaches will be provided prior to project implementation and for a period of ten years following project completion.

images.caption: Figure 10.  How to number channel segments within a site. The main channel is assigned segment 1 throughout the site. Both large and small side channels are assigned sequential segment numbers working upstream. In the figure, channel segment numbers are preceded with a “S” (S1-S3) and channel unit numbers with a “U” (U1-13).

Figure 01. Examples of benchmark spacing.Optimally placed benchmarks are as far apart as possible, whilke still maintaining an equilateral triangle, are inter-visible, and extent the length of the site. Poorly place benchmarks are close in proximity and in a non-equilateral triangle (CHaMP 2013).
Figure 02.  Example of a good site overview photo.  Photo captures the stream as well as the surrounding riparian area and floodplain.

2231.title: BPA MBACI Protocol for Monitoring the Effectiveness of Off-Channel Habitat / Floodplain Enhancement Projects

2232.background:
Many streams in the Pacific Northwest have depleted wood volume due to past human activities such as logging in riparian areas, salvage logging of wood in streams, splash-dams, and misguided attempts to remove perceived obstructions to salmon migration.  In addition, streams have been modified and simplified due to agriculture and urban development.  This process has reduced channel complexity, isolated main stem habitats from side-channels and floodplains, reduced cover for aquatic species, and altered channel morphology.  Instream structures can be used to create pools, increase habitat complexity, reduce sediment transport, trap gravel needed for spawning, stabilize stream channels, provide food for aquatic invertebrates, and provide stream nutrients, increasing overall stream productivity (Roni and Quinn 2001). As a result, installation of instream structures, particularly placement of large woody debris (LWD), has become one of the longest used and most common techniques for improving fish habitat and mitigating human-caused degradation (Roni and Quinn 2001; Roni et. al. 2005).  Use of instream structures began as early as the 1930’s in the Midwest and has been adapted to the higher gradient systems in the Pacific Northwest (Roni et al. 2005).

The effectiveness of instream structures in enhancing habitat has been debated due to the lack of evaluation, as well as confounding results due to improper structure placement and lack of documentation of effects on factors directly limiting habitat quality (Roni et al. 2005). Calls to better evaluate habitat improvement projects began in the early 1980s (Reeves and Roelofs 1982), and continued throughout the 1990s (Reeves et al. 1991; Chapman 1996; Kauffman et al. 1997). Others have suggested the approach to restoration should shift to protecting high-quality habitats and restoring connectivity and watershed processes before implementing instream habitat improvement projects (Roni et al. 2008; Frissell and Nawa 1992), or focusing on restoring riparian forests with trees large enough to replenish LWD naturally in the system over time (Collins and Montgomery 2002). The need for additional effectiveness monitoring and evaluation is widely apparent in the Pacific Northwest.

This document details the monitoring design, procedures and quality assurance steps necessary to document and report the effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects at the Project site scale. This supports the Bonneville Power Administration’s Programmatic approach to project level Action Effectiveness Monitoring (AEM), as documented in "Action Effectiveness Monitoring of Tributary Habitat Improvement: a programmatic approach for the BPA Fish and Wildlife Program". This protocol is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board  (SRFB) protocol, “SRFB - Monitoring Effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects” (ID: 35) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/35); however, variations in the design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol.  This approach also draws heavily from the Scientific Protocol for Habitat Surveys within the Columbia Habitat Monitoring Program (CHaMP) (ID:806). This document details the monitoring design and procedures necessary to document and report reach scale effectiveness of projects treating:

·         Channel Reconfiguration

·         Installed Deflectors

·         Log and Rock Control weirs

·         Roughened Channels

·         Woody Debris
objectives: Bank Stability (a) -Determine if bank stability changed (amount and rate) as a result of the project (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Bank Stability (b) -Determine how bank erosion rate changed as a result of bank stabilization project (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Bank Stability (c) -Determine if percent pool tail fines changed as a result of the project (Only if change in fines is a goal) (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Vegetation Enhancement – see Riparian Planting protocol for evaluation procedures
Determine if local juvenile fish density increased as a result of the project (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10) (seasonal focus for specific project habitat outcome)
Determine if fish use differs by structure type (e.g. wood revetment, rock revetment, vegetated revetment), life stage, or species composition (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the distribution of habitat types within the reach (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if pool frequency, area and depth and pool/riffle ratio changed due to the project
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the volume of functional wood increased by Year 10 (Years -2 -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the amount of instream cover increased as a result of the project by Year 10 (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the complexity of the channel increased as a result of the project (only if increasing complexity is a stated goal of the project)(Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Increase Spawning Habitat - Determine if spawning habitat been enhanced. (Only if enhancing spawning habitat is a goal) (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
2232.assumptions: Access to impact and suitable control sites is provided

2232.title: BPA MBACI Monitoring Effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects (Bank Stabilization)

2234.background:
Efforts to recover threatened and endangered species often rely on models to identify management strategies that will improve the status of at-risk populations (Good et al., 2007; Sweka and Wainwright, 2014). Fundamental to this work is the task of building models that are structurally and/or numerically consistent with the scales of relevant biological processes and management actions (Green et al., 2005). For species like Pacific salmon and steelhead (Oncorhynchus spp.), this is especially challenging given that they respond to factors operating at widely varying spatial and temporal scales. For example, the foraging success, growth, and survival of individuals can be influenced by conditions within small (10-100 m2) patches of stream habitat (e.g., Rosenfeld and Taylor, 2009), yet a river’s overall capacity to produce juvenile fish may be set by a habitat limitation for another life stage that is governed by broader-scale geomorphic controls (e.g., spawning, Buffington et al., 2004; Palm et al., 2007). Similarly, global climatic phenomena (e.g., El Niño Southern Oscillation) can affect the survival of salmon during marine life stages (e.g., Sharma et al., 2013) to an extent that makes it difficult to detect the effects of other factors (e.g., Schaller et al., 2013). Accordingly, there is a great need for modelling approaches that can accurately depict complex life histories and simultaneously maximize the realism of species–environment relationships for life stages targeted by management/restoration.

Despite a rich history of life-cycle model (LCM) applications to salmon recovery-related questions (see Good et al., 2007 for a recent review), previous attempts to link habitat restoration scenarios with future population performance have met with limited success. For example, studies have quantified population responses to hypothetical survival increases assumed to be achievable through habitat restoration, but without explicit consideration of current conditions and/or restoration feasibility (e.g., Kareiva et al., 2000). More recent assessments have integrated habitat–survival relationships and basin-specific habitat information into modelling (Honea et al., 2009; McHugh et al., 2004; Scheuerell et al., 2006), assessed restoration potential based on relationships between watershed condition and in-stream habitat metrics (Bartz et al., 2006; Jorgensen et al., 2009; Sharma et al., 2005), and/or increased the spatial resolution of LCMs (Scheuerell et al., 2006). The realism of LCMs has thus improved greatly, yet these tools continue to inform restoration practice at a coarse level of resolution only (e.g., current condition vs. historic potential) and in the absence of mechanistic insight on fish–habitat associations. Thus, approaches that integrate LCMs with reach-level habitat observations and restoration plans are needed.

This protocol develops Life Cycle Models for populations of stream rearing salmonids, in particular Chinook and Steelhead.  The Life Cycle Model explicitly incorporates multiple life stages (e.g., fry, parr, smolts), but allows the user to specify how the life cycle is represented based on data and knowledge available.
objectives: Develop Life Cycle Models that can be used to support decision making for management actions targeting ESA listed salmonids in the Columbia River Basin.
2234.assumptions:
Beverton-Holt stock recruitment relationship is the correct freshwater productivity relationship for salmonids.

Model consumes derived estimates and each of those estimates are accompanied by own suite of assumptions e.g., rotary screw trap estimates of juvenile abundance.

Relationship between fish productivity is known and relative to metrics of habitat quality and quantity

2234.title: ISEMP Life Cycle Models

2235.background:
Decreased levels of wood volume in Pacific Northwest streams resultant of anthropogenic activities has reduced channel complexity, isolated main stem habitats from side-channels and floodplains, reduced cover for aquatic species, and altered channel morphology. Placement of instream structures to improve channel complexity, pool number and area, cover and improve and create spawning and rearing habitat for salmon and other fish is one of the oldest and most common habitat improvement techniques (Roni et al. 2002; 2008). Common instream habitat improvement techniques include placement of large woody debris (single or multiple logs), constructed or engineered logjams (ELJS), boulder or boulder weirs, and bank stabilization.

Despite the long history of placement of LWD and other structures in streams to improve fish habitat, they remain controversial and little data exists on their effectiveness for species such as Chinook or interior Columbia River steelhead (Roni et al. 2008; Roni et al. 2013). This controversy likely stems from the lack of evaluation, and lack of documentation of effects on factors directly limiting habitat quality (Roni et al. 2005). Calls to better evaluate habitat improvement projects began in the early 1980s (Reeves and Roelofs 1982), and continued throughout the 1990s (Reeves et al. 1991; Chapman 1996; Kauffman et al. 1997). The need for additional effectiveness monitoring and evaluation is widely apparent in the Pacific Northwest.

More than 600 instream habitat improvement projects have been funded and implemented since 2004 through the Northwest Power and Conservation Council’s (NWPCC) Fish and Wildlife (F&W) Program implemented by the Bonneville Power Administration (Roni et al. 2014).  In addition, many more actions are being planned for implementation from 2016 to 2018 as part of the Biological Opinion. To evaluate the success of these and other habitat improvement actions under the F&W Program, BPA developed a programmatic approach to evaluate each of the five major habitat improvement categories (fish passage, instream structures, off-channel/floodplain, riparian, sediment reduction/addition/ and acquisition/protection) (Roni et al. 2014).

In this document, we outline the detailed monitoring plan for programmatic action effectiveness monitoring (AEM) of instream habitat improvement projects. This includes the monitoring goals and questions, the study design, sample size (spatial and temporal replication), parameters (metrics), protocols for data collection, data analysis, and the expected results (Roni et al. 2005). We focus on AEM of three categories of instream habitat improvement 1) LWD and boulders designed to improve habitat complexity, 2) ELJs, and 3) bank stabilization.  LWD and boulder placement typically occur together so they are included as one action type. Bank stabilization monitoring is outlined in a separate protocol (ID: 2232).

This protocol is based on the Washington Salmon Recovery Funding Board  (SRFB) protocol, “SRFB - Monitoring Effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects” (ID: 35) (https://www.monitoringmethods.org/Protocol/Details/35); however, variations in the design and metrics collected required modification of the protocol. This document details the monitoring design and procedures necessary to document and report reach scale effectiveness of projects treating:

·         Salmonid Rearing Capacity

·        Stream Complexity

·         Log and Rock Control weirs

·         Channel Reconfiguration

·         Woody Debris

This protocol replaces protocol #1871.
objectives: Determine if local juvenile fish density is different between treatment and control reaches.
LWD and ELJ - Determine if the complexity of the channel is different between treatment and control reaches.
LWD and ELJ - Determine if there is a difference in the volume of functional wood between treatment and control reaches
LWD and ELJ - Determine if pool frequency, area and depth and pool/riffle ratio differ between treatment and control reaches.
Determine distribution of habitat types within the reach.
Is fish response to LWD placement related to difference in habitat quality (e.g., functional LWD, pool frequency, variation in depth, stream channel slope) among sites?
Are there differences among regions (Chinook salmon evolutionary significant units or ESUs) in physical and biological response to LWD placement?
2235.assumptions: Access will be provided to impact and suitable control reaches.

2235.title: BPA EPT Monitoring Effectiveness of Instream Habitat Projects (ELJs/LWD/Boulders)

2236.background: The purpose of this protocol is to combine two existing protocols under BPA's Action Effectiveness Monitoring Program: Protocol for Monitoring Off-Channel/Floodplain Projects (ID: 2231) and Protocol for Monitoring Bank Stabilization Projects (ID: 2232). A combined protocol facilitates the monitoring of restoration projects that have both floodplain and bank stabilization project actions. Please refer to the background sections of each individual protocol for detailed information on the background and rationale of each, since space is limited here.
objectives: Determine the pre-project topography of the floodplain and channel bed (Year -2 and -1)
Map habitat area by habitat type (turbulent, non-turbulent, edge) (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the proportion of slow water habitat at various flows through mapping or modeling (<0.15m/s (Beechie 2005) (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the value of the River Complexity Index (Brown 2002), braid-channel ratio, and sinuosity (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the ratio of floodplain area to channel area (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the variation (standard deviation) in residual depth and channel size (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine inundated floodplain area (length2)/channel length (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the proportion of each habitat type relative to total area (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the channel migration rate (between survey years, or with aerial photos) (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine secondary production (benthic macroinvertebrates) by habitat type (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the relative fish abundance by habitat, season, species and life stage (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Determine the presence of fish species by season (Years -2, -1, 1, 3, 5, and 10)
Develop predictive model for inundation of off-channel habitat (Years 1, 3, 5, and 10)

images.caption: Figure 10.  How to number channel segments within a site. The main channel is assigned segment 1 throughout the site. Both large and small side channels are assigned sequential segment numbers working upstream. In the figure, channel segment numbers are preceded with a “S” (S1-S3) and channel unit numbers with a “U” (U1-13).

Figure 01. Examples of benchmark spacing.Optimally placed benchmarks are as far apart as possible, whilke still maintaining an equilateral triangle, are inter-visible, and extent the length of the site. Poorly place benchmarks are close in proximity and in a non-equilateral triangle (CHaMP 2013).
Figure 02.  Example of a good site overview photo.  Photo captures the stream as well as the surrounding riparian area and floodplain.

Figure 03. Example of a good repeat photo.  Photo captures both sides of the stream as well as the woody debris in the foreground.  The trees are also lined up in the exact location as the previous year’s photo.

2236.title: BPA MBACI Protocol for Monitoring the Effectiveness of Off-Channel Habitat / Floodplain Enhancement and Bank Stabilization Projects

2242.background:
The Nez Perce Tribe's (NPT) Department of Fisheries Resources Management (DFRM) utilizes rotary screw traps (RSTs) as a collection tool for capturing and marking naturally- and artificially-produced anadromous juvenile salmonids.  The RST’s are operated by NPT staff throughout various portions of the Snake River Basin.  Information obtained from the captured fish are used to estimate population abundance, survival, and life history characteristics, which in turn are used to inform hatchery effectiveness and status and trends evaluations. The juvenile sampling design consists of a combination of comparative performance testing (treatment vs. natural), small-scale experiments, and population status monitoring to address management objectives and answer questions fundamental to salmonid recovery in the Clearwater, Snake and Salmon subbasins. Data obtained from the operation of RSTs is also used to calculate smolt performance characteristics, provide over-winter survival estimates, and life stage specific survival estimates, smolt-to-adult survival rates and recruit per spawner metrics. They also provide a means to calculate Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) and steelhead (O. mykiss) juvenile emigration timing and travel from tributary specific areas to Snake and Columbia dams. Population status and trend monitoring of natural and hatchery origin fish is used for effective population management, assessing effectiveness of conservation actions, viability, and recovery metric monitoring.

Please see protocols #2248 and #2249 for data analysis methods describing the calculation of metrics and indicators.
objectives: Obtain life stage-specific estimates of abundance, survival and life history characteristics.
Obtain life stage-specific estimates of emigration timing.
Obtain life stage-specific estimates of travel time from tributary specific areas to Snake and Columbia River dams.
Use collected data to calculate smolt-to-adult survival rates.

Use collected data to estimate performance measures to monitor population status, viability and trends, assess hatchery and habitat conservation effectiveness and progress towards population recovery.
2242.assumptions:
1. Juvenile screw traps effectively allows us to test quantifiable hypotheses as they relate to our monitoring and evaluation objectives.
  2. Trap efficiency estimates accurately reflect the true proportion of the captured emigrating population and provide valid total abundance estimates.

2243.background:
The Nez Perce Tribe's Department of Fisheries Resources Management utilizes seining (boat and shore based) as a collection tool for capturing and marking juvenile salmonids for determination of survival, growth, and life history characteristics. Data are utilized for hatchery effectiveness and status and trends evaluations. The juvenile sampling design consists of a combination of comparative performance testing and population status monitoring to address management objectives and answer questions fundamental to salmonid recovery.  Population status and trend monitoring of natural and hatchery origin fish is used for effective population management, assessing effectiveness of conservation actions, viability, and recovery metric monitoring.

Please see protocols #2248, #2249, #2250 and #2215 for data analysis methods describing the calculations of metrics and indicators.
objectives: Collect juvenile salmonid data, from seining (boat and shore) with a capture and marking program for determination of survival, growth and life history characteristics.
Provide a means to calculate natural Chinook salmon emigration timing and survival to Snake and Columbia river dams.
Collect data to monitor and evaluate the acclimated releases of juvenile fall Chinook salmon in the Snake River basin.
2243.assumptions: Collected fish are randomly sampled and represent the un-caught population.

2245.background:
The Nez Perce Tribe's Department of Fisheries Resources Management utilize dual frequency identification sonar (DIDSON) and underwater video technology as a passive collection tool for salmon abundance and productivity monitoring in the Snake River Basin. Data are utilized for determination of abundance, survival and life history characteristics, hatchery effectiveness and status and trends evaluations.  Population status and trend monitoring of natural and hatchery origin fish is used for effective population management, assessing effectiveness of conservation actions, viability, and recovery metric monitoring.

Please see protocols #2246 and #2249 for data analysis methods describing the calculation of metrics and indicators.
objectives: Operate adult weirs to encompass the entire adult runs of anadromous adult salmonids.
Collect adult salmonid data, from DIDSON for determination of adult abundance, natural, hatchery, and stray composition.
Collect adult salmonid data, from underwater video for determination of adult abundance, natural, hatchery, and stray composition.
2245.assumptions: Application of DIDSON sonar assumes that the entire water column is ensonified, which is verified through use of calibration targets.

2247.background:
The Nez Perce Tribe's Department of Fisheries Resources Management utilizes in-stream adult picket weirs as a tool for capturing, marking, and collecting biological data on returning adult runs of anadromous salmon and steelhead (e.g., Chinook and Coho salmon).  Weirs also enable the implementation of management sliding scales.  Collected data are utilized in estimating abundance, survival and life history characteristics, and evaluating hatchery effectiveness and population status and trends.  Population status and trend monitoring of natural and hatchery origin fish is critical to effective population management, assessing effectiveness of conservation actions and population viability, and evaluating recovery metrics.

Please see protocols #2246 and #2249 for data analysis methods describing the calculation of metrics and indicators.
objectives: Trap entire returning adult runs of anadromous salmonids.
Calculate Chinook salmon and steelhead natural and hatchery adult abundance, survival and life history characteristics.
Determine natural, hatchery, and stray composition, obtain broodstock, mark fish for mark-recapture abundance methods or assess movement and distribution via radio telemetry.
Manage returns with an agreed upon sliding scale to implement pass/keep scenarios

2255.background:
The Nez Perce Tribe's Department of Fisheries Resources Management utilize spawning ground surveys to gather information from returning anadromous adult salmonids (e.g. Chinook salmon, steelhead, Coho salmon).  Information is used for life history, abundance and productivity monitoring in the Snake River Basin. Data are utilized for hatchery effectiveness and status and trends evaluations.  Population status and trend monitoring of natural and hatchery origin fish is used for effective population management, assessing effectiveness of conservation actions, viability, and recovery metric monitoring.

Please see protocols #2246, #2249 and #2250 for data analysis methods describing the calculation of metrics and indicators.
objectives: Obtain an index of spawner abundance (i.e. observed redds)
Determine spatial distribution of spawners
Determine temporal distribution of spawners
Obtain life history characteristics of spawners (i.e. age, sex, origin)
Recover carcasses for genetic studies
Recover carcasses for mark/recapture studies
2255.assumptions:
1. All redds are enumerated.

2. Females build one redd.

3. Carcasses are collected randomly and represent the unobserved individuals.

2255.title: Nez Perce Tribe Spawning Ground Survey Data Collection

2256.background:
Project staff will assist Lyons Ferry and Tucannon FH staffs with broodstock collection, spawning activities (collection of biological samples, recording mating crosses, estimation of eggs taken, etc..) and documenting survivals in the hatchery based on data provided from the hatchery staff. Project and hatchery staff will spawn broodstock using a 1x2 or 2x2 spawning matrix. Crosses between individuals will be documented by project staff to ensure that all fish collected for broodstock contribute to the next generation when possible. 
 
Incubation of eggs allows for fecundity monitoring by age class. WDFW LSRCP staff have tracked fecundity of female steelhead by stock since 2000 to document any changes over time that could be attributed to hatchery practices. Eggs are picked at the eyed stage, with mortality to eye-up determined by the number of dead eggs picked from each female's egg lot. Live eggs are determined by an egg counter. Additional mortality occurs prior to hatching, which is also determined. 
 
Project staff will also sample juvenile summer steelhead when necessary, or when requested by hatchery staff, for tag/mark retention or size at release sampling prior to release. Project staff will report tag/mark retention and size at release in annual reports, and will use this information in hatchery program evaluations. Project staff will consolidate all appropriate data collected while fish are in the hatchery (it is anticipated that the information will inform the recommendations made to hatchery and fish management staff for changes in the program).
objectives: Provide support and perform hatchery effectiveness monitoring and evaluation to adaptively manage Nez Perce Tribe hatchery programs.
Provide support and perform critical uncertainty analysis research for action effectiveness.

2258.background:
The Nez Perce Tribe's Department of Fisheries Resources Management utilize radio telemetry to gather information from returning anadromous adult salmonids (e.g. Chinook salmon and steelhead).  Information is used compare the relative performance of hatchery (supplementation and conventional) and natural origin steelhead with the focus on adult distribution (above and below barriers), and evaluation of the fidelity of adults to their natal stream of origin. Data are utilized for determination of abundance, survival and life history characteristics, hatchery effectiveness and status and trends evaluations.  Population status and trend monitoring of natural and hatchery origin fish is used for effective population management, assessing effectiveness of conservation actions, viability, and recovery metric monitoring. 

Please see protocols #2250 for data anlaysis methods describing the calculation of metrics and indicators.
objectives: Determine adult return fidelity to natal stream of origin.
Determine spatial overlap in the spawning distribution of natural, supplementation and conventional adults (above and below barriers)
Compare the relative performance of supplementation and conventional hatchery steelhead and salmon

2260.background:
The Upper Mississippi River System (UMRS) provides habitat to a wide array of fish and wildlife species distributed among a complex assortment of flowing channels, floodplain lakes, backwaters, wetlands, and floodplain forests. In ecosystems as diverse and complex as the UMRS, many processes and their interrelationships are not well known. Long-term monitoring is perhaps most effective means—and in some cases, the only means—by which large, complex ecosystems such as the UMRS can be studied and managed.

As Long Term Resource Monitoring Program (LTRMP) databases have matured in scope and accumulated more years’ worth of data, their utility in research and management in the UMRS basin has increased notably. Today, the LTRMP’s data assets represent one of the world’s largest and most extensive datasets on a great river.

Fishes were chosen as a key ecological component to be monitored by the long term monitoring program of the Upper Mississippi River because of their economic importance to the region, conservation potential, and their utility for assessing the ecological integrity of the UMRS aquatic ecosystem (Jackson et al. 1981, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service 1992). Fisheries data, thus collected, are used to quantify the status and trends of fish populations and communities (U.S. Geological Survey 1999; Johnson and Hagerty 2008), fisheries data are used to identify relations with various other ecological attributes (Barko and Herzog 2003; Barko et al. 2004; Koel 2004; Barko et al. 2005; Chick et al. 2005; Ickes et al. 2005; Barko et al. 2006; Kirby and Ickes 2006; Irons et al. 2007; Knights et al. 2008; Irons et al. 2009; Garvey et al. 2010; Dukerschein et al. 2011; McCain et al. 2011), and fisheries data are used to address fisheries management concerns in a multiuse, large river resource (U.S. Geological Survey 1999).

Herein, information is presented on the most current procedures and the rationale for monitoring nearly one-fifth of the entire North American freshwater fish fauna (representing the greatest freshwater fish diversity on the planet at temperate latitudes). The strategies employed for data collection and site selection as well as the uses for LTRMP data are also included.
objectives: To coordinate and standardize methods, procedures, and field behaviors in the execution of long-term monitoring.
Aims toward gaining data that is scientifically valid, comparable over time, and comparable over space.
2260.assumptions:
At the “systemic” UMRS scale, representing the LTRMP’s legislative domain (all navigable reaches of the UMRS), each of the study reaches is representative of proximate navigation pools.

Because over the past 20 years the LTRMP has observed 144 fish species and many additional hybrids. The LTRMP has gained requisite information to achieve absolute abundance or density estimates across all design elements, time, sampling methods, and species. The LTRMP fisheries component makes the necessary simplifying assumption that indexed abundance reflects changes in true abundance over time.

2260.title: Upper Mississippi River Long Term Resource Monitoring

2264.background:
Coded wire tags (cwt) can be an excellent way to monitor the life history and behavior of hatchery population.  Summer/fall Chinook released in the Okanogan River Basin (through the Similkameen Program operated by WDFW and the Chief Joseph Hatchery Program operated by the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Indian Reservation) are fitted with coded wire tags that can be extracted, read, and uploaded to the Regional Mark Processing Center (RMPC) cwt database for later analysis and interpretation of data.

Three things the Chief Joseph Hatchery Monitoring and Evaluation Program monitors are 

  1. The estimated genetic contribution of hatchery-origin Okanogan-released Chinook to other, nontarget basin spawning populations for a given brood year
  2. The estimated genetic contribution of hatchery-origin non-Okanogan-released Chinook to the Okanogan River Basin spawning population for a given brood year
  3. The overall stray rate of hatchery-origin, Okanogan-released Chinook for a given brood year.

Monitoring these helps to monitor the flow of hatchery-origin genes throughout the Upper Columbia Basin and inform hatchery management decisions.

 

Carcasses are collected within the Okangaon River Basin from September through November annually (see Method 5490), and coded wire tags are extracted, read, and submitted to RMIS from November through February.  Once coded wire tag data for all Upper Columbia River Basins has been made publicly available on RMIS, the queries for retrieving and analyzing coded wire tag data are carried out, typically annually in April.

 

Calculating the estimated genetic contribution of Okanogan River Basin hatchery-origin summer/fall Chinook to out-of-basin spwaning populaitons and calculating the rate of Okanogan River in-to-basin summer/fall hatchery-origin stray Chinook are queries that are run annually.  Calculating the brood year out-of-basin stray rate is performed after the cycle for a given brood year is complete - for example, all of the returns from brood year 2010 should be complete by 2016, so that is the year in which the estimate is calculated. Queries are repeated and these calculations are updated annually to include any revisions or additions the the RMIS data set (i.e. more coded wire tags are submitted and added to the RMIS database).
objectives: Examine, through analysis of cwt data, life history patterns of hatchery-origin summer/fall Chinook Salmon, specifically homing and stray rates to and from the Okanogan River Basin.
2264.assumptions:
All hatchery-origin summer/fall Chinook on a spawning ground have an equal chance of recovery

All deciphered tags are read correctly

RMPC provided estimates of fish numbers are correct

Spawning escapement estimates for a given basin are correct

2266.background:
The Chief Joseph Hatchery Program (CJHP) collects late arriving brood from the CJH ladder and Okanogan River Adult Weir for the integrated program.  In order to determine whether Chinook from other stocks, specifically the Priest Rapids Hatchery fall Chinook, the program collects otoliths from all ladder and weir brood.  The Priest Rapids Hatchery fall Chinook have been thermally marked since run year 2008.  The management questions that are addressed include:

1.) Are unmarked Priest Rapids Hatchery fall Chinook included in the late collected brood?

2.) What is the abundance and proportion of Priest Rapids Hatchery fall Chinook in the CJH ladder?

Lab analyses (Volk et al. 1994) on the otolith from the late broodstock collections will indicate whether a thermal mark is present.  If a thermal mark is present then it would be considered a Priest Rapids Hatchery fall Chinook.  If Priest Rapids Hatchery fall Chinook are collected and included in the broodstock at the time of spawning, then eggs from the female would be culled or included in the CJH segregated program.  The segregated program is released from CJH directly into the Columbia River and adult returns are targeted exclusively for harvest.  For more information regarding the lab analysis methods please see the Literature cited section in this protocol.
objectives: Identify CJH ladder and weir brood at the time of spawning
Sample and collect otolith from all ladder and weir collected brood
Obtain results from WDFW lab, analyze number and proportion of PRD fall Chinook in broodstock and cull those eggs associated with PRD brood
2266.assumptions: Our frame is representative of our target population. We plan to collect at least 100 otoliths.

2267.background:
The ISEMP is a collaborative effort to 1) design, test, implement and evaluate Status and Trends Monitoring for salmon and steelhead populations and their habitat and 2) conduct watershed-scale Effectiveness Monitoring for management actions impacting salmon and steelhead populations and habitat in the Interior Columbia River Basin. ISEMP takes a pilot-project approach to the research and development of monitoring by implementing experimental programs in several major subbasins of the Interior Columbia.

To achieve these goals, population-specific and aggregate estimates of juvenile abundance and survival are necessary. These metrics will be estimated using information from the recapture of juveniles that are PIT tagged during remote tagging surveys or at rotary screw traps. Recapture data for tagged individuals will be obtained interrogations at Instream PIT Tag Detection Systems (IPTDS) and from recapture at rotary screw traps. ISEMP operated rotary screw traps in the South Fork Salmon and Lemhi rivers to estimate juvenile abundance and survival in those sub-basins.

The multiple locations and variable scale nature of this goal requires the standardization of protocols and sampling designs that are statistically valid and powerful. This protocol aims to 1) provide standardization of trapping and fish handling methods among rotary screw traps operated by ISEMP, and 2) provide a brief description of trap efficiency and juvenile abundance estimation methods using rotary screw traps.

This monitoring protocol is a component of the overall ISEMP, and while it stands alone as an important contribution to the management of anadromous salmonids and their habitat, it also plays a key role within ISEMP as it is built on a standardized format following Oakley et al. (2003) that all of the ISEMP protocols adhere to. Downstream migrant trapping of juvenile salmonids can be a valuable tool to estimate abundance, production, size, survival, migration timing and behavior (Volkhardt et al. 2007). Of significance to status, trend and effectiveness monitoring programs, simple mark-recapture methods can be used with downstream migrant traps to estimate total freshwater production, and enable the estimation of survival (and mortality) between life stages (e.g., egg-to-smolt).
objectives: Provide standardization of trapping and fish handling protocols among rotary screw traps operated by ISEMP in the South Fork Salmon and Lemhi rivers
Indirectly, estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead survival (egg-to-smolt)
Estimate juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead emigration abundance at ISEMP rotary screw traps
Estimate trap efficiency for juvenile Chinook salmon and steelhead at ISEMP rotary screw traps
2267.assumptions:
Regarding efficiency estimates:

  1. Rotary screw traps are function properly (when not attended) on intended trapping days
  2. Mortality of marked and unmarked individuals is equal
  3. Marked individuals retain their marks (tags) and all tags are detected upon recapture
  4. Marked individuals are captured at the same rate as unmarked individuals (no trap avoidance or happiness)
  5. Marked individuals mix randomly among unmarked individuals
  6. Marked individuals are representative of the entire target population for which abundance and survival will be estimated

Moreover, we assume that trap efficiency estimates accurately reflect the true proportion of the captured emigrating population.

2269.background: Scales are collected from natural-origin adult broodstock to determine the age structure of the brood that are propagated for the Chief Joseph Hatchery integrated program.  Samples are sent to a lab on scale cards with appropriate biological information (species, date, length, mark,  status).  Results for individual fish will include age and natural (wild) or hatchery classification. A summary of the results will inform hatchery managers on the age composition of hatchery broodstock and performance standards for the integrated program.

2271.background:
Net primary production is a fundamental ecological process that reflects the amount of carbon synthesized within an ecosystem which is ultimately available to consumers (Davies, Bunn, and Hamilton 2008). By selecting the appropriate environmental variables in a watershed system, gross primary production (GPP) may be calculated in stream ecosystems, predicting food consumption by a variety of aquatic species. Used as an input in a bioenergetics model, it can aid in making spatially-explicit predictions regarding habitat needs and capacity. Preliminary GPP model development work by Eco Logical Research, Inc. (ELR) has shown promising results using temperature, solar insolation, and electrical conductivity as model inputs for GPP predictions for steelhead populations. This protocol describes the methods for operating the ArcGIS toolsets to calculate solar insolation and electrical conductivity within a watershed’s stream network.

Solar insolation directly affects stream temperature (Sinokrot and Stefan, 1993) and the primary productivity of streams (Fisher and Likens, 1973; Hill et al., 1995). Work to date has explored using area solar insolation for the solar input parameter. ELR has developed a preliminary workflow for predicting solar insolation for a stream network, summarizing the average upstream solar insolation values (watt hours per square meter, WH/m²) per 200-meter stream segments.  South Fork Research, Inc. (SFR) is improving this method and automating the solar insolation modeling process through the development of ArcGIS Python tools. Accuracy of solar results were validated using field data collected using SunEye, described in the Solar Input v2.0 Methods associated with this protocol (Bouwes et al. 2011).

Electrical conductivity has been shown to be a potential indicator of aquatic macroinvertebrate species richness (Spieles and Mitsch 2000, Brown, Hannah et al. 2007) and also can influence faunal life stages (Tarín and Cano 2000). By incorporating a previously developed electrical conductivity predictive model (Olson and Hawkins 2012), we built an automated workflow for predicting conductivity for a stream network, summarizing predicted upstream conductivity values (μS cm-1) per 1000-meter stream segments.
objectives: Summarize predicted upstream conductivity values (µS cm-1) per 1000-meter stream segments for HUC4 watersheds.
Summarize the average upstream solar insolation values (watt hours per square meter, WH/m2) per 200-meter stream segments for HUC4 watersheds.
Generate and compile solar insolation and electrical conductivity outputs for use in a gross primary production (GPP) model.
