2274.background:
This protocol presents methods and guidelines to persons sampling fishes in a large watershed along the main channel of a major river, to help ensure consistency in fish handling, fish tagging, and data collection among different projects and organizations. This document is intended to provide guidance to fieldworkers regarding methods and procedures that may vary from year to year depending on specific projects and objectives. Methods and changes to these methods have been documented since the Fall of 2002, and will continue to be refined each year if necessary.

Monitoring for native and nonnative fish occurs throughout the our sample reach on the main stem of the Colorado River, the Colorado River tributaries, and the Lees Ferry tailwater reach. Attached is a map depicting the extent of the monitoring area. Little Colorado  River sampling is opportunistic, but population estimates typically occur during a spring and fall trip each year. For the mainstem Colorado River and Lees Ferry, sampling is conducted throughout the year but with a larger effort in spring and fall. 

All fish data collected was done by trained professionals. The collected fish data is kept in a large database that is housed at the Grand Canyon Monitoring Research Center in Flagstaff, AZ. All data for the Colorado River used in this protocol was obtained from this database.
objectives: Determine the abundance, life stage, feeding habits, and general health of each fish species in our study reach.
Provide guidance to fieldworkers regarding procedures and methods that may vary from year to year depending on specific projects and objectives.
Provide documentation of standard methods used in the Grand Canyon that can be cited in scientific publications.
2274.assumptions:
All fish data collected was done by trained professionals.

The collected fish data is kept in a large database that is housed at the Grand Canyon Monitoring Research Center in Flagstaff, AZ. All data for the Colorado River used in this protocol was obtained from this database.

3274.background: Wild emigrating juvenile Snake River steelhead and spring-summer Chinook Salmon are sampled at Lower Granite Dam to estimate their abundance and composition at the Evolutionary Significant Unit (ESU) scale and by genetic stock through Genetic Stock Identification (GSI). Monitoring the abundance and composition of juvenile emigrants allows us to describe current status and trends in survival and productivity of the ESU. Additionally, decomposing these metrics by genetic stock allows us to compare and contrast population performance over time among Snake River basin populations (Camacho et al. 2019). Furthermore, Parentage-Based Tagging (PBT) analysis is conducted to exclude adipose-intact hatchery adults not detected with a CWT to ensure only truly wild returning fish are examined. Data are collected by IDFG, personnel from the smolt monitoring program, and contracted agencies cooperatively and are used in stock assessment analyses. The results are valuable for assessing stock status and the impact of habitat, harvest, hatchery, and hydrosystem management actions.
objectives: Sample natural/wild emigrating juvenile Snake River steelhead and spring-summer Chinook Salmon at Lower Granite Dam.
Estimate abundance, productivity, survival, and composition (age structure, sex, and genetic stock) of natural/wild emigrating juvenile Snake River steelhead and spring-summer Chinook Salmon ESUs.
3274.assumptions: The juvenile bypass system allows representative sampling of the smolt emigration.

3277.background:
This protocol was developed to assess current conditions or to track temporal and spatial trends in specific water quality metrics at point locations or throughout a watershed.  This protocol can be employed throughout the year at various levels of stream flow, depending on what the objectives are for the individual/organization.  For example, this protocol can be used to assess current water quality conditions, track changes within a year, or from year to year.  Our program tracks water quality throughout the Hangman Creek watershed at a total of 25 sites.  These sites are distributed throughout the mainstem and tributaries of the upper Hangman Creek watershed; SF Hangman Creek, Indian Creek, Smith Creek, Nehchen Creek, Sheep Creek, and Mission Creek.

Beaver can have a large influence on stream function as well as on habitat for various aquatic species.  In order to gain a better understanding of this and how water quality metrics may differ from adjacent free-flowing stream habitat, our program will take opportunistic water quality measurements throughout the vertical profile of a beaver pond.  This typically takes place at or near the deepest location within the beaver pond and data is gathered at 1-foot intervals.
objectives: To obtain water quality metrics within a watershed to assess current conditions or monitor trends over time for a represented stream reach.
Obtain water quality metrics (dissolved oxygen and temperature) throughout the vertical profile of pool(s) created by beaver.

3278.background: The status and trend of migratory salmonid populations can be monitored by tracking the number of outmigrating juveniles at either the tributary or watershed scale.  Monitoring annual numbers of outmigrating juveniles permits the tracking of watershed-wide trajectories in juvenile production, and aids in the assessment of the collective in-stream population response to prospective restoration actions (Bradford et al. 2005).  In our streams, we chose to use a rotary screw trap to capture juvenile outmigrants that would provide data on their abundance, size at outmigration, and their timing at outmigration.  The rotary screw trap also permits the PIT-tagging of large numbers of juveniles within an outmigrant cohort.  PIT-tagged fish are used in trap efficiency trials and in analyses of smolt-to-adult return rates.  Since 2013, a single rotary screw trap has been used in each of the Lake and Benewah creek watersheds of the Coeur d'Alene basin to intercept and obtain demographic information on migratory westslope cutthroat trout.
objectives: PIT-tag juvenile outmigrating salmonids to enable prospective return rate analyses.
Examine and track changes in the distribution of outmigration times for juvenile salmonids at the tributary or watershed scale.
Examine and track the size of outmigrating juvenile salmonids at the tributary or watershed scale.
Estimate the annual abundance of outmigrating juvenile salmonids within a tributary or watershed.
3278.assumptions:
Assumptions are associated with trap efficiency release trials that are used to generate outmigrant abundance:

1. Release trial marked fish remain alive until they are available to be recaptured.

2. Marked fish retain their marks and are observable upon recapture.

3. Marked and unmarked fish are captured at similar rates.

4. Marked fish mix with unmarked fish prior to recapture.

The following assumptions are associated with trapped juvenile outmigrants in general:

1. Captured fish are representative (e.g., size, timing) of the population of interest.

3279.background: Examining the diversity of seasonal and life-history behaviors of salmonids in monitored watersheds will improve the understanding of in-stream habitat use and production of the migratory life-history variant.  Monitoring in-stream movement patterns will provide data on seasonal habitats used (e.g., overwintering), and could aid in evaluating the response to restorative actions implemented to improve the quality of seasonal habitats.  Monitoring the propensity of juvenile salmonids to move out of natal, stream habitats and into larger bodies of water (e.g., larger rivers, lake) and monitoring the spatial distribution of spawning adults returning from these larger bodies of water will identify tributaries within watersheds that support the migratory life-history strategy.  Understanding the current spatial distribution of the migratory life-history variant may aid in prioritizing future restoration efforts.  Half-duplex (i.e., HDX) passive integrated transponder (i.e., PIT) technology is being implemented across projects of the Coeur d'Alene Tribe's fisheries program to monitor seasonal and life-history movements of targeted salmonids.  In the upper Hangman Creek watershed, stationary PIT arrays have been installed to monitor movements of migratory redband trout.  In the Coeur d'Alene basin, stationary PIT arrays have been installed in the upper Benewah and Lake creek watersheds to monitor movements of migratory westslope cutthroat trout.  This protocol is intended to be used for each of these two projects.
objectives: Use interrogation data from stationary PIT arrays to describe the spatial distribution of the migratory life-history variant within watersheds.
Create interrogation histories for individual PIT tagged fish to evaluate seasonal movements within watersheds.
3279.assumptions:
1.  PIT tagged fish and their patterns of movement represent the population from which they were sampled and tagged.

2  Series of stationary PIT antenna arrays within watersheds operate at sufficient efficiency to confidently generate conclusions regarding seasonal and life-history movements within watersheds.

3280.background: Summer rearing temperatures have been considered to be a primary factor in explaining distributional patterns of resident forms of inland species of trout (Dunham et al. 1999; Paul and Post 2001; Sloat et al. 2001; de la Hoz Franco and Budy 2005).  Similarly, in watersheds of interest to the Coeur d'Alene Tribe, inland salmonids have consistently been found at higher densities in cooler, higher-elevation tributary reaches than in warmer lower elevation mainstem reaches throughout the summer.  Many of the restorative actions that have been implemented by the Tribe's Fisheries Program in mainstem reaches, such as channel modifications to increase pool formation and riparian re-vegetation, have addressed these sub-optimal summer water temperatures.  Given that high summer water temperatures have been considered to be a major factor limiting trout production, stream temperatures are monitored annually in tribal watersheds to track changes over time and to examine responses to restoration measures.  Water temperatures are currently being monitored in tributaries and mainstem reaches in the Hangman Creek watershed, which supports a metapopulation of fluvial redband trout, and in the Benewah Creek and Lake Creek watersheds, which both support metapopulations of adfluvial westslope cutthroat trout.
objectives: Track changes in water temperature metrics over time to evaluate if restoration actions implemented in mainstem habitats are improving summer rearing thermal conditions for trout.
Monitor surface stream temperatures throughout the year in both tributary and mainstem reaches to provide profiles of continuous water temperature.
Collect air temperatures in representative reaches of a watershed to provide reference data to which the  water temperatures can be compared.
3280.assumptions:
1. The temperature recorded by a data logger at a stream location is representative of the water in that reach of the stream.

2.  Temperature data loggers retain their calibration so that they are accurately recording the true stream temperature.

3.  Data loggers are located in well-mixed zones of the stream so that they are capturing the ambient surface temperature (e.g., not positioned at the stream bottom where they may be either unduly influenced by groundwater input or represent conditions in a stratified pool).

4.  Temperature changes that have occurred due to restorative actions (e.g., planting that increase stream shading) will be captured by the dataloggers.

5.  During low flow periods, the logger does not get de-watered.

3281.background: Studies have found certain measurable habitat attributes in stream reaches are linked with the quality of in-stream rearing habitat for salmonids (Bjornn and Reiser 1991; Rosenfeld et al. 2000).  Our program chose to monitor four of these in-stream habitat attributes, which include pool metrics (e.g., percent pool, mean residual pool depth), large woody debris (LWD) frequency, percent fines in substrate and pool tail-outs, and mean bankfull width.  In addition, our program also chose to monitor percent canopy cover, which can be considered an attribute that describes the condition of riparian habitat.  Percent canopy cover was chosen because it provides an indirect measure of the amount of shading over a stream which is a factor contributing to thermal loading in a stream reach.  Furthermore, the reason that these attributes were chosen is that most of these are responsive to habitat restoration actions that are implemented to improve stream habitat.  For example, restorative actions implemented to address sediment delivery from hydrologically-connected roads or to improve the stability of erodible banks should lead to a decrease in the percentage of fine materials deposited in riffle and tail-pool habitats.  As another example, LWD additions in stream habitats are often implemented to increase the frequency and percent of pool habitat for salmonids.  In addition, measuring canopy cover should be able to address whether riparian re-vegetation efforts are successfully reducing solar input on the stream.  This protocol is intended to be implemented across watersheds of interest to the Coeur d'Alene Tribe in which habitat restoration actions are being implemented to improve the quality of in-stream rearing habitat for redband trout and westslope cutthroat trout.
objectives: Track changes in riparian and in-stream habitat attributes in a representative sample of stream sites after channel restoration activities have been implemented.
Determine the status of riparian and in-stream habitat attributes in a representative sample of stream sites prior to projected channel restoration activities.
Collect habitat data at representative proximate control sites to evaluate if changes detected in restored stream reaches are due to the treatments.
3281.assumptions:
1. The status of habitat attributes in the sampled reach prior to restoration is representative of the condition of the stream habitat throughout the reach that is projected to be restored.

2. The change in habitat attributes measured in the sampled reach after restoration actions have been implemented is representative of the average change in these same attributes over the entire length of the restored section of stream.

3.  Habitat attributes in control sites in untreated reaches are not unduly affected by other unintended actions that do not influence attributes in treated reaches.

4. Changes in measured habitat attributes in treated stream reaches can be detected after the treatment has been implemented.

3282.background: Otolith microchemical analysis is a technique used in fisheries managment to delineate stocks and characterize movements and natal origin of various fish species. The concentrations of elements and isotopes in otoliths or other bony structures are compared to those in the water in which the fish inhabited in order to identify where it has been. Otoliths record specific isotope ratios that can remain stable irrespective of variation in elemental concentration. Strontium isotope ratios, for example, are substantially related to the age of the rocks in the surrounding watershed due to the decay of 87Rb into 87Sr. Thus, older rocks tend to be more radiogenic with higher 87Sr/86Sr values, which in turn influence the water and otolith isotope ratios. Isotopes of other elements such as lead also vary due to radiogenic origin, but also as a result of anthropogenic sources (e.g. industrial processes).
objectives: Use otolith micro chemistry to determine Northern Pike origin and general movements
3282.assumptions: Water chemistry throughout the basin is different enough to detect changes in isotope ratios.

3283.background:
Stream channel incision is one cause of riparian zone degradation in the arid western United States. Channel incision may be initiated by factors such as major floods, changes in sediment regimes, urban development, and channelization (Rosgen, 1997). As the stream bed becomes progressively deeper, the channel can contain large peak flows and the stream can no longer dissipate energy, water, and materials across its former floodplains (Simon and Rinaldi, 2006). This reduces the area for surface water and groundwater exchange, and aquifer infiltration and water table elevation decline (Brunke and Gonser, 1997). Therefore, streambed degradation is associated with reduced groundwater recharge, reduced reliability and consistency of baseflow, and damaged hyporheic zone connections (Brunke and Gonser, 1997; Cluer and Thorne, 2014). Riparian vegetation that relies on high water tables may also be undercut or stressed (Scott et al., 1999; Shafroth et al., 2000). Ultimately, this impairs stream channel habitat by isolating it from the floodplain, limiting nutrient cycling, and increasing water temperatures (due to lack of shade and poor hyporheic exchange), with negative effects on both in-stream and riparian biota (reviewed in Brunke and Gonser, 1997; Cluer and Thorne, 2014).

Channel incision may be mitigated if beaver return and build dams on streams (Pollock et al., 2007). Pollock et al. (2014) describe how beaver dams can greatly accelerate the channel recovery process by promoting trench widening and aggradation. Beaver dams are an integral part of the restoration strategy currently underway in Hangman Creek and Benewah Creek, two streams located on the Coeur d'Alene Tribe reservation, where channel incision has limited habitat quantity and quality for populations of native interior redband trout and westslope cutthroat trout, respectively.  Several restoration techniques have been implemented in both these streams to improve stability of beaver dam complexes.  In upper Hangman creek, un-incised relict meanders have been re-activated and incised channels filled to increase the duration and extent of overbank flows.  This has dissipated the energy of in-stream flows and will facilitate the development of more stable beaver dam complexes.  In upper Benewah Creek, beaver dam analog (BDA) structures have been installed to inundate stream reaches, elevate stream levels, and promote overbank flooding. Under both these strategies it is expected that 1) groundwater recharge will increase as the duration and spatial extent of floodplain inundation increases; and 2) water table elevations will increase as surface water elevations rise due to the stability of these natural and emulated beaver dam impoundments and the consequent sedimentation and bed aggradation.

The response of groundwater elevations to restoration actions will be monitored using well fields located in three different floodplain areas.  Two of these are found in the upper Hangman Creek watershed, and the other is located in the upper Benewah Creek watershed.
objectives: Monitor hourly changes in water table elevation during base flow summer periods in well fields adjacent to restored stream reaches in target watersheds.
Determine whether trends in water table elevation over years support the hypothesis that restoration actions have improved hydrologic connectivity.
3283.assumptions:
1. The depth and spatial locations of the groundwater wells are appropriate for detecting changes in water table elevation and resulting from restoration activities

2. Data loggers are calibrated and functioning properly

3. Field measurement data for each well (well elevations, cap perch measurements, and cable length measurements) are accurate

3297.background: ~~The Yakima/Klickitat Fisheries Project (YKFP) is, perhaps, the largest and most complex fisheries project in the Columbia Basin (Fast et al. 2015). The YKFP was designed to test the assumption that artificial production of targeted fish populations (initially spring Chinook salmon) could be used to increase natural production while maintaining the long term genetic fitness of the population and keeping adverse genetic and ecological interactions with non-target fish populations within acceptable limits (RASP 1992; BPA 1996; Fast et al. 2015). This YKFP domestication selection research is intended to monitor the phenotypic divergence associated with three genetic lines maintained by the hatchery that are subjected to varying levels of hatchery exposure, and therefore subject to varying levels of domestication selection. Genotypic change is monitored under a separate protocol (3299). Raising fish in hatcheries can cause unintended behavioral, physiological, life history, and morphological changes. Such changes are often defined as domestication selection, whereas there is a change in genotype and/or phenotypic traits resulting exposure to the hatchery environment. Releasing fish that have altered genotypic or phenotypic traits that may be maladapted to the natural environment may result in reduced population productivity and fitness for naturally spawning fish with hatchery ancestry and also has the potential to reduce the fitness of natural origin spawners. The Domestication Monitoring Plan for the YKFP was developed to evaluate the effect hatchery exposure has on spring Chinook in the Yakima basin, and to separate genetic effects from phenotypic plasticity that has been difficult for other studies to demonstrate (Busack et al. 2003).
objectives: Compare developmental abnormalities for three genetic lines of Yakima spring Chinook (Hatchery Control, Supplementation Hatchery and Supplementation Natural origin sublines, and a Wild Control)
Compare egg-to-fry survival for three genetic lines of Yakima spring Chinook (Hatchery Control, Supplementation Hatchery and Supplementation Natural origin sublines, and a Wild Control)
Determine developmental condition at emergence for three genetic lines of Yakima spring Chinook (Hatchery Control, Supplementation Hatchery, and Supplementation Natural)
Determine emergence timing for three genetic lines of Yakima spring Chinook (Hatchery Control, Supplementation Hatchery and Supplementation Natural origin sublines, and a Wild Control)
Determine fertility for three genetic lines of Yakima spring Chinook (Hatchery Control, Supplementation Hatchery and Supplementation Natural origin sublines, and a Wild Control)
Determine Reproductive effort for three genetic lines of Yakima spring Chinook (Hatchery Control, Supplementation Hatchery and Supplementation Natural origin sublines, and a Wild Control)
3297.assumptions: The Domestication research was designed to test the hypothesis that supplementation hatchery rearing does not reduce the fitness of hatchery fish spawning in the wild, or of the natural population.  The three lines of fish used for comparisons include fish that have not had hatchery exposure (Wild Control Line), fish with minimal hatchery exposure (maximum of one generation; Supplementation Hatchery/Supplementation Natural  sub-lines), or fish with repeated hatchery exposure for many generations (Hatchery Control Line).  Differences in any of the traits monitored are assumed to be the result of Domestication Selection.

3298.background:
The CWT (Coded Wire Tag) program was introduced during the 1960's as a way to alleviate external marking of anadromous salmonids along the North American West Coast. Agencies in Alaska, Canada, Washington, Idaho, Oregon, and California adopted this program and as of 2009, tagged over 50 million predominantly hatchery salmonids yearly (Nandor. et. al.). Chinook salmon (O.tshawytscha) are tagged in their snout, using various equipment such as Auto tagging trailers or other hand held devices. Multiple fish will receive the same tag number. This specific code provides useful information to fishery managers about the origin, brood year, average weight as well as many other unique fields pertaining to that batch of fish (all fields can be found at http://www.rmis.org/rmis_login.php?action=Login&system=cwt). 

When cwt fish are recovered, their snouts are removed posterior to the eye. Detections can be made using a T-Wand or a V-reader. It is important to include the eyes as many cwt recoveries are found within this tissue. When a tag is recovered it can be viewed under a microscope or MagniViewer. Information collected from cwt's can assist agencies to  evaluate hatchery contributions to catch, smolt to adult survival rates, spawner abundance on spawning grounds, differential in-hatchery treatments, and other related studies that may be important for fisheries management and research (Nandor. et. al.).
objectives: Extract and recover coded wire tag from Colville Tribes hatchery ladder, weir, purse seine, spawning ground and creel survey's to monitor the stray rate of hatchery origin fish into the Okanogan Basin

Estimate Smolt-to-Adult Rate (SARs)
Age Structure of Adult Returns
In-To-Basin Stray Rate
3298.assumptions: The methods selected are standard practices for CWT recovery, extraction and reading used by other Columbia River basin labs (i.e. WDFW, CRITFC).

3299.background: The Yakima/Klickitat Fisheries Project (YKFP) is, perhaps, the largest and most complex fisheries project in the Columbia Basin (Fast et al. 2015).  The YKFP was designed to test the assumption that artificial production of targeted fish populations (initially spring Chinook salmon) could be used to increase natural production while maintaining the long term genetic fitness of the population and keeping adverse genetic and ecological interactions with non-target fish populations within acceptable limits (RASP 1992; BPA 1996; Fast et al. 2015).  The YKFP genetic monitoring program supports the genetic monitoring component of the project.  There are two genetic components of this protocol.  First is collecting genetic samples on returning adult spring Chinook salmon from wild and hatchery fish.  The samples are collected by Yakama Nation Biologists at the Roza Adult Monitoring Facility (RAMF) on the Yakima River, and processed in the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) Molecular Genetics Laboratory (MGL).  The genetic assignments are forwarded to the Columbia River Intertribal Fish Commission (CRITFC) lab to contribute to a whole river parentage analysis.  The parentage analysis is designed to estimate differences in relative reproductive success of hatchery and wild origin chinook spawned in the wild at the population level.  Second is a genetic stock population of origin assignment for juvenile spring Chinook. Smolt migrants that are represent three distinct populations of spring Chinook that are co-mingled are sampled at the Chandler juvenile Sampling Facility are sub-sampled throughout the out-migration.  Subsampling includes genetic sample collections.  The samples are sent to the WDFW MGL and genetic assignments were used to partition the annual basin-wide smolt production estimate to the contribution from population.
objectives: Collect and Process juvenile spring Chinook smolt samples using single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) panels to partition mixed stock migrants into population of origin.
Collect and Process spring Chinook adult genetic samples using SNP panels to contribute to a whole river pedigree analysis.
3299.assumptions: The primary assumption being tested is that supplementation can be used to increase natural production while maintaining long-term genetic fitness of the population and keeping adverse genetic and ecological interactions with non-target fish populations within acceptable limits.

3300.background: Examining the diversity of seasonal and life-history behaviors of salmonids in monitored watersheds will improve the understanding of in-stream habitat use and production of the migratory life-history variant.  Monitoring in-stream movement patterns will provide data on seasonal habitats used (e.g., overwintering), and could aid in evaluating the response to restorative actions implemented to improve the quality of seasonal habitats.  Monitoring the propensity of juvenile salmonids to move out of natal, stream habitats and into larger bodies of water (e.g., larger rivers, lake) and monitoring the spatial distribution of spawning adults returning from these larger bodies of water will identify tributaries within watersheds that support the migratory life-history strategy.  Understanding the current spatial distribution of the migratory life-history variant may aid in prioritizing future restoration efforts.  Half-duplex (i.e., HDX) passive integrated transponder (i.e., PIT) technology is being implemented across projects in the Yakima Basin, (e.g. Yakima/Klickitat fisheries program) to monitor seasonal and life-history movements of targeted salmonids.  In the upper Yakima watershed, a stationary PIT array has been installed to monitor movements of resident and anadromous salmonids in and out of the Teanaway River Basin.  The Teanaway Basin is a large watershed housing one of the Yakima/Klickitat Fishery Project spring Chinook salmon off site acclimation facilities representing 1/3 of the project hatchery production.  This interrogation site serves to monitor movement of juvenile fish released from this facility (timing, abundance) as well as the adult returns that utilize this watershed (abundance, movement, timing).  This array may be used in conjunction with other PIT tag interrogation facilities at permanent structures  (e.g., Roza Dam, Prosser Dam), or PIT tag arrays operated by other entities (e.g., U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, U. S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife; Conservation Districts)   located throughout the Yakima Basin to monitor large scale migrations through out the Basin.
objectives: Use interrogation data from stationary PIT arrays to describe the spatial distribution of the migratory life-history variant within watersheds.
Create interrogation histories for individual PIT tagged fish to evaluate seasonal movements within watersheds.
3300.assumptions:
1.  PIT tagged fish and their patterns of movement represent the population from which they were sampled and tagged.

2  Series of stationary PIT antenna arrays within watersheds operate at sufficient efficiency to confidently generate conclusions regarding seasonal and life-history movements within watersheds.

metrics.title: Seasonal interrogation history for juvenile fish
Seasonal interrogation history for adult fish
Total number of interrogated fish at a specific site

3301.background:
The Bridge Creek watershed is used by a by a run of Mid-Columbia steelhead that are part of the ecologically distinct and ESA (Endangered Species Act) “threatened” Lower John Day population. It is also used intermittently by Mid-Columbia Chinook salmon, another "threatened" population. Bridge Creek was listed as one of 11 tributary Major Spawning Areas (MaSAs) critical to the recovery of the Lower John Day steelhead Major Population Group (MPG), and was identified as having high restoration potential. Many areas along Bridge Creek have historically experienced high levels of incision, degradation, and high stream temperatures making them inhospitable to salmon populations.

Floodplain connectivity and riparian structure were listed as a high restoration priority for the lower valley on Bridge Creek. Re-establishing both surface and groundwater connections between the stream and floodplain increases the amount and quality of fish habitat. Since 2009, beaver dam analogs (BDAs) have been installed in the area, encouraging beaver migration into the area and beaver dam formation (Pollock, et al. 2014). The damming of Bridge Creek has resulted in soil aggradation and floodplain inundation. Floodplain inundation promotes groundwater recharge and water table rise, which in turn support perennial streamflow, cooler water temperatures (due to groundwater upwelling), and riparian vegetation growth (Pollock et al. 2012). Riparian vegetation provides shade and organic inputs to the stream ecosystem (e.g., prey, woody debris, leaf litter) which improves fish habitat quality (Pollock et al. 2012). In addition, riparian vegetation is also critical for supporting and maintaining stable beaver colonies, which are an important part of the Bridge Creek restoration strategy. Finally, connected floodplains can also directly provide important off-channel refuge for fish during high flows, expand rearing areas, and increase foraging opportunities (Pollock et al. 2012). 

This protocol presents a framework by which to monitor the effectiveness of the Bridge Creek restoration efforts in transforming incised stream networks into healthy, functioning riparian ecosystems. It outlines which vegetative and landscape factors should be measured to determine riparian health. It will also address the restoration methods specific to Bridge Creek, with variables that take into account the impact of BDAs and beaver introduction on floodplain vegetation and landscape structure. By repeating this survey protocol over multiple years, temporal trends in vegetation and landscape may be observed. The survey methods implemented in this protocol are supported by the methodologies outlined in two other government-agency led reports: the multiple indicator monitoring of stream channels and streamside vegetation (MIM 2011), and the PACFISH/INFISH effectiveness monitoring program for sampling vegetation in streams and riparian areas (PIBO-EM 2008). These two protocols helped guide us in choosing important riparian indicators to measure and allows us to place this effectiveness monitoring protocol in the context of other monitoring studies.
objectives: Species-level vegetation surveys will help describe the effects of beaver dams and beaver browse on floodplain vegetation composition, abundance, and biodiversity.
Monitoring will also track beaver utilization of riparian vegetation.
Observations in riparian cross sections (transects) will describe how these variables change with increasing distance from the main channel, and will help track landscape-level response.
Observations along the greenline will track changes in this highly variable and critical area along the main channel edge.

3307.background: This protocol is aimed at providing fishery managers with information regarding entrainment of juvenile trout and non-game fish species in three of the large unscreened canals which divert water from the South Fork Snake River. Densities of trout downstream of the canal headgates are lower than densities of trout in upstream river reaches and movement studies have documented trout from the lower South Fork Snake River migrating upstream past the canals during spawning seasons (High et al. 2015). Entrainment of all species of fish and size classes has been observed in the canals, but has not been quantified. Fishery managers are concerned about the effect of entrainment on fish abundance in the South Fork Snake River, especially on native Yellowstone Cutthroat Trout Ocorhynchus clarkii bouvieri. Previous research has been focused on quantifying entrainment of sub-adult and adult trout, but the methodology used for this research was limited to just those larger size classes of fish. Fry and juvenile fish entrainment has not been quantified. These data are necessary to gain a more complete understanding of how entrainment of fish in South Fork Snake River canals is affecting population abundances.
objectives: Quantification of the entrainment of juvenile trout and non-game fish in three South Fork Snake River canals during the summer irrigation season.
3307.assumptions:
• The entrainment rates observed in the three canals are constant through time
  • Entrainment rates of fish in other canals are similar to those monitored with screw traps
  • Entrained fish are not able to navigate back to the South Fork Snake River
  • Rotary screw traps are suitable gear to sample small trout and non-game fish in the South Fork

3309.background: Hatchery adult trapping facilities provide the opportunity to collect information on wild salmonids. Three existing facilities in the Salmon River basin are utilized to monitor wild Chinook salmon abundance using mark-recapture methods. The three facilities include the McCall Fish Hatchery satellite facility on the South Fork Salmon River, Pahsimeroi Fish hatchery on the Pahsimeroi River, and Sawtooth Fish Hatchery on the Upper Salmon River.
objectives: Estimate Chinook salmon spawner abundance above hatchery weirs
Estimate hatchery fraction of Chinook salmon passed above hatchery weirs

3310.background: Walleye are an emerging potential threat to native and desire sport fish populations. Walleye likely entered the lake from an upstream source population. To better understand the role this species will play in the lake, we will evaluate their diet, origin via isotopic analysis, and locations of fish aggregations during spawning via telemetry.  We will also evaluate trends in catch rates using fall Walleye index netting methods.
objectives: Determine origin, spawning locations, home range, feeding habits, growth rates, population dynamics, and general life histories of Walleye.
3310.assumptions:
Radio and acoustically tagged walleye will behave in a manner representative of the walleye population.

Selected sampling location and gear types will representatively sample the walleye population and provide applicable baseline datasets to compare future population trends.

3311.background: Redd counts and carcass surveys are conducted to estimate Viable Salmonid Population (VSP) metrics (i.e. abundance, productivity, and spatial structure) for Chinook salmon populations in Idaho. These metrics are used by NOAA to assess the status of Snake River Spring/Summer Chinook salmon, which are currently listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act. Additionally, these surveys have been conducted in a consistent manner in Idaho since 1957 and thus provide a valuable long-term dataset.

Estimate age composition of adult Chinook salmon at the population level

3315.background: Survival of fish stocked into waters depends on factors such as fish species, water quality, and acclimation to the stocking environment. Lahontan Cutthroat Trout Oncorhynchus clarkii henshawi have evolved to inhabit lakes with higher pH and total dissolved solids levels compared to other salmonid species. Omak Lake, on the Colville Reservation, is a popular fishery for Lahontan Cutthroat Trout. As natural reproduction does not occur in the lake, fish must be stocked annually in order to maintain the fishery. A pilot study on Omak Lake showed very low survival (1%) of stocked Lahontan Cutthroat Trout.  In order to improve post-stocking survival, a saltwater transition feed for hatchery reared fish has been suggested. The following protocol describes an experiment to test the effects of a saltwater transition feed diet on post-stocking survival of juvenile Lahontan Cutthroat Trout.
objectives: Identify the transition feed treatment period with maximum post-stocking survival.
Assess post-stocking daily survival rate for different transition feed treatment periods.
3315.assumptions: No fish escape or enter the net pens over the duration of the study.

3315.title: Lahontan Cutthroat Trout Feed Study Data Collection and Analysis

3317.background: The carrying capacity of a watershed is an important factor in determining whether supplementation is a viable technique of increasing natural production. Preliminary analysis suggests that density dependent mechanisms affecting spring Chinook growth and survival are present in the monitored river basin prior to abundance estimates conducted in the fall, and potentially prior to or during the summer rearing period. If the river is at capacity for rearing subyearlings in some years, then supplementation efforts can only serve to increase the number of naturally produced smolts when natural production is below that capacity.  Therefore, identifying the factors that limit natural production is critical if restoration efforts aimed at maintaining or increasing natural production are to achieve their intended biological goals. We conducted snorkeling surveys documenting observed abundance of rearing subyearling Chinook by habitat classification.  Our data suggests that habitat type is a significant factor determining abundance of rearing subyearling Chinook, and that the space required of rearing subyearlings appears to expand linearly with increasing growth. A multi-year analysis of abundance indicates that summer rearing densities track well with fall abundance estimates, suggesting that the absence of density dependent mechanisms significantly affects growth and survival during the two life-stages. Temperature and visibility do not appear to have significantly affected estimates of observed abundance among study reaches. (Johnson et. all 2011)
objectives: Annually assess the limiting factors of carrying capacity for Spring Chinook Salmon.
3317.assumptions:
All fish species are being correctly identified.

All measurement devices are correctly calibrated and being read correctly.

Habitat types are representative.

3322.background:
The goal of this biomonitoring program is to assess the effectiveness of CTUIR sponsored habitat restoration actions on spring Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha), summer steelhead (Oncorhynchus mykiss), and bull trout (Salvelinus confluentus) populations. Monitoring of the biological and geo-fluvial responses to habitat restoration actions is fundamental to informing future management actions.

Multiple pass spawning surveys document the temporal and spatial distribution and abundance of salmon and steelhead redds.  Adult abundance and distribution is estimated based on redd and carcass counts conducted in treatment and control reaches. Sampling occurs annually commencing at the onset of the spawning season and continues approximately every 10–14 days until spawning is complete. Analysis under this protocol is related to habitat data collected with CTUIR’s Habitat Monitoring Protocol (https://www.monitoringresources.org/Document/Protocol/Details/1955) to correlate habitat restoration actions with redd distribution and abundance over time.

Data for this protocol is usually collected by cooperative agencies and projects that have long term status and trend RM&E efforts in the CTUIR Sub basins of interest.
objectives: Map and compare spatial distribution and density of redds in treatment and control reaches related to fish habitat data over time.
Correlate the biological effects of habitat restoration actions on redd abundance and distribution over time between treatment and control reaches.
3322.assumptions: Assumptions of multiple pass spawning surveys include: 1) reasonably consistent observations within and between surveyors, passes, and years; 2) flagging redds minimizes double counting; 3) surveyors on subsequent passes track previous redds sufficiently to reduce double counting in cases where flagging loss occurs between surveys; 4) spring Chinook census spawning survey reaches bracket all spawning activities in time and space; 5) sites are accessible during steelhead spawning surveys to allow for redd visibility and documentation.

3323.background:
Previous monitoring of the mainstem Willamette River from 2011 to 2013 provided an important baseline for future monitoring of native and non-native fish communities and evaluation of status and trends. However, how fish assemblages and different species of salmonids use mainstem rearing habitats, particularly in warmer seasons and water temperatures, is not well described because of temperature limitations on when and where sampling can occur. In addition, future comparisons to evaluate trends in native and nonnative fish communities with those circa 2010 will be hampered by inherent biases of sampling methods and protocols. Different species and different sizes of fish have different capture probabilities because of behavior, efficiency in different habitats, and the physics of electrofishing. The proposed work is designed to make categorical estimates of: • abundance of native and non-native fish • richness of native and non-native fish communities • proportion of native fish species • proportion of salmonids across a broad range of habitats in the mainstem Willamette, McKenzie, Santiam, and Middle Fork Willamette rivers, and determine the repeatability of this estimates. Information gained on the use of mainstem habitats by juvenile salmonids will be used to help Action Agencies and the Services make adaptive management decisions on a year-to-year basis, will provide valuable occupancy and habitat use information in warmer water conditions to inform long-term management planning, and will aid in evaluating the effectiveness of temperature and habitat restoration mitigation measures.

Ultimately data collected in this effort will be used to validate the fish community monitoring protocol used in 2011-13, determine the repeatability of boat and backpack electrofishing, and assess the status of native and non-native fish communities in the Willamette River basin.  In addition, project collaborators will incorporate products in the SLICES framework, providing a common archive and information resource regarding ecological status and trends.

Note that this is a collaborative project between Oregon State University (OSU) and the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife (ODFW).  ODFW's role relating to this sampling protocol is primarily data collection; this is reflected in the objectives listed below.  All of the analysis and reporting (except that which is required by ODFW's BPA contract) will be conducted by OSU.
objectives: Collect data to estimate (1) abundance of native and non-native fishes; (2) richness of native/non-native fish communities; (3) proportion of native species, and (4) proportion of salmonids.
Collect water quality data at sites sampled for fish and in known coldwater refuges to determine their suitability as fish habitat.
Collect physical habitat data at sites sampled for fish and in known coldwater refuges to determine their suitability as fish habitat.
3323.assumptions: Differences in environmental conditions between 2011-13 and 2017 do not affect sampling results.  Electrofishing efficiency similar among years.  Crew experience and abillity similar among years.  Changes in fish communities are detectable using this protocol.  Sufficient sampling is being conducted to effectively evaluate the protocol.  Time frame and other logistics in 2017 are consistent with past efforts.

3326.background: The goal of the CTUIR Biomonitoring program is to assess the effectiveness of CTUIR sponsored habitat restoration actions on spring Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawystscha), summer steelhead (Oncorhynchus mykiss), and bull trout (Salvenlinus confluenctus) populations. Benthic macroinvertebrates are considered an excellent indicator of water quality and overall stream health. Their quantified response to in-stream restoration actions makes them a valuable tool for monitoring restoration effectiveness (Miller et al. 2010).  Due to their limited mobility macroinvertebrates are directly affected by their immediate surroundings making them an important indicator at a smaller reach monitoring scale (Platts et al. 1983).
objectives: Determine how benthic macroinvertebrate communities have changed as a result of in stream and floodplain habitat restoration.
3326.assumptions:
Access to impact and suitable control reaches will be provided.

Correct identification of macroinvertebrates by processing laboratory. 

Macroinvertebrate species captured in a particular habitat type are indicative of the actual species living in that habitat.

3336.background: Significant investments have been made to monitor anadromous fish populations and restore habitats within the Columbia River Basin in previous decades. Spatially indexed juvenile salmon and steelhead counts and redd counts now exist at hundreds to thousands of stream sites throughout the region. In addition to answering status and trend questions that originally motivated collection of those datasets, they can often be integrated and used with new spatial-stream-network (SSN) models to understand the effects of habitat conditions and to make predictions of fish abundance and distributions at unsampled site throughout full river networks. The SSN models differ from previous models in that they do not require spatially independent samples but instead benefit from some degree of non-independence among samples in close proximity. This provides an incentive to aggregate large samples from multiple sources because the models become increasingly accurate as the amount of data and clustering in the dataset increase. The SSN models describe the spatial decay in patterns of non-independence and use it with fixed effect parameter estimates for habitat factors to make accurate spatial predictions of fish abundance. Because the SSN models are spatially explicit, their integration with geospatial stream hydrography layers like the National Hydrography Dataset and National Stream Internet network (Nagel et al. 2015) facilitates the development of accurate prediction maps that show patterns in fish distributions. Spatially-explicit estimates of uncertainty may also be developed with those prediction maps, which are useful for allocating subsequent sample collections to those areas that address the greatest uncertainties. The rationale for this project is to develop the means of applying SSNs in a computationally efficient manner to anadromous fish datasets and the creation of a Fish Data Analysis Tool (FDAT) that enables visualization of results through an online data portal.
objectives: 1) Organize and summarize an anadromous fish density dataset for a pilot area, 2) link fish densities to habitat variables, 3) fit SSN model and map predictions, 4) deliver results online through FDAT
3336.assumptions: Key assumptions for FDAT are: 1) sufficient numbers of juvenile anadromous fish density samples or redd counts exist within a river basin to show evidence of spatial autocorrelation, 2) the fish data can be assembled into a properly formatted dataset for use with the SSN and STARS software, 3) patterns in fish abundance will be related to available geospatial representations of stream habitat conditions, and 4) steps associated with fitting SSN models and linking fish data to geospatial habitat descriptors can be semi-automated. Once a functional FDAT prototype exists, it could be linked to a regional fish database to enable efficient modeling and mapping of patterns in anadromous fish density.

3339.background:
The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) developed the National Aquatic Monitoring Framework (NAMF) (Miller et al. 2015) to monitor the condition and trend of aquatic systems as part of the Assessment, Inventory, and Monitoring (AIM) Strategy (Toevs et al. 2011). Following the AIM principles, the NAMF standardized aquatic core indicators, field sampling methodologies, electronic data capture, and the use of statistically valid sample designs for wadeable streams and rivers (i.e., lotic systems). This protocol outlines the field methodologies for the collection of the core and contingent indicators for lotic systems, as well as suggested covariates.

The BLM AIM Aquatic Core Indicator Work Group (ACIWG), with guidance from an external science advisory team, identified 11 core indicators, 7 contingent indicators, and several covariates applicable to lotic systems (see attached Table 1). The 11 core indicators represent a consistent, quantitative approach for determining the attainment of BLM land health standards for perennial wadeable streams and rivers, among other applications (Miller et al. 2015). AIM aquatic core indicators are applicable across many different ecosystems, management objectives, and agencies and are recommended for application wherever the BLM implements monitoring and assessment of lotic systems. To help determine the potential of a stream reach to support a given condition or to assist in interpreting monitoring data, the ACIWG also identified six aquatic covariates—slope, bankfull width, wetted width, human influence, photos, and flood-prone width (Table 1). 

The ACIWG also identified seven aquatic contingent indicators (Table 1) that have the same cross-program utility and definition as core indicators, but they are measured only where applicable. The use of contingent indicators should be considered during the design phase of monitoring project development and be selected to address specific management and monitoring objectives. The aquatic core and contingent indicators and covariates are not expected to be inclusive of all BLM lotic data needs, as additional indicators may be required (i.e., supplemental indicators).

The methods attached to this protocol reflect those from the Lotic Field Protocol for Wadeable Systems 2017 Field Season (PDF attached as Supplemental Information) and the Lotic Field Protocol for Wadeable Systems 2021 Field Season (PDF attached as a Form below). Protocols for other previous field seasons are made available attached as Forms.
objectives: Determine the attainment of BLM land health standards for perennial wadeable streams and rivers using a quantitative approach of eleven core indicators.
Determine the potential of a stream reach to assist in interpreting monitoring data.
Maximize compatibility with existing monitoring programs, accurately and precisely estimating condition and trend, and meeting BLM lotic data needs and state and federal regulations.

3353.background:
Environmental DNA (eDNA) is DNA that have been released by an organism into its environment and can be detected in the air, water, or soil. In aquatic systems, eDNA has been shown to provide a sampling approach that is sensitive enough to detect species presence or absence and can be performed rapidly and efficiently (Laramie et al. 2015; Carmin et al 2016).

The National Genomics Center for Wildlife and Fish Conservation (NGC) has developed taxon specific eDNA assays for a number of native fish species including Bull Trout Salvelinus confluentus ,  Westslope Cutthroat Trout Oncorhynchus clarkii, Chinook Salmon Oncorhynchus tshawytscha and as well as non-native species such as the Northern Pike Esox Lucius (Laramie et al. 2015; Carmin et al 2016).

Invasive Northern Pike are suspected to have migrated from the Clark Fork river system in Montana, downstream to the Pend Oreille River, and now into the upper reaches the Columbia River in the United States.  Northern Pike were first captured in standardized fishery surveys in Lake Roosevelt in 2007 when a single fish was captured in a gill net at Alder Creek (rkm 1058.5) (Lee et al. 2010). Subsequently, Northern Pike have been captured in increasing numbers during Fall Walleye Sander vitreus Index Netting (King and Lee 2016), White Sturgeon Acipenser transmontanus juvenile netting (Seibert et al. 2015), and creel surveys (Blake et al. 2015) in the upper reaches of Lake Roosevelt, near Kettle Falls, WA.

The increasing observations of Northern Pike in Lake Roosevelt prompted the Lake Roosevelt co-managers (Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife [WDFW], Colville Confederated Tribes [CCT] and Spokane Tribe of Indians [STI]) to implement gill netting surveys in 2015 and 2016 to investigate localized abundance, diet, and age structure (Lee and King 2015; King and Lee 2016). Northern Pike have been captured in the upper reaches of Lake Roosevelt upstream of the Colville River confluence (rkm 1120 on the Columbia River). They have also been captured up to Napoleon Bridge (14.7 rkm ) on the Kettle River.  Minimal sampling has occurred above this point due to the difficulty of sampling in a shallow fast flowing river.

The co-managers of Lake Roosevelt have worked together to combine BPA and Agency funds to increase efforts to combat the expansion and invasion of Northern Pike in Lake Roosevelt. Removal efforts have included a combination of gill nets, boat electrofishing, and angling.

The downstream spread of Northern Pike is of concern to regional fisheries managers because Pike pose a serious threat to the conservation and existence of native fish species. The use of eDNA monitoring may assist with monitoring Northern Pike distribution and the early detection of downstream expansion. 

The CCT developed a monitoring strategy to monitor 48 sites in the Upper Columbia River basin to facilitate early detection of Northern Pike spreading into new waters.
objectives: Use eDNA as an early detection tool for monitoring the distribution and expansion of Northern Pike in the Upper Columbia River watershed.
3353.assumptions: A key assumption of the study is that the water sample reflects the actual presence or absence of Northern Pike.

3354.background:
Northern Pike Esox luscious are classified as a prohibited species in Washington State. An invasive Northern Pike population is present within Franklin D. Roosevelt Lake (Lake Roosevelt), WA, a mainstem impoundment of the Columbia River formed by Grand Coulee Dam. It is assumed that Northern Pike entered Lake Roosevelt from upstream waters. Prior to 2015, Northern Pike were rarely observed in standardized fish surveys conducted on Lake Roosevelt (Lee and King 2015, Blake et al. 2017). Through 2016 to 2019, over 12,000 Northern Pike have been removed by the co-management entities of Lake Roosevelt (the Spokane Tribe, Confederated Tribes of the Colville Reservation, and Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife). Natural recruitment of Northern Pike was documented in 2016 and 2017 within the Kettle River and Evans Campground areas of Lake Roosevelt. 

Gillnetting can be an effective means of controlling invasive Northern Pike populations (Sepulveda et al. 2013, Baxter and Neufeld 2015, Bean 2014, Walrath et al. 2015). In Lake Roosevelt, gill net suppression occurs between March and June in known Northern Pike staging and spawning locations. Since 2016, the majority of the  suppression effort  has been focused within the Kettle River (48.681428, -118.115458), Marcus (48.681371, -118.086362), Evans Campground (48.688228, -118.033233), Singer Bay (48.622975, -118.075942), Colville River (48.573482, -118.087433), Haag Cove (48.556980, -118.154128), and Gifford (48.297843, -118.175735) areas of Lake Roosevelt (see map of suppression locations).

Spring suppression effort is occasionally suspended in April when the reservoir is at its lowest drawdown point due to closed boat launches limiting access, high water flows, and loss of suitable sampling habitat. The decision to suspend suppression is made each year by the Lake Roosevelt Northern Pike Technical Team (Technical Team).

Post-spawn gill net suppression occurs between July and November in known and suspected Northern Pike rearing locations. Arc Map was used to develop a map that identified the top 9.1 m from full pool (393 m amsl) with less than 45° shoreline slope (see reservoir elevation-habitat map). Co-management agencies divide suppression effort between the known and suspected sites.

All bycatch is released back into the reservoir. The co-managers mutually agreed to species specific bycatch limits. If a bycatch limit is reached in a particular area, sampling is suspended in that area for the rest of the week.

All fish are measured (total length). Additional data collected from Northern Pike include weights, otoliths, cliethra, sex, and maturity. Data is also kept on capture per gill net mesh size to inform development of a Lake Roosevelt specific gill net to increase Northern Pike catch and reduce bycatch. The efficacy of Northern Pike suppression efforts will be evaluated by a reservoir wide monitoring survey.

Suppression information from all three agencies will be collated and summarized in one annual report submitted March 15 of the following year.
objectives: Reduce the abundance of Northern Pike to the point at which they are rarely observed - <1 Northern Pike/100 overnight gill net sets in reservoir-wide Northern Pike Monitoring Program gill net catch.
3354.assumptions:
1.) Reducing Northern Pike abundance will protect native and managed fish species (such as Redband Trout, Kokanee, and Burbot), reduce/eliminate recruitment of Northern Pike within the reservoir, and limit downstream movement of Northern Pike below Grand Coulee and Chief Joseph Dams.

2.) Northern Pike will remain highly susceptible to capture by gill net and bycatch mortality will not cause negative population level changes in native or managed fish species.

3366.background: OBMEP is a long term status and trends monitoring program that collects data on habitat conditions for salmonids in their freshwater life stages. OBMEP Habitat Monitoring methods were developed according to the Monitoring Strategy for the Upper Columbia Basin (2004) by Tracy Hillman, and aligned with the methods of the Collaborative Systemwide Monitoring & Evaluation Program (CSMEP), the Pacific Northwest Aquatic Monitoring Partnership (PNAMP) and originally implemented following the Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP). To ensure compatibility with other regional and basin wide projects, OBMEP coordinates with multiple disciplines and agencies throughout the Okanogan River Basin, Columbia Cascade Province, and Columbia River Basin.
objectives: Monitor status and trend of physical habitat of salmonids below anadromous barriers.
3366.assumptions: Sites selected with the GRTS approach can be used to measure changes in the status and trends of habitat, water quality, and biota over time if taken in a scientifically rigorous manner per specific protocols.

3368.background:
Anadromous salmonids emigrating from a tributary watershed can be captured in downstream river system near the mouth of the tributary.  At that capture location, juvenile fish may be outfitted with a PIT tag.  However, the natal stream of these fish is not known with certainty, and a proportion of may have originated from the downstream river. This can confound analysis if the assumption is that all fish captured near the mouth of the tributary are native to that specific tributary.

Unique Oxygen 18/16 and Strontium 87/86 isotopic ratios found can be found in water samples collected at sites in the different watersheds.  Once these ratios are known, the natal stream of a juvenile anadromous salmonid can be assigned once the isotopic signatures contained in its otoliths are determined and matched to a specific watershed.  This can allow for refinement of estimates regarding tributary-specific fish stocks such as smolt production estimates, outmigration timing, and brood year SAR per river.  Isotopic ratios can also be used to document the presence or absence and estimate abundance of salmonids by natal stream in the population fitted with PIT tags and captured near the mouth of the tributary.
objectives: Collect fish for otolith analysis
Extract and preserve otoliths from anadromous salmonids for isotope analysis
Collect water samples for Strontium isotope analysis
Collect water samples for Oxygen isotope analysis
3368.assumptions:
1. That Oxygen 18O/16O and 87Sr/86Sr ratios measured in water samples are reflected in the otoliths of fish rearing in those streams
  2. That subyearling Chinook captured in the most upstream spawning reaches of a given watershed are captured in their natal streams.

metrics.title: Establish Sr 87/86 ratio signatures for Okanogan, Similkameen, and Columbia below Chief Joseph Dam

3370.background:
This protocol monitors genetic changes associated with hatchery propagation in multiple Snake River sub-basins for Chinook salmon and steelhead. The information obtained from this protocol directly addresses a critical knowledge gap identified by comanagers: under what conditions does hatchery supplementation provide a sustained contribution to natural production? This protocol uses changes in gene frequencies through time in hatchery, natural, and wild Chinook salmon and steelhead populations to evaluate the genetic effects of hatchery supplementation on a broad geographic scale.  Co-managers are ODFW, CTUIR, NPT, WDFW, IDFG, and SBT.  

This type of monitoring work is now an essential part of hatchery reform and the goal of using widespread hatchery propagation in recovery of natural populations. Tier 2 sites use changes in gene frequencies through time in hatchery, natural and wild Chinook salmon and steelhead populations to evaluate the genetic effects of hatchery supplementation on a broad geographic scale (described here in this Protocol).  Tier 3 sites involve direct measures of the relative reproductive success of hatchery fish spawning in the wild by using parentage analysis to construct pedigrees (See Protocol ID:364).  

The samples needed for this protocol are collected by a number of different entities. Our personnel sample several hatcheries and 4 natural sites in the Salmon River basin every summer. Other sampling locations in the Salmon River are sampled by Gordon Axel (NMFS Pasco) as part of Project 2010-076-00). Other collections may be contributed via opportunistic sampling.

We created this new version of the original protocol (original ID:363) because we transitioned this project from using microsatellite markers to SNP markers. See the attached form for a list of SNP markers we utilize for this protocol.
objectives: Determine the degree to which supplemented populations affect nonsupplemented populations of Chinook and steelhead
Monitor population genetic relationships within and among populations of Chinook salmon and steelhead in the Snake River Basin
3370.assumptions: We assume that by sampling a stretch of each site ranging from 1/4-1 mile in length, that we are not sampling a single family grouping. Additionally, we choose to sample juveniles at each study site rather than returning adults, as juveniles are not as susceptible to straying issues.

3373.background:
Environmental DNA (eDNA) is DNA released by an organism into its environment and is now detectible using modern field sampling and laboratory analysis techniques (Carim et al. 2016). In aquatic systems such as streams, river, and lakes, eDNA sampling has been demonstrated as a sensitive enough technique to detect the presence or absence of fish that are rare or in low abundance (Carim et al. 2016). Historically standard fisheries sampling techniques such as electrofishing, snorkeling, angling, or netting have been applied to detect the presence of specific fish species in a given system. With the advent of eDNA sampling, determining presence or absence of even rare fish species has become more efficient and cost effective.

Non-native and invasive fish species continue to expand in terms of their abundance and distribution in Pend Oreille River basin. Detection is the key to understanding the scale of their distribution and potential impacts to native fish species. Using eDNA sampling results, management agencies can inform decisions to be directed toward no action (i.e., target species not detected), further data collection required, or significant species management action required (i.e., non-native fish suppression or eradication measures). In the Pend Oreille river basin in Washington and Idaho, introduced Eastern Brook Trout Salvelinus fontinalis have supplanted the vast majority of native Westslope Cutthroat Trout Oncorhynchus clarki lewisi populations. In recent years, actions have been initiated to identify and address populations of Eastern Brook Trout in an effort to allow Westslope Cutthroat Trout to reestablish or expand populations into a larger portion of their native range.

In the lower Pend Oreille River and its tributaries, Managers from the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) and Kalispel Tribe have been both independently and collaboratively conducting activities to mechanically suppress (i.e., electrofishing) and eradicate (i.e., electrofishing or piscicide application) Eastern Brook Trout with the eventual outcome of restoring native Westslope Cutthroat Trout. These projects are typically identified or conducted as part of FERC license requirements for Box Canyon (Pend Oreille Public Utility District) and Boundary (Seattle City Light) Dams, as well as BPA funded projects through the Kalispel Tribe.

The Kalispel Tribe has and will continue to utilize BPA projects to conduct eDNA sampling in tributary streams in an effort to identify areas suitable to conduct Eastern Brook Trout suppression and eradication activities and monitor project success long term (i.e., eventual absence or Eastern Brook Trout and presence of Westslope Cutthroat Trout). Samples are collected according to Carim et al. (2016), submitted to the National Genomics Center for Fish and Wildlife Conservation in Missoula, MT and processed in the lab according methods adapted from Goldberg et al. (2011).

The use of eDNA for non-native fish management is innovative and rapidly becoming an invaluable tool. This technique allows management agencies in the Pend Oreille River basin to concentrate resources on projects that have significant potential to contribute to the conservation of native Westslope Cutthroat Trout.This sampling method also has merit for detecting addional target native and non-native species in this system.
objectives: Use Environmental DNA (eDNA) sampling to determine the presence or absence of target non-native fish in tributary streams within the Pend Oreille River basin.
Use Environmental DNA (eDNA) sampling to determine the presence or absence of target non-native fish in lakes or rivers within the Pend Oreille River basin.
Use Environmental DNA (eDNA) sampling to determine the presence or absence of target native fish in tributary streams within the Pend Oreille River basin.
3373.assumptions: 1) If present, eDNA is detectable for target fish species when collected according to protocols in Carim et al. (2016).

3374.background: The carrying capacity of a watershed is one of the main factors in determining whether supplementation is a viable technique of increasing natural production.  Preliminary analysis suggests that density dependent mechanisms affecting spring Chinook survival exists sometime after spawning, prior to the fall parr stage, and potentially prior to the summer rearing period.  Each year we collect and measure spring Chinook fry in the early spring and into early summer to identify areas of potential growth limitation.  Lengths are collected between March and June (Johnson et. al. 2012).  The sampling of Chinook fry is done on a reach scale.  The reach is then broken down spatially into sections.  Each section of the reach is sampled via backpack electrofishing once during a one-week period.  There is a one-week bye time between sampling intervals.  The one-week interval between sampling is done to allow a measurable increase in growth.  We index growth between sampling periods by dividing the difference in mean length between sampling periods by the number of days between sampling periods.  We use mean daily water temperatures near our sampling sites (USBR 2011) to calculate accumulated thermal units through the incubation and early rearing period (Johnson et. al. 2012).
objectives: Annually access the growth and distribution of Spring Chinook fry across reach specific productivity.
3374.assumptions:
Chinook generally move or are displaced to downstream rearing areas following emergence. (Healey 1991; Quinn 2005)?

Specific timing and movement patterns of spring Chinook annually are unknown in the basin.  Fry are often found in areas of low spawner density, suggesting considerable downstream movement during this life stage. Therefore, detectable differences in growth among sampling reaches may be partially attributable to size selective movement within the sampling period and should be considered as a potential variable when interpreting results. (Fast et al. 1991, Johnson et al. 2010, 2011)

3377.background: Different species and life stages of fishes show different preferences for specific microhabitat parameters (Lister and Genoe 1970; Hearn and Kynard 1986; Roper et al. 1994).  Further, the variation of microhabitats used by a species and life stage of fish are typically and positively related to the density of that species/life stage as well as the density of competitor species (Allee 1982; Ross 1986; Grant and Kramer 1990; Robertson 1996).  Knowing the temporal and spatial dynamics of rearing Chinook abundance at the reach scale allows for the evaluation of productivity through the development of stock recruit relationships, but may not be sufficient to identify the specific factors that are limiting production.  Comparisons of the types of microhabitat utilized and the ranges used between high and low productivity sites may allow us to better identify these factors. We conduct timed underwater observations of sub-yearling spring Chinook. Each observation is timed, and done on one selected fish at a time.  We measure the distance and frequency of feeding and agonistic strikes, characterized the focal position by measuring environmental factors such as depth and velocity, and attempted to index the ratio of food availability and energy required to hold at known focal positions.  Feeding and agonistic behavior is marked on the observation data sheet in correlation to where the feeding strike, or agonistic behavior was observed per quadrant (see field data sheet) and later each quadrant mark is then numerated.  Flow ratio (Pearsons et al. 2006) is a parameter designed to index the ratio of food availability and energy required to hold at a known focal position.  This ratio is defined as the highest flow velocity within two body lengths of the focal position divided by the focal point velocity.  A flow ratio greater than one, indicates at least one adjacent velocity greater than the focal point velocity.  We measure velocities at one and two body lengths to either side and above and below the observed spring Chinook focal positions. Core microhabitat variables: estimated length, focal point velocity, focal depth, total depth, and temperature, are measured around the each observed focal position (Johnson et. al. 2012).
objectives: Identify specific factors that are limiting Chinook productivity on a reach scale.
3377.assumptions:
Fish are being correctly identified to species.

Measurement instruments are calibrated and correctly read.

3381.background: The goal of this project is to determine the abundance and current productivity of the Asotin Creek steelhead population and to estimate life stage survival rates in the mainstem Asotin Creek. This relates to work conducted under the Asotin Creek Juvenile Salmonid Sampling and Analysis (2002-053-00) v1.0 (ID: 791)  and Asotin Adult Sampling(2002-053-00) v1.0 (ID: 295) protocols.  The ESA, the TRT, the Snake River Salmon Recovery Plan (SRSRB 2007) and NOAA Fisheries included George Creek and several other small adjacent Snake River tributaries (Tenmile Creek, Couse Creek, Almota and Alpowa Creek) as part of the Asotin Creek Steelhead population. As such, a full understanding of the abundance and productivity of steelhead in those tributaries is necessary to adequately understand the status of the Asotin Creek steelhead population. This project also implements the research, monitoring and evaluation (RM&E) criteria specified in the Asotin Subbasin Plan (ASP 2004), the MERR, and the Anadromous Salmonid Monitoring Strategy (ASMS 2010), by establishing a baseline of the salmonid population in Asotin Creek, upstream of the confluence with George Creek. The project provides estimates of abundance, productivity, survival rates, and additional information on temporal and spatial distribution of ESA-listed species, primarily for summer steelhead, and secondarily on spring Chinook salmon. In addition, this project will document the abundance of bull trout captured at the trapping locations. Future estimates of smolt-to-adult and adult-to-adult survival for the wild steelhead population in Asotin Creek will provide the data necessary to help determine if salmonid production in the subbasin is being limited by within- or out-of-basin factors. This protocol focuses on juvenile steelhead trapping, data collection and analysis. This protocol is closely tied with the Asotin Creek Adult Trapping and Analysis protocol(#295). For further information and detail please refer to that protocol. (Estimated cost refers to the cost of a rotary smolt trap)
objectives: Conduct steelhead juvenile productivity (juveniles per adult spawner) assessment.
Conduct steelhead Smolt to Adult Survival SARs assessment.
3381.assumptions: We assume that our gear (smolt trap) is functioning properly, and we are sampling a representative portion of the population. We also work under the key assumptions of smolt trapping.
