3395.background:
Precocious male maturation occurs in spring run Chinook Salmon Oncorhynchus tshawytscha, both as subyearlings (precocial parr) and as age 1+ juveniles (minijacks) (Thorpe 1994; Sloat et al. 2014). While rates of precocious maturation in wild stocks is thought to be very low (less than 5%), the proportion of juvenile males maturing as minijacks in hatchery populations has been observed to be as high as 80% (Harstad et al. 2014). Minijacks apparently will initiate out-migration along with the other non-maturing smolts, however they do not continue to the ocean for overwintering, nor do they return to their natal spawning areas and participate in natural production (Zimmerman et al. 2003; Beckman and Larsen 2005). Production of minijacks therefore, represents an economic and management loss to a hatchery programs whose objective(s) is to produce large adult size fish for harvest fisheries and/or adults to supplement the naturally spawning population.

Studies indicate that exceeding a threshold level for growth and lipid content during the fall one year following egg fertilization, will induce hatchery-reared juvenile male Chinook Salmon to precociously initiate maturation and become fully mature minijacks by the following spawning season, 5-6 months following smolt release (Larsen et al. 2006; Mangel and Satterthwaite 2008; Spanenberg et al. 2014; Good and Davidson 2016).  However, beyond environmental factors that may alter growth rate and adiposity of the juveniles, there is also evidence for genetic-based factors that influence precocious male maturation rate, apparent both among different stocks, as well as among individuals within stocks (Debes and Hutchings 2104; Harstad et al. 2014; Spanenberg et al. 2015).
objectives: Determine the effect of broodstock age, within sexes, on minijack rate among male hatchery reared spring Chinook Salmon smolts.
Quantify minijack rates among male spring Chinook Salmon smolts sired by age 3 versus age 4 broodstock, and correlate the rates to age structure, size, sex ratio, and SARs of returning adult progeny.
Quantify the timing and magnitude of growth divergence of non-maturing versus maturing minijack hatchery reared juvenile male spring Chinook Salmon.
Determine the effect of dietary supplementation with tetradecylthioacetic acid (TTA) on minijack rate among male hatchery reared spring Chinook Salmon smolts.
3395.assumptions: Inferences regarding precocious male maturation from these studies conducted with this spring Chinook Salmon stock can be generalized to other Chinook Salmon stocks, as to other salmonid species.

3417.background:
Test the Hypothesis: Spring Chinook salmon stocks that possess an increased propensity for minijack maturation will also possess an increased propensity for jack maturation
This investigation will involve rearing a stock of fish with high propensity for minijack maturation and a stock of fish with low propensity for minijack maturation hatchery spring Chinook salmon under a high and low growth regime and evaluate minijack and jack maturation rates. This study will also evaluate growth profiles that increase and decrease the propensity for early male maturation (minijack and jack) in stocks with variable genetic thresholds for expressing these life histories in order to develop hatchery rearing regimes for BPA and other sponsored hatchery programs.
objectives: Assess minijack and jack rates of high and low growth rearing groups of hatchery spring Chinook salmon
3417.assumptions: The key assumption of this protocol is that the 11-KT ELISA and genetic sex marker protocol is conducted according to standard published biochemical techniques.

3446.background: Redd counts are conducted to estimate Viable Salmonid Population (VSP) metrics (i.e. abundance, productivity, and spatial structure for Chinook salmon populations in Idaho. These metrics are used by NOAA to assess the status of Snake River Spring/Summer Chinook salmon, which are currently listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act. Additionally, these surveys have been conducted in a consistent manner in Idaho since 1957 and thus provide a valuable long-term dataset. In many areas of Idaho, Chinook salmon spawn in remote, roadless areas which are difficult to access by foot. As such, it is efficient to utilize aerial survey methods to count redds in these areas. This protocol only describes data collection methods. Analysis using these data incorporates additional data collected from other protocols suchs as 3594: IDFG GROUND-BASED REDD COUNTS and carcass sampling for wild Chinook Salmon in Idaho, so it is described in a separate protocol
objectives: Survey for Chinook Salmon redds from a helicopter at remote areas in the Middle Fork Salmon River basin.
Document spatial distribution of Chinook salmon redds

3450.background: Adult summer steelhead life history information can be scarce for wild Snake River A-run fish. The existence of a weir on Lookingglass Creek allows for collection of adult summer steelhead escapement and life history information.  Data collected from the Lookingglass weir is compared with data from Catherine Creek weir and the Upper Grande Ronde weir (operated by CTUIR Artificial Production). Data collected by CTUIR are shared with cooperator and funding agencies so that it can be used in recovery planning in the Grande Ronde Basin.
objectives: Describe wild adult summer steelhead life history and abundance for Lookingglass Creek.

3451.background: The goal of the CTUIR Biomonitoring program is to assess the effectiveness of CTUIR sponsored habitat restoration actions on spring Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawystscha), summer steelhead (Oncorhynchus mykiss), and bull trout (Salvenlinus confluenctus) populations. Benthic macroinvertebrates are considered an excellent indicator of water quality and overall stream health. Their quantified response to in-stream restoration actions makes them a valuable tool for monitoring restoration effectiveness (Miller et al. 2010).  Due to their limited mobility macroinvertebrates are directly affected by their immediate surroundings making them an important indicator at a smaller reach monitoring scale (Platts et al. 1983).
objectives: Determine how benthic macroinvertebrate communities have changed as a result of in stream and floodplain habitat restoration.
3451.assumptions:
Access to impact and suitable control reaches will be provided.

Correct identification of macroinvertebrates by processing laboratory. 

Macroinvertebrate species captured in a particular habitat type are indicative of the actual species living in that habitat.

3455.background: Spring Chinook occupied the Okanogan river basin until becoming functionally extirpated in the mid-20th century.  In 2015, under Section 10(j) of the Endangered Species Act, hatchery-origin spring Chinook were released into the Okanogan River near Riverside, Washington.  As these fish return as adults, monitoring the status of the Okanogan spring chinook population through spawning grounds surveys becomes an important component in evaluating the success of the reintroduction and the status of spring Chinook in the Okanogan River.  Although at the beginning of implementation of this protocol it is expected that the majority of observed Chinook will be part of the 10(j) program, ALL spawning salmonids encountered during spawning grounds surveys, (hatchery and wild, 10(j) fish and otherwise, etc.) will be examined.
objectives: Recover spring Chinook carcasses in the Okanogan river basin, and compile data associated with carcass recoveries (age, length, sex, origin, tag history [PIT, cwt, radio tag, etc.], and spawn status).
Document and quantify spring Chinook spawning in the U.S. portion of the Okanogan river basin
3455.assumptions:
Surveyed stream reaches are representative such that extrapolation to portions of streams that are not able to be surveyed (due to access permission through private lands, etc.) are valid.

Carcasses located in surveyed stretches have equal probabilities of detection and persistence to the next sampling occasion

Fish per redd ratios remain constant throughout the Okaogan river basin

3458.background: A fundamental understanding of in-channel habitat condition is important for restoration practitioners engaged in assessments of factors limiting salmonid production, prioritization of protection and restoration activities, and coarse-scale evaluations of pre and post implementation conditions. To assist practitioners who would like low resolution assessments across broad spatial scales, or lack resources for intensive habitat status and effectiveness monitoring surveys, this protocol guides collection of datasets addressing channel unit composition, substrate, undercut banks, large woody debris, entrenchment and incision.

3460.background: Single-pass backpack electrofishing is a useful technique for evaluating presence-absence and coarse-scale relative abundance of fish species within wadeable streams while facilitating specimen procurement for tagging or genetic sampling purposes. This survey method is of particular value when sampling small streams which lack sufficient depth or pool frequency to snorkel effectively.
objectives: Delineation of standardized single-pass electrofishing techniques for the NPT Watershed Division in the interest of maximizing data consistency and minimizing injury to native fish species.
3460.assumptions: Capture efficiencies may vary profoundly between survey sites exhibiting dissimilar site-scale covariates (wetted width and depth, habitat and substrate composition, gradient, LWD and macrophyte density, etc.). Capture efficiencies are also affected by variables such as species age class/size structure, water temperature and lighting (intensity/glare/shade) at time of survey, equipment maintenance and survey staff.

3470.background:
Moist soil management is a valuable tool for the treatment of wetland habitats and the wildlife species associated with wetlands.  The ability to manage water levels, create disturbance, and manipulate vegetation to allow for more productive early successional wetland habitats is crucial to the TD-1 project.   Moist soil management provides critical habitat and food sources for wetland obligate and wetland associated species, while also allowing for valuable recreation opportunities.  Through this survey effort it is our goal to see how seed biomass differs in natural versus manipulated wetland basins.  Basins that are being surveyed have been harrowed and broadcast seeded, harrowed and drill seeded, and tilled to allow for volunteer crops to establish.

**2017 survey did not have tilled volunteer crops and sample quardants were 1 meter squared.

**2018 survey had sample quadrants that were 0.25 meter squared and sample sites were in different location in wetland basins.
objectives: To evaluate different moist soil management practices and compare effectiveness in producing high yields of seed for wildlife forage.
3470.assumptions: Wetlands that have been harrowed and seeded with Wild Millet and Smartweed will exhibit higher rates of seed biomass than wetlands left to naturally establish.  Furthermore, wetland basins that have been tilled will benefit from turning over soil and desirable vegetation will be allowed to establish.

3471.background: Our monitoring project is using this protocol to investigate the potential of using eDNA sampling to estimate population-level allele frequencies in Chinook and steelhead.  eDNA sampling is most commonly used for determining presence/absence of various species, but we are attempting to determine overall SNP genotypes and their frequencies at any given sampling site. The ability to estimate allele frequencies from eDNA sampling would allow for genetic sampling even if the stream temperatures are too hot for electrofishing safely, and could also increase the overall sampling coverage by allowing water collections below stream reaches that are inaccessible for whatever reason.
objectives: The objective of this protocol is to determine the feasibility of generating allele frequency information from eDNA sampling.
3471.assumptions:
1) eDNA in the water column is shed from a living organism or a recent corpse of the target species or taxonomic group;

2) eDNA does not move counter to the flow of water and does not enter the water column from a reservoir in sediments;

3) eDNA is not appreciably moved by predators/parasites or derive from anthropogenic sources.

metrics.title: SNP allele frequencies for Chinook and steelhead
metrics.subcategory: Genetics: Fish Diversity, Fitness or Variation

3473.background: The Kootenai River floodplain ecosystem has been significantly degraded due to wetland losses and impoundment during the last century causing nutrient deficiencies and reductions in habitat types and complexity. As a result, many fish and wildlife habitats along the river have collapsed to include, but not limited to, Kootenai River white sturgeon, burbot, bull trout, kokanee and other salmonids important to the Kootenai Tribe of Idaho and regional sport-fisheries. In response to declining fisheries and wildlife, the Kootenai Tribe of Idaho (KTOI) has started several mitigation efforts to offset habitat and chemical losses caused by Libby Dam. This protocol and the associated KTOI project (Kootenai River Operational Mitigation and Evaluation, BPA project # 200201100; and Albeni Falls Wildlife Mitigation, BPA project # 199206105), were designed to develop a biological baseline to determine which mitigation measures to implement, and, as a monitoring tool for future mitigation actions, such as in-river habitat improvements, to measure success by. Additionally, these projects (in conjunction with 199404900) currently assist in monitoring a nutrient restoration efforts on the Kootenai River. Thus it is important for this protocol to cover a broad swath of the Kootenai River's food web to include primary, secondary and tertiary productivity, along with important water chemistry parameters, such as dissolved phosphorus and nitrogen. This floodplain monitoring protocol allows habitat managers to adaptively manage the ecosystem's response to floodplain nutrient contributions and other project actions in the basin.
objectives: Evaluate potential changes in water quality and nutrients as a result of wetland contributions to the Kootenai River
3473.assumptions: Similar to the 199404900 project, key assumptions of this monitoring protocol are: laboratory results are reliable accurate; that spatially and temporally robust field data collection efforts will provide good long-term estimates of primary, seconday and tertiary biological productivity in the Kootenai River wetylands and floodplains; and, that statistically derived sample size estimates are adequate to characterize various trophic levels.

3481.background: The status of migratory salmonid populations are monitored by generating annual estimates of the number of adult spawners at either the tributary or watershed scale.  It is imperative to generate reliable estimates of spawners given that one of the primary objectives of recovery efforts is to augment sub-populations of migratory adults that would support a persistent meta-population structure at the watershed scale and ultimately provide a sustainable fishery.  Survival rates of salmonids during their residence time outside their spawning and early life-history rearing environment, a key vital rate in influencing population trajectories (Stapp and Hayward 2002), are also estimated to understand whether processes in adult rearing environments (e.g., larger streams or lakes) are limiting adult production.  Inclined-plane traps and weirs have been employed as a technique to sample juvenile and adult Westslope Cutthroat Trout in four tributaries to Priest River. The sampled tributaries to Priest River are Big, Quartz, Sadler, and Sanborn creeks.
objectives: Generate annual abundance estimates for migratory adult Westslope Cutthroat Trout at the tributary scale.
Generate annual estimates of juvenile to adult return rates for migratory Westslope Cutthroat Trout at the tributary scale.
Annually examine life-history attributes of migratory Westslope Cutthroat Trout (e.g. migration timing, sex ratio, mean size of fish).
Create interrogation histories for individual PIT tagged Westslope Cutthroat Trout to evaluate seasonal movements within watersheds.
Use interrogation data from stationary PIT arrays to describe the spatial distribution of the migratory life-history of Westslope Cutthroat Trout within watersheds.
3481.assumptions: Individual fish sampled at the migrant trap represent the population of interest at the tributary or watershed scale.

3482.background: Northern Pike invaded the Pend Oreille River, WA prior to 2004 from upstream illegal introductions in the Clark Fork and Flathead river systems, MT. Northern pike have become firmly established in Box Canyon Reservoir and expanded in number and range and to downstream reservoirs and the upper Columbia River. They threaten local native species recovery efforts and migration to the anadromous zone of the Columbia River is imminent and could be disastrous to multi-billion dollar tribal, commercial, and recreational salmon and steelhead fisheries and further complicate the recovery of ESA-listed species. Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife and the Kalispel Tribe developed the Spring Pike Index Netting Survey (SPIN) to monitor trends in abundance and population structure of northern pike in Box Canyon Reservoir and to evaluate the effectiveness of measures taken to drastically reduce their abundance.
objectives: Reduce and maintain Northern Pike (NP) abundance, measured by CPUE, in the SPIN survey to <1.7 NP/net night in the south half and 0.5 NP/net night in the north half of Box Canyon Reservoir.
3482.assumptions: Northern pike inhabitat near-shore littoral zones and sloughs during spring. Northern pike aged 2 and older are recruited to multimesh gill nets (1"-2" panels). Gill nets can be effectively fished during spring under varying reservoir flows and elevation. Catch-per-effort as an index of abundance is linearly related to true abundance.

3487.background: Egg-to-fry survival is one of the major factors thought to limit freshwater production and recovery of Chinook salmon Oncorhynchus tshawytscha and other salmon populations (Reiser and White 1988; Peterson and Quinn 1996; DeVries 1997). Despite being critical data that is needed to assist with efforts to recover threatened and endangered salmonid populations, adequate estimates of egg-to-fry survival for Chinook salmon do not currently exist (Healey 1991; Bradford 1995). This lack of information is likely due to the difficulty in measuring Chinook salmon and other salmonid egg-to-fry survival in the field because they deposit their eggs in the gravel during periods that make extensive field research difficult (Quinn 2005). This is particularly true for Chinook salmon, which spawn in large rivers with deeper and swifter water than most other salmon, and for which developing embryos remain in the gravel throughout the winter and early spring when it is difficult to sample (Quinn 2005). Therefore, many of the existing studies of Chinook salmon egg-to-fry survival have occurred in a laboratory setting (Jensen et al. 2009) and may not adequately represent egg-to-fry survival in the natural environment. This work provides estimates of survival and development, and an assessment of factor potentially affecting either metric, over large temporal and spatial scales, in the natural environment. See Johnson et al (2012) for a complete explanation of the methodology associated with this protocol
objectives: Investigate the extent to which environmental factors such as scour, redd superimposition, fines sediment infiltration, and temperature may influence survival and development spatially and temporally.
Estimate relative developmental stage at recovery among and within primary spawning locations of the target watershed, within and among years, while controlling for parental effects.
Estimate relative summer Chinook egg-to-fry survival among and within primary spawning locations of the target watershed, within and among years, while controlling for parental effects.
3487.assumptions:
1) Selected study locations are spatially and temporally representative of the population

2) Environmental conditions within buried Whitlock-Vibert egg boxes are representative of conditions in the surrounding environment (see Wesche et al. 1989; Garrett and Bennett 1996).

3) Environmental conditions experienced among study years sufficiently represent inter-annual variation within the target watershed.

4) A simple thermal sums model is sufficient to calculate duration of deployment such that developmental stage at recovery is similar among study areas; which may differ substantially in the rate and magnitude of temperature unit delivery to the egg pocket.

citation.title: Estimating Summer Chinook Egg-to-Fry Survival in the Okanogan Basin v1.0

3497.background: The subpopulation of white sturgeon inhabiting the upper Columbia River above Grand Coulee Dam is classified as Critically Endangered (CE) by the IUCN and listed as endangered under the Canadian Species At Risk Act (SARA) due to persistent recruitment failure. Recruitment failure in the area between Grand Coulee and Hugh Keenleyside dams (the Transboundary Reach) white sturgeon population was first documented during surveys of both the Keenleyside Reach (British Columbia) and the Roosevelt Reach (Washington state) in the 1990’s (Hildebrand et al. 1999; DeVore et al. 2000). In response to concerns over the threat of extinction, the Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Initiative (UCWSRI) was formed in 2000. The Initiative produced an Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Plan (UCWSRP) that is compatible with the ESA and SARA legislation. The goal of the UCWSRI, as defined in the UCWSRP, “is to ensure the persistence and viability of naturally reproducing populations of white sturgeon in the upper Columbia River and restore opportunities for beneficial use if feasible.” Population status and trend monitoring are considered core components of the recovery effort and this protocol describes how setline stock assessment surveys in the Roosevelt Reach will provide information on population parameters. Survey methodology and implementation will be standardized, coordinated, and conducted simultaneously with surveys conducted in Lake Roosevelt by the Colville Tribe White Sturgeon Enhancement Project (Project # 2008-116-00) and BC Hydro in the Keenleyside Reach.
objectives: Estimate the abundance of hatchery and wild components of the white sturgeon population.
Describe spatial and depth distributions of white sturgeon.
Estimate growth and condition of hatchery and wild components of the white sturgeon population.
Estimate survival rates in the hatchery and wild components of the white sturgeon population.
3497.assumptions: Our frame is representative of our target population.

3498.background:
White Sturgeon (Acipenser transmontanus) have seen a worldwide decline in the previous century due to habitat loss, population fragmentation and changing environmental conditions. The sturgeon population located in the Roosevelt Reach of the Columbia River in Washington State was isolated from other Columbia River populations following the construction of Grand Coulee, Hugh Keenleyside and Waneta Dams during the 20th century. This population is listed as Critically Endangered by the IUCN and endangered under the Canadian Species at Risk Act.

In the 1990s recruitment failure was documented in this population (Hildebrand et al. 1999; DeVore et al. 2000) and recreational fishing was prohibited. Conservation measures were undertaken through coordination between multiple US and Canadian agencies throughout the 2000s and 2010s, including an conservation aquaculture program. This program provided hatchery juvenile sturgeon through the capture of wild broodstock adults, which were then artificially spawned out. The numbers produced from broodstock were sufficient for hatchery aquaculture, but the survival rate of these releases were much higher than anticipated. This led to a potiental genetic overrepresentation issue.

Beginning in 2017 a fishery for White Sturgeon was began on the US portion of the transboundary reach due to concerns that the overrepresented families from the conservation aquaculture program releases could swamp the genetic diversity of the population when they reached sexual maturity.This fishery was reopened again in 2018, 2019 and is planned to be reopened annually in coming years. In response to this fishery a White Sturgeon specific creel was designed and implemented in 2019 in order to gain an accurate harvest/effort rate of the population.
objectives: To accurately estimate White Sturgeon harvest, angler effort, catch rate and success during the annual Washington State sturgeon fishery on Lake Roosevelt

3499.background:
The Columbia River Redband Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss gairdnerii) are a subspecies of Rainbow Trout native to the Columbia River basin east of the Cascades to barrier falls on the Spokane, Pend Oreille, Kootenay and Snake rivers. Both anadromous (ocean migrating; A.K.A. steelhead) and potamodromous (freshwater only) forms of Columbia River Redband Trout exist, but migration of anadromous stocks in the upper Columbia River drainage were eliminated with the construction of Grand Coulee and Chief Joseph dams. Potamodromous Columbia River Redband Trout (hereafter referred to as Redband Trout) were estimated to reside in 43% of their historic range. Of the remaining potamodromous Redband Trout, four life history strategies have been identified: fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, lacustrine-adfluvial, and allacustrine.

Currently Redband Trout are classified as a sensitive species or a species of concern by several state and federal agencies. The Northwest Power and Conservation Council’s Spokane Subbasin and Upper Columbia Management Plans, as well as the Lake Roosevelt Guiding Document, list Redband Trout as native focal species and provide goals and objectives that protect, restore and enhance native Redband Trout populations and their habitats. A four-year study on Redband Trout in the Blue Creek watershed on the Spokane Indian Reservation found survival of outmigrating redband trout to be low; with a survival from juvenile to adfluvial adult ranging from 0.16%-1.68%. Predation by introduced species is one of the limiting factors of Redband Trout in the Spokane River and Lake Roosevelt. A study conducted by McLellan et al. (2000) calculated Walleye abundance in Lake Roosevelt to range from 84,335-180,568 individuals in 1998. Baldwin et al. (2003) estimated that Rainbow Trout was up to 25% of walleye’s diet and calculated that 7.3% of hatchery Rainbow Trout were consumed by Walleye within 41 days of release in Lake Roosevelt. Another study conducted in the Sanpoil Arm of Lake Roosevelt estimated that introduced Smallmouth Bass and Walleye consumed 24% of yearling wild Redband Trout and 27.4% of two and three-year-old wild Redband Trout (Stroud et al. 2010). Although few studies have been conducted in Lake Roosevelt, the results from these studies show a substantial impact to Redband Trout populations caused by predation from non-native species. The 2016 Fall Walleye Index Netting (FWIN) surveys found that the mean total length of Walleye in Lake Roosevelt was 337mm (76mm Standard Deviation; Silver et al. 2018; Schmuck 2017). The Baldwin et al. 2003 study mentioned above also calculated the gape limit of walleye at various sizes, and found that a walleye at approximately 337mm would not be able to feed on trout larger than approximately 165mm in total length.

This project aims to protect and enhance native Redband Trout populations by reducing the level of predation on outmigrating juveniles. This project identifies watersheds with low or declining Redband Trout populations, captures juvenile adfluvial Redband Trout and repatriates the trout at a larger size, which should result in a greater return of spawning adults and improve the Redband Trout populations within watersheds in the upper Columbia River basin.
objectives: Repatriate captured juvenile Redband Trout near their natal spawning grounds.
Raise captured juvenile Redband Trout to an average minimum of 165mm in fork length.
Capture a proportion of outmigrating juvenile Redband Trout in watersheds with low or declining populations to reduce predation.

3501.background:
Due to persistent recruitment failure, the subpopulation of white sturgeon inhabiting the upper Columbia River above Grand Coulee Dam is classified as Critically Endangered by the IUCN and endangered under the Canadian Species at Risk Act. Recruitment failure in the area between Grand Coulee and HLK dams (the Transboundary Reach) White Sturgeon population was first documented during surveys of both the Keenleyside Reach (British Columbia) and the Roosevelt Reach (Washington State) in the 1990’s (Hildebrand et al. 1999; DeVore et al. 2000). A conservation aquaculture program was began in 200??? in order to mitigate for this lack of recruitment. However, continued monitoring for natural recruitment is essential. Further, monitoring allows for researchers to gauge effectiveness of treatments addressing recruitment failure and to monitor the conservation aquaculture release populations.

Surveys will be standardized, coordinated and conducted simultaneously with efforts by the Colville Tribe's White Sturgeon Enhancement Project (WSEP BPA Project # 2008-116-00 ) and those conducted in the Keenleyside Reach.

3504.background: Since 2003, entities in the U.S. and Canada working collaboratively under the Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Initiative Transboundary Telemetry and Data Management Project have collectively acoustic tagged approximately 450 white sturgeon of various sizes and ages in the Transboundary Reach (Grand Coulee Dam in WA to HLK Dam in BC) of the Columbia River to monitor movements (e.g. spawning migrations) spawning fidelity, survival rates and seasonal habitat use (e.g. overwintering areas). Tagged sturgeon are passively tracked with a longitudinal array of acoustic receivers that has been developed and maintained by various U.S. and Canadian agencies that extends from Grand Coulee Dam in Washington state to HLK Dam in British Columbia. While a great deal of acoustic data has been collected to date, continued operation of the array is desirable. Many sturgeon have been outfitted with acoustic tags in both the US and Canada and these individuals provide the opportunity to continue to build upon a data set that is meaningful in the context of long term sturgeon behavorial movements. In addtion, the maintenance of the array over the long term also provides the opportunity for its utilization by other researchers to conduct studies on other species of interest in Lake Roosevelt
objectives: Monitor general movements and habitat use of telemetered sturgeon in the Roosevelt Reach
Maintain, monitor and download data from receiver array 4 times annually for addition to data bank
3504.assumptions: Our frame is representative of our target population.

3508.background:
Temporal and spatial predator-prey overlap and consequential predatory impacts on juvenile anadromous salmonids is becoming a major source of their mortality in sections of the Columbia River (Erhardt et al. 2018; McMichael 2018). Currently, 51% of non-native species in the upper Columbia River are piscivores and have negative impacts on native salmonids and on the Columbia River food webs (ISAB 2011; Naiman et al. 2012).

Carpenter et al. (2019) indicated that catch rates in the lower Columbia River for SMB in 2018 was the highest for the period of record and WAL were in relatively high abundance compared to previous years. Several studies in the John Day Reservoir have documented that WAL and SMB consumed juvenile salmon and had significant impacts on their survival (Rieman et al 1991; Zimmerman 1999). Most predator studies in the Columbia River have been conducted downstream of McNary Dam (Poe at al. 1986; Beamesderfer and Rieman. 1991; Poe at al. 1991; Rieman et al. 1991; Vigg et al. 1991; Hansel et al. 1993; Isaak and Bjorn 1993; Marinelli et al. 1993; Ward et al. 1995; Friesen and Ward 1999; Zimmerman 1999; Petersen 2001; Thomas and Ward 2011; Ward and Zimmerman 2011) and have documented or estimated substantial predation losses of salmon to native and non-native piscivores.

The Independent Science Advisory Board (2011) found the need to implement a region-wide monitoring program on the temporal pace and spatial extent of non-native introductions, identifying impending problems while they are still small and manageable. Once identified, intervention should happen quickly whenever and wherever invasive problems are likely to emerge, averting problems when possible, or slowing them down, when not completely avoidable. The ISAB and ISRP recently identified two new uncertainties related to predation (ISAB/ISRP 2016). The first uncertainty relates to which predators jeopardize the viability of native fishes and the second relates to the effectiveness of management actions to ameliorate undesirable impacts of predation. More recently, the ISAB identified predation as a major concern in recovery of ESA-listed salmonids and recommended an ecosystem based approach to better understand the relative impacts of predation on salmonids by different native and non-native species throughout the Columbia Basin (ISAB 2019). Sanderson et al. (2009) suggest that the overall impact of non-indigenous species on salmon recovery may meet or exceed the cumulative impact of the conventional 4-H’s sources of mortality (i.e., habitat, hydro, hatcheries and harvest).

Currently, fish predator abundance and population trends, and juvenile salmonid consumption estimates upstream of McNary Dam are not well understood. The objective of this study is to determine the status and trend of non-native fish predator density and abundance upstream of McNary Dam in the mainstem Columbia River. Under an adaptive management approach, predator population abundance and growth rates will be monitored and used to evaluate the effectiveness of current (i.e., deregulating harvest) and future management actions designed to increase juvenile salmon survival, with the ability to identify significant changes in predator population status over time and space.
objectives: Estimate predator fish density and abundance by habitat class in the mainstem Columbia River upstream of McNary Dam.
Estimate predatory fish consumption rates by species and size class on juvenile salmon and steelhead.

3513.background:
The Columbia River Redband Trout Oncorhynchus mykiss gairdneri are a subspecies of Rainbow Trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains. Their known distribution extends upstream as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992). There is considerable variability in the life history of Columbia River Redband Trout (Redband Trout) including both anadromous (O. mykiss that migrate to the ocean) and potamodromous (O. mykiss that migrate solely within fresh water) forms (Behnke 1992). Recently, potamodromous Redband Trout were estimated to occur in 42% of their historic range with invasive species habitat degradation and fragmentation, and climate change being the primary threats to their long term survival (Muhlfeld 2015). Redband Trout are classified as a sensitive species or species of special concern by several states and federal agencies and the American Fisheries Society Endangered Species Committee (Williams et al. 1989; Muhlfeld et al. 2001).

The construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939 eliminated the opportunity for Redband Trout in the Upper Columbia River to express anadromy (Scholz et al. 1985) and likely blocked migration routes and isolated populations and habitats of potamodromous Redband Trout. Lake Roosevelt formed in the impounded portion of the Columbia River behind Grand Coulee Dam and supports important tribal and recreational fisheries. Non-native hatchery Rainbow Trout (McCloud River, California  O. stonei) have been stocked in the upper Columbia River and its tributaries to provide angling opportunities and as mitigation for hydropower related impacts (Stober et al. 1977; Peone et al. 1989). Naturally reproducing Rainbow Trout still occur in the upper Columbia River drainage upstream of Grand Coulee Dam. 

Potamodromy can be divided into four types: fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, lacustrine-adfluvial, and allacustrine (Varley and Gresswell 1988; Northcote 1997). Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries support fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, and lacustrine-adfluvial life history types. All three life history types have also been documented within the Sanpoil River drainage, including a small fall run of lacustrine adfluvial fish (Brown et al. 2013). The Sanpoil is the only documented tributary in Lake Roosevelt supporting fall migrating adult Redband Trout.

Microsatellite DNA analysis conducted on wild-born Rainbow Trout in the upper Columbia River drainage indicated that some stocks were pure Redband Trout (Powell and Faler 2002; Taylor 2002; Small and Dean 2006, 2007; Small et al. 2007). Redband Trout persisted in many tributaries with no history of coastal-lineage hatchery Rainbow Trout introductions and where barriers prevented hatchery fish from moving into tributaries (Small et al. 2007).

The Redband Trout Stock Assessment Project (RTSAP) was initiated in Lake Roosevelt by the three co-managers in 2010, Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW), Colville Confederated Tribes (CCT), and the Spokane Tribe of Indians (STI). One of the objectives of RTSAP study is to develop a basin wide genetic stock inventory of the remnant Redband Trout populations in the Lake Roosevelt watershed. This information will be used by regional fisheries managers to assist with habitat restoration plans, conservation needs, and harvest regulation changes.
objectives: Determine the genetic status (pure, introgressed, or naturalized non-native) of wild trout populations within the Lake Roosevelt watershed.
3513.assumptions:
The tissue samples collected for each population are representative of the entire genetic diversity found within the population and not just a small sample representing siblings.

The 192 SNPs are appropriate for determining Redband Trout population level distinctions.

3515.background: The migration of the anadromous life history form of redband trout was eliminated from the upper Columbia River with the construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939 and likely isolated populations of potamodromous redband trout. Identification of wild redband trout populations and their life history strategies have not been completed in portion of the Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River. This protocol evaluates Redband Trout populations in tributaries to the Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River. Stock assessments under this protocol will use a variety of trapping, electrofishing and tagging methods to estimate population size within the stream, as well as evaluate recruitment to larger water bodies, survival within and outside of tributaries, age class structure, proportions of fluvial to adfluvial Redband Trout within tributaries, movement within and outside of tributaries and spawner escapement.

Estimate annual spawner escapement of Redband Trout.
Estimate age at maturity of Redband Trout.
Estimate growth of fluvial and adfluvial Redband Trout.

Estimate recruitment of Redband Trout from their natal tributary to the Columbia and Spokane Rivers.

Estimate abundance of Redband Trout within tributaries.

3517.background: The migration of the anadromous life history form of Redband Trout was eliminated from the upper Columbia River with the construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939, and likely isolated populations and habitats of potamodromous Redband Trout. Comprehensive habitat assessments in riverine systems that contain Redband Trout populations have not been completed in the Spokane River, Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River. This protocol evaluates Redband Trout habitat in riverine systems within the upper Columbia River basin. Habitat assessments will allow managers to better understand Redband Trout population characteristics as well as identify habitat factors that may influence populations. 3518.background:
White Sturgeon diet in the impounded Upper Columbia River has seen less study compared to other sturgeon populations in the Pacific Northwest. Some moderate research regarding larval and juvenile life stages has been done (Crossman; Hildebrand et al 2016), but little data is available on adult diet composition. A better understanding of adult sturgeon diet in the Upper Columbia is essential in determining carrying capacity and designing bioenergetics models as repatriation continues.

The largest hurdle in studying adult diet composition is that White Sturgeon are classified as Critically Endangered (CE) by the IUCN and listed as endangered under the Canadian Species At Risk Act (SARA) due to persistent recruitment failure, which makes the sacrifice of adults for stomach samples not a viable option unless deceased adults are recovered from the river, which is rare and does not provide enough data for study. However, other options for exploring White Sturgeon diet are available. Using isotope analysis for the study the diet of White Sturgeon in the Upper Columbia River is a non-lethal, low impact method and has been proven an effective option (Smith et al 2016).
objectives: To determine proportions of prey items contributing to White Sturgeon diet
To examine intra-specific diet variability and size related shifts in diet

3520.background: Submerged aquatic habitat in the Spokane Tribe’s usual and accustomed areas has not been assessed to date. Quantifying aquatic habitats in deep, swift, cold water is challenging and can be costly; however, accurate assessment of aquatic habitat is critical to improve the understanding of the distribution and status of aquatic species. Low-cost sonar habitat mapping technology has been shown to accurately assess critical habitat for many aquatic species including sturgeon and freshwater mussels (Litts and Kaeser 2016; Smit and Kaeser 2016; Kaeser and Litts 2010). Low cost side scan sonar and habitat mapping will provide baseline substrate, vegetation, and morphological habitat condition in the form of raster imagery and polygon shapefiles that can be easily shared, archived, and used to direct and inform management actions across program disciplines.
objectives: Produce sonar imagery of submerged features and create benthic aquatic habitat mosaic maps from the usual and accustomed areas of the Spokane Tribe.

3525.background:
Conservation aquaculture programs can minimize the risk of inbreeding in supplemented populations by maximizing the number of parents represented within and across year classes produced in the hatchery. Including many parents in conservation aquaculture will also bolster the genetic diversity of the supplemented population and increase effective population size. Conventional conservation aquaculture programs that spawn wild broodstock and rear full-sibling or maternal half-sibling families separately typically know the actual or maximum possible number of parents represented in released cohorts. Repatriation-based conservation aquaculture programs, which capture eggs or larvae directly from wild spawning sites, do not know how many parents contribute to the spawning events sampled. However, genetic markers can be used in concert with statistical approaches to reconstruct family groups and estimate the number of spawners contributing to individual spawning events or total released cohorts. We propose to use genetic markers (microsatellites and/or SNPs) to reconstruct family groups and estimate the number of spawners contributing to a repatriation program for Upper Columbia River white sturgeon at the Waneta spawning site. 

Task 1 (Years 1-2). DNA will be extracted from fin clips collected from juvenile white sturgeon released from the Waneta and American repatriation programs (N = 100-200/year/program; 2 years = 400-800 samples total). Individuals will be genotyped at 13 microsatellite loci (Rodzen and May 2002; Zhu et al. 2005; Börk et al. 2008) and ~300 SNP loci (CRITFC, unpublished data) in Year 1. In Year 2, individuals will be genotyped at whichever marker exhibits superior performance at pedigree reconstruction.  The program Colony (Jones and Wang 2010) will be used with each marker set to reconstruct full sibling families and estimate Ns. Analysis of microsatellite data will follow the pipeline of Thorstensen et al. (accepted). In brief, genotypes from Upper Columbia samples will be used to simulate families of known parentage to establish which inclusive and exclusive probability values in Colony maximize the accuracy in identifying full sibling and unrelated individuals for spawner number estimation. Once inclusive and exclusive probability thresholds have been established, total Ns per year and Ns per spawning event (for the Waneta program) will be estimated. Genetic diversity represented by spawning events and by year classes will be estimated by calculating the number of alleles per locus and number of alleles/individual/locus.

Task 2 (Years 2-3). DNA will be extracted from fin clips taken from larval white sturgeon collected in the American Upper Columbia repatriation program (N = 100-200/year, 2 years). Colony will be used to determine whether individuals captured in the American reach in a particular year originate from Waneta spawning that year. Samples from the American reach and the Waneta repatriation program from each year will be analyzed together to determine whether any inferred full sibling families include individuals from both sampling locations. This would be evidence that Waneta-origin larvae are drifting into American sampling sites.
objectives: Determine if white sturgeon drifting downstream from the Waneta spawning site are captured in the American repatriation program.
Assess number of spawners (Ns) represented and genetic diversity captured in the Waneta and American repatriation efforts

3526.background: In 1949, the construction of Grand Coulee Dam on the Columbia River formed Franklin D. Roosevelt Lake (Lake Roosevelt). Grand Coulee Dam was built without fish passage and permanently blocked the anadromous migratory pathways of numerous fish species, extirpating salmon and lamprey and fragmenting resident fish populations. The current resident fishery is supported by the Lake Roosevelt Artificial Production Program (LRAPP), comprised of the Spokane Tribal Hatchery, WDFW Sherman Creek State Hatchery, and the volunteer operated Lake Roosevelt Rainbow Trout Net Pen Project. The LRAPP releases hatchery fish as partial mitigation for the loss of anadromous fish runs and supports a recreational and subsistence fishery for kokanee and rainbow trout. Rainbow Trout production began in 1986 which provided Rainbow Trout fingerlings to the volunteer net pen program operated by the Lake Roosevelt Development Association . Stocking strategies for Rainbow Trout include hatchery rearing from egg to fingerlings, then transfer to net pens to grow to yearlings, at which time they were released into the reservoir. The Lake Roosevelt Rainbow Trout Net Pen Program (BPA Project No.1995-00900) coordinates volunteers to feed the trout, maintain the net pens and release the fish after reservoir drawdown and when zooplankton biomass is adequate for forage (May-June). With the goal of monitoring production and success of the LRAPP the LRFEP assesses triploid Rainbow Trout fin clip quality and performance prior to release from net pens, and manually enumerates a subset of net pens to characterize rearing survival.
objectives: Conduct annual net pen Quality Assurance (QA) surveys assessing triploid Rainbow Trout fin clip performance, condition, and enumerations of net pens to characterize rearing survival.

3527.background:
Due to persistent recruitment failure, the subpopulation of white sturgeon inhabiting the upper Columbia River above Grand Coulee Dam is classified as Critically Endangered by the IUCN and endangered under the Canadian Species at Risk Act. Recruitment failure in the area between Grand Coulee and HLK dams (the Transboundary Reach) White Sturgeon population was first documented during surveys of both the Keenleyside Reach (British Columbia) and the Roosevelt Reach (Washington State) in the 1990’s (Hildebrand et al. 1999; DeVore et al. 2000). A conservation aquaculture program was began in 2012 in order to mitigate for this lack of recruitment. However, continued monitoring for natural recruitment is essential. Further, monitoring allows for researchers to gauge effectiveness of treatments addressing recruitment failure and to monitor the conservation aquaculture release populations.

Surveys will be standardized, coordinated and conducted simultaneously with efforts by the Colville Tribe's White Sturgeon Enhancement Project (WSEP BPA Project # 2008-116-00 ) and those conducted in the Keenleyside Reach.
objectives: To monitor annual natural recruitment of White Sturgeon in Lake Roosevelt.

3528.background:
The Columbia River Redband Trout Oncorhynchus mykiss gairdneri are a subspecies of Rainbow Trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains. Their known distribution extends upstream as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992). There is considerable variability in the life history of Columbia River Redband Trout (Redband Trout) including both anadromous (O. mykiss that migrate to the ocean) and potamodromous (O. mykiss that migrate solely within fresh water) forms (Behnke 1992). Recently, potamodromous Redband Trout were estimated to occur in 42% of their historic range with invasive species habitat degradation and fragmentation, and climate change being the primary threats to their long term survival (Muhlfeld 2015). Redband Trout are classified as a sensitive species or species of special concern by several states and federal agencies and the American Fisheries Society Endangered Species Committee (Williams et al. 1989; Muhlfeld et al. 2001).

The construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939 eliminated the opportunity for Redband Trout in the Upper Columbia River to express anadromy (Scholz et al. 1985) and likely blocked migration routes and isolated populations and habitats of potamodromous Redband Trout. Lake Roosevelt formed in the impounded portion of the Columbia River behind Grand Coulee Dam and supports important tribal and recreational fisheries. Non-native hatchery Rainbow Trout (McCloud River, California  O. stonei) have been stocked in the upper Columbia River and its tributaries to provide angling opportunities and as mitigation for hydropower related impacts (Stober et al. 1977; Peone et al. 1989). Naturally reproducing Rainbow Trout still occur in the upper Columbia River drainage upstream of Grand Coulee Dam. 

Potamodromy can be divided into four types: fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, lacustrine-adfluvial, and allacustrine (Varley and Gresswell 1988; Northcote 1997). Lake Roosevelt and its tributaries support fluvial, fluvial-adfluvial, and lacustrine-adfluvial life history types. All three life history types have also been documented within the Sanpoil River drainage, including a small fall run of lacustrine adfluvial fish (Brown et al. 2013). The Sanpoil is the only documented tributary in Lake Roosevelt supporting fall migrating adult Redband Trout.

An acoustic tagging study will allow researchers to determine effects of hydropower operations at Grand Coulee Dam on upper Columbia River Redband Trout populations. Several populations of Redband Trout in the upper Columbia River are designated as conservation populations. Understanding where these fish migrate within the reservoir, and the impacts of hydropower operations (i.e., entrainment) will allow researchers to better manage these populations.
objectives: Determine Redband Trout reservoir usage and entrainment by in Lake Roosevelt

3530.background:
An expanding Walleye population has the potential to put several fish populations in Lake Pend Oreille at risk through direct predation and competition.  Walleye are prolific piscivores and their establishment in other western lentic systems has led to significant fishery management challenges, particularly where they overlap with salmonid fisheries.  Lake Pend Oreille represents a critical stronghold for Bull Trout within their native range.  Cutthroat Trout populations in Lake Pend Oreille are depressed relative to historic abundances, but they appear to be reasonably ubiquitous, thus providing some diversity to the sport fishery as well as life history diversity and conservation value.  Rainbow Trout provide a popular world-class trophy fishery that largely depends on abundant kokanee for forage.  Kokanee provide a popular yield fishery on the lake and represent a forage base for adfluvial Bull Trout.  Lake Trout suppression programs were instituted to reduce predation risk when we began to observe rapid population increases, as we are now seeing with Walleye.  Should Walleye abundances continue to increase and the scope of their niche expand to include ecologically significant predation on kokanee, Cutthroat Trout, and juvenile Bull Trout and Rainbow Trout, some of the conservation advancement made through previous suppression programs may be jeopardized.

Habitats used by nonnative fish populations that threaten our recovery efforts are currently unknown in Lake Pend Oreille.  Telemetry is a useful tool for providing information on general movements, spawning locations and timing, and habitat use.  Stationary telemetry receivers and active tracking results will provide locational data on areas where fish are concentrated spatially and temporally and will be shared with commercial netters to guide net placement and improve netting efficiencies.  Telemetry results will also be shared with anglers to improve catch rates and exploitation rates.
objectives: Document movement extent, habitat use, spawn timing of Walleye, Northern Pike, Rainbow Trout, and Lake Trout to help guide suppression efforts and to determine factors limiting recruitment (RBT).

3534.background:
To address impacts to native Westslope Cutthroat Trout (cutthroat) populations by non-native Brook Trout, actions have been implemented to reduce their abundance in select streams. Mechanical, chemical or alternative removal methods have been applied, that reduce Brook trout abundance and allow natural or assisted re-occupancy of vacated habitat.

In Mill Creek, multiple-pass backpack electrofishing has been employed as the primary method to reduce Brook Trout, yet established populations can be difficult to control or eradicate with traditional techniques (Britton et al. 2010). To augment this method, we are attempting to shift the sex ratio of the Brook Trout population through use of the Trojan Y Chromosome method, consisting of production and stocking of male fish that are genetically YY (MYY), instead of XY, into areas inhabited by the non-native species targeted for removal (Gutierrez and Teem 2006; Teem and Gutierrez 2010; Schill et al. 2016, 2017).  All offspring produced by MYY males are male.  In theory, if stocked MYY males successfully spawn with female Brook Trout from the target population and contribute sufficient numbers of offspring, the sex ratio of the target population should shift toward male fish.  Over time, given continued stocking, the target population should eventually become 100% male, resulting ultimately in extirpation.

IDFG developed MYY Brook Trout stocks (Schill et al. 2016) and modelled the success of coupling various MYY Brook Trout stocking strategies and levels of active suppression of the extant population (Schill et al. 2017). The Western Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies subsequently initiated trials of stocked MYY Brook Trout in several western states. Mill Creek was selected as a a pilot project due to active Brook Trout suppression that has taken place by the Kalispel Tribe since 2018. Approximately 3,000-4,000 MYY Brook Trout have been stocked in Mill Creek annually since 2018. The the intent of this project is to evaluate MYY contribution toward shifting the population to predominantly males, thus expediting the extirpation of Brook Trout from Mill Creek and allowing cutthroat to eventually reoccupy >30 km of vacated habitat.

Using annual genetic tissue sampling of juveniles, parentage information collected will inform the spawning success of stocked MYY Brook Trout. Genetic determination of sex will inform ratio shifts from the expected normal proportion of males in a wild population (i.e., 0.5).
objectives: Conduct annual genetic parentage analyses to determine if Myy Brook Trout have successfully spawned with the extant population.
Conduct annual genetic evaluation to estimate the sex ratio and determine if male Brook Trout abundance is increasing as a result of successive Myy Brook Trout spawning with the extant population.

3537.background:
The White Sturgeon population of Lake Roosevelt has documented recruitment failure since the early 1990s (Hildebrand et al. 1999; DeVore et al. 2000). The UCWSRI (Upper Columbia White Sturgeon Recovery Initiative) which was established for the continued conservation of White Sturgeon in the Transboundary Reach, decided that a conservation aquaculture program was needed in order to account for this loss of recruitment. Annual conservation aquaculture operations utilize wild caught larvae as a source of progeny in order to preserve the remaining genetic diversity. These wild caught larvae harbor greater genetic diversity than hatchery broodstock progeny (Schreier and May 2012) and therefore it was decided to pursue wild caught larvae over the previously used broodstock for aquaculture sources. 

Larval collection efforts for the conservation aquaculture program are conducted just above the China Bend boat launch during the months of June and July. White Sturgeon larval monitoring is conducted to detect a peak in larval numbers. After a peak in numbers is detected, the collection phase begins a week later. Sampling is conducted throughout the spawning period in order to increase the genetic diversity represented by the aquaculture program.
objectives: Annually collect wild origin White Sturgeon Larvae during their larval dispersion drift phase
Annually release 3,000 wild caught White Sturgeon larvae at a size of release of 200g to meet adult abundance and harvest targets

3540.background: Fish inhabited wetlands versus fish free wetlands and the effects that fish have on invertebrate populations and waterfowl production has been an ongoing investigation for decades. In North America most studies pertaining to this issue are conducted in the prairie pothole region. This region is considered the most important duck production habitat in North America because it can account for 50% of annual production of ducks on this continent (Smith et al. 1964) and 20 of 34 species of ducks that breed in North America are present in the area (Batt et al. 1989). Much of the importance of the prairie pothole region to breeding ducks stems from high biomass and secondary productivity of macroinvertebrates in prairie potholes (Bataille and Baldassarre 1993). The Columbia Basin Irrigation Project (CBIP) has created attractive wetland habitat for breeding ducks, and after completion of CBIP, breeding duck pairs increased significantly (Foster and Myers 1984). In 1985, when weighted breeding population indices were around 200,000 the wasteway stratum (primarily in the Desert unit of the Wildlife Area) supported 77 breeding duck pairs/km2, which is comparable to densities in the prairie pothole region (M. Monda, WDFW, unpublished data, Giudice et al. 2000). However, waterfowl productivity and wetland diversity within the Columbia Basin have consistently declined in recent years (Columbia Basin Wildlife Area Wetland Management Plan, WDFW, 2006). Fish are believed to be a culprit for this decline because they depress vegetative and invertebrate communities. Fish presence significantly alters composition and abundance of invertebrate communities (Batzer et al. 2000, Zimmer et al. 2001) and typically reduces invertebrate availability to waterfowl (Bendell and McNicol 1995, Bouffard and Hanson 1997). Most wetlands within the CBIP are currently inhabited by fish. However, there are a few isolated wetlands that do not include fish and others that have potential to be rehabilitated and managed as fish-free. Our hypothesis that we tested is that relative abundance of invertebrates differs between ponds with and without fish.
objectives: To assess invertebrate biomass, species richness, and diversity in wetlands that include and exclude fish.  Then evaluate how that impacts local waterfowl production.

3542.background:
The Northwest Forest Plan, hereafter referred to as “the Plan”, was approved in 1994. The Plan includes an Aquatic Conservation Strategy that requires the protection, rehabilitation, and monitoring of aquatic ecosystems under the Plan’s jurisdiction (U.S. Forest Service, & U.S. Bureau of Land Management, 1994). The Aquatic and Riparian Effectiveness Monitoring Program (AREMP or the monitoring plan) was developed to fulfill these monitoring requirements. The primary purpose of AREMP is to determine the current condition of 6th-field watersheds and track changes in watershed condition over time. A total of 250 watersheds will be monitored under AREMP. One of the most important aspects of the program is the collection of consistent data throughout the Northwest Forest Plan area to provide comparative data used to assess watershed condition.

The field data collected is combined with upslope and riparian information to determine watershed condition. Condition is determined using a decision support model that evaluates individual indicators and then aggregates the evaluation scores. The stream data collected in the field represent about 2/3 of the data included in the decision support model. As natural variance both within and between the watersheds is quite high, it is imperative that errors due to sampling and observer bias are minimized. The data collected will be used as the basis for management decisions throughout the Pacific Northwest. These data comprise one of the largest data sets that exist in the Pacific Northwest, both spatially and temporally. Therefore, it is of the utmost importance to make the effort to produce the highest quality data possible. This document is addressed in section 11.1 Standard Operating Procedures of the Quality System Management Plan (Palmer, in prep).

The goal is to efficiently and safely collect the best data possible within a watershed.
objectives: Is the Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) maintaining or restoring aquatic and riparian ecosystems to desired conditions on federal lands in the Forest Plan area?
Provide information for adaptive management by analyzing trends in watershed condition and identifying causes of unsuitable or unacceptable conditions.
Provide a framework for adaptive monitoring at the regional scale.
Develop predictive models to improve use of monitoring data, potentially reducing the number of attributes measured and long-term monitoring costs.
Develop and validate decision support models that are used to evaluate the data collected and assess the condition of the watersheds that have been sampled.
Assess the condition of 250 watersheds within the Northwest Forest Plan area by collecting information on upslope, riparian, and in-channel attributes within each watershed.
3542.assumptions: Errors due to sampling and observer bias are minimized.

3546.background:
Salmon and steelhead populations within SE Washington are monitored for returns and in some instances are collected for hatchery broodstock for production at Lyons Ferry/Tucannon Fish Hatchery Complex opearated by Washington Department of Fish and Wlidlife (WDFW).  Mutliple rivers and tributaries wiers are used in comination with other methods to enumerate adult returns, supporting hatchery broodstock collections, and provide informaiton on diversity assessments. 

The proposed protocol would provide the following information for Weirs/Traps operated in SE Washinton:   

1) adult abundance

2) the proportion of hatchery origin spawners, origin of hatchery fish from coded wire tags or PIT tags,

3) population age structure,

4) proportional distribution of the populations in major spawning areas (MSAs) and minor spawning areas (mSAs), and

5) contribute to genetic characterization of SE Washington salmonids.

Genetic characterization analysis for steelhead DNA is sent to WDFW lab for archive until funds are available to analyze the tissue. Other DNA from brood etc...are handled per Idaho fish and game PBT analysis.

While not part of this protocol, WDFW will also operate PIT arrays and conduct spawning surveys in selected tributaries where weir operation is not possible or effective, or where information on spawning distribution of salmonids is limited.
objectives:
Estimate adult steelhead abundance, distribution, and the proportion of hatchery origin fish in tributaries, collect broodstock for hatchery programs where appropriate.
Collect tissue samples from adult salmonids in SE Washington where applicable.
3546.assumptions:
OBJ-1: 1) adult traps can be installed, maintained and operated adequately to successfully enumerate migrating adult steelhead 2) adult steelhead cannot ascend the stream without being enumerated, or they will accurately be estimated from mark –recapture techniques 3) marks and tags will not be missed during recapture

OBJ-2: 1) that we will be able to tissue sample 30-100 unmarked steelhead per trap site/stream 2) that funding is available and the samples will be run for DNA and SNPs analyses, as part of the Snake River genetics database 3) that DNA analyses will be run with existing funding (project 20102600) to compare steelhead from these small tributaries with the core Asotin and Tucannon populations

3549.background: This project aims to sample juvenile wild Steelhead Oncorhynchus mykiss in headwater streams of the Wind River, WA, to characterize population attributes and investigate life-history metrics, particularly age at migration, seasonal migratory patterns, growth, and early life-stage survival. Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT)-tagging and a series of instream PIT-tag interrogation systems (PTISs) are used to track juveniles, in addition to smolt trapping by WDFW. The PTISs also provide information on adult Steelhead migrations and populations. The Wind River subbasin is considered a wild Steelhead refuge by Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW). No hatchery Steelhead have been planted in the Wind River subbasin since 1997, and hatchery adults are estimated at less than one percent of spawners in most years (Thomas Buehrens, WDFW, pers comm.). Data generated from this work will contribute to understanding the diversity of steelhead life-histories, their spatial distribution, and inform life-cycle models. This work will also contribute to assessing Steelhead population response to numerous restoration actions in the subbasin, including removal of Hemlock Dam from Trout Creek in 2009.
objectives: Assess survival and age at migration of age-0 and age-1 Steelhead parr from their headwater rearing habitat to downstream sample sites.
Describe population attributes (size, growth, distribution, and abundance) and data trends of age-0 and age-1 Steelhead parr in headwaters areas of the Wind River, WA.
Assess distribution and relative abundance of non-native Brook Trout and Chinook Salmon.
Operate a series of instream PIT-tag Detection Systems to detect PIT-tagged juvenile and adult Steelhead to contribute data to assess migration timing, survival, and abundance.
Determine abundance of migratory Steelhead parr from headwater to downstream rearing areas.

3552.background:
The PACFISH/INFISH (PIBO) Effectiveness Monitoring Program for aquatic and riparian resources was developed in 1998 in response to monitoring needs addressed in the Biological Opinions for bull trout (USFWS 1998) and steelhead (NMFS 1995). The primary objective is to determine whether priority biological and physical attributes, processes, and functions of riparian and aquatic systems are being degraded, maintained, or restored in the PIBO area. The program samples within the interior Columbia River basin on lands managed by U.S. Forest Service (FS) Regions 1, 4, and 6 and the Idaho and Oregon/Washington State Offices of the Bureau of Land Management (BLM).

This document (hereafter the PIBO Monitoring Protocol) describes the sampling methods used by the PIBO Monitoring Program to quantify stream and riparian attributes. The methods are a result of over two decades of use, evaluation, and peer review. We worked with the Aquatic and Riparian Effectiveness Monitoring Program to standardize methods, which resulted in a document titled “Effectiveness Monitoring for Streams and Riparian Areas within the Pacific Northwest: Stream Channel Methods for Core Attributes” (USDA 2006).
objectives: Determine if specific Designated Management Area practices related to livestock grazing are maintaining or restoring riparian vegetation structure and function.
Determine the direction and rate of change in riparian and aquatic habitats over time as a function of management practices.

Determine whether a suite of biological and physical attributes, processes, and functions of upland, riparian, and aquatic systems are being degraded, maintained, or restored across the PIBO landscape
3552.assumptions: Methods are a result of 11 years of use, evaluation, and peer review. We worked with the Aquatic and Riparian Effectiveness Monitoring Program to standardize methods, which resulted in a document titled “Effectiveness Monitoring for Streams and Riparian Areas within the Pacific Northwest: Stream Channel Methods for Core Attributes” (USDA 2006).

3555.background:
This protocol describes field methods and daily operations for crews to use in the Wadeable National River and Stream Assessments (NRSA) procedure. The NRSA is a probability-based survey of our Nation’s rivers and streams.

This is one of a series of water assessments being conducted by states, tribes, the U.S. EPA, and other partners. In addition to rivers and streams, the water assessments will also focus on coastal waters, lakes, and wetlands in a revolving sequence. The purpose of these assessments is to generate statistically valid reports on the condition of our Nation’s water resources and identify key stressors to these systems.

The protocol includes methods from National Rivers and Streams Assessment 2018/19 Field Operations Manual Wadeable Version 1.2 (PDF attached as Supplemental Info) and the National Rivers and Streams Assessment 2018/19 Laboratory Operations Manual (PDF attached as a Form).
objectives: Evaluate changes in condition over time
Help build State and Tribal capacity for monitoring and assessment and promote collaboration across jurisdictional boundaries
Assess the condition of the Nation’s rivers and streams.

3557.background: This protocol describes how Parentage Based Tagging (PBT) and Genetic Stock Identification (GSI) are implemented in Snake River sockeye salmon. These genetic assignment techniques are powerful tools to effectively monitor Oncorhynchus nerka life history composition and evaluate hatchery release stratgies. The Snake River sockeye salmon nursery lakes in the Sawtooth Valley support three distinct life histories of Oncorhynchus nerka (anadromous sockeye salmon, residualized sockeye salmon, and kokanee; Winans et al. 1996). Immature individuals captured in the Sawtooth Valley basin lakes can only be assigned to a life history type based on their genotype. In addition, the Snake River sockeye salmon captive broodstock program has employed a variety of release strategies (from eyed-egg to maturing adults) across the history of the program. The success of these individual release strategies can be tracked using PBT. All released individuals are genetically tagged because all maturing adult Snake River sockeye salmon spawned in the hatchery or released into Sawtooth Valley basin lakes are genotyped to inform captive broodstock management. Therefore, genetic assignment methods are a critical component to the monitoring and evaluation efforts of the Snake River sockeye salmon captive broodstock program.
objectives: This protocol outlines how individual assignments (PBT and GSI) are completed for Snake River sockeye salmon.

3562.background: High summertime water temperatures are a limiting factor for populations of native fish in the Walla Walla River and several of its tributaries. The Walla Walla River is 303(d) listed for temperature in both Oregon and Washington. Several tributaries are listed for temperature as well. Temperature impairment is of particular concern because the watershed is used by threatened populations of bull trout, summer steelhead, and culturally significant reintroduced spring Chinook salmon. Walla Walla Basin Watershed Council has collected seasonal temperature data in the Walla Walla River and its tributaries for almost 20 years with funding provided by the Oregon Watershed Enhancement Board, Oregon Department of Environmental Quality, and BPA. This protocol describes the continuation of that effort, which is particularly important in light of the notable increases in peak seasonal temperatures following a 100+ year flow event in the Walla Walla River in 2020 (WWBWC, 2022). Additional data are needed to understand flood impacts, guide restoration efforts, and measure outcomes.
objectives: Use data loggers to collect seasonal water temperature data, at 15-minute intervals, from May-November at 27 locations in the Walla Walla Basin.
3562.assumptions: 1 - Temperature recorded by the data logger is representative of the water in that reach of the stream. 2 - Temperature data loggers have been compared to a NIST thermometer. 3 - Temperature measurements are taken every 30 minutes therefore short temperature spikes may not be captured.

3569.background:
IDFG captures and samples wild anadromous adults at temporary weirs (steelhead) and hatchery adult trapping facilities (steelhead and Chinook Salmon) to obtain crucial demographic data. These data are subsequently rolled-up or combined with other data sources (e.g. - PIT detections, genetic assignments) to summarize select population perfomance metrics for wild adult Chinook Salmon and steelhead.

Wild adult Chinook Salmon are sampled at three hatchery trap facilities in the Salmon River basin including the McCall Fish Hatchery satellite facility on the South Fork Salmon River, Pahsimeroi Fish hatchery on the Pahsimeroi River, and Sawtooth Fish Hatchery on the Upper Salmon River. 

Wild adult steelhead are captured using both temporary weirs and hatchery traps. In the Clearwater River basin steelhead are sampled at temporary weirs on the East Fork Potlatch River (Lower Clearwater River) and Fish Creek (Lochsa River); and at a hatchery trap on Crooked River (South Fork Clearwater). In the Salmon River basin wild steelhead are captured and sampled at the Rapid River Fish Hatchery adult trap on Rapid River (Little Salmon River), the Pahsimeroi Fish Hatchery adult trap on the Pahsimeroi River, the Sawtooth Fish Hatchery satellite adult trap on the East Fork Salmon River, and at the Sawtooth Fish Hatchery adult trap on the Upper Salmon River.
objectives: Capture and sample wild adult Chinook salmon and Steelhead at IDFG-operated temporary weirs and hatchery traps.
Collect critical data from weir and trap sampled wild adult Chinook Salmon and steelhead including return timing, fork length, phenotypic sex, and tissue samples for genetic analyses.

3570.background: Rotary screw traps (RSTs) are used as a collection tool for capturing and marking juvenile anadromous emigrants for determination of abundance, survival, and life history characteristics. Some sites include additional sampling infrastructure (e.g. temporary picket weir, hatchery trap, or PIT array), which enable more complete monitoring of select populations (or major spawning aggregates, depending on logistics). These high intensity; 'fish in, fish out' monitoring sites support life cycle modeling leading to a more mechanistic understanding of population dynamics.
objectives: Produce estimates of Chinook Salmon and steelhead emigrant abundance past RSTs by season and cohort.
