3574.background:
Temporal & spatial predator-prey overlap and consequential predatory impacts on juvenile anadromous salmonids is becoming a major source of their mortality in sections of the Columbia River (Erhardt et al. 2018; McMichael 2018). Currently, 51% of non-native species in the upper Columbia River are piscivores and have negative impacts on native salmonids and on the Columbia River food webs (ISAB 2011; Naiman et al. 2012).

Carpenter et al. (2019) indicated that catch rates in the lower Columbia River for SMB in 2018 was the highest for the period of record and WAL were in relatively high abundance compared to previous years. Several studies in the John Day Reservoir have documented that WAL and SMB consumed juvenile salmon and had significant impacts on their survival (Rieman et al 1991; Zimmerman 1999). Most predator studies in the Columbia River have been conducted downstream of McNary Dam (Poe at al. 1986; Beamesderfer and Rieman. 1991; Poe at al. 1991; Rieman et al. 1991; Vigg et al. 1991; Hansel et al. 1993; Isaak and Bjorn 1993; Marinelli et al. 1993; Ward et al. 1995; Friesen and Ward 1999; Zimmerman 1999; Petersen 2001; Thomas and Ward 2011; Ward and Zimmerman 2011) and have documented or estimated substantial predation losses of salmon to native and non-native piscivores.

The Independent Science Advisory Board (2011) found the need to implement a region-wide monitoring program on the temporal pace and spatial extent of non-native introductions, identifying impending problems while they are still small and manageable. Once identified, intervention should happen quickly whenever and wherever invasive problems are likely to emerge, averting problems when possible, or slowing them down, when not completely avoidable. The ISAB and ISRP recently identified two new uncertainties related to predation (ISAB/ISRP 2016). The first uncertainty relates to which predators jeopardize the viability of native fishes and the second relates to the effectiveness of management actions to ameliorate undesirable impacts of predation. More recently, the ISAB identified predation as a major concern in recovery of ESA-listed salmonids and recommended an ecosystem based approach to better understand the relative impacts of predation on salmonids by different native and non-native species throughout the Columbia Basin (ISAB 2019). Sanderson et al. (2009) suggest that the overall impact of non-indigenous species on salmon recovery may meet or exceed the cumulative impact of the conventional 4-H’s sources of mortality.

Fish predator abundance and population trends, & juvenile salmonid consumption estimates upstream of McNary Dam are not well understood. The objective of this study is to determine the status and trend of non-native fish predator density and abundance upstream of McNary Dam in the mainstem Columbia River, based on the protocol "Piscivorous Fish Status and Trend Monitoring in the Columbia River Upstream of McNary Dam", this stduy will delienate habitat classifications for Columbia River habitat.  Under an adaptive management approach, predator population abundance & growth rates will be monitored and used to evaluate the effectiveness of current (i.e., deregulating harvest)  & future management actions designed to increase juvenile salmon survival.
objectives: Classify habitat to understand Piscivore habitat specific density.
Expand piscivore density by habitat type for reservoir wide piscivore abundance estimate.

3574.title: Piscivorous Fish Habitat Delineation in the Columbia River Upstream of McNary Dam

3576.background:
We will use detections (recoveries) of juvenile salmonid Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags at piscivorous colonial waterbird nesting sites, loafing sites, and roosting sites in the Columbia River estuary to generate more accurate and precise estimates of smolt survival to Bonneville Dam in 2020. Detections acquired as part of this objective are necessary to increase sample sizes of tagged fish in the estuary, fish that were known to have survived migration past Bonneville Dam, to compensate for a lack of detection at NOAA’s pair trawl in the estuary in 2020. Smolt tags will be detected from numerous sites occupied by piscivorous colonial waterbirds during the peak smolt outmigration period of April to June 2020. Locations will be based on aerial images collected by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers during the 2020 nesting season. Sites will include (1) the base structures of the Astoria-Megler Bridge, (2) the western portion of East Sand Island, and (3) Rice Island, as feasible.

 

The methods of Hostetter et al. (2018) and Payton et al. (2019) will be used to incorporate these additional detections into the mark-recapture-recovery (MRR) survival model that is being used to complete Objective 2. In brief, we will investigate whether detections of smolt PIT tags at additional locations in the estuary increase sample sizes of available fish for survival analysis in 2020. We will also estimate detection probabilities of smolts passing Bonneville Dam with and without these additional detections in the estuary, plus survival to Bonneville Dam with and without these additional detections. This research will directly augment our ability to complete Objective 2, Task 2.2 by potentially providing a more robust dataset for analyses of survival rates and predation rates. The research will also benefit several other federal, state, and tribal agencies by uploading these detections of tagged fish to the PIT Tag Information System (PTAGIS), a regional database maintained by the Pacific States Fisheries Marine Commission (https://www.ptagis.org).

 

A more detailed description of methods, including statistical derivations, are provided in Hostetter et al. (2018) and Payton et at. 2019 (see also Objective 2, Task 2.2).
objectives: We will use detections of juvenile salmonid Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags in the Columbia River estuary to generate more accurate and precise estimates of smolt survival to Bonneville Dam
3576.assumptions: Methods and techniques to determine piscivorous colonial waterbird impacts to juvenile salmonids rely on field observations of birds and fish. The abundance (number), nesting chronology, productivity and diet of birds can vary greatly both within and between nesting seasons. As such, adaptable methods (ability to rapidly change the location or timing of sampling) are the most likely to succeed. Field observations also rely on the accuracy of sampling equipment and the experience of field staff to carry out research objectives.

3576.title: Avian Predation on Juvenile Salmonids in the Columbia River Estuary Tag Recovery

3577.background:
Fisheries sampling is an important component of the SAFE Program because it provides real-time feedback to fisheries managers, who are charged with maximizing fishing opportunities for SAFE fishers in Select Areas while minimizing ESA-allocated impacts of this fishery.  This is particularly important during the winter/spring/summer (WSS) Chinook fishery when the limiting factor for the fishery is impacts to upriver spring Chinook.  

Successful fishers take their landing to buyers as soon as the fishery is closed, when they have reached their limit, or when the boat can hold no more.  SAFE fishing periods can last 4 hours, 12 hours, to several continuous days, depending on risk of harvesting ESA-listed.  Buyers report catch by submitting fish tickets to state agencies responsible for fisheries resources.  There are buyers in both states, thus fish samplers from both ODFW and WDFW must coordinate activities and share fish ticket and bio-sampling results.  Fish tickets report landings by license number, total of species/stock caught, landing date, pounds purchased and price paid to fishers.  They typically have a time frame with which to report landings. 

Sampling is usually performed by state agency personnel.  It is conducted at the location where buyers purchase the catch.  Fisheries managers determine the sampling rate necessary to provide reliable information, develops the sampling schedule, and send samplers out accordingly.  Sampling may include some of the following: length, weight, fin marks, visual stock identification, fish may be wanded for CWT and PIT tags, tissue samples collected for genetic analysis, scale samples for aging, and perhaps others (see attached supplemental information).  Fisheries samplers must be well trained on fish identification, sampling skills, and provided proper equipment that has been well maintained.  Data indicating the proportion of fish stocks caught is applied to landings, either daily, weekly, or some other time frame, and cumulative landings, by stock, are reviewed by managers with particular attention paid to stocks with ESA allocations.
objectives: Perform in-season monitoring of commercial landings in Select Area fisheries
Deliver feedback to fisheries managers for review and decision making

3577.title: Fisheries Sampling for the Select Area Fisheries Enhancement (SAFE) Program

3593.background:
The Pacific Lamprey (Entosphenus tridentatus) is an anadromous lamprey species of the Pacific Northwest with populations from Alaska to California. However, the species has suffered severe declines in abundance across its range, including the Columbia Basin. Concern on the part of the Columbia River Treaty Tribes (Close et al 2002) prompted development of the “Tribal Pacific Lamprey Restoration Plan for the Columbia Basin”. An understanding of the need for improved monitoring as well as the implementation of regional and rangewide restoration efforts was described shortly afterwards in the “Conservation Agreement for Pacific Lamprey (Entosphenus tridentatus) in the States of Alaska, Washington, Oregon, Idaho, and California” (USFWS 2012). In both documents it was recognized that the population substructure of Pacific Lamprey is poorly understood and represents a critical uncertainty relative to designing restoration efforts.

The situation is complicated by the fact that traditional tagging methods (e.g. fin-clipping, PIT, acoustic, and radio tags, etc.), that have been used to study other fish species, are largely unavailable for use with lamprey, due to the small size of the fish through their extended larval and juvenile life stages. An alternative approach is to analyze the fish genetically – an animal’s genotype providing a natural “tag” that can be exploited for species identification, to assess population structure, individual-specific identification, and parentage analysis (Matala et al. 2011; Hess et al. 2013; Hess et al. 2014).

The apparent lack of, or minimal at least, genetic differentiation has offered the possibility of using adult translocation as a means to supplement depressed populations while minimizing the threat of disrupting genetic substructure, such as is strongly observed among salmon populations. The Umatilla, Yakama, and Nez Perce Tribes have each initiated translocation programs in attempts to restore local populations within their ceded territories (Umatilla Tribe, BPA 1994-026-00; Yakama Nation, BPA 2008-470-00; Nez Perce Tribe, Pacific Lamprey Restoration Project). Additionally, projects to monitor existent populations are being conducted by the Warms Springs Tribe (BPA 2008-308-00 and 2011-014-00) and CRITFC is providing support to these programs, plus additional work through BPA project 2008-524-00.

In order to better adaptively manage regional lamprey projects, each has associated activities for the collection and counting of lampreys at all life history stages. In order to exploit incorporation of genetic analyses and to provide additional information from fish as they are intercepted during these monitoring activities, the CRITFC project (2008-524-00) included a work element to develop a standardize a suite of single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) DNA markers (https://www.monitoringresources.org/Document/Protocol/Details/713) that would provide consistent analyses within and among regional and rangewide lamprey projects. This effort resulted in the establishment of a panel of SNPs for use in fluidigm 96-SNP microarrays (Hess et al. 2015) capable of species identification, understanding physiology and life history of returning adults, calculating effective number of tributary spawners, and evaluating size, age and transformation status of outmigrating juveniles from the tributary environment, among other things.
objectives: Collect tissue samples from all adult lamprey collected for regional restoration efforts (e.g. translocation and artificial propagation) from mainstem Columbia River dams.
Strategically collect tissue samples from larval/juvenile lampreys during regional research/monitoring efforts (e.g. electrofishing and screw trap monitoring) in CRB study/control streams.
Strategically collect tissue samples from all life history stages at sites throughout the CRB, including but not limited to, mortalities and lampreys handled at mainstem/tributary dams.
Collect tissue samples from all adult lamprey handled for regional monitoring and evaluation efforts (e.g. passage monitoring at Willamette Falls and mainstem Columbia River dams).
Utilize multifunctional SNPs panel for Pacific Lamprey on CRB lamprey collections (Obj. 1-4) to provide qualitative and quantitative assessment of productivity and life history characteristics.
3593.assumptions:
Collection and tissue sampling procedures for adults and juveniles, and for adult PIT tagging are all well established, and these procedures are followed in each of the current tribal lamprey programs (Campbell et al. 2012, Method 1432, Tissue sampling for Parentage Based Tagging v1.0, https://www.monitoringresources.org/Document/Method/Details/1432).

The SNP marker panel for use in Pacific Lamprey genetics analyses has been developed, refined, and tested using financing from BPA 2008-524-00 (McIlraith 2015, Method 713, Developing new genetic markers to understand and monitor Columbia River Basin Pacific Lampreys v1.0, https://www.monitoringresources.org/Document/Protocol/Details/713; Hess et al. 2015).

The SNP marker panel developed by Hess et al. 2015 through BPA 2008-524-00 has contributed to information on physiology and life history of returning adults (Hess et al. 2014), gene flow, or lack thereof, of lampreys within the Columbia River basin (Hess et al. 2013), effective spawner abundance in a stream reach (Whitlock et al. in review), and species identification (Baker et al. 2015).

3594.background: Redd counts and carcass surveys are conducted to estimate Viable Salmonid Population (VSP) metrics (i.e. abundance, productivity, and spatial structure) for Chinook salmon populations in Idaho. These metrics are used by NOAA to assess the status of Snake River Spring/Summer Chinook salmon, which are currently listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act. Additionally, these surveys have been conducted in a consistent manner in Idaho since 1957 and thus provide a valuable long-term dataset. This protocol only describes data collection methods. Analysis using these data incorporates additional data collected from other protocols such as Protocol 3446: IDFG AERIAL SURVEYS for Chinook Salmon redds in the Middle Fork Salmon River basin, so it is described in a separate protocol (3629).
objectives: Survey for Chinook Salmon redds at long-term index transects representing important production areas in Idaho.
Survey for Chinook Salmon carcasses at long-term index transects in order to estimate age composition  and quantify hatchery fraction of spawning populations.
Document spatial distribution of Chinook salmon redds.
3594.assumptions: Transects selected for redd counts are representative of populations of interest.

3605.background: Pacific Lamprey (Entosphenus tridentatus) is an anadromous fish whose distribution extends along the West Coast of North America as far South as Baja, Mexico and North along the Pacific Rim to Alaska, Russia and Japan. Since the 1970s, populations have declined drastically, and distribution has been greatly reduced from their historic range. Factors that have contributed to this decline include man made passage barriers, dams, water quality, contaminants, habitat degradation, predation, and climate change impacts. Monitoring of environmental DNA (eDNA) is a cost effective, efficient, noninvasive tool that can be used to monitor translocation programs as part of a pre- and post- release monitoring program, recolonization after barrier removals, presence/absence in translocation and control streams, seasonal differences in occupancy, and provides a method to distinguish genus - Entosphenus/ Lampetra (Carim et al. 2017;Grote and Carim 2017). EDNA is useful in detecting invasive species, species present in low abundance and to monitor the extent of a species ranges (Carim et al. 2016; Ostberg et al. 2019). To develop an eDNA assay specific to Pacific lamprey, DNA of the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase I (COI) of Pacific Lamprey and unidentified freshwater lamprey was sequenced (Carim et al. 2016).
objectives: Determine which Columbia River Basin tributaries are utilized by Pacific Lamprey as indicated by the presence of Pacific Lamprey environmntal DNA (eDNA).
Monitor the status and trends of Paific Lamprey distribution throughout the Columbia River Basin using environmental DNA (eDNA) analysis.
Monitor Pacific Lamprey restoration/reintroduction methods (e.g. translocation) within the Columbia River Basin using environmental DNA (eDNA) analysis.
3605.assumptions: The presence of Chinook DNA at a stream site is the result of the recent presence of Chinook at the site (i.e. not from alternative, less likely sources such as site contamination from birds, etc.)

metrics.title: Trends in presence/absence above and below release sites post release over time (24 hours, weeks, months, years)

3608.background: The Columbia River Inter-Tribal Fish Commission's (CRITFC) member tribes utilize rotary screw traps (RSTs) as a collection tool for capturing and marking downstream migrating larval and juvenile Pacific Lamprey. The RST’s are operated by the Yakama Nation (YN), the Umatilla Tribe (CTUIR), and the Warm Springs Tribe (CTWSRO) throughout various portions of the Columbia River Basin. Information obtained from the captured fish are used to estimate population abundance, survival, migration timing, and life history characteristics, which in turn are used to inform restoration effectiveness and status and trends evaluations. The sampling design consists of a combination of comparative performance testing (treatment vs. natural), small-scale experiments, and population status monitoring to address management objectives and answer questions fundamental to Pacific Lamprey in the Columbia River Basins. Data obtained from the operation of RSTs is used to estimate larval/juvenile performance characteristics, provide over-winter survival estimates, and life stage specific survival estimates. They also provide a means to calculate Pacific Lamprey larval and juvenile emigration timing and travel from tributary specific areas to Columbia and Snake River Dams. Population status and trend monitoring of Pacific Lamprey is used for effective population management, assessing effectiveness of restoration actions, viability, and recovery metric monitoring.
objectives: Obtain life stage-specific estimates of abundance, survival and life history characteristics.
Obtain life stage-specific estimates of emigration timing.
Obtain life stage-specific estimates of travel time from tributary specific areas to Snake and Columbia River dams.
Use collected data to estimate larval/juvenile-to-adult survival rates.
Use collected data to estimate performance measures to monitor population status, viability and trends, assess hatchery and habitat restoration effectiveness and progress towards population recovery.
3608.assumptions:
1. Juvenile screw traps effectively allows us to test quantifiable hypotheses as they relate to our monitoring and evaluation objectives.
  2. Trap efficiency estimates accurately reflect the true proportion of the captured emigrating population and provide valid total abundance estimates.

3609.background:
The CRITFC Member Tribes utilize radio telemetry to gather information from returning anadromous adult Pacific Lamprey. Information is used compare the relative passage performance of adult Pacific Lamprey at mainstem and tributary barriers with the focus on adult distribution (upstream and downstream of barriers). Data are utilized for determination of abundance, survival and life history characteristics, restoration effectiveness and status and trends evaluations.  Population status and trend monitoring of natural and hatchery origin fish is used for effective population management, assessing effectiveness of restoration actions, viability, and recovery metric monitoring. 

Please see protocols #2250 for data anlaysis methods describing the calculation of metrics and indicators.

3613.background: On December 14, 2018, the State of Oregon, the State of Washington, the Nez Perce Tribe, Bonneville Power Administration, Bureau of Reclamation and the Corps entered into the 2019-2021 Spill Operation Agreement, referred to as the “flexible spill agreement.” The Corps agreed to increase spill to improve juvenile salmonid migration during times of low hydropower demand. For the 2020-2021 spring spill, the flexible spill agreement calls for increasing the total dissolved gas (TDG) cap to 125 percent in the tailraces of dams in the Columbia and Snake rivers. This change to the water quality standard for TDG requires the monitoring of native, resident fishes for incidence of gas bubble trauma (GBT) resulting from increased TDG.
objectives: Measure the incidence and severity of GBT in native, resident fishes rearing immediately downstream of mainstem Columbia and Snake River dams during the spring spill period.

3614.background:
The Wind River has a TMDL for temperature, a limiting factor for steelhead spawning, rearing, and migration. To help assess changes in this parameter, continuous temperature monitoring is essential. Underwood Conservation District (UCD) will work with partnering agencies to continue to monitor temperature throughout the watershed, utilizing UCD's standard operating procedures and water quality database. UCD supports operation and maintenance of 6 thermographs in the Wind River watershed. USGS has managed an additional 11 sites as well, and both agencies coordinate placement of thermographs to best capture watershed conditions while avoiding duplication. Data from this effort will inform and guide habitat restoration work.

3617.background:
Moist soil management is a valuable tool for the treatment of wetland habitats and the wildlife species associated with wetlands.  The ability to manage water levels, create disturbance, and manipulate vegetation to allow for more productive early successional wetland habitats is crucial to the TD-1 project.   Moist soil management provides critical habitat and food sources for wetland obligate and wetland associated species, while also allowing for valuable recreation opportunities.  Through this survey effort it is our goal to see how seed biomass differs in natural versus manipulated wetland basins.  Basins that are being surveyed have been harrowed and broadcast seeded, harrowed and drill seeded, and tilled to allow for volunteer crops to establish.

**2017 survey did not have tilled volunteer crops and sample quardants were 1 meter squared.

**2018/2019/2020 survey had sample quadrants that were 0.25 meter squared and sample sites were in different location in wetland basins.

**2020 survey due to Covid-19 work restrictions all cells were volunteer crops.
objectives: To evaluate different moist soil management practices and compare effectiveness in producing high yields of seed for wildlife forage.
3617.assumptions: Wetlands that have been harrowed and seeded with Wild Millet and Smartweed will exhibit higher rates of seed biomass than wetlands left to naturally establish.  Furthermore, wetland basins that have been tilled will benefit from turning over soil and desirable vegetation will be allowed to establish.

3619.background:
Effectiveness monitoring for the Southern Cross project is conducted by CTUIR’s Biomonitoring project, Grande Ronde Research, Monitoring, and Evaluation (RM&E) project, Grande Ronde Fish Habitat project, and the Grande Ronde Model Watershed (GRMW). These efforts include: Spawning and snorkel surveys, physical habitat monitoring (following BPA’s Action Effectiveness Monitoring program (AEM) protocols (Bonneville Power Administration 2016)), temperature monitoring, and photo-points/aerial imagery.

During steelhead spawning surveys in spring 2017 project biologists noted large groups of juvenile Chinook within the floodplain swales, alcoves, and blind channels (perennial spring fed channels connected to the main channel at the downstream end but only connected at the upstream end in high flows). The first observations saw very few fish in late April when the main channel was running at an estimated 350 cfs (9.9 m/s) – based on the Oregon Water Resources flow gauge near Union, approximately 2.6 miles (4.1 km) downstream of the site (station # 13320000). However, as the hydrograph increased so did the observations of juvenile Chinook, and underwater videos as the hydrograph peaked at 900 cfs (25.4 m/s) provided qualitative evidence of the floodplain utilization by young-of-the-year.

The approach taken to restoring floodplain connectivity at the Southern Cross site is providing ephemeral and perennial off-channel habitat for juvenile Chinook that had not previously been available within the simplified channel. We know from the literature that floodplain access can have significant growth benefits for juvenile Chinook, but questions remain about the effectiveness of the Southern Cross project because currently we do not possess quantitative data of Chinook and O.mykiss abundance, density, or growth at this site. Nor are we able to provide information to the restoration implementers on what habitats within the floodplain are being used by these juveniles so that they can mimic them at their next floodplain projects.
objectives: Collect biological metric information of juvenile salmonid species using the floodplain habitat during spring/early summer for a three season period and compare these with main channel salmonids.
Quantify habitat features outside the main channel being used by juvenile salmonid during spring/early summer.
Compare outmigration survival of floodplain reared salmonid's to main channel reared salmonids.

3621.background: The Upper Grande Ronde stock of spring Chinook salmon migrate into the upper reaches of the Grande Ronde River beginning in early May and continue to move into the spawning grounds through August (McLean, et al., 2016). There is a weir and trap located at rm 153.5 operated by the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation (CTUIR). The weir is designed to capture broodstock and enumerate upstream migrating salmon and has been in operation since 1997 (McLean, et al., 2016). The migration of Grande Ronde adults in the lower Columbia River system has been well documented (Keefer, et al., 2004; Keefer, et al., 2008). The movement and habitat use of adult Chinook in other basins has also been studied (Conder, et al., 2008), and within the Grande Ronde Basin at the Lostine River (Harbeck, et al., 2014). However, for the Upper Grande Ronde River stock once the adults are captured and released at the weir their migration patterns and the stream reaches they use prior to spawning is still unknown. In most years, their habitat in the Upper Grande Ronde River is plagued by low stream flows and high stream temperatures throughout the summer (Nowack, 2004; Justice, et al., 2017; Justice, et al., 2017). Discovering where the salmon hold and when they choose to stay in those areas may help in understanding which stream reaches and habitat types need to be protected or enhanced and radio telemetry is a common technique that has been used to document the movement of fish and other animals within their habitat (Contour, C.R., 2010; Harbeck, et al., 2014; Contor, C. R., 2014). There is also a large portion of the upper river (Vey Meadows, 6.5 river miles) that is under private ownership and currently access to monitor fish has been denied. Historically, when access was regularly granted to this area (1986 to 1993), an average of 43% of the total redds for the upper Grande Ronde River were counted there, with an average of 49% of redds counted in the section above the meadow to the top of the spawning area (4.2 river miles) (Tranquilli, et al., 2001). Current redd distribution information is unknown for this reach and understanding usage of this historical spawning area is important from a population dynamics aspect.
objectives: Document migration patterns and habitat use of a sub-sample of returning adult spring Chinook salmon in the upper Grande Ronde River during the pre-spawning period for restoration planning.

3624.background:
This protocol monitors genetic changes associated with hatchery propagation in the upper Columbiar River sub-basins for Chinook salmon and steelhead. The information obtained from this protocol directly addresses the potential for changes in genetic diversity in natural populations as a result of safety-net and conservation hatchery programs. The long-term fitness of populations is assumed to be related to maintaining the genetic diversity of natural populations. However, hatchery programs select a subset of individuals from the population to pass on genetic material to the next generation. This is often a relatively small number of individuals that produce a large number of offspring and can result in changes in allele frequencies and reductions of effective population size. Therefore, it is important to monitor the genetic status of the natural populations to determine if there are signs of changes in genetic distance among populations, changes in allele frequencies, linkage disequilibrium, and to estimate effective population size. Assessing the genetic effects of the hatchery program on natural populations does not require annual sampling but does require regular sampling at generational time scales. Additionally, genetic status of hatchery-origin returns should be monitored to further evaluate potential genetic risks to the natural population. This protocol uses changes in gene frequencies through time in hatchery, natural, and wild Chinook and steelhead salmon populations to evaluate the genetic effects of hatchery supplementation on a broad geographic scale.  Co-managers are Chelan County PUD, Douglas County PUD and Grant County PUD.  

Beginning with brood years 2017 and 2018 (and then at subsequent ten year intervals), testing statistical hypotheses associated with genetic components will be conducted with natural-origin baseline samples (the earliest genetic samples available for each program), natural-origin contemporary samples, and hatchery-origin contemporary samples.   

Alternatively, genetic divergence between the hatchery-origin population and natural-origin population is expected with segregated programs. Monitoring of genetic risks associated with utilizing multi-generations of hatchery-origin broodstock is important. Beginning with brood years 2017 and 2018 (and then at subsequent ten-year intervals), testing statistical hypotheses associated with genetic components will be conducted with hatchery-origin baseline samples (the earliest genetic samples available for each program) and hatchery-origin contemporary samples (brood years 2017 and 2018).

The samples needed for this protocol are collected from the Wenatchee, Methow, Entiat and Okanogan basins.  Samples are sent to the WDFW Molecular Lab in Olympia, WA.  

WDFW Molecular Genetics (MG) Lab will determine which samples from the programs have been genotyped with the appropriate SNP panel and compile the genetic data from these analyses. Every effort will be made to avoid running duplicative samples and to use the samples that have already been processed.  Additionally, WDFW MG Lab will genotype samples that have not been genotyped with the appropriate SNP panel. If the genetic data is available for the programs, and there is no cost to the PUDs, then the genetic data from these programs will be incorporated into the analyses. All SNP genotypes will be analyzed in order to answer the monitoring questions which are outlined in the objectives.
objectives: Monitoring question 1: Is the contemporary allele frequency of natural-origin fish and hatchery-origin fish similar to the baseline allele frequency of natural-origin fish over time?
Monitoring question 2: Is the contemporary allele frequency of hatchery-origin broodstock similar to the baseline allele frequency of hatchery-origin broodstock over time?
Monitoring question 3: Is contemporary linkage disequilibrium (LD) of natural-origin and hatchery-origin fish similar to the baseline LD of natural-origin fish over time?
Monitoring question 4: Is contemporary linkage disequilibrium (LD) of hatchery-origin broodstock similar to the baseline LD of hatchery-origin broodstock over time?
Monitoring question 5: Does the genetic distance among supplemented subpopulations (where applicable) and populations remain the same over time?
Monitoring question 6: Is the ratio of effective population size (Ne) to spawning population size (N) constant or increasing over time?
3624.assumptions: We assume that by sampling a stretch of each site ranging from 1/4-1 mile in length, that we are not sampling a single family grouping. Additionally, we choose to sample juveniles at each study site rather than returning adults, as juveniles are not as susceptible to straying issues.

3627.background:
Upper Columbia River spring Chinook Salmon stock assessment is intended to estimate the abundance, origin, and age composition of returning Upper Columbia River spring Chinook Salmon. Stock assesment sampling and PIT tagging will enable monitoring of viable salmonid population parameters, and provide data to multiple monitoring and evaluation programs. Specifically, Upper Columbia River spring Chinook Salmon stock assessment activities will provide the opportunity to:

  • Conduct status and trend monitoring in the Upper Columbia River ESU
  • PIT tag a representative sample of Upper Columbia River spring Chinook Salmon to be used in PIT tag based escapement estimates
  • Set regulations for selective fisheries aimed at reducing the abundance of hatchery fish and the spawning grounds
objectives: Determine the origin of all spring Chinook Salmon sampled at Priest Rapids Dam Off-Ladder Adult Fish Trap.
Determine the age of all spring Chinook Salmon sampled at Priest Rapids Dam Off-Ladder Adult Fish Trap.
PIT tag a representative sample of returning Upper Columbia River ESU spring Chinook Salmon. PIT tag detection data will be used to generate PIT tag-based escapement estimates.
3627.assumptions: Operation of the Off Ladder Adult Fish Trap (OLAFT) at Priest Rapids Dam for equal intervals throughout the entirety of the run provides the opportunity to tag a sample representative of the Upper Columbia River ESU steelhead run-at-large.

3631.background:
In the Upper Columbia region numerous salmonid-focused habitat restoration projects have been implemented in the past decade to address habitat limiting factors and improve the survival of ESA-listed salmonids. Pacific lamprey are present in many of these project areas, but little information exists to determine whether or not these salmonid-focused projects are benefitting lamprey through the creation/enhancement of larval rearing habitat and its use by larval lamprey.

By examining the development of larval rearing habitat at salmonid-focused projects that were implemented to address identified limiting factors (threats), we can determine if these types of projects will have the added benefit of providing lamprey rearing habitat and observe if lamprey are indeed occupying this created/enhanced habitat.
objectives: Quantify the area and condition of Type 1 lamprey rearing habitat present (as per Close 2000) at a suite of historic salmonid-focused habitat restoration projects in the Methow and Entiat Subbasins.
Quantify the presence and biomass of larval lamprey in available Type 1 habitat present at sampled salmonid-focused habitat restoration projects (see attached field data sheet).
Assess salmonid-focused project types and features that promote development of Type 1 larval rearing habitat.

3632.background:
Project staff will assist Lyons Ferry and Tucannon FH staffs with broodstock collection, spawning activities (collection of biological samples, recording mating crosses, estimation of eggs taken, etc..) and documenting survivals in the hatchery based on data provided from the hatchery staff. Project and hatchery staff will spawn broodstock using a 1x2 or 2x2 spawning matrix. Crosses between individuals will be documented by project staff to ensure that all fish collected for broodstock contribute to the next generation when possible. 
 
Incubation of eggs allows for fecundity monitoring by age class. WDFW LSRCP staff have tracked fecundity of female steelhead by stock since 2000 to document any changes over time that could be attributed to hatchery practices. Eggs are picked at the eyed stage, with mortality to eye-up determined by the number of dead eggs picked from each female's egg lot. Live eggs are determined by an egg counter. Additional mortality occurs prior to hatching, which is also determined. 
 
Project staff will also sample juvenile summer steelhead when necessary, or when requested by hatchery staff, for tag/mark retention or size at release sampling prior to release. Project staff will report tag/mark retention and size at release in annual reports, and will use this information in hatchery program evaluations. Project staff will consolidate all appropriate data collected while fish are in the hatchery (it is anticipated that the information will inform the recommendations made to hatchery and fish management staff for changes in the program).
objectives: Provide support and perform hatchery effectiveness monitoring and evaluation to adaptively manage Nez Perce Tribe hatchery programs.
Provide support and perform critical uncertainty analysis research for action effectiveness.

3633.background:
Snake River basin steelhead trout Oncorhynchus mykiss (hereafter steelhead) populations have declined substantially following the construction of hydroelectric dams in the Snake and Columbia rivers. Survival of juvenile steelhead emigrating from the Snake River basin decreased following the construction of dams on the lower Snake River during the late 1960s and early 1970s (Raymond 1988). Degradation of freshwater spawning and rearing habitats have also reduced wild steelhead abundance (Nehlsen et al. 1991; Gregory and Bisson 1997; Williams et al. 1999). The abundance of wild steelhead in Idaho streams has fluctuated at low levels since the completion of Lower Granite Dam in 1975 (Busby et al. 1996). Consequently, Snake River steelhead were classified as threatened under the Endangered Species Act in 1997. Presently, returns of naturally produced steelhead remain critically low, especially for populations with later run timing and older age structure (Busby et al. 1996).

There are six major population groups (MPGs) within the Snake River steelhead Distinct Population Segment (DPS). Three MPGs are located in Idaho that include the Clearwater River, Salmon River, and Hells Canyon tributaries (ICTRT 2007; Figure 1). Only a small number of tributaries in the Hells Canyon MPG support spawning, and these streams are geographically separated from historical major spawning areas now considered to be extirpated. Thus, it was determined none of these tributaries were large enough to support an independent population (ICTRT 2007). Nonetheless, there are 17 demographically independent and extant steelhead populations identified within the Clearwater River and Salmon River MPGs (ICTRT 2007; NWFSC 2015; Table 1).

The Idaho Department of Fish and Game (IDFG) anadromous fish program’s long-term goals to preserve Idaho’s wild steelhead runs and recover them to provide benefit to all users (IDFG 2019) are consistent with basinwide mitigation and recovery programs. Snake River basin anadromous fish management programs include: 1) hatchery programs intended to mitigate for the impacts of hydroelectric dam construction and operation, 2) recovery planning and implementation efforts aimed at recovering ESA-listed wild steelhead stocks, and 3) management of sport and tribal fisheries. The IDFG Management Goals for wild- and natural-origin steelhead for the Snake River basin including populations in Oregon and Washington is 104,500 with a goal of 72,000 for the Idaho component (IDFG 2019). The mean return of wild- and natural-origin steelhead from 2008?2017 was 30,452 (IDFG 2019). An understanding of how salmonid populations function (McElhany et al. 2000), as well as long-term trend monitoring for status assessments, is required to achieve these management goals.

Wild steelhead population status in Idaho are evaluated by IDFG based upon the viable salmonid population (VSP) criteria (McElhany et al. 2000). Hence, this protocol’s objectives follow the VSP framework including the following VSP metrics: abundance and productivity, diversity, and spatial structure. For steelhead, IDFG uses steelhead parr distribution as a surrogate to evaluate spatial structure, and is addressed through IDFG’s snorkel survey protocol (ID: 89). Diversity criteria are evaluated from information on population demographic metrics including sex ratio, length and age composition, migration timing, and genetic sampling at weirs.
objectives: Summarize IDFG’s intensive, high-precision monitoring of adult wild steelhead in the following twelve locations and ten populations of the Clearwater River and Salmon River MPGs (see table 1).
Estimate adult wild steelhead adult abundance and productivity at all twelve locations.
Estimate wild steelhead smolt-to-adult return (SAR) rates at select locations.
Estimate wild steelhead population demographics and diversity metrics including sex ratio, length and age composition, and run timing at all locations. Enumerate genetic samples collected.

3634.background:
Fish passage in proximity to water diversions has long been a concern of fish managers in the West, with the first fish screening laws being passed in the late 1800’s.  And large-scale State led screening programs beginning in the 1930’s.  Fish screening at water diversions prevent fish mortality and injury, while still allowing water to be delivered for agricultural, industrial, and domestic use.  A variety of positive barrier fish screening alternatives are available to water users and design is site specific, however, there are two basic concepts.  The first uses screens to exclude fish at the point of water withdrawal, and the second allows fish to enter the water diversion facility and uses screens to exclude, guide, and return fish to the river.  The second concept typically uses a dam to help divert water and can include infrastructure to capture, count, and examine fish that enter the facility.

Downstream migrating juvenile salmonids can pass in-canal water diversion projects by one of three routes, via an adult fish ladder, spill, or through the fish screening facility.  Fish that enter the fish screening facility are guided away from the canal and into the bypass channel by positive barrier screens.  The bypass channel leads to a pipe or flume that returns fish to the river.  Fish trapping infrastructure is typically located within the bypass channel.  However, custom built traps can be located in the screen forebay or downstream of the bypass channel to intercept fish.

Facilities low in the watershed with built in juvenile fish trapping infrastructure in addition to adult enumeration capabilities are ideal when selecting a site.  The ability to estimate both out-migrant abundance and adult returns allows for estimates of marine survival (smolt-to-adult) and freshwater productivity (smolts-per-spawner).  These metrics and indicators can be used to determine population status, evaluate the effectiveness of management actions, and assess recovery of a population.  Another important element when selecting a site is how closely water diversion operations overlap with the target fish species and how much river flow is diverted.

While the data for this protocol is primarily derived from the Three Mile Falls Dam (TMF) fish screening and bypass facility located on the Umatilla River, the methods are intended to be applicable to all fish screening facilities were downstream migrating juvenile salmonids can be captured and counted, although some site- or species-specific modifications may be necessary.
objectives: Provide unbiased estimates of salmonid smolt abundance from populations located and/or watersheds located upstream of water diversion projects.
Provide a long-term time series of consistently collected data allowing for comparison of the impacts of changing river conditions and project operations.
Provide data on juvenile fish behavior and performance associated with water diversion projects.

3648.background:
Wetland location and functionality depends on the interaction of the hydrologic regime and land elevation.The lower Columbia River and Estuary (LCRE) generally has been very slowly infilling with sediment during the Holocene epoch since the ice age, but rates are spatially variable and not all subareas have net positive sedimentation rates (Sherwood and Creager 1990). Tidal marsh surfaces along the seaward 120 km of the Columbia River have closely tracked changing water surface elevation for millennia (Peterson et al. 2013). Emergent march distribution on the LCRE mainland and island floodplain can be predicted by the cumulative sum of the water depth over the marsh surface during the growing season (Borde et al. 2020).

Thus, estimating long-term morphological change, including accretion and erosion, relative to water surface elevations is necessary for understanding the long-term viability of existing wetlands and identifying potential restoration locations. The resilience of land surface elevation may be gauged based on the 3-dimensional position of land considered for acquisition and governing sedimentary processes (e.g., Cahoon et al. 2019). This is of increasing importance today, because the global sea level rise is expected to affect the LCRE in coming decades (Talke et al. 2020).
objectives: Monitor long-term changes in LCRE wetland elevation.
Monitor long-term changes in LCRE wetland accretion.
Develop a long-term record of quarterly accretion/erosion wetland elevation measurements at multiple wetlands within the Lower Columbia River Estuary.

3650.background:
PIT-tags are one of the key technologies used to monitor anadromous fish populations in the Umatilla River basin and an extensive network of release and recapture sites exist across the Columbia River basin.  PIT-tags can be used with mark-recapture techniques to estimate the size of a population or the survival for a group of fish.  Performance metrics including travel time, migration timing, and passage timing can be derived and used to characterize life history characteristics and fish behavior.  PIT-tag data sets are also used to estimate adult escapement, monitor overshoot rates, and smolt-to-adult return. 

The electrical properties and performance of a PIT-tag interrogation system can change with changes in environmental conditions (i.e., water level, water temperature, conductivity, and air temperature).  Performance is also affected by metal and ambient electromagnetic fields of similar frequency, which can be generated by a wide variety of things commonly found at juvenile and adult fish passage facilities including electric motors, pumps, and power lines. 

PIT-tag systems cannot read two tags at once, so multiple tags in the detection field at the same time compromises system performance.  This can occur when more than one tagged fish is in the detection field, or when a bare tag, resulting from tag shedding or mortality, rolls into the detection field creating collision with tagged fish swimming through the field. 

Because of these factors, system performance should be monitored on a regular basis and detection efficiency should be calculated.  When possible, detection efficiency estimates should be species and life stage specific and during discrete periods of differing conditions that are known to affect system performance.
objectives: Operate and maintain PIT-tag interrogation system to provide consistent passive interrogation and uploading of data to the regional PIT-tag database (PTAGIS).
Calculate detection efficiencies to characterize system performance.

3653.background: Partial capture traps and mark-recapture methods are frequently used to monitor downstream migrating juvenile fish to assess the performance and status of anadromous salmonids.  A variety of important fish population metrics can be obtained from these methodologies, including abundance, migration timing, and survival.  These metrics can be used to evaluate trends in habitat productivity, without the masking influence of Columbia River migratory and ocean survival conditions. And when paired with adult abundance, high-level indicators such as smolt-to-adult survival and smolts-per-adult can be estimated.
objectives: Provide unbiased estimates of juvenile salmonid abundance from populations located and/or watersheds located upstream of the trapping site(s).
Determine juvenile life history characteristics and downstream survival.
Provide a long-term time series of consistently collected data to monitor fish population status and trends.

3674.background:
Moist soil management is a valuable tool for the treatment of wetland habitats and the wildlife species associated with wetlands.  The ability to manage water levels, create disturbance, and manipulate vegetation to allow for more productive early successional wetland habitats is crucial to the TD-1 project.   Moist soil management provides critical habitat and food sources for wetland obligate and wetland associated species, while also allowing for valuable recreation opportunities.  Through this survey effort it is our goal to see how seed biomass differs in natural versus manipulated wetland basins.  Basins that are being surveyed have been harrowed and broadcast seeded, harrowed and drill seeded, and tilled to allow for volunteer crops to establish.

**2017 survey did not have tilled volunteer crops and sample quardants were 1 meter squared.

**2018/2019/2020/2021 survey had sample quadrants that were 0.25 meter squared and sample sites were in different location in wetland basins.

**2020 survey due to Covid-19 work restrictions all cells were volunteer crops.
objectives: To evaluate different moist soil management practices and compare effectiveness in producing high yields of seed for wildlife forage.
3674.assumptions: Wetlands that have been harrowed and seeded with Wild Millet and Smartweed will exhibit higher rates of seed biomass than wetlands left to naturally establish.  Furthermore, wetland basins that have been tilled will benefit from turning over soil and desirable vegetation will be allowed to establish.

3675.background:
Columbia River Redband Trout Oncorhynchus mykiss gairdneri are a subspecies of Rainbow Trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains extending upstream as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992). There is considerable variability in the life history of Columbia River Redband Trout including both anadromous (steelhead) and potamodromous forms (Behnke 1992). Currently, Redband Trout occupy 42% of their historical range of stream habitat in the western United States, according to Muhlfeld et al. (2015).

Redband Trout populations in the Columbia River have been negatively impacted by a variety of factors, including invasive species, habitat loss, and other anthropogenic causes. The construction of Grand Coulee Dam in 1939 eliminated the anadromous life history form of Redband Trout from the upper Columbia River (Scholz et al. 1985; Nehlsen et al. 1991) and likely blocked migration routes and isolated populations and habitats of potamodromous Redband Trout. As a result, non-native hatchery Rainbow Trout were subsequently stocked in the upper Columbia River and its tributaries to provide angling opportunities and later as mitigation for hydropower related impacts (Stober et al. 1977; Crawford 1979; Peone et al. 1990; WDFW, unpublished data). Naturally reproducing Rainbow Trout still occur in the upper Columbia River drainage upstream of Grand Coulee Dam and identifying the stock structure, life history strategies, and population dynamics of wild Redband Trout in Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River is necessary conserve, enhance, restore, and manage Redband Trout stocks in Lake Roosevelt and the upper Columbia River.
objectives: Estimate tributary abundance, distribution, and age structure of Redband Trout in Big Sheep and Onion creeks below the terminal falls.
Estimate recruitment and age of recruitment of juvenile Redband Trout from their natal tributary to the Upper Columbia River.
Estimate annual spawner escapement and population structure of adult Redband Trout.
Assess Redband Trout spawning by monitoring the status and trends in spawner abundance (redds) along with the spatial and temporal distribution of redds over time.
Estimate age at maturity of Redband Trout along with documenting and quantifying rematuration rates of adfluvial Redband Trout.
Document and quantify the different life history strategies of Redband Trout.
Estimate survival of Redband Trout to different life stages.
Document and quantify migrations patterns of juvenile and adult Redband Trout into and out of the tributary.
Monitor and suppress invasive Brook Trout populations in Big Sheep and Onion creeks below the terminal falls.

Contribution and Survival of Repeat Spawners to the Population

3680.background: Pacific Lamprey (Entosphenus tridentatus) abundance in the Columbia River Basin is in decline and constricted distribution is likewise being observed. Efforts to conserve and restore Pacific Lamprey populations and their habitats are ongoing throughout the Columbia River Basin. Pacific Lamprey have a complex life cycle that includes a protracted 3-10-year larval stage that occurs in freshwater streams and rivers. Monitoring and evaluation of larval distribution and relative abundance (i.e., density) in freshwaters throughout their range are a critical component of restoration and conservation actions. Backpack electrofishing is the most widely used method for capture and collection of larval lampreys in freshwater habitats. These research, monitoring, and evaluation efforts provide vital information to fill Pacific Lamprey knowledge gaps that have been identified through the recovery and restoration planning processes. Without this information, recovery of this species within the Columbia River Basin is uncertain.
objectives: Monitor and evaluate the distribution patterns and presence/absence of Pacific Lamprey within Columbia River Basin freshwater environments.
Estimate larval and juvenile Pacific Lamprey relative abundance and/or density in wadeable depth streams through backpack electrofishing.
Strategically measure (e.g. length, weight, girth), enumerate, and collect genetic samples from all Pacific Lamprey life history stages at sites throughout the CRB.

3691.background: Temporal and spatial predator-prey overlap and consequential predatory impacts on juvenile anadromous salmonids is becoming a major source of their mortality in sections of the Columbia River. Boat electrofishing will be used to collect piscivores for diet conetnt removal via lavage and discection. Temporal stratification of sites during sampling will provide data representative of the period of greatest overlap between non-native predator fishes and rearing/migrating juvenile salmonids.  Two sampling times will occur to collect predator fish diet contents. The first will occur during the first half of May to represent age-1 chinook, sockeye, Coho, and steelhead smolt (e.g. yearlings). The second will occur in early to mid-June to represent age-0 Chinook smolt outmigration (e.g. subyearlings). The Fish Bioenergetics 4.0 mass balance bioenergetics model (Deslauriers et al. 2017) will be used to quantify the consumption of each prey type by each predator species. Parameters for the model are predator growth rate, diet composition, prey energy density (joules/g) (literature values), and water temperature of the predator’s environment. Monitoring diet composition and relative predation rates will provide results to lead management decisions to reduce predation on salmonids above McNary Dam on the Columbia River.
objectives: Analyze northern pikeminnow, smallmouth bass, and walleye diets to quantify consumption rates on juvenile salmonids above McNary Dam on the Columbia River.
Collect the diets of northern pikeminnow, smallmouth bass, and walleye above McNary Dam on the Columbia River using boat electrofishing or other applicable methodology.
3691.assumptions: The key assumption is that seasonal sampling represents the annual diet compostion of piscivores.

metrics.title: 6 years of walleye and smallmouth bass diets

3693.background:
On December 14, 2018, the State of Oregon, the State of Washington, the Nez Perce Tribe, Bonneville Power Administration, Bureau of Reclamation and the Corps entered into the 2019-2021 Spill Operation Agreement, referred to as the “flexible spill agreement.” The Corps agreed to increase spill to improve juvenile salmonid migration during times of low hydropower demand. For the 2020-2021 spring spill, the flexible spill agreement calls for increasing the total dissolved gas (TDG) cap to 125 percent in the tailraces of dams in the Columbia and Snake rivers. This change to the water quality standard for TDG requires the monitoring of native, resident fishes for incidence of gas bubble trauma (GBT) resulting from increased TDG.

The current criteria used to monitor GBT in native, resident nonsalmonids are the ones used by the regional Smolt Monitoring Program to monitor GBT in salmonids. It is unknown whether these criteria are suitable for use in nonsalmonids and how GBT progresses in nonsalmonid species. Therefore, it is necessary to collect resident fish and identify protential GBT.
objectives: Measure the incidence and severity of GBT in Northern Pikeminnow, Smallmouth Bass, and Walleye rearing downstream of Priest Rapids dam during the spring spill period.
Determine feasibility to describe GBT in resident Northern Pikeminnow, Smallmouth Bass, and Walleye fishes while in the field, on a boat, and working at night.

Illustration of how to estimate gas bubbles in fins and eyes of fish.

3693.title: Gas Bubble Trauma for Resident Fish

3696.background: Piscivory on juvenile salmonids in the Columbia River is not fully understood but recognized as major source of their mortality. Annual index sampling in Columbia and Snake River reaches have indicated that Smallmouth Bass (SMB) Micropterus dolomieu and Walleye (WAL) Sander vitreus abundance is increasing and Northern Pikeminnow (NPM) Ptychocheilus oregonensis abundance decreasing (Carpenter et al. 2019). Currently, fish predator abundance and population trends upstream of McNary Dam are not well understood. Estimating the abundance of piscivores is required to quantify their consumptive impacts and set a baseline for future comparisons.This project will establish a baseline dataset that will be used to evaluate the effectiveness of current (e.g., deregulating harvest) and future management actions designed to increase juvenile salmon survival, with the ability to identify significant changes in predator population status over time and space.

3706.background: The Columbia River redband trout Oncorhynchus mykiss gairdneri are a subspecies of rainbow trout native to the Columbia River drainage east of the Cascade Mountains extending as far as barrier falls on the Snake, Spokane, Pend Oreille, and Kootenai rivers (Allendorf et al. 1980; Behnke 1992). Redband Trout populations in the Columbia River have been negatively impacted by a variety of factors, including invasive species, habitat loss, and other anthropogenic causes.Naturally reproducing rainbow trout still occur in the Spokane River and until recently there was speculation that these populations were hybridized with rainbow trout from hatchery plants. However, recent microsatellite DNA analysis conducted on wild rainbow trout in the Spokane River drainage indicated that rainbow trout in the Spokane River are pure redband trout and are presumed to be native (Small et al. 2007).Naturally reproducing Rainbow Trout still occur in the upper Spokane River and the population dynamics of wild Redband Trout in Spokane River is necessary conserve, enhance, restore, and manage their populations.
objectives: Estimate abundance and age structure of Redband Trout in an index area of the Spokane River, Spokane County, WA between the Washington/Idaho stateline (rkm 154.8) and Harvard Road (rkm 149.2).
3706.assumptions: Redband trout can be effectively samplied using driftboat electrofishing.

3709.background: Pacific Lamprey (Entosphenus tridentatus) abundance in the Columbia River Basin is in decline and constricted distribution is likewise being observed. Efforts to conserve and restore Pacific Lamprey populations and their habitats are ongoing throughout the Columbia River Basin. Pacific Lamprey have a complex life cycle that includes a protracted 3-10-year larval stage that occurs in freshwater streams and rivers. Monitoring and evaluation of larval distribution and relative abundance (i.e., density) in freshwaters throughout their range are a critical component of restoration and conservation actions. Backpack electrofishing is the most widely used method for capture and collection of larval lampreys in freshwater habitats. These research, monitoring, and evaluation efforts provide vital information to fill Pacific Lamprey knowledge gaps that have been identified through the recovery and restoration planning processes. Without this information, recovery of this species within the Columbia River Basin is uncertain.
objectives: Monitor and evaluate the distribution patterns and presence/absence of Pacific Lamprey within Columbia River Basin freshwater environments.
Estimate larval and juvenile Pacific Lamprey relative abundance and/or density in wadeable depth streams through backpack electrofishing.
Strategically measure (e.g. length, weight, girth), enumerate, and collect genetic samples from all Pacific Lamprey life history stages at sites throughout the CRB.

metrics.title: Genetic tagging of all Columbia River basin population segments
Population segment origin of Pacific Lamprey

3711.background:
To address impacts to native Westslope Cutthroat Trout populations by non-native fish such as Brook Trout, actions have been implemented to reduce their abundance in select streams within Pend Oreille River . Mechanical, chemical or alternative removal methods have been applied, that decrease or eliminate Brook Trout, allowing Westslope Cutthroat Trout  to naturally or by assisted means (i.e., reintroduction, augmentation), re-occupy historic habitat.

Following project management actions (e.g., non-native fish removal, native fish reintroduction), periodic assessments are required to evaluate the status of the standing or reintroduced Westslope Cutthroat Trout population in designated tributaries. This can also be conducted prior to management actions as a baseline for action effectiveness monitoring or in allopatric populations as a natural condition reference. Using multiple-pass depletion electrofishing techniques, data collected can be used to calculate abundance estimates and describe biological metrics (e.g., relative weight, cohort distribution) that can be compared to baseline or natural conditions, as a method of evaluating the population status.
objectives: Estimate abundance of Westslope Cutthroat Trout.
Determine spatial extent of Westslope Cutthroat Trout.
Summarize age (length) class structure of Westslope Cutthroat Trout

citation.title: Westslope Cutthroat Trout Assessment - Resident Tributary Populations v1.0
citation.author: Bean, N.J.

3711.title: Westslope Cutthroat Trout Assessment - Resident Tributary Populations

3716.background:
Complex life cycles make anadromous fishes particularly susceptible to environmental and anthropogenic change. Anadromous lampreys (family: Petromyzontidae), for example, move over extensive spatial and temporal scales in order to successfully complete their life cycles. They use freshwater benthic habitats as larvae, freshwater streams and rivers as downstream migrating juveniles, the ocean as parasitic juveniles adults, and then freshwater again during their upstream migration prior to spawning. Human impacts on habitats and ecological communities potentially affect these fish at each life history stage.

PIT telemetry has been used widely to document passage efficiency of anadromous fishes within mainstem rivers, tributaries, and at barriers within these environments. The data are used to evaluate structural and operational modifications made to improve passage success of adult Pacific Lamprey at mainstem and tributary dams. Fixed-site PIT arrays are strategically positioned to detect PIT tagged fish passing at specific areas of interest in the fishways. The resulting detections are then used to document passage success, passage duration, and timing of fish movements. The original fishway design and sub-sequent modifications have focused on maximizing salmonid passage efficiencies. However, fishes that do not share salmonid migration behaviors may not respond positively to these configurations.

Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags can be used for a variety of monitoring purposes such as determining migration timing, passage through fish ladders, and assisting in mark-recapture studies. PIT tags are inexpensive, and the tagging procedure is relatively non-invasive, quick, and has a short recovery time. PIT tags do not have an internal battery, instead relying on power supplied by the antenna array on which they are detected to activate them. This allows for indefinite tag life as well as a very small size. PIT tags are also feature a unique alpha-numeric ID number that allows an individually tagged lamprey to be identified whenever it is detected.

The CRITFC Member Tribes utilize radio PIT to gather information from returning anadromous adult Pacific Lamprey. Information is used compare the relative passage performance of adult Pacific Lamprey at mainstem and tributary barriers with the focus on adult distribution (upstream and downstream of barriers). Data are utilized for determination of abundance, survival and life history characteristics, restoration effectiveness and status and trends evaluations. Population status and trend monitoring of natural and hatchery origin fish is used for effective population management, assessing effectiveness of restoration actions, viability, and recovery metric monitoring.
objectives: Evaluate the relative passage performance of Pacific Lamprey at mainstem and tributary barriers.
Evaluate behavior and distribution patterns of migrating Pacific Lamprey at mainstem and tributary barriers.
Evaluate behavior, distribution patterns, and final fates of migrating Pacific Lamprey within mainstem and tributary river environments.

3722.background: Stream flow (discharge) monitoring provides critical information for restoration efforts. Knowing how much water is in a stream is extremely important for fish restoration. Many communities rely upon stream water for irrigating their crops and livestock. By having a robust stream flow monitoring program information is collected to inform water management, restoration and other decisions.

Quantify stream flow, especially with the use of data loggers for analysis of stream trends and status.

3741.background:
Prey quantity and quality in part determine the growth opportunity of rearing juvenile fall Chinook salmon in lower Snake River reservoir habitats. Growth opportunity in part dictates the life history pathway (i.e, ocean-type or reservoir-type) that fish will select. The food web in the lower Snake River has changed in the last 20 years. Species like Neomysis mercedis and the Siberian prawn (Exopalaemon modestus) were not present 20 years ago when Curet (1993) found that subyearling fall Chinook salmon in Lower Granite Reservoir consumed mainly aquatic insects. Today, Corophium spp., and Neomysis makes up the majority of subyearling diets at certain times in Lower Granite Reservoir (Tiffan et al. 2014). The quantity and quality (i.e., energy content) of these prey are not known. It is possible that food resources have influenced the shift in subyearling outmigration timing that has been observed in recent years.  Furthermore, work conducted under this protocol will increase our understanding of the food web that supports juvenile salmon and native fishes in the lower Snake River.

One of the recent developments in the Snake River reservoirs is the occurance of harmful algal blooms (HABs) in late summer and early autumn that can affect subyearling fall Chinook salmon indirectly through negaitive impacts on the food web and directly if fish take up harmful toxins into their bodies either through the prey they consume or across their gills. Sampling microcystin toxin levels in fish tissue is a first step in determining whether HABs potentially pose a risk to juvenile fall Chinook salmon residing Lower Granite Reservoir during a harmful algal bloom.
objectives: 1. Determine the different types of prey available to juvenile fall Chinook salmon during reservoir rearing and their spatial and seasonal densities.
2. Determine whether the microcystin toxin produced by harmful algal blooms can accumulate in subyearling fall Chinook salmon, thus creating a mortality risk or reduced performance.
3741.assumptions:
Collected taxa are either directly or indirectly important to the production of juvenile salmon.

Sample sites are representative of the entire reservoir.

Sampling frequency is sufficient to detect seasonal trends.

citation.title: Snake River reservior invertebrate prey availability for juvenile salmon v2.0

3744.background:
Harmful algal blooms (HABs) are becoming more prevalent in lower Snake River reservoirs. HABs typically occur in late summer and early autumn and are composed of blue-green algae that can produce neurotoxins (cyanotoxins) that are harmful to birds, animals, and humans. The effects of these cyanotoxins on fishes has received little study but may affect juvenile salmon directly by impairing physiological functions and behavior or indirectly by impacting prey resources that juvenile salmon feed on. Many ESA-listed juvenile Snake River fall Chinook salmon migrate through, or delay migration, in the four lower Snake River Reservoirs potentially exposing them to toxins produced by HABs. This study will examine whether juvenile salmon take up cyanotoxins in their body tissues and to what extent, and how toxin uptake varies seasonally. Initial sampling will focus on analyzing the livers from juvenile fall Chinook salmon mortalities collected at Lower Granite Dam. The reason for examining liver tissue is that it is more metabolically active than other tissues and thus more likely to take up toxins. The reasons for initially examining mortalities are two-fold. First, a mortality at Lower Granite Dam died of something and there may be a higher likelihood that it died from cyanotoxin. Second, because the Snake River fall Chinook population is ESA-listed, sampling mortalities is a way to reduce lethal take.

The temporal and spatial distribution of blue-green algae will be described along with toxin levels in the water that fish are exposed to. Two approaches wil be used to accomplish this. First, toxins present in the water column in Lower Granite Reservoir will be concentrated using SPATT (Solid-phase adsorption toxin tracking) samplers. The reason for using this particular sampler is that toxins can be collected over a longer time period (days or weeks) thus minimizing that a toxin spike might be missed as if a single grab sample was collected at single point in time. Second, the relative surface distribution of algae will be mapped during mobile surveys of Lower Granite Reservoir. The reason for this is to describe the spatial and temporal variability in algae distribution that will complement the SPATT sampling.
objectives: Describe the temporal and spatial distribution of blue-green algae in reservoirs.
Quantify the amount of cyanotoxins in reservoir water both spatially and temporally
Quantify the amount of cyanotoxin taken up by tissues of juvenile fall Chinook salmon.

metrics.title: Presence of cyanotoxin in juvenile fall Chinook salmon

citation.title: Harmful Algal Blooms in the Snake River v1.0
citation.author: Kenneth Tiffan
